HEADLINE: Italian Conservative Assures Europe He's in the Mainstream 

BYLINE:  By ALESSANDRA STANLEY 

DATELINE: ROME, May 15 

 BODY:
Assuring Europe and the United States that he was proud to be their partner, the conservative media tycoon Silvio Berlusconi today began the business of becoming Italy's next prime minister by seeking to allay foreign fears.
 In the election on Sunday, Mr. Berlusconi did more than simply defeat the center-left that has ruled Italy for the past five years. He also won a second chance to launch a "revolution" that he says Italy needs to compete. 
 Unlike in 1994, when his coalition government collapsed after seven months after the leader of the Northern League, Umberto Bossi, withdrew, now Mr. Berlusconi could have enough support in Parliament to govern without Mr. Bossi. That could bring stability to a country that has had 58 governments since the end of World War II. 
In a solemn address broadcast on state television, Mr. Berlusconi reached out to all Italians. But he also sought to legitimize his victory abroad. 
European leaders and editorial writers have expressed alarm about the conflicts of interest presented by Mr. Berlusconi's three private television networks and his vast financial empire. They have particularly criticized his alliance with Mr. Bossi, who is often likened to Austria's leading nationalist, Jorg Haider.
President Bush sent a warm congratulatory telegram today but Germany's chancellor, Gerhard Schroder, was more guarded. And the French foreign minister, Hubert Vedrine, warned Mr. Berlusconi that Europe "would pay close attention to what the government is, and to what it is doing." Mr. Haider was one of the first to react, offering congratulations and his support.
Actually, however, Europe may have reason to relax, at least about Mr. Bossi. The leader of the Northern League will be "irrelevant," in the new government, according to Roberto D'Alimonte, a political scientist at the University of Florence. 
"Berlusconi has enough seats in both houses to form a majority without the Northern League," Mr. D'Alimonte said. But he added: "Berlusconi has no alibis. There is nobody he can blame if he fails to deliver on what he thinks he can do." 
Mr. Berlusconi said he was ready. 
"You asked for a government that works and makes the state work like an efficient machine at the service of its citizens," he told viewers, outlining a few of his ambitious proposals for the first 100 days. "We feel the full responsibility of this freely made choice. I assure you, you won't be disappointed." 
Mr. Berlusconi defeated his liberal rival, Francesco Rutelli, 46, the pragmatic former mayor of Rome, mostly because he convinced many Italians that he really could cut taxes, increase minimum pensions, trim the bloated government and undertake vast public works projects -- all without increasing Italy's huge debt and putting the country on a collision course with the European Union. 
Many economists are skeptical. His political rivals are scornful.
In a concession speech today, Mr. Rutelli promised "intransigent" opposition against "a right wing we do not trust, and who we know will not be able to maintain its campaign promises." 
The vote tally was delayed because a reduced number of voting stations forced many polls to stay open until almost dawn today to accommodate floods of irate voters. 
But when the counting was over, Mr. Berlusconi's center-right coalition had won a clear majority in both houses of Parliament. His party, Forza Italia -- in essence an advertising vehicle for his candidacy that he set up in 1994 with his own vast fortune -- won 29.4 percent of the votes cast in districts where seats were allotted proportionally, far more than any other party. 
Mr. Berlusconi had expected to win handily in the north, but he surpassed expectations by also sweeping Sicily and large parts of the south.
It looked tonight as if Mr. Bossi's party failed to reach the neccesary 4 percent of votes cast to qualify for parliamentary seats awarded proportionally, which in Italy's hybrid system account for 25 percent of the total. He will undoubtedly acquire other seats in Parliament, at least 16 in the Senate. But 4 percent is less than half of what the Northern League got in 1996. 
Mr. Bossi complained on Sunday that the Northern League had paid "a monstrous price" by supporting Mr. Berlusconi. He closeted himself in his office today, refusing all interviews. 
Mr. Berlusconi won Mr. Bossi's electoral support by working out a joint program that includes more autonomy for regions. (Mr. Bossi started his career demanding that the wealthy north secede from the needy south.) Throughout the campaign, Mr. Berlusconi said he would invite Northern League politicians to join his cabinet, as some did in 1994. A spokesman said tonight that it was "premature" to say whether he really would.
The losing side reacted with much rancor and hand wringing about Mr. Berlusconi's success and its own failure to unite. 
The Marxist Refounded Communists refused to join forces with Mr. Rutelli's coalition but won 5 percent of the vote, which Mr. Rutelli's supporters called wasted votes that could have helped Mr. Rutelli's center-left coalition. 
Several cabinet ministers lost their Senate races, including Enzo Bianco, the interior minister, who was widely blamed for the election-night confusion. In a cost-cutting measure, the government had reduced the number of polling stations by a third, contributing to long lines of angry voters. 
Cardinal Camillo Ruini, head of the Italian bishops conference, called the delays "very disagreeable." Mr. Bianco humbly asked forgiveness from the Italian people.
Mr. Bianco, like others, could nevertheless get into the Senate through his party, which receives a certain percentage of seats awarded proportionally.
Massimo D'Alema, a former Communist who was prime minister twice during the center-left's up-and-down reign, was one of the few prominent politicians to take the risk of running in a winner-take-all race, in Gallipoli, in the south. He won, despite a cameo campaign appearance there by Mr. Berlusconi, whose helicopter arrival was described by D'Alema supporters as "Apocalypse Now." 
But the center-left coalition was weakened by other, more centrist candidates who ran as independents, tempted by Italy's hybrid election system, which awards 75 percent of seats on a winner-take-all basis, and 25 percent proportionally. That system is intended to give even small parties a way into Parliament, where they often use their leverage to bring down coalition governments. 
The center-left's failure to reform election laws to encourage a two-bloc system hurt Mr. Rutelli's chances. And its failure to pass a stringent conflict-of-interest law frees Mr. Berlusconi to introduce his own. He has yet to indicate that he sees his three private networks and financial empire, which spans insurance, banking, real estate and publishing, as a real cause for concern.
Mr. Berlusconi did not mention a law to resolve conflict-of-interest problems today, when he listed the goals for his first days in office. 
"I don't know if it will be the first, the second or the third thing on the agenda," said Gianfranco Fini, head of the right-wing National Alliance Party, a part of Mr. Berlusconi's coalition. "But we will draft a law on conflict of interest." 

GRAPHIC: Photo: At a polling station in Naples, voters frustrated by long delays tipped over boxes of unused ballots left over from the election on Sunday. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Medicare Panel Head Is Replaced as Holdings Are Questioned 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 14 

 BODY:
Gail R. Wilensky, one of the Republican Party's top health care experts, is losing her job as chairwoman of an influential commission that advises Congress on Medicare, in part because of concerns about her substantial investments in health care companies.
 Dr. Wilensky was an adviser to George W. Bush in the presidential campaign and worked for Mr. Bush's father as head of the federal agency that runs Medicare and Medicaid. She has been chairwoman of the Medicare Payment Advisory Commission and one of its predecessor panels since 1995. 
 Medicare provides health care to 40 million people who are elderly or disabled, at a cost of more than $215 billion a year. The program is technically complex and politically explosive. Congress often follows the commission's advice when deciding how much to pay doctors, hospitals and other care providers. It has also sought the commission's advice on adding drug benefits to Medicare.
The 17 commission members are appointed by the comptroller general of the United States, now David M. Walker, who is head of the General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress.
Mr. Walker said today that his decision to replace Dr. Wilensky, whose term expired last month, had been prompted by two factors. He wanted to see some turnover in the leadership of the commission and he was somewhat concerned that Dr. Wilensky might be perceived as having potential conflicts of interest. In recent years she has served on the boards of eight health care companies, in which she held stock and stock options worth more than $4 million. The companies include the UnitedHealth Group, a large managed care company.
Mr. Walker named Glenn M. Hackbarth, a health care consultant in Bend, Ore., to replace Dr. Wilensky as head of the Medicare advisory commission. Mr. Walker named Robert D. Reischauer, former director of the Congressional Budget Office, to be vice chairman of the panel.
Dr. Wilensky, an economist, tried to hold on to her job, and she had bipartisan support. But she had irritated one important House member, Bill Thomas, the California Republican who is chairman of the Ways and Means Committee.
"My independence was troublesome" to some lawmakers, Dr. Wilensky said. "I say what I think."
Members of the Medicare commission include hospital and insurance executives, doctors, employers, an officer of AARP and an employee of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.
Congress assumed that some commissioners would have financial interests in the health care industry, and such interests must be disclosed. But in an interview today, Mr. Walker said that the chairman of the commission should be held to a higher standard because the chairman "has additional power and responsibilities," including the authority to call meetings and set the agenda.
"As a certified public accountant," Mr. Walker said, "I know that independence is important, and appearances do count."
Dr. Wilensky said that her work on the commission had not been influenced by her financial holdings, and that Congress had chosen to deal with such issues by requiring public disclosure.
Mr. Walker is planning to appoint three new commission members. They are Sheila P. Burke, under secretary of the Smithsonian Institution, who was chief of staff to Bob Dole, the former Senate Republican leader; Allen D. Feezor, health benefits administrator for the California Public Employees' Retirement System, and Ralph W. Muller, president of the University of Chicago Hospitals and Health System.
The commission annoyed some lawmakers last year when it recommended a substantial increase in Medicare payments to hospitals.

HEADLINE: Bush Actions, And Inaction, Set Scientists Grumbling 

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM J. BROAD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
Dr. Marye Anne Fox was a science adviser to George W. Bush when he was governor of Texas. So in March, when she was called to Washington for an interview, the rumor mill had her all but installed as the new White House science adviser.
 But Dr. Fox, a chemist, was uninterested, federal officials said. "There were too many restrictions," one recalled. "They were saying, 'Hey, be in the president's office, but don't do anything." 
 For specialists worried about the fate of science in the Bush administration, the continuing lack of a presidential science adviser symbolizes what they see as a troubling lack of interest in science and research. 
The administration's proposed spending on science for next year has far more decreases than increases, key leadership positions are unfilled and grumbling has reached new heights. Even Republican leaders are criticizing some of the budget cuts as dangerous for the nation's well-being.
In President Bush's budget proposal for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1, research spending, after inflation, is down at Agriculture, Commerce, Interior, Energy, Education, the National Science Foundation, the Environmental Projection Agency and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. The main winners are health and defense.
Critics say some cuts make no sense, given the administration's own priorities and the problems it is confronting. Take the 11 percent reduction for the federal geologists who aid the hunt for fossil fuels.
"The year of a power-production crisis seems an odd time for a cutback," said Donald Kennedy, the editor of the journal Science. The administration also proposes to cut research spending for alternative energy sources and energy conservation.
To be sure, scientists regularly grumble that the government is not spending enough on research, and many of the administration's sharpest critics would stand to benefit from increased support for research. Also, previous administrations have occasionally left major science posts unfilled in their early months.
But perhaps because science research budgets enjoyed robust expansion in the Clinton years, scientific leaders are now expressing an unusual sense of dismay. They have also criticized the administration's early actions on climate, the environment, antimissile defense and toxic chemicals, saying good science advice could have averted missteps.
For their part, administration officials defend their actions, appointments and budgets as sound. The scientists who complain, they say, are often just angling for money or disagreeing about policy.
"Science is something the administration cares about," Richard Russell, staff director of the White House science office, said in an interview. The overall budget is up 6 percent, he said. "That's significant," he said.
But critics of the administration's research budget, including influential Republicans in Congress, disagree, saying the 6 percent figure ignores inflation and promotes health and defense research at the expense of hundreds of other efforts.
Representative Sherwood Boehlert, a Republican of New York, who is chairman of the House Science Committee, said recently that the administration's overall science budgets were too low and that some proposed cuts left him "very disturbed." He singled out those planned for the Energy Department (4.5 percent) and the National Science Foundation (1.6 percent), which is the main conduit of government support for civilian basic research in the physical sciences.
And Dr. Fox, who became chancellor of North Carolina State University in 1998 after working at the University of Texas for two decades, added her own voice to the warnings soon after her White House visit. "Without a major investment," she wrote in The News and Observer of Raleigh, "we should expect innovation, and with it our competitive edge, to shift overseas."
Defenders of the administration say the budget situation has altered in recent years because corporate America is putting so much money into research and development. This year, the private sector is expected to spend $180 billion -- about twice what Washington does.
The Bush White House hails the shift, as do some of its vigorous supporters. Dr. Edward E. David, President Richard M. Nixon's science adviser and a former head of Exxon research, said the change meant that the president's science office should become a "window on the private sector," not, as it has been, a guiding force behind federal research.
But many other experts disagree. They say corporations focus largely on near-term goals -- projects that can be expected to turn into moneymakers in relatively short order -- rather than the long-range, blue sky research that has produced some of the most important breakthroughs in physics, medicine, energy and understanding the universe.
Also, they note, corporations cannot necessarily be relied upon to maintain research budgets in economic downturns.
Dr. D. Allan Bromley, a Yale physicist, who was White House science adviser for President Bush's father, has all but ignored the industry argument in leading calls for raising the federal research budget.
"No science, no surplus," he wrote in an Op-Ed article for The New York Times on March 9. "It's that simple."
Dr. Bromley and Dr. David have clashed on the topic. "I didn't think that was logical or rational," Dr. David said in an interview.
Despite their differences, the two men recently joined to lobby the White House when rumors spread that its science office was to be killed or left empty. Dr. Bromley said he had written to both President Bush and his father.
"We succeeded, I believe," he told a symposium this month at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in observation of the 25th anniversary of the White House Office of Science and Technology Policy. In an interview, he said White House staff members had assured him the office would be maintained. 
Still, as of yet, there is no presidential science adviser, no commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration, no head of the National Institutes of Health and no heads of science at the Environmental Protection Agency or the Departments of Energy and Agriculture.
Mr. Russell, the science office staff director, said the staffing situation was fairly normal for this stage of a new administration and that the president had moved rapidly on an important post, when in late March he named E. Floyd Kvamme, a businessman with industry experience at Apple Computer and National Semiconductor, to be co-chairman of the President's Council of Advisors on Science and Technology. This group aids the science adviser in evaluating issues for the president.
"This is one of the premier spots," Mr. Russell said, adding that the committee of private experts was "the single best conduit to the president from the nonacademic sector."
But Dr. Charles M. Vest, the president of M.I.T., told the symposium recently that the administration's budget was "dangerously lopsided" toward health and urged more emphasis on nonmedical basic science, engineering research and advanced education.
"When the most interesting ideas are emerging at the surprising overlaps and intersections between previously unrelated fields," Dr. Vest said, "that unbalanced investment represents a serious strategic error."
John E. Porter, who represented Illinois in the House for 21 years and helped win financing increases for biomedical research, told the group that the lack of a presidential science adviser at this point meant that the Bush administration had inadequate planning advice for two budgets, 2002 and 2003.
Mr. Boehlert, the House Science Committee chairman, said the picture, though bleak, was bound to get better because support for science remained strong in the administration and Congress. Friends of science will improve the proposed budget before it is finally adopted, he said.
"These numbers are going to be better -- most likely, a little better this year, and a lot better next year," he told the American Association for the Advancement of Science recently.
He said the current figures did not reflect administration hostility toward science but rather a sense of drift, because science played no major role in Mr. Bush's presidential campaign.
He urged scientists to speak out in order to encourage a renewed commitment and to reverse the downward spiral. Complacency, he added, is "a recipe for failure."

HEADLINE: Hearing Bush Energy Plan, Union Leaders Offer Praise 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Union leaders praised parts of President Bush's energy plan yesterday after attending a White House meeting where Vice President Dick Cheney and other administration officials outlined the plan and predicted that it would create hundreds of thousands of jobs.
 Leaders of the Teamsters, the Steelworkers and various building trades unions said they were pleased to hear that the plan called for building 1,300 to 1,900 power plants and more than 18,000 miles of fuel pipeline in the next 20 years. 
 In a major overture to labor, the Bush administration invited more than 30 union officials to the meeting in the hope that organized labor, long one of Mr. Bush's fiercest foes, would support his plan, the details of which are to be announced on Thursday. The union leaders were delighted by forecasts that each new power plant would create 1,000 construction jobs and 200 permanent jobs and that every 1,000 miles of pipeline built would create 5,000 jobs. 
"It's a plan that the majority of unions who were there support," said Bret Caldwell, a spokesman for the International Brotherhood of Teamsters. "It's about job creation."
Several union leaders explicitly withheld support from the overall plan, saying they first wanted to see all of the details. 
"We think in certain areas we're going to be able to work together," said Edward C. Sullivan, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s Building and Construction Trades Department. Among the unions that sent top officials to the meeting were the Plumbers, Laborers, Carpenters, Operating Engineers, Steam Fitters, Seafarers and Marine Engineers.
The building trades department, the Teamsters and several maritime unions have endorsed the administration's plans to allow oil exploration in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, to the chagrin of environmentalists. Union officials say they expect exploration in the refuge to create thousands of jobs.
Environmental leaders and even some union leaders have voiced concern that the administration was seeking to divide two core Democratic constituencies, environmentalists and labor, by trying to gain union backing for the plan. Environmentalists have denounced the plan, saying it will ruin the Arctic refuge.
Trent Lott, the Senate majority leader, said today that he wanted the Senate Energy Committee to begin hearings next week on the energy plan and that he hoped to have an energy bill on the Senate floor by mid-June.
After the hourlong meeting today, several union leaders echoed Mr. Cheney's remarks about the importance of building power plants and doing more drilling to increase output and reduce energy prices.
"One of the things that the vice president said is we need supply, if we have more supply the price will go down," said Douglas McCarron, the president of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters. "That's very important."
James P. Hoffa, president of the Teamsters praised the administration's plans to build more nuclear reactors, refine more oil and use more coal, but he warned that unions could sour on the plan if it unduly favors industry.
"We want to make sure we get lower prices, not higher prices," Mr. Hoffa said. "The point that I stressed in there, the bottom line here, is this is not about enriching the oil companies. This is about affordable gas prices for working Americans."
At the meeting, union leaders repeatedly stressed that they wanted the jobs created by the plan to go to unionized American workers. Leo Gerard, the president of the United Steelworkers of America, said the steel used to construct pipelines should not be imported.
Labor Secretary Elaine Chao sought to build cooperation by telling the labor leaders that there were some issues they could work on together, while there would be others they disagreed on.
Deb Callahan, president of the League of Conservation Voters, said after the meeting that she expected that environmentalists and labor would continue working together and would find some common ground on the energy plan.
"I have confidence that as labor unions look more deeply at the economics of the plan they may think twice about some of the solutions the White House is proposing," she said. 
In introducing Vice President Cheney at the meeting, Karl Rove, a senior adviser to the president, noted that he was the first vice president to have ever been a member of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers. After Mr. Cheney left Yale without graduating, he worked briefly as a utility company lineman in Wyoming.

HEADLINE: Bank One Names a Chief for First USA 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, May 14 

 BODY:
The Bank One Corporation named a former vice chairman of U.S. Bancorp as the president and chief operating officer of First USA Inc., its credit card subsidiary.
 The executive, Daniel J. Frate, 40, succeeds Anthony Vuoto, who resigned in March after a year in the position. 
The company said Mr. Frate, who started yesterday, reports to First USA's chief executive, Philip Heasley, who took over the Bank One credit card business in mid-January. 
 Mr. Heasley, who was president and chief operating officer at U.S. Bancorp until August, was hired by Bank One's chief executive, Jamie Dimon, to rebuild the credit card business, which has lost millions of customers since 1999.
First USA has hurt Bank One's profit since 1999, when it lost customers after giving them less time to pay their bills and then imposing late fees and raising interest rates for those who missed the deadline.

HEADLINE: Signs in China and Taiwan Of Making Money, Not War 

BYLINE:  By CRAIG S. SMITH 

DATELINE: KUNSHAN, China, May 11 

 BODY:
Despite the visions of war conjured by President Bush's suggestion that the United States could help defend Taiwan from a Chinese invasion, the social and economic integration between the mainland and the island is stronger than ever, and growing.
 Tension across the 100-mile strait separating the two sides of a decades-old civil war has recently ebbed considerably. Some experts say that if the trend continues, Taiwan's government will soon be unable to afford antagonizing China, and that the cost to China of attacking Taiwan may become prohibitive. 
 Nowhere is that on starker display than in Kunshan, a town that Taiwan built. About 10 percent of Taiwan's $50 billion investment in the mainland has landed here, just off the 60-mile highway from Shanghai to Suzhou. 
And almost all of the town's tax revenue comes from 900 Taiwan companies that have transformed the once ramshackle farming community into one of China's brightest new cities.
During the spring and autumn wedding seasons, a few women a month here marry men from Taiwan. The women wear dresses from brightly-lit bridal shops with names like Ruby, Venus and Taiwan Flavor. They move into one of the town's upscale Taiwanese compounds, like Beautiful Crystal Plaza or Treasure Island Garden, a reference to Taiwan. And they bear children who are half of the mainland and half of Taiwan.
"What we may be seeing in cross-strait relations is a kind of Hong Kong-ization of Taiwan-mainland relations," said Orville Schell, a longtime China watcher now at the University of California at Berkeley. 
He noted that the economic promise of friendly ties with Beijing had earlier eroded the anti-Communism of Hong Kong's business elite and smoothed the territory's 1997 return to mainland rule.
"Simply put, the tension of politics may be cut by the imperatives of business and trade," Mr. Schell said.
Kunshan's silver 20-story city hall rises across from a massive science and culture exhibition center, still under a wrap of sheeted scaffolding.
Near the center of town, freshly painted pastel apartment blocks line streets so clean and orderly that they look more like Tokyo than China, where urban centers are more often a mess. 
Businessmen from Taiwan patronize restaurants like Taipei Small Town or Champs Elysee, which serves whipped iced tea -- a fad imported from Taipei -- and Taiwanese marinated pork with rice, served in a Japanese-style lacquered box as it is in Taiwan, which was a Japanese colony from 1895 until the end of World War II.
"Even in 1995, the streets were run down," said Lu Caiping, a middle-aged woman standing amid clouds of tulle and organza in a wedding shop along Advance Street. "Now the sidewalks are paved with granite."
Taiwan's economic presence on the mainland has risen steadily for the last decade, even though the island and China have never formally ended the civil war that left the Communist Party in control of the mainland after 1949 and Chiang Kai-shek's Nationalist forces in control of Taiwan. 
Chiang and his archfoe Mao Zedong both died in the 1970's, and Taiwan, under pressure from business people eager to take part in China's economic opening to the world, began allowing indirect travel, trade and investment in the mainland in 1987. Taiwan has since become one of China's top investors.
Investment accelerated markedly after a devastating earthquake on Taiwan in 1999. The quake temporarily shut down much of the computer-related industry on the island, which is prone to quakes, prompting many technology companies to shift production to China. Taiwan investors are also drawn to the vast mainland market. Half of Taiwan's high-tech products are now made on the mainland.
Belligerency and political mistrust may still, of course, vanquish economic imperatives.
China's weapons purchases and recent sharp increase in military spending are directed almost exclusively at Taiwan. China has not slowed the frequency of its military exercises or new missile deployments facing the island, which in turn has not slowed its own program to acquire weapons. 
The same economic growth that is drawing Taiwan to the mainland is financing Beijing's military expansion, aimed at giving China a coercive edge over Taiwan.
Talks between the two governments show no sign of resuming after breaking down two years ago. China's leaders, trapped by their Marxist-Leninist past, have yet to define a more democratic future in which Taiwan might want to take part.
Growing economic ties to Taiwan's business community could even work against political reforms as that community becomes increasingly reliant on a stable government in China to protect its investments and interests, Mr. Schell said.
But there have been no military tensions in the strait since President Chen Shui-bian of Taiwan was elected a year ago. And he has proven more open to developing economic ties than was his predecessor, Lee Teng-hui. 
Taiwan investment on the mainland is booming, and at any one time there are hundreds of thousands of people from Taiwan living in or visiting China.
As much as $10 billion has poured into China from Taiwan in the last two years, compared with $40 billion in the previous decade, when the country had already become the main destination for overseas investment from the island of 23 million people. 
Cross-strait trade reached $30 billion in 2000, making Taiwan China's sixth-largest trading partner.
By some estimates, Taiwan is poised to invest more money in the mainland in the next three years than it has in the last 10. If so, that could further blend the two economies. 
"After visiting Taiwanese companies along the Shanghai-Suzhou corridor, I'm convinced that the cross-strait issue will resolve in 10 years," said Andy Xie, an economist at Morgan Stanley in Hong Kong.
In his New Year address this year, President Chen said China and Taiwan should begin "the integration of our economies, trade and culture" to gradually "build a new framework of permanent peace and political integration."
He opened direct trade and transport between the mainland and two tiny Taiwan-controlled islands hard against the mainland coast, and he is reviewing such links between the mainland and Taiwan proper.
He plans to begin allowing mainland tourists to visit Taiwan later this year and is considering relaxing restrictions governing Taiwan investment on the mainland. Taiwan companies regularly ignore the rules by investing through offshore companies in any case.
"Over the long run I believe that economic integration will lead to some kind of social and political integration," said Lin Chong-ping, vice chairman of Taiwan's Mainland Affairs Council, in a telephone interview.
Taiwan's investment in the mainland, most of which comes into the country indirectly through Hong Kong, once focused on Guangdong Province in southern China, lured by cheap land and low-cost labor. 
It has more recently migrated north toward Shanghai and shifted into increasingly advanced technologies and larger, longer-term projects.
Formosa Plastics, Taiwan's largest enterprise, is considering plans to invest in a huge petrochemical plant in Ningbo, south of Shanghai. And last year Winston Wong, the son of Formosa Plastics' chairman, joined President Jiang Zemin's son, Jiang Mianheng, to break ground on a $1.63 billion Shanghai plant that will produce circuit-etched silicon wafers -- the most critical component in computer chips. Nearby, another Taiwanese-financed wafer foundry, as the plants are known, is under way.
"With China entering the World Trade Organization, we are looking more at the domestic market here than at China as a base for exports," said D. C. Yang, the former head of the Shanghai association of Taiwan business people. 
While no exact figures are available, he estimates that there are a quarter of a million people from Taiwan in Shanghai at any one time. There are many more living in or visiting the south.
"East China is becoming the hub of Taiwan investment radiating out to other parts of the country," Mr. Yang said.
The highway between Shanghai and Suzhou has become a technology corridor, with Kunshan drawing most of the investment because of prompt service to investors by the town's mayor and easy access to Shanghai, just 40 minutes away.
And despite a recent mainland spy hunt that has led to the arrest of ethnic Chinese scholars visiting China, Beijing is more welcoming to people from Taiwan today than any time in the last decade. 
It has drastically increased the number of mainlanders allowed to visit Taiwan and aggressively courted visits from Taiwan opinion leaders, including legislators, former government officials, scholars and celebrities.
Taipei and Shanghai have exchanged visits by deputy mayors. And Taiwan's former prime minister, Vincent Siew, is currently in China to lobby for a common market between the mainland and Taiwan. He is the second vice chairman of Taiwan's main opposition party, the Nationalist Party, to set foot in China in less than six months.
"In cross-strait relations, we are in something of a race between the forces of economic integration and political separation," said Mr. Schell. "Barring some really nasty bump in the road, I would bet on integration."

HEADLINE: Even for Wealthy, Tax Plan's Benefits Could Vary Widely 

BYLINE:  By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
Much of the debate about President Bush's plan to cut income taxes has focused on its benefits to the richest Americans. But the government has provided few details about which taxpayers would get the biggest cuts.
 Now a new analysis gives a far clearer picture. Under the version of the plan that was passed by the House earlier this spring with Mr. Bush's support, the biggest cuts would go more to the extraordinarily wealthy than to the merely wealthy and the affluent. While the Senate version is less generous to the extraordinarily wealthy, it gives much more than does the plan approved by the House to the affluent. The Senate Finance Committee will take up the proposal today. Page A16. 
 Indeed, under the House plan, the vast majority of taxpayers whose income is in the top 20 percent -- those who make more than $72,000 -- would average fewer dollars from the tax cut than the $1,600 that President Bush says the typical middle-class family would save. 
But the very richest, the 400 Americans with the highest incomes, averaging $110 million each in 1998, would save more than $1 million a year under the House plan. Even under the proposal in the Senate, they would save an average of $622,900 each, according to an analysis by The New York Times of figures provided by Prof. Joel Slemrod, a tax specialist at the University of Michigan. He obtained the data from the Internal Revenue Service, which had previously refused numerous requests for detailed breakdowns on the very-highest-income Americans.
The final shape of the tax plan will depend on what the Senate passes, and then on what the House and Senate agree to send to President Bush. Under the current Senate version of the plan, intended to reduce the impact of the alternative minimum tax on the cuts Mr. Bush wants, people in the top 20 percent income group would on average fare better than they would under the House plan, while the very richest would not do as well, according to Citizens for Tax Justice, a nonprofit group that says the tax system favors the rich. 
The New York Times asked this group for a more detailed analysis, using its computer model. Economists who disagree with Citizens for Tax Justice's views on taxes, including Bill Beach of the Heritage Foundation, a major backer of Mr. Bush's plan, say they accept the reliability of the group's calculations. 
They show that top 1 percent of taxpayers -- the 1.25 million who make more than $373,000 and pay higher taxes -- would receive an average tax cut of $28,608 under the House plan, but $20,135 under the Senate proposal. 
Because the Senate plan would change the way the alternative minimum tax kicks in, taxpayers in the next 4 percent -- the five million two-income couples, professionals and business owners who make $147,000 to $373,000 -- would average $3,593 each if the Senate proposal became law but would get $1,302 under the House plan. 
The $1,302 is less than the $1,600 Mr. Bush has said his plan will give back to families with children that are making around $60,000 -- an income far less than in the top groups.
The next 15 percent -- the nearly 19 million taxpayers who make $72,000 to $147,000 -- would get a tax cut of $2,093 each under the Senate plan, and $1,509 under the House plan, according to the Citizens for Tax Justice calculations.
The House plan calls for cutting the top tax rates to 33 percent from 36 percent and 39.6 percent, and the administration says this remains a top goal. But last Friday, two leaders of the Senate Finance Committee, Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, and Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, put forth a plan that would lower the top rate to 36 percent instead of 33 percent, citing insufficient support for the deeper cut. 
Before the House passed its version of the plan, Mr. Bush and Congressional leaders agreed to scale back the tax cut from $1.6 trillion over 10 years to $1.35 trillion. 
In Congress, the Joint Committee on Taxation has issued a limited analysis. 
The Heritage Foundation and other supporters of the president's plan say that the top tax rates are unfairly high and that the most economically productive taxpayers would be even more productive if their tax rates were significantly reduced. They add that because most taxes are paid by high-income Americans, most of the savings should go to them.
Indeed, the plan approved by the House would give the very-highest-income Americans a tax cut equal to 1 percent of their incomes. That is less in percentage terms than the tax cuts proposed for the middle class, although higher than the cuts for the poorest 20 percent and for those affected by the alternative minimum tax. Under the Senate version, the top 400 would get a 0.6 percent tax cut. 
The tax cut proposals come three years after another tax cut that also benefited the very richest Americans most, a 1998 reduction in tax rates on long-term capital gains. The new I.R.S. data show that the top 400 taxpayers saved an average of $6.4 million each that year, assuming that all their gains were long term. While Congress made these cuts available to all 125 million taxpayers, these 400 taxpayers alone received 7 percent of all the savings. These taxpayers account for about 1 percent of all income tax revenues. 
As a result of the cut in capital- gains tax rates, which began to take effect in 1997, the share of income that the top 400 taxpayers owe in taxes has fallen significantly. The top 400 paid an average of 22 percent of their adjusted gross incomes in 1998, down from 30 percent in 1995. Under Mr. Bush's plan, as approved by the House, the figure would fall further, to 20.9 percent; 21.4 percent under the Senate plan.
For all taxpayers, the average income tax rose to 14.6 percent from 14 percent over these same years, the I.R.S. data shows. Under Mr. Bush's plan, as the House passed it, the average income tax for all Americans should fall to 12.3 percent, Treasury officials said. No such figures have been calculated for the Senate alternative to the Bush plan. 
Mr. Bush also proposes to repeal the estate tax, which he calls the death tax. The administration has not provided estimates of how much various income groups would benefit from this cut, but the tax is paid on the fortunes of only the richest 2 percent of Americans who die.
Mr. Bush originally proposed to cut all tax rates. The two highest rates, 39.6 percent and 36 percent, would fall to 33 percent. The 31 percent and 28 percent rates would fall to 25 percent, and a fourth of the money taxed at 15 percent would fall to a new 10 percent bracket.
The highest rate is paid by the top 1 percent, and the second highest by the top 2 percent. 
But the almost 25 million taxpayers making $72,000 to $627,000 would get far less than these rate cuts would imply because of the alternative minimum tax. White House officials have said they are aware that the alternative minimum tax will take away some of the tax savings Mr. Bush proposes. The proposal under discussion in the Senate Finance Committee would seek to reduce somewhat the effect of the alternative minimum tax.
That tax was adopted 32 years ago to make sure that very wealthy individuals could not use deductions or tax-avoidance schemes to escape paying a fair share of taxes. But because Congress has not adjusted the tax to keep pace with inflation or other changes in the law, it no longer applies to people who make more than $627,000.
Indeed, it has increasingly come to apply to middle- and upper-income taxpayers who claim wholly legitimate deductions.
For example, on its face the Bush plan passed by the House would save a couple making $373,000 about $8,800, or 11 percent of their tax bill, the Citizens for Tax Justice model shows. But the alternative minimum tax would take away $6,370 of that, wiping out all but $2,430 of the income tax savings.
The Senate version gives this taxpayer $4,551 because of changes it makes in the alternative minimum tax.
The alternative minimum tax hits hardest at large families and people who live in places with high state taxes like New York, Connecticut, New Jersey, Massachusetts and California. That is because it reduces or eliminates deductions taxpayers take for themselves, for their children and for state income and local property taxes, as well as some medical bills. 
Indeed, Mr. Bush's plan would increase revenue from the alternative minimum tax by $130 billion and that increase would help hold down the overall cost of the Bush tax cuts.
The alternative minimum tax has come under renewed scrutiny recently as legislators and tax analysts study the effect it would have on any broad-based tax cut.
But Mr. Bush did not address the problem in his tax proposal, saying that reducing all tax rates, increasing the child credit, reducing the so-called marriage penalty and eliminating the estate tax were higher priorities. 
The White House referred all questions to Mark Weinberger, the Treasury's assistant secretary for tax policy, who said Mr. Bush's plan was intended to provide cuts for all taxpayers in proportion to their income.
"We did not focus on the top 1 percent or on the alternative minimum tax" in designing the package, Mr. Weinberger said. He said that the alternative minimum tax must be changed, but that the tax cut must come first because Mr. Bush ran for office on a promise to cut tax rates, not to fix the alternative minimum tax. 
The proposal being considered by the Senate Finance Committee would somewhat reduce the scale of the problem, but eliminating the alternative minimum tax would cost as much as several hundred billion dollars over the next decade -- more than Republican leaders can allocate to it and still include all of Mr. Bush's priorities in the $1.35 trillion tax bill.
Mr. Bush and Republican leaders seem to have made a decision that they would rather push through the underlying tax cut now and rely on public pressure to help them enact another tax bill in the next year or two to address the alternative tax problem.
David Keating, executive director of the Club for Growth, a Washington group that works to defeat members of Congress who resist deep tax cuts, said the disparity in benefits within the top 1 percent was evidence that the alternative minimum tax should be overhauled or abolished. "For someone to lose three-fourths of their tax cut because of the alternative minimum tax shows that rates are not being pushed down nearly as much as advertised," he said.
Robert McIntyre, director of Citizens for Tax Justice, said taking away tax breaks through the alternative minimum tax illustrates what he said was deceptive marketing by the White House of a tax plan that supposedly benefits everyone. "This is a plan designed solely for the rich," he said, "and everybody else gets a trivial tax cut that they will pay for with the loss of valuable government services."

HEADLINE: $25 AND UNDER; 
The Isles of Greece in Microminiature

BYLINE:  By Eric Asimov 

 BODY:
AT 380 square feet, kitchen included, and with seating for 10, barely, Snack is one of Manhattan's smallest restaurants. Even so, Elias Varkoutas, who opened Snack in SoHo in 1999, thought there was room enough to take on a partner. So he has joined forces with Adam Greene, a former general manager of Aquavit and Union Pacific. Together, they have expanded Snack's menu and hours, transforming a luncheonette serving vegetarian Greek appetizers into a restaurant with full Greek meals.
 Now, a tiny place like Snack could be viewed as a curiosity, a testament to the rigors of the Manhattan real estate market. But taste Snack's stifado ($13), a wonderful stew of braised lamb, delicately spiced with cinnamon and oregano and touched with the sweet juices of a currant, apricot and almond pilaf, and you know right away that Snack is worth squeezing into. 
 And I do mean squeeze. Plain wooden tables line one side of the narrow dining room, and access to the banquette requires lifting a table out of the way. Arrive with a party of three, and you will hunker around a table built for two rather than leaving a seat empty at a table for four. Small-scale economics, you know.
Still, the two-man operation (I'm told there's kitchen help, but I've never seen anybody else) handles awkward seating moments with good nature. At Snack, where your neighbor's business inevitably becomes yours, everybody nonetheless seems to get along. 
Maybe that's because everybody is enjoying the food, starting with impeccable cold appetizers ($9 for a selection of three). Hummus is sharpened to a lively tang with copious lemon juice, while melitzanes salata, an eggplant spread, is chunky and deliciously smoky. Fluffy and light taramosalata, a whipped carp-roe spread, tastes of the briny sea, while tzatziki, the cucumber-and-yogurt dip, is a refreshing anodyne to skordalia, a classic garlic-laden potato puree. 
The skordalia reappears in an excellent beet salad ($6), contrasting well with mildly sweet beets and peppery arugula. Roasted red pepper salad ($6) is on the sedate side, not as sweet as I expected but augmented by feta cheese and a garlic vinaigrette. Neither chewy octopus in a garlic sauce ($8) nor rubbery saganaki ($6) rivaled the cold appetizers, but chicken boureki ($8), a triangle of puff pastry layered with sesame seeds and stuffed with chicken, feta, mushrooms and herbs, is a close-your-eyes-and-sigh kind of dish. Olive boureki ($8) is pretty good, too, and since it comes with a salad or an appetizer, it can make a light meal.
I find it difficult to pass over the stifado, but Snack does offer other gems among its small selection of main courses. Keftedes ($13), or savory veal meatballs with pine nuts and almond slivers, are served with sweet prunes in a red wine sauce over tiny, paper-thin squares of pasta. Juicy roast chicken ($11), redolent of lemon, rosemary and garlic, comes with greens and roasted lemon potatoes, crisp and flavorful. I can do without the pastitsio ($12), a layered dish of beef, pasta and bechamel, which is like a flavorless Greek lasagna, but a pepper and a tomato, both stuffed with an airy yet spicy mixture of brown rice, onions, mint and dill ($11), are superb.
Desserts are simple and satisfying, whether yogurt with honey ($3) or a moist semolina "halvah" in a cinnamon-orange syrup. Snack does not have a wine-and-beer license but is expecting one soon.
While the cramped size is a drawback, it is a virtue, too. I wondered how Snack differed from the big, high-end restaurants Mr. Greene worked at previously. "We oversee everything here," he told me by telephone. "Very little is unobserved."

Snack

105 Thompson Street (Prince Street), SoHo, (212) 925-1040.

BEST DISHES: Lamb stifado, hummus, eggplant spread, carp roe spread, tzatziki, skordalia, chicken boureki, olive boureki, veal keftedes, roast chicken, stuffed peppers and tomatoes, desserts.

PRICE RANGE: Appetizers, $3 to $8; main courses, $8 to $13.

CREDIT CARDS: Cash only.

HOURS: Tuesday through Saturday, noon to 10 p.m. Sunday and Monday, noon to 8 p.m.

WHEELCHAIR ACCESS: Steps at entrance; way to restroom is narrow.

HEADLINE: ARTS ABROAD; 
Not Just for Brightening Up the Old Yurt Anymore

BYLINE:  By Douglas Frantz 

DATELINE: BISHKEK, Kyrgyzstan 

 BODY:
For centuries, the folk art of this mountainous realm reflected the nomadic wanderings of its people, and even the most beautiful and precious goods had to be useful and portable.
 The prized works were colorful lightweight felt rugs known as shyrdaks (pronounced SHEER-dox) and exquisitely embroidered cotton and silk wall hangings called tush-kiiz (TOOSH-kees). Spread across the floor and hung on walls, they brightened the yurt and kept this round, tentlike structure warm in winter. 
 By the end of the 20th century most Kyrgyz were in villages and cities and the artisans' skills had withered. Felt rugs of inferior quality were still produced for the occasional tourist. No one seemed willing to spend months stitching the intricate patterns of a traditional tush-kiiz. 
A reporter's tour of the teeming bazaars in Bishkek, the capital, and Osh, the largest city in southern Kyrgyzstan, failed to turn up anything matching the quality and workmanship of the older goods, though there were poor imitations among the endless wares in hundreds of stalls.
But efforts are being made to revive the crafts of Kyrgyzstan and the other countries along the ancient Silk Road that spans Central Asia. The impetus is part reverence for tradition and part recognition that a thriving folk art industry will bring economic benefits, no small matter in former Soviet republics where half the people live below the poverty line.
"We have tried to involve the poorest part of the population," Dinara Chochunbaeva, the force behind the revival, said in an interview. "People have the skills and, with some help, they can produce wonderful things." She runs Kyrgyz Style, a nonprofit organization in Bishkek that is trying to resurrect traditional arts and culture. It conducts workshops throughout the country to help rural women relearn the traditional folk arts and the knowlege to market their products.
Most of the 4.5 million residents of Kyrgyzstan are far too poor to buy crafts; the per capita income is $330 a year. Most tourists who visit are hunters hoping to bag a big-horned sheep or mountain climbers and hikers eager to test the Tian Shan and Pamir ranges, which Marco Polo called the roof of the world.
The export market offers the biggest hope for the crafts revival. Though the totals remain small, figures have been promising. In 1997, the first year the group counted exports, goods valued at $2,442 were sold. Last year sales were $102,412; a third of that involved sales in the United States.
The star of the felt rug revival is Janyl Aliebekov, who lives in the mountain village of Acha-Kayingi and is regarded as the country's best maker of shyrdaks.
The quality of her rugs is clear even to a novice. The felt is thinner and more supple than that of other rugs yet strong and light: a result, she says, of carefully selecting the right wool from the right sheep. The colors are subdued and harmonious.
Working on five or six rugs at a time, with help from family members, Mrs. Aliebekov can earn $250 to $300 a month, nearly a year's per capita earnings here. Her work will be displayed in late July at an international symposium on felt rugs in Naryn, Kyrgyzstan.
It has proved harder to stimulate a rebirth in tush-kiiz. These colorful hand-made wall panels resemble thin quilts, with a three-sided border surrounding an elaborately embroidered center panel. The bottom side was left unfinished because beds were usually pushed beneath the tush-kiiz or rugs were piled in front of it.
Few people are willing to devote the hundreds of hours required to stitch the intricate patterns in silk thread on the cotton backing. Because they are still considered compulsory dowry items for brides, modern tush-kiiz are usually bright patches of silk sewn together. 
But Bishkek is flooded with gorgeous tush-kiiz from the 1950's and 60's, generally selling for as little as $70 or $80 in the shops and galleries of Bishkek. The finest examples usually have the date and name of the maker stitched onto them.
When Ms. Chochunbaeva and Francois Colcanap, a Peace Corps volunteer working for Kyrgyz Style, took some old ones to show the British Museum in London recently, the museum purchased every item for its collection. The prices were so low, Mr. Colcanap said, that he refused to disclose them. 
In an effort to promote the folk art revival, the Central Asia Crafts Support Association was created last year. The association has 16 organizations and 3,000 members in five countries, from carpet weavers in Turkmenistan to ikat silk robe makers in Uzbekistan.
There is a parallel attempt to revive fine arts in Bishkek, the most hospitable and liberal city in Central Asia. Abandoned Soviet-era factories throughout the city have been transformed into studios and a handful of galleries have opened.
The United Nations Development Program in Kyrgyzstan published a catalog of local artists to showcase and stimulate the revival. Tourists and foreign workers in Bishkek have provided a small, but steady market.
An ambitious exhibition of art from Central Asia and Russia opened recently at the Aytiev Museum of Fine Arts in Bishkek and is to travel to Almaty, Kazakhstan, St. Petersburg, Russia, and the Netherlands.
Called "Internal Asia," the exhibition of 144 works is intended to demonstrate the energy and diversity of the region's contemporary painting and sculpture.
Many of the works are mundane and could have come from anywhere in the world, but others capture the uniqueness and vibrancy of Asia. A collage of photographs and diary installments from a trip to Tibet by Francisco Infante, a Moscow-based artist, for example, offers different perspectives on that remote and mysterious part of the world.
In one large installation, four blackened cooking pots called kazans are overturned on a strip of white cotton, mud and straw. A pathway leads to a traditional skin used to hold fermented mare's milk, which the nomads used as a cure for illnesses.
"The nomads turned the kazans over as a signal that it was time to move," said Murat Jumaliev, one of four local artists who created the installation. "It's symbolic of the wide road of our past and the new road we hope to follow in the future."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Decorating tips by way of Bishkek: A detail from a typical tush-kiiz, a wall hanging from Kyrgyzstan made of embroidered silk and cotton. (Douglas Frantz/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: MANAGEMENT; 
Cyclical School of Hard Knocks

BYLINE:  By REED ABELSON 

 BODY:
Roger Siboni had never experienced anything like it. One day, investors were rewarding a sevenfold annual increase in sales at his company, E.piphany Inc., by pushing its stock price above $200 a share. Then, seemingly without warning, they began to worry about costs and a slowdown in sales, and the stock started a descent that reached as low as $7.
 "I don't recall ever seeing such a rapid drop-off from exuberance to despair," said Mr. Siboni, the 46-year-old chief executive of E.piphany, a San Mateo, Calif., software company that went public less than two years ago. "It's almost like someone's flipped a switch." 
 As the exaggerated swings in stock markets illustrate, many investors have never had to navigate a bear market. At the same time, there are many chief executives whose memory of the last economic slowdown is dim. 
During the last recession of the early 90's, most of today's top executives were not in the jobs they now hold -- and many were not even among a company's senior management.
While managing during any economic downturn is a challenge, executives face a particularly formidable task this time around.
After a decade in which companies flourished seemingly without effort -- the longest period of uninterrupted economic growth on record -- many executives now face a radically different environment, according to management consultants and some of the executives themselves.
Shareholders have become deeply skeptical, demand has slowed drastically in many areas and there is intense pressure to cut costs to show profits or, at the very least, to conserve cash.
Executives who have led their companies only through rapid growth are having a difficult time, said Peter Crist, a vice chairman of Korn/Ferry International, an executive recruiting firm. "I can guarantee you that they have the deer-in-the-headlights look when they get to a soft spot," he said.
Mr. Siboni acknowledged that the suddenness of the slowdown had rattled his peers. "This has hit the psyche of every C.E.O. across the U.S., and even globally," he said.
While some of the youngest and least-experienced managers are found among the many companies that were created in boom times, even some established companies lack a lot of gray hair in the executive suite. "You have companies that have lost so many of their top and middle managers that they are dependent on someone who was in school during the last downturn," said Gary Stibel, principal of the New England Consulting Group in Westport, Conn. Many of those managers went to dot-coms and other start-ups, and some were asked to leave.
The combination of a widening gap between the performance that investors expect and what companies can deliver, combined with the high level of turnover among chief executives, is creating what Chris Zook, the head of the worldwide strategy practice for Bain & Company, describes as the management equivalent of "the perfect storm."
Executives are also being forced to rethink what they tell Wall Street and the kind of promises they can make, according to executives and consultants.
"Companies have been in a trap of false enthusiasm in the last six to eight years," Mr. Zook said.
While some chief executives may still think they can get away with promising double-digit growth in revenue or earnings even when they may not be able to deliver, most are learning a newfound realism based on old-fashioned business methods that were learned the hard way by those who were around in the last recession.
No one says that having lived through the last recession was complete protection against this decline, of course, and even relatively seasoned chief executives like John T. Chambers at Cisco Systems seem to have been caught unaware.
Mr. Chambers, who joined Cisco as a senior vice president during the last downturn, said last month that a 30 percent drop in third-quarter sales at his company was symptomatic of a broader slump that "may be the fastest any industry our size has ever decelerated." He likened the slowdown that Cisco was experiencing to "a 100-year flood."
But experience with an earlier recession may help executives steer their companies through the current slowdown. Gone are the days when promises of growth were enough to levitate a stock, which helped many executives look like heroes.
"The slogan du jour was get big, fast," recalled Mr. Siboni of E.piphany, which had been blessed with a stock price that topped $216. Mr. Siboni joined the company in 1998 after a 20-year career as a consultant with KPMG Peat Marwick.
Back then, he said, "so much of our efforts were directed at modulating the highs." Today, the emphasis is on digging out of the lows.
Mr. Siboni, for example, is paying careful attention to his company's costs, especially after revenue proved disappointing in the first quarter. He is exiting less profitable businesses like software integration because the high cost of hiring people makes profits hard to come by.
Like many other executives, Mr. Siboni must also use a stock that is trading around $11 to motivate employees who for the most part know only what it is like to work in a company with a rising stock price and seemingly unlimited potential.
At a recent meeting, for example, he tried to persuade his employees that the current period "is probably a more important time in your career than the last five great and glory years."
He argues that those who prove themselves during these hard times will benefit from the lessons they have learned and the depth of their experience.
Executives who were once punished for not delivering dazzling dot-com-style results say that by not being caught up in the mania, they are having an easier time making their case to the investment community now. Harry M. Jansen Kraemer Jr., the chief executive of Baxter International, recalled the questions from Wall Street about why Baxter, which makes blood products, vaccines and other medical products in Deerfield, Ill., could not increase its annual earnings as much as 25 percent.
"We didn't grow at 20 to 30 percent when some of the craziness was going on," said Mr. Kraemer, 46, who has spent the last 19 years at Baxter and was named chief executive in early 1999. But his focus on delivering profits that he knows Baxter can achieve, in the midteens on a yearly basis, means that the company's stock is now being rewarded and is trading near its 52-week high. 
Unlike many companies, Baxter is not in a position radically different than it was a few years ago, according to Mr. Kraemer. The company has always been under pressure to contain expenses, for example, because it cannot increase its prices to protect its profits. "What you have to do now is what I have to do every year," Mr. Kraemer said.
Certainly some young executives are not convinced that having run a company through the last downturn would make their job any easier today. Managing during times like this "is not something you can learn from one downturn to the next," said Guy Gecht, the 36-year-old chief executive of Electronics for Imaging, a Foster City, Calif., company that makes devices for printers.
Mr. Gecht, who was a software manager during the last recession, now oversees a work force of about 900 people. The company warned last June that its second-quarter earnings would be lower than Wall Street was expecting because of lower demand. Electronics for Imaging's stock, which reached about $69 in April, fell as low as $11 by October.
When the economy began to slow, Mr. Gecht said that he met with his senior managers and talked about how to handle the shifting environment, and they discussed what steps they needed to take. The company now gives clearer guidance trends in sales and profits, he said, and this has helped it meet Wall Street's expectations for the last two quarters. As a result, the stock has rebounded somewhat, to trade around $29.
Mr. Gecht is also focusing on talking with employees. Until very recently, he said that he used to block out an hour each day on his calendar to walk around the offices and talk to people, hearing their concerns and explaining the company's strategy.
Other executives, however, say that they think there is a clear benefit to experience.
"The most important thing you learn about a business cycle is that it ends," said Umang Gupta, the 51-year-old chief executive of Keynote Systems, a San Mateo, Calif., company that helps other companies measure the effectiveness of their Web sites.
Mr. Gupta, who created an earlier software company that went public and prospered until it stumbled in the mid-90's, when Mr. Gupta left, thinks the perspective offered by seeing an economic decline is useful.
Last year, for example, Mr. Gupta said he and his management team were convinced that the boom would end, given their experience with other business cycles, so they raised as much cash as they could before the bubble burst. Although the company went public in September 1999, it raised $350 million for itself in a secondary offering in early 2000. 
The company has also shifted its client base away from Internet companies that may or may not survive to corporate clients like Bank of America and Charles Schwab.
"That requires a hardheadedness," Mr. Gupta said, and an understanding that the company cannot afford to do everything.
Experience with slowdowns can give executives the perspective needed to choose wisely among difficult options.
In the coming months, many executives will stumble, cutting staff too deeply or refusing to become realistic about how quickly their businesses can grow.
"True leaders really shine in a downturn," said Mr. Crist, the executive recruiter. "The impostors are defrocked in tough times."

Guy Gecht, 36, below, head of Electronics for Imaging, said that managing during hard economic times "is not something you can learn from one downturn to the next." HEADLINE: Business Travel; 
Airlines await the return of business passengers, creating bargain opportunities in leisure fares.

BYLINE:  By Joe Sharkey; The Business Travel column appears each Wednesday. E-mail: sharkey@nytimes.com

 BODY:
SOARING air fares usually get most of the blame for the cutbacks in business travel that hammered the airline industry's balance sheets in the first quarter of this year. But there are some early indications that the ascent in air fares has leveled off.
 Far less clear, though, is when we can expect to see robust growth again in domestic business travel. 
 Airlines, struggling to keep revenue up as costs rise and business demand slackens, are obviously becoming aggressive on discounting some fares. The Air Transport Association, a trade group, reported recently that average domestic air fares declined 2.5 percent in March over March 2000. 
That doesn't necessarily indicate that conditions are improving for corporate travel, which is one of the barometers of a rebounding economy, said David A. Swierenga, the chief economist at the association.
"What you have today are two countervailing forces," Mr. Swierenga said. On one hand, higher fuel and labor-settlement costs are pushing fares up, while plummeting demand the last two months has prompted selective fare discounts by airlines that are looking for ways to fill seats, he said.
The newspapers currently brim with airline fare-sale ads. But the discounting is aimed mostly at the leisure-travel end of the market, in which airlines are essentially hoping to pick up small change until the far more lucrative business-travel side resumes its recent growth levels -- something a few industry experts don't expect to see until next year.
"Demand has been really weak in the full-fare and premium-cabin categories" that constitute the bulk of the business travel market, Mr. Swierenga said.
"The real difficulty with soft demand in the airline industry is the business traveler," he added, "and that's not going to turn around until businesses see their incomes beginning to rise again." Discretionary business travel is usually among the first expenditures to be cut when quarterly results start looking wobbly.
The leisure travel market, meanwhile, does not appear to be reacting with the same intensity to economic worries. In fact, more than 80 percent of leisure travelers say they will travel this summer as much as (59 percent) or more than (23 percent) they did last summer, according to the American Express leisure travel index released yesterday.
There isn't any indication that people are planning to cut back on vacation spending this summer. According to the American Express survey, 44 percent of leisure travelers plan to spend more this year than last, and 39 percent said they expected to spend about the same amount.
Joanne Fisher, a spokeswoman for the leisure travel index, said that the figures shouldn't be interpreted to suggest that an inordinate amount of Americans are laughing off a soft economy and "booking vacation safaris" or piling on other luxuries. They just don't seem to be panicking.
As always, the most popular leisure trips are visiting family and friends, and the favorite type of accommodations remains "moderately priced hotels," said Elizabeth Cohen, vice president for the lodging industry at American Express.
There's also encouraging news from another American Express survey, to be released later this week, which shows that companies are seeing some respite from steadily rising business air fares, at least for the time being.
According to the American Express Business Travel Monitor, which tracks business air fares in 215 domestic city pairs each month, while typical business air fares remain at record high levels and have shot up 77 percent since 1996, they stayed flat in March and February at about an average of $1,158 for a round-trip ticket. For the entire first quarter, however, the fares were 13 percent higher than the period a year earlier.
American Express defines typical business fares as the standard rate "basically the sticker price, the lowest economy-class fare available" at close to last-minute purchase, said Don Munro, an American Express spokesman.
The survey tracks another index, however, the so-called average fare paid. This fare "reflects what a company's business travelers actually wind up paying" for an airline ticket, Mr. Munro said.
In March, the average business fare paid was $638 for a round trip. Those fares grew only 4 percent during the first quarter over the average for the first quarter of 2000.
One reason for that is the revolution currently sweeping corporate travel departments, where traveling employees are being encouraged -- and pressed -- to adhere better to travel-budget policies intended to allow planners to negotiate prices using volume discounts, advance purchasing, online booking and other cost-saving techniques.
"More companies are using nonrefundable tickets," which are less
expensive because they must be bought weeks in advance, Mr. Munro said.
"Companies are getting the word out to employees," he said, "that you have to plan earlier for your trip if you want to take advantage of these lower fares."
Also, Mr. Munro added, "companies are doing a better job telling their employees about negotiated discounts" with specific airlines. To a growing extent, he said, more employees are starting to cooperate through corporate intranet travel engines, which are seen by travel managers as ways to reduce long-term travel costs.
All in all, he said, "companies are becoming increasingly successful at buffering the full effects of air fares."

HEADLINE: Zale Jewelry Chain Posts Weak Results 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: DALLAS, May 15 

 BODY:
The Zale Corporation, the largest jewelry retailer in the nation, said today that its profit fell more than 50 percent in its most recent quarter because of a slowdown in consumer spending and inventory problems.
 Zale, which operates more than 2,300 stores in the United States, Canada and Puerto Rico, said it earned $3.5 million, or 10 cents a share, down from $10.5 million, or 30 cents a share, a year earlier. 
 Sales in the period, which ended April 30 and was the third quarter of Zale's fiscal year, rose 13.9 percent, to $411.5 million, while comparable-store sales, a critical measure of performance, fell 7.3 percent from a year earlier.
Excluding a charge for severance payments, Zale earned $4.8 million, or 14 cents a share, which fell short of the 15 cents expected by analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/ First Call.
Zale said it expected a flat performance for the coming year.
"Profit numbers were in line with our expectations for this quarter," the chairman, Robert DiNicola, said in a statement. "However, as we look ahead I would anticipate a flat profit performance for next fiscal year since both internal and external factors are negatively impacting our business."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Shares Finish Flat After Initial Excitement Over Rate Cut

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stocks initially spiked higher yesterday but ended nearly flat in reaction to the Federal Reserve's fifth cut in interest rates this year to try to jump-start the sagging economy.
 "The market opened up the present, pulled the tissue away and looked for the bonus gift at the bottom of the box. It didn't see anything at the bottom and sold off, almost like a 3-year-old on Christmas morning," said David Sowerby, a market strategist for Loomis Sayles, which oversees about $65 billion. "I think people were looking for the Fed to say more definitively that they are not done cutting rates." 
 In a move that was widely anticipated by the financial markets, the central bank lowered the federal funds rate, a benchmark for short-term interest rates, by 50 basis points, to 4.0 percent from 4.5 percent. The Fed, citing signs of weakness in the economy, hinted it might cut more.
With the Fed not scheduled to meet again until late June, Wall Street is desperately searching for signs that profits are improving, analysts said. Lower interest rates encourage business investment and increase consumer spending. But the question is: When will it show up in corporate America's bottom line?
"The next quarter's earnings will look pretty yucky, but I think that's discounted in the marketplace," said Michelle Clayman, chief investment officer at New Amsterdam Partners. "Now, really, the issue is: What are third- and fourth-quarter earnings going to look like?"
The Dow Jones industrial average finished down 4.36 points, at 10,872.97, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index inched up just 0.52 point, to 1,249.44.
The technology-dominated Nasdaq composite index edged up 3.66 points, or 0.2 percent, to 2,085.58, after initially rising more than 2 percent on news of the rate cut.
Before the news, the broad stock market was slightly lower, along with the Dow, although technology stocks held modest gains.
The Fed, which with its latest action took the federal funds rate to its lowest level in seven years, also reduced the discount rate -- charged on direct Fed loans to commercial banks -- by half a percentage point, to 3.5 percent.
In its accompanying statement, the central bank said it still saw excessive weakness as the main threat to the economy, citing concerns about falling investment spending and weak corporate profits.
The Fed's warning about the threat of economic weakness, as well as its comment that inflation remained contained, helped bolster the view that the central bank was poised to trim rates further if the need arose.
Since the last monetary easing on April 18, stocks have moved higher on the expectation that lower rates will reduce borrowing costs for businesses and consumers, thereby aiding spending and corporate profits.
Wal-Mart Stores fell $2.35, to $52, after the retailer offered cautious comments on the economy's effect on its future business, while reporting earnings that were slightly higher than expected.
Home Depot gained 95 cents, to $50.10, after saying it expected to meet Wall Street's forecasts for the next quarter because of strong cost-control measures, while J. C. Penney fell 86 cents, to $20.19, after reporting lower results, citing a slowdown in its catalog business because of the slumping economy.
In other corporate news, Motorola said it was considering selling its Integrated Information Systems Group, a government communication and information technology business. Motorola slipped 78 cents, to $14.96.
 --------------------

Treasury Prices Drop
 (By Bloomberg News) -- Most Treasury bond prices fell after the Federal Reserve lowered its benchmark interest rate half a point, to 4 percent, fueling speculation that the five rate reductions this year will accelerate inflation.
The 10-year Treasury note fell 16/32, to a price of 96 8/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.50 percent from 5.43 percent on Monday. 
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 25/32, to 92 19/32. The bond's yield rose to 5.91 percent from 5.85 percent on Monday.

HEADLINE: Text of Fed's Statement 

 BODY:
Following is the text of a statement by the Federal Reserve yesterday after the Federal Open Market Committee, the Fed's monetary policy panel, decided to lower interest rates: 
 The Federal Open Market Committee at its meeting today decided to lower its target for the federal funds rate by 50 basis points, to 4 percent. 
In a related action, the board of governors approved a 50-basis-point reduction in the discount rate, to 3 1/2 percent. 
 A significant reduction in excess inventories seems well advanced. Consumption and housing expenditures have held up reasonably well, though activity in these areas has flattened recently. Investment in capital equipment, however, has continued to decline. The erosion in current and prospective profitability, in combination with considerable uncertainty about the business outlook, seems likely to hold down capital spending going forward. This potential restraint, together with the possible effects of earlier reductions in equity wealth on consumption and the risk of slower growth abroad, continues to weigh on the economy.
With pressures on labor and product markets easing, inflation is expected to remain contained. Although measured productivity growth stalled in the first quarter, the impressive underlying rate of increase that developed in recent years appears to be largely intact, supporting longer-term prospects.
The committee continues to believe that against the background of its long-run goals of price stability and sustainable economic growth and of the information currently available, the risks are weighted mainly toward conditions that may generate economic weakness in the foreseeable future. 
In taking the discount rate action, the Federal Reserve Board approved requests submitted by the boards of directors of the Federal Reserve Banks of New York, Richmond, Chicago, St. Louis and San Francisco.
