HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place; 
The FedCut Rates, and Wall Street Yawned

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Investors got what they expected from the Federal Reserve yesterday, but didn't jump for joy.
 The Fed again lowered its benchmark short-term interest rate -- the federal funds rate on overnight loans between banks -- by half a percentage point, to 4 percent, and indicated that it was prepared to cut again. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average, which had been down around 50 points before the announcement, finished 4.36 points lower, at 10,872.97. The Nasdaq composite index, up about 6 points before the announcement, ended the day up 3.66 points, or 0.18 percent, at 2,085.58. 
In the bond market, shorter-term rates rallied a bit on the expectation of further rate cuts, but longer-term securities sold off, pushing yields higher.
Still, yesterday's response from the stock market was a bit more positive than it had been after the two earlier rate cuts the Fed made this year at regularly scheduled meetings. On Jan. 31, the Dow was essentially unchanged, and on March 20, it fell 2.4 percent. The Nasdaq composite index fell 2.3 percent on Jan. 31 and 4.8 percent on March 20.
By contrast, the two surprise rate cuts, made between scheduled meetings, produced big surges in stock indexes.
Bonds had responded positively to three of the previous four rate cuts, with prices rising and yields consequently declining across the board.
For the markets, the crucial aspect of the Fed's decision yesterday was not so much the size of the rate cut, but the indication that Federal Reserve policy makers stood ready to reduce interest rates again. That is what gives investors confidence these days.
"They will not quit," said Christine A. Callies, chief United States investment strategist at Merrill Lynch, "until they achieve success in turning around capital spending and compensating for the negative wealth effect" undermining consumer spending. She was citing two of the three factors that Fed policy makers said continue "to weigh on the economy" -- the third being the risk of slower economic growth abroad.
But Ms. Callies also said she "would not be surprised to see short-term stagnation in the stock indexes." This, she explained, is because investors were given what they had expected, and since their portfolios were positioned for a rate reduction, many saw no need to change them.
The latest rate cut comes at a time when both stock and bond investors seem to believe that the central bank will be able to engineer an economic recovery in the second half of the year. Such sentiment is reflected in recent rises in the Nasdaq composite index, which is up more than 25 percent from its low in April, and in the rise in longer-term Treasury yields as investors prepare for the higher interest rates that would presumably come with an economic recovery.
In part, such confidence stems from the rapidity of the Fed's rate cuts and their combined force -- with the benchmark short-term rate now down 2.5 percentage points in five half-point moves starting on Jan. 3.
This is the fastest that the central bank has lowered interest rates since a combined reduction of two and a half percentage points between July 20 and Aug. 16, 1982. While such rate cuts are expected to take months to have practical effects on the economy, the stock market in the past has recovered sooner with aggressive moves by the Federal Reserve.
In fact, after the first three cuts this year, the Dow Jones industrials were down two weeks later; the Nasdaq composite index was down two weeks after the second and third rate cuts. But after the surprise cut on April 18, both indexes were up two weeks thereafter. And while those two stock indexes have since given up some of the gains, before the Fed announced its move yesterday, both were still higher than they had been with the previous rate cut.
The economic data, though, have not yet confirmed that a recovery is in place, and the rising number of layoffs points to a risk of the economy's slowing further before it recovers. The unemployment rate is now 4.5 percent, up from a 30-year low of 3.9 percent six months earlier.
"The Fed is very worried about the economic outlook" said William Dudley, chief United States economist at Goldman, Sachs, "because they are not precluding a further rate cut."
John Lipsky, chief economist at J. P. Morgan Chase, said only clear signs that the economy was turning around would preclude another rate cut when Fed officials next meet on June 26-27.
"It seems unlikely that such signs would appear," Mr. Lipsky said, adding that he is expecting another half-point cut next month.
But while more reductions are anticipated, the Federal Reserve seemed to indicate that it was not likely to make another cut between meetings before June 26. In their statement yesterday, Fed officials dropped language in their March 20 statement that investors interpreted then as signaling the possibility of another rate cut between sessions.
Corporate profits, which are declining, could also keep investors off balance because the decline is likely to result in further pressure on employers to reduce costs by cutting jobs.
In the first quarter of this year, profits for the companies in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index were down 6.4 percent, according to Thomson Financial/First Call.
For the second quarter, Wall Street analysts forecast a decline in earnings of 11.4 percent, and then a drop of 2.9 percent in the third quarter. If these forecasts prove correct, it would be the first three consecutive quarterly earnings declines since 1991, during the last recession.
Recent economic data confirm this mixed picture. Last week, the government reported a surprising 0.8 percent jump in retail sales in April and a rise in consumer confidence. A recent sharp increase in first-time claims for unemployment benefits also stopped. But on the negative side, industrial production fell 0.3 percent in April, the seventh consecutive monthly decline.

HEADLINE: Ruling May Erode Longshoremen's Grip on Ports 

BYLINE:  By LESLIE EATON 

DATELINE: NEWARK 

 BODY:
In a major blow to the longshoremen's union and its grip on the docks of New York Harbor, a stevedoring company will be allowed to use members of its laborers' union to unload some ships at Port Newark.
 The company says it challenged decades-old rules and pushed to use its own employees to unload the ships as a way to bring new business to Port Newark and end a government-sanctioned monopoly unique to the Port of New York and New Jersey. 
 Yesterday, the government body that regulates the port agreed, at least in part. The Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor gave the company permission to use those workers, but only to unload steel products that have not been coming into the port until now. 
"I'm a little disappointed that they restricted us to just handling steel," said Andrew J. Naporano Jr., the former owner of Metal Management's Newark operation, who is leading the company's move into stevedoring. "But overall, I'm pleased." 
The company plans to start lining up clients right away, he said, and hopes to begin unloading steel in the fall.
The president of the International Longshoremen's Association, John Bowers, said that his union planned to fight Mr. Naporano. He said the union's lawyers would meet today with lawyers for the shipping companies, which also oppose Mr. Naporano's plans, to try to figure out what to do next.
"This opens the door for somebody else to do the same thing, that's what we're worried about," Mr. Bowers said. "Today it's steel, tomorrow it will be some other cargo."
The stakes are high, for Mr. Naporano and his business, for roughly 2,700 local members of the International Longshoremen's Association, and for the area's ports, which directly and indirectly employ more than 166,000 people, according to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.
In its heyday in the middle of the last century, half of everything that came into the United States from abroad went through New York Harbor, where 25,000 men were hired every day to unload ships. And the longshoreman's union controlled it all, for better and for worse.
It was the worse that prompted the legislatures to create the commission in 1953, just before the film "On the Waterfront" dramatized the situation on the docks, where mob bosses and corrupt union leaders forced longshoremen to pay bribes to get work.
The commission also tries to bring supply and demand for longshoremen into balance, a task performed at other ports by free-market forces and collective bargaining.
What made that task so tough was the rise of shipping containers, those truck-trailer-size boxes that came into use in the 1960's. Suddenly, the port did not need 31,000 longshoremen to unload ships anymore; it needed a couple of thousand who knew how to use a crane.
In 1966, the New York Shipping Association, which represents employers in the port, agreed to pay a guaranteed annual income to longshoremen who could no longer get enough work. To try to keep a lid on costs, the Waterfront Commission soon stopped approving new longshoremen.
Even so, by 1983, the annual payments to longshoremen hit $65 million a year, and shippers complained about the high costs of doing business in New York.
Containers, which made it easy to move cargo by rail or truck, allowed them to go elsewhere economically, said Wayne K. Talley, executive director of the Maritime Institute at Old Dominion University in Norfolk, Va. So New York began losing out to other ports.
This was the situation when Mr. Naporano came to know the port. He and his brother were running Naporano Iron and Metal, a scrap business his grandfather founded in 1907.
For two decades, Mr. Naporano's imports were unloaded and his exports loaded by stevedores using I.L.A. labor. But a strike in 1991 threatened to keep them from loading a ship -- and made him decide to take matters into his own hands.
The port rules exempted from the I.L.A. contract bulk cargo -- oil, orange juice, salt -- things that could not be counted as individual items. He decided that scrap metal was bulk, too. So he used his own crews to load that ship.
Hundreds of members of the longshoremen's union walked off their jobs briefly in protest. But Mr. Naporano's company continued to load and unload his own cargo and, in 1997, began to do bulk stevedoring work for other companies.
In the meantime, longshoremen began to retire and the guaranteed-income charges plummeted. The union agreed to less restrictive work rules. Trade through the port picked up.
By the late 1990's, there was no longer a surplus of longshoremen, but rather a shortage of people trained to use computers and complicated equipment. So last year, for the first time in three decades, the Waterfront Commission added new longshoremen, 481 of them, to its approved list.
Even so, the commission's staff said that by its calculations, a third of the time last year there would not have been enough I.L.A. longshoremen available to do Mr. Naporano's work.
Mr. Naporano's critics say the plan could cause unnecessary labor strife and upset the port's delicate balance just as New York Harbor is booming again.
In its decision, the commission said that Metal Management's laborers would unload only steel products that were not now coming into the port. Therefore, the commission wrote, approving Mr. Naporano's plan "will not adversely impact the existing work force of longshoremen, but will affirmatively advance the public interest of the Port of New York District."

HEADLINE: Job and Tax Data Show the Slowdown Reaching New York 

BYLINE:  By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
The New York metropolitan economy, so strong for so long, is finally beginning to show signs of strain from the national slowdown.
 In New Jersey, almost 7,000 jobs were lost in April, and the state's unemployment rate jumped to 4.2 percent from 3.8 percent the month before, according to data released yesterday. In Rockland County, N.Y., shoppers have cut back spending so much that the county fears a $10 million shortfall in sales tax collections. 
 And in New York City, hotel rooms are increasingly empty, and a rising number of workers are filing for unemployment insurance benefits. Surveys in the region show that optimism is waning among consumers and business executives. 
None of this suggests that the economic sky is falling, but people in the New York area have more reason to worry. 
"We are now officially part of the national economic slowdown," said James W. Hughes, the dean of the Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University. "A month ago, we were certainly impacted, but not fully embraced by the slowdown."
Until now, the slowdown has been concentrated in areas with a lot of manufacturing; unemployment has surged in Michigan and Illinois, for example. In the New York City area, factories are scarce, which helps explain why unemployment here has not been rising.
April jobs data for New York State and New York City will not be released until tomorrow, and some economists think signs of a slowdown in employment may not show that soon. But the weakness of New Jersey's April results has made others more cautious about the outlook for New York.
"We've had two months of job declines on the national level, which means we might get a surprise in New York," said Thomas J. Spitznas, an economist in Mount Vernon, N.Y. "We're kind of at a critical point here."
More than half the 6,900 job losses in New Jersey were in manufacturing, which dropped by 3,800, the New Jersey Department of Labor said. Construction jobs also fell by 1,900.
But employment in the service sector also declined, by about 1,100. Services -- a category that includes everything from store clerks to stockbrokers -- have been the strong point in the local economy until now.
In what may be a warning sign for New York City and its major industry, employment at brokerage firms fell by 500. That may not sound like much, but jobs at securities firms in New Jersey have been rising steadily since late 1994, as Wall Street moved clerical and other jobs to Jersey City.
Faced with a sullen stock market and reluctant corporate clients, investment companies like Merrill Lynch, Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs have announced big layoffs. Until now, however, the effects have not really shown up in the jobs data.
While some economists think that the weakness in manufacturing is spreading to services in general, others, like Marc M. Goloven of J. P. Morgan Chase & Company, say most of what look like job losses in the service sector have been suffered by temporary workers who have been placed at manufacturing firms. In New Jersey in April, personnel suppliers accounted for 1,500 job losses.
New Jersey officials preferred to emphasize the positive yesterday, noting that despite the 0.4 percentage point increase in the unemployment rate, New Jersey's 4.2 percent jobless level remains below the national average of 4.5 percent. "The New Jersey economy continues to perform well despite this upswing in the unemployment rate," said Mark Boyd, the state labor commissioner.
In fact, the meaning of much economic data remains murky, even to economists. Some are alarmed by the steep rise in weekly initial claims for unemployment insurance in New York, which are up by about 25 percent this year. Others say such claims have not proved to be useful indicators in New York City.
Similarly, the New York State comptroller's office reports that collections of sales tax fell by 5.6 percent in April, compared with the previous year. But analysts there are not sure if the decline comes from consumers keeping their wallets in their pockets, or from things like the elimination of the tax on clothing that costs less than $110.
But in Rockland County, government officials are convinced that the county's shortfall is caused by cautious consumers, said C. Scott Vanderhoef, the county executive. Sales taxes, which account for more than 70 percent of the county's budget, have been rising by about 9 percent a year, Mr. Vanderhoef said. But though the county only budgeted a 6.5 percent rise this year, he added, collections are falling far short of that.
Some businesspeople sense that the good times may have rolled away. Bob Maguire, a second-generation car dealer in Bordentown, N.J., said his customers were increasingly interested in buying used cars rather than the more expensive new Chevrolets and Saturns he sells.
"They realize they would like a new car, but a late-model used car will meet their budgets," said Mr. Maguire, who is president of the National Automobile Dealers Association.
Are his customers worried about their financial futures? "No, I don't see worry," Mr. Maguire said. "But people are not as expansive in outlook as they once were. They're not talking about going on a cruise or buying a new house."

HEADLINE: In the Catskills, Water Hazards; 
A 36-Hole, 500-Acre Resort Plan Draws Opposition

BYLINE:  By ROBERT WORTH 

DATELINE: SHANDAKEN, N.Y. 

 BODY:
There were snickers and snide comments five years ago when Dean L. Gitter built Catskill Corners, a gaudy gift-shop mall featuring the world's largest kaleidoscope and a silo painted with psychedelic designs. Even Mr. Gitter, an actor-turned-developer who wears a cowboy hat and ponytail, seemed happy to poke fun at his hucksterish image, promoting himself as "the P.T. Barnum of the Catskills." 
 But few people here, Mr. Gitter included, are laughing about his latest proposal, for a $300 million resort atop a mountain in the heart of the Catskill Park. 
 It is the largest development ever proposed in the state park: a 500-acre complex with two 18-hole golf courses, two hotels, several lodges and hundreds of time-share residences. To slake its thirst, Mr. Gitter has bought the local water company. And in the process, he has split this normally peaceful town into two angry camps and drawn fire from environmental groups in Albany and even from New York City mayoral candidates. 
To some, the resort is a godsend that could jump-start the depressed economy of this quiet hideaway in Ulster County, about 125 miles northwest of Manhattan. Others warn that it will mar the landscape and contaminate the nearby reservoirs that supply most of New York City's drinking water.
At the very least, the project is expected to pose the biggest test yet for the fragile agreement the city and state reached with upstate communities four years ago to keep the reservoirs clean. Under that agreement, the city gives towns in the watershed money to promote economic development, and the towns in return have dropped their long resistance to water-protection efforts.
The state environmental officials who will soon review the resort proposal face a tricky decision. If they order it scaled back, Mr. Gitter and his allies, who supported the watershed accord, are likely to say they have been betrayed because they believed the pact would encourage projects like theirs. But if the state approves the project, environmentalists warn, water quality will suffer and the federal government could follow through on its threat to force the city to spend billions of dollars on a filtration plant. 
"This project is shaping up as an unavoidable test of the state's commitment to watershed protection," said Eric Goldstein, a lawyer for the Natural Resources Defense Council, who has included the resort project on a list of issues to raise with New York City mayoral candidates. Already, two of those candidates, City Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone and Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi, have spoken out against the plan.
Reviving tourism has long been a preoccupation in the Catskills, where flashy resorts drew tens of thousands of visitors each year until the 1960's. A number of major developments have been proposed in recent years, including plans for a $500 million hotel and conference center at the former Concord Hotel, south of the Catskill Park in Kiamesha Lake.
But in the park, "nothing proposed or discussed is anywhere near the scale and scope of this proposed development," said James M. Tierney, an assistant state attorney general who serves as the inspector general for the city's watershed.
Before publicizing their proposal in late 1999, Mr. Gitter and his partners acquired 2,000 acres for the complex, to be called the Belleayre Resort, after the mountain where it would surround the small, state-run Belleayre Mountain Ski Center. They will soon submit a detailed plan to the State Department of Environmental Conservation, which will then seek public comment and make a decision.
Although about three-quarters of the land would remain undeveloped except for nature trails, opponents say the plan could endanger two of New York City's most important reservoirs with pesticides and soil erosion from the golf course, along with runoff from new roads and traffic and development fostered by the resort.
Any project this large is bound to stir opposition. But Mr. Gitter's flamboyant style has provoked a special rancor among many of the year-round residents and summer people who chose Shandaken (pronounced shan-DAKE-in) for its remoteness and tranquillity.
"This is the most controversial thing a sleepy town like this has ever seen," said the town supervisor, Wayne Guttman. "And Mr. Gitter's personality does get involved."
The developer, who began his business career by recording the folk-music legend Odetta's first major album in the late 1950's and went on to earn an M.B.A. at Harvard, clearly has big dreams. A decade ago, he tried to build a $500 million cultural theme park and trade center near Baltimore with the help of the former Democratic presidential candidate Paul Tsongas and a $23 million investment from the Chinese government, but the project foundered, in part because of local opposition. 
Mr. Gitter, 65, moved here from Boston in 1971 to be with his guru, Rudrananda, known locally as Rudy, who ran an ashram here. Mr. Gitter still follows Rudy's teachings and maintains a small outdoor shrine to the guru's memory. From the silo at Catskill Corners, a painted pair of Buddha eyes stare out at the mountains. 
But Mr. Gitter's spiritual talk conceals a ruthless businessman, said Peter DiModica, an opponent of the project who runs an antiques shop. Opponents have accused the developer of getting town and county officials to help him gain control of one hamlet's water supply to use for his resort.
Mr. Gitter dismisses those accusations as a ploy to kill his project, which he calls "a civic-minded effort to do good. I have been painted into a posture of villainy," he said during an interview at the Emerson Inn, a $7 million venture that is his largest successful project so far. 
He conceded that the $300 million Belleayre resort would be a quantum leap for him, and said he might sell the project to a larger company with more experience in resort management.
The project's goal, he said, is simply to restore the area's tourist economy -- "to get people sitting around the kitchen table in Long Island or New Jersey to say, 'Let's go to the Catskills.' "
Mr. Gitter said his critics exaggerate the resort's environmental impact and ignore the glaring need for jobs in a town where he says "every single child who graduates from the regional high school gets a diploma and a bus ticket." 
The state owns most of the land in Shandaken as part of the Catskill Park, and New York City has been buying land for several years in an effort to protect the city's watershed, shrinking the amount of taxable land and forcing residents to shoulder an ever-higher portion of the tax burden.
"The fact is that more people favor this project than oppose it, and it's going to be good for the area," said Robert Linge, the owner of the Cold Spring Lodge here. He added that 170 business owners in Shandaken and neighboring towns signed a petition supporting the resort proposal last year. 
The resort would create 350 full-time jobs, Mr. Gitter said. It would contribute about $80 million a year to the local economy and add about $100 million to the tax base, said Eric Griesser, the town assessor and a supporter.
Opponents counter that most of the new jobs would be low-paying and seasonal, and that the increase in the tax base would not compensate for the added services and roads the town would have to supply. Above all, they say, the project is totally out of character with the region's unspoiled mountain scenery.
"He's offering a theme-park vision that threatens our most precious resource -- virgin wilderness," said Adam Nagy, co-chairman of the Catskills Heritage Alliance, formed in 1999 to oppose the resort.
But for many here, a bigger concern is Mr. Gitter's purchase and management of the water system that serves the hamlet of Pine Hill, within the Town of Shandaken. He bought the system in March 2000, just as the town appeared close to a deal to buy it from a private owner and shortly after state officials informed his lawyers that the availability of drinkable water would be a crucial element in the resort's environmental review.
A number of local residents and officials, including the area's representative in Congress, Maurice D. Hinchey, have raised questions about how Mr. Gitter acquired the company and have pressured him to sell it to the town. But he has insisted on keeping part of it for his resort -- a stance that infuriates many residents, who say they will be left without an adequate water supply.
"This is unheard of, it's very unethical," said Margaret Loyd, a former mayor of Pine Hill.
Mr. Gitter said private polls he commissioned showed that people in Shandaken and neighboring Middletown supported his proposal. But Mr. Guttman, the town supervisor, said a survey the town conducted last year showed that most residents did not want any resort in Shandaken.
He recalled a conversation several years ago, when Mr. Gitter was planning another development that did not succeed.
"Listen -- what do you hear?" he recalls asking the developer as they stood outdoors. 
"I don't hear anything," Mr. Gitter said.
"That's just it," Mr. Guttman told him. "It's quiet, and that's the way people here like it."

HEADLINE: Jobs, and a City's Revival, Suffer in a Factory's Blaze 

BYLINE:  By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD 

DATELINE: ANSONIA, Conn., May 15 

 BODY:
The Latex Foam Products plant here churned out tens of thousands of pillows, foam mattresses and cosmetic sponge pads every year, a world leader in the pillow industry and a source of pride -- and jobs -- for this struggling blue-collar city.
 "The largest manufacturer of pillows -- it allowed us to lay claim to something," said Claude Perry, the city's economic development officer and, as a resident for 40 years, an observer of the cycles of boom and bust that have visited the Naugatuck River Valley. 
 Today, the factory was a smoldering pile of twisted metal, ash and collapsed brick walls, after a fire on Monday that drove the city's more than 100 volunteer firefighters to exhaustion and rained debris -- some of it containing asbestos -- on neighborhoods downwind from the downtown plant. Most of Latex Foam's 240 employees are out of work, and the Valley, which had shown signs of revival, has suffered a setback. 
"We were just starting to turn a corner," said James T. Della Volpe, the mayor of this city of nearly 19,000 people about 10 miles west of New Haven. In the last few years new stores, a new high school and new businesses moving into vacant factories offered hope for a recovery after years of factory closings in the area. "This is just a major blow," the mayor said.
The plants that studded the valley were once seen as an extension of family, with generations of relatives employed by the same company. Today, community life revolves more around churches and high school sports, particularly football. (The mayor is a former football coach at Ansonia High School.) 
There is not enough manufacturing work left, officials said, to absorb Latex's employees. Many are expected to go on unemployment or seek retraining for other jobs, city officials said.
The fire has left workers like Carmen Gonzalez, 35, in a daze, wondering how she will feed her four children and pay the rent on the apartment they just moved into. 
"I'm not feeling well about this," Ms. Gonzalez said, as she watched smoke drift over the rubble this afternoon as firefighters doused the last of the flames and bulldozers began cleaning up. "I cried all night. Every time I close my eyes, I see the whole thing."
Officials have not determined the cause of the fire, which was fought by firefighters from 12 towns.
Officials with the State Department of Environmental Protection said some debris from the fire contained asbestos, though they said a health risk is usually posed only to those who inhale high levels of the fibers over long periods of time. Still, the agency advised residents to wear gloves and wet any suspicious material before throwing it away, so that fibers do not become airborne. Residents should call the City Health Department to remove any large pieces, officials said.
As Latex Foam officials walked the factory site today, the charred ruins brought to mind the company's origins in a devastating fire a quarter-century ago.
Latex Foam was founded by former workers of the Sponge Rubber Products Company, whose plant at a former tire factory in nearby Shelton exploded and burned in 1975 in what the F.B.I. said at the time was the nation's largest arson case. Eight people were convicted.
The new company, Latex, moved to Ansonia in 1984, occupying a 10-acre riverfront site and, said Peter C. F. DeMarco, the chief operating officer, enjoying good times. It is the only maker of latex mattresses and pillows in North America, Mr. DeMarco said, and is the world's largest producer of latex pillows and cosmetic sponges.
The company had sales of about $50 million last year, he said, and recently signed contracts with Sealy, the mattress company, to supply foam bedding for a new product.
"The company was about to take off," Mr. DeMarco said, adding that its officers would not decide whether to rebuild until discussing its finances with insurers. He said all but about 20 administrative employees would be immediately furloughed.
The city is bracing for the inevitable ripple effect when one of its largest employers closes.
Paul Ciocco, co-owner of Eddy's Bake Shop, a block from the plant, relied on the steady stream of Latex employees.
"That's a lot of people that it brings down here and there really is nobody else," said Mr. Ciocco, whose family has owned the bakery for about 40 years. Mr. Ciocco said he was considering cutting back his staff of 20 part-time and full-time workers. "You've got to survive one way or another," he said.
But Judy Armstrong, who has lived in Ansonia for more than 30 years, showed the grit that many said is a local trademark.
"We're a small town," she said, "but we'll come back."

HEADLINE: LESSONS; 
Weighing Students' Skills And Underlying Attitudes

BYLINE:  By Richard Rothstein; E-mail: rrothstein@nytimes.com

 BODY:
AMERICANS' low math and science scores are well known. On the 1999 international math and science survey, our eighth graders scored below their peers in almost every other industrial nation that took part.
 Students in Japan and Korea ranked near the top. In math, average American eighth graders would have scored below the 25th percentile in Japan or Korea. 
 But the study also asked students if they liked math and science, thought it important and would want a job using these skills. Here, Japanese and Koreans scored at the very bottom. Only 9 percent of their eighth graders had positive attitudes toward math; only 10 percent felt positively about science.
In the United States, 35 percent felt positively about math and 32 percent about science, more than in almost every other industrial nation.
For 20 years, Americans have tried to remake schools, partly to be more like high-scoring East Asians. A Reagan administration report, "A Nation at Risk," warned in 1983 that America would soon lose its competitive edge to countries with superior schools, like Japan and Korea. Since then, our graduation requirements have been raised, testing has been increased, with severe penalties for failure, and instructional time has grown.
Meanwhile, schools in Japan and Korea have been trying to copy ours. Across East Asia, leaders are trying to reform education so students will know fewer facts and spend less time preparing for tests but, like Americans, be more willing to take risks and more creative in applying what they know.
The Japanese and Koreans also believe that economic survival demands education reform. Jaekyung Lee, a University of Maine professor who studies schools in his native Korea, said Korean employers realized that disciplined and highly skilled workers were not what they needed most. Instead, companies had to develop new products for new markets, and for that, workers unafraid to question authority or take initiative were essential.
A Korean presidential commission in 1994 demanded reform, much like President Ronald Reagan's group a decade before. The Korean commission proposed a de-emphasis of testing, more electives that depart from standardized curriculums and college admissions based more on recommendations and overall high school records than on standardized tests.
In Japan, too, policy makers are trying to relax standards. Recently, the government required new textbooks to reduce content by 30 percent so study time could be cut to encourage nonacademic leisure. And Saturday school has been dropped. Officials hope that with less textbook material to cover, teachers will encourage more student inquiry and initiative.
Teiichi Sato, director of the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science and a former deputy minister of education, argues that the 21st-century economy requires such reforms. He says Japanese education, emphasizing obedience and standards, is ill-suited to help students adapt easily to the rapid change that characterizes the new economy.
Japanese reform, Mr. Sato said in a recent speech, should inspire "zest for living," a trait he thinks characteristic of Americans but not of his own students. He defined it as "development of abilities to uncover issues, to study and think alone, reach judgments independently and to act and solve problems well."
Japanese officials, Mr. Sato said, no longer attach great importance to students' high rankings on international tests because the exams measure skills valued by the old education system, not the new. A zest for living cannot develop, he added, "under the former style of education in which students simply acquired as much knowledge as possible."
In Korea, as in the United States, the biggest bar to reform is poor teacher training. Dr. Lee said it was hard for Koreans to teach differently from the way they were trained. Many only know how to dictate information for students to memorize. Teachers have not been equipped to show students how to question, try different ways of solving problems or make informed guesses about the unknown.
None of this means American school reform is misguided. Americans may have veered too far from high standards, just as East Asians veered too far from developing the inquisitive boldness they now find lacking. But it is also too mechanistic to conclude simply that the ideal is halfway between these extremes.
The apparently inverse relationship between these nations' rankings on skills and their rankings on love of math and science should certainly be a warning. Can American schools inch up the skills scale without sacrificing their place on the attitudinal scale? Nobody knows which may ultimately prove more important.

HEADLINE: CITING DOWNTURN, FED LOWERS RATES 5TH TIME THIS YEAR 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 15 

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve continued its campaign to reinvigorate the weakened economy today, cutting its benchmark interest rate half a percentage point for the fifth time this year.
 Suggesting that the worst of the slowdown may still not be past, the Fed said its decision was primarily driven by the deteriorating outlook for businesses, which have been cutting investments in new plants and equipment in the face of declining profits. 
 Today's action reduced the federal funds rate on overnight loans among banks to 4 percent, from 4.5 percent. 
The decision brought the total reduction since the Fed began cutting rates in January to 2.5 percentage points, making this one of the most concentrated efforts it has ever undertaken to reignite economic growth. And the central bank, dismissing any concern that inflation might become a threat, hinted that it was likely to ease monetary policy further at its next scheduled meeting in late June. 
After fretting for several days that the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, and his colleagues might limit their rate cut to a quarter percentage point, Wall Street bid up stock prices after the announcement at 2:15 p.m. But prices then fell back and finished flat.
The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 4.36 points, to 10,872.97; the Nasdaq composite index rose 3.66 points, to 2,085.58. Page C1. 
The Fed's action was intended to put downward pressure on borrowing costs throughout the economy, making it more affordable for consumers to buy a car or a new refrigerator as well as providing them with some assurance that their own financial situation would not worsen.
That process was under way within minutes, when banks began lowering their prime lending rates to 7 percent from 7.5 percent, a step that most directly affects small-business borrowers but also helps consumers who have certain types of credit cards, auto loans and adjustable mortgages.
Ultimately, the cumulative reductions in the short-term rates controlled by the Fed should have some impact on a variety of loans. But they will have only an indirect effect on the biggest borrowing expense for most people -- mortgages.
Mortgage rates are determined primarily by the bond market's assessment of the long-term economic outlook. And despite the cuts in short-term rates engineered by the Fed this year, mortgage rates have been more or less steady since January, reflecting a calculation by bond traders that any improvement in economic growth prospects could be offset by the risk of inflation.
Today's move came against the backdrop of an economy that appeared to have dipped into a zone of tepid growth just short of recession.
Retail sales rose in April, and consumer confidence stabilized, suggesting that consumer spending, the chief bulwark of the economy, was weathering the slowdown. Companies made progress in bringing their backlogs of unsold goods and supplies into line with reduced demand. The stock market stabilized.
But the economy lost 223,000 jobs in April, the biggest downturn in more than a decade, and the unemployment rate rose to 4.5 percent from 4.3 percent. Industrial production fell again last month.
And most worrying to many analysts, businesses continued to reduce investment spending plans. In doing so, they dragged down a segment of the economy that had been a leading engine of growth and raised questions about whether gains in productivity, the most fundamental measure of the economy's long-term potential, could be sustained.
"The erosion in current and prospective profitability, in combination with considerable uncertainty about the business outlook, seems likely to hold down capital spending going forward," the Fed's policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee said in a statement. "This potential restraint, together with the possible effects of earlier reductions in equity wealth on consumption and the risk of slower growth abroad, continues to weigh on the economy."
The federal funds rate -- the Fed's principal short-term rate -- has not been as low as 4 percent in almost seven years, when the central bank finished its campaign to turn around the economy after the recession of 1990-91. The Fed also cut its discount rate on loans to banks from the Federal Reserve by half a point, to 3.5 percent from 4 percent.
The Fed gave no signal that it saw a need to cut rates again before its next scheduled meeting on June 26-27 but left little doubt that a reduction of at least another quarter-point would be on the agenda.
The Fed emphasized that "inflation is expected to remain contained," an indication that it felt it still had plenty of leeway to cut rates.
And it held to its policy bias toward further rate reductions, concluding that "the risks are weighted mainly toward conditions that may generate economic weakness in the foreseeable future."
Some economists said the Fed had reached a point where it needed to let its interest rate medicine do its work before administering another dose.
Not only does it take at least six months or so for a reduction in short-term rates to ripple through the financial system and into the economy, but Congress and the Bush administration are also working on a tax-cutting plan that would provide some additional stimulus later this year and into next year.
Some economists said they were surprised that the Fed was not more concerned about inflation, given that by most measures price increases accelerated this year. 
They also suggested that further cuts in interest rates might not have the desired effect on capital spending.
While lower interest rates clearly provide a boost to consumers and to interest-sensitive sectors of the economy like housing, they are believed to have only a limited impact on decisions by a business about whether to modernize a factory or upgrade a computer system. Those decisions tend to be driven more by calculations of potential profit and how much capacity is needed to meet expected demand than by the cost of borrowing money.
"The Fed did note that consumption is healthy, that housing is healthy and that inventory adjustment is rapid," said Mickey D. Levy, chief economist at Bank of America. "Obviously they are concerned about capital spending, which is a legitimate concern. But they can't do anything about it. And what really jumps out is that the Fed says inflation is contained, and it's not."
The Fed also sounded another optimistic note that was questioned by some analysts. Reflecting the view of Mr. Greenspan that huge investments in technology were making the economy fundamentally more efficient, the statement asserted that the underlying trend of improvement in productivity growth "appears to be largely intact, supporting longer-term prospects."
Improvements in productivity, or output per hour, mean that companies can pay higher wages or absorb cost increases without passing them along to their customers.
But productivity growth stalled in the first quarter. Economists said that if capital spending remained weak, productivity growth would remain muted.
David Orr, chief economist at First Union, said Mr. Greenspan seemed to have weighed the risk of fueling inflation and allowing productivity growth to ebb and favored promoting productivity growth by jump-starting the stalled expansion.
Mr. Greenspan "believes the path to containing inflation is through productivity," Mr Orr said, "and in order to assure its continued progress, growth and profits are the key."

HEADLINE: California Panel Spells Out Rise in Rates for Electricity 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, May 15 

 BODY:
Seven weeks after approving the biggest electric rate increase in California history, state power regulators decided today how to spread the pain, raising rates for the biggest residential users by an average of $85 a month.
 More than half of the residential ratepayers served by the state's two largest utilities will see no increase at all in their rates. But for those who consume the most, the new rates would mean an increase of up to 80 percent. 
 The plan, approved 3 to 2 by the State Public Utilities Commission, affects about nine million customers of the state's two largest utilities, the Pacific Gas and Electric Company and the Southern California Edison Company. 
The new rates, which will appear on June bills, fill out the details of a $5 billion rate increase that the commission approved in late March in an effort to provide financial relief to the state's utility companies. Today's vote came after a week of intense lobbying by industrial, commercial, agricultural and residential groups -- all trying to influence how the commission would allocate the rate increases.
The average rate increase for all residential customers of the two utilities is 19 percent. But low-income ratepayers and those who use the least electricity will face no rate increase at all.
Residential ratepayers are divided into five tiers, and those in PG&E's top tier -- about 9 percent of that utility's residential customers -- will see electric rates jump to 25.8 cents per kilowatt-hour from 14.3 cents, an 80 percent increase. That translates into an average monthly increase of $85, from $232 to $317.
For Edison's heaviest residential users, the rate increase is 71 percent, or an average increase from $194 to $265 on monthly bills.
Industrial customers of PG&E and Edison face rate increases of about 50 percent, while commercial and agricultural ratepayers will see less significant increases. The increases, which will begin appearing on June bills, will be retroactive to March 27, the day the overall rate increase was approved.
"This is probably the worst economic calamity the state has ever seen," said David Marshall, chief financial officer at Gregg Industries, a 400-person iron foundry in El Monte. "It has got ramifications well beyond anything that we can begin to understand."
Today's vote took place amid the jeers of protesters, who wore tombstone-shaped placards that read, "R.I.P. Affordable Energy."
Commissioner Jeff Brown bellowed back at the protesters: "We cannot walk away from it. We cannot pretend that this is some sort of problem that we can walk away from."
The rate plan approved today was a revision of the plan released by the commission president, Loretta Lynch, last week. Ms. Lynch reworked her plan after a huge outcry from businesses proclaiming that the proposed rate increases would doom California's economy and a critical statement from Gov. Gray Davis. 
Customers of the San Diego Gas and Electric Company and those who buy electricity directly from energy wholesalers like the California university system, are shielded from rate increases.
 --------------------

State's Credit Downgraded
 SACRAMENTO, May 15, (AP) -- A second major credit rating agency has downgraded California's credit, pointing to the energy crisis' increasing drain on the state's finances.
Moody's Investors Service lowered its rating on $19.8 billion in state general obligation bonds from Aa3 to Aa2. The agency also lowered the rating on $5.7 billion in lease revenue bonds from Aa3 to A1.
Last month, Standard & Poors downgraded California's credit and put the state almost at the bottom of its ranking of creditworthiness.
Credit ratings help determine how much states and other borrowers must pay when issuing bonds. The lower the rating, the higher the interest rate the state must pay to attract investors.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
EGL, A GLOBAL FREIGHTCOMPANY, TO LAY OFF 950 WORKERS

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
 EGL Inc., an international freight company whose customers have been hurt by a slow economy, is cutting its United States work force about 15 percent to help trim $30 million in annual costs after an unexpected first-quarter loss. EGL, based in Houston, dismissed more than 450 employees through May 5 and plans to cut 400 more full-time workers, mostly in the United States, the company said. 
EGL employs more than 5,000 people in the United States and 9,000 worldwide and is trimming jobs through layoffs and attrition, a spokeswoman, Heather Fedele, said. EGL said its first-quarter loss was $9.1 million, or 19 cents a share, in contrast to net income of $8.5 million, or 18 cents, a year earlier. EGL expects to save $20 million a year from the job cuts and $10 million from other cost-cutting moves, which include consolidating offices.

HEADLINE: Brown Lungs, Lost Fingers; Now, a Lost Mill 

BYLINE:  By RICK BRAGG 

DATELINE: JACKSONVILLE, Ala., May 11 

 BODY:
When it was running wide open, when its workers fed truckloads of 500-pound bales of cotton into its gigantic machines, the mill almost seemed to come alive. It roared, the scarred wooden floors trembled and popped, and tiny scraps of cotton swirled like gnats in the vast, windowless rooms.
 Like something alive, the cotton mill bit and clawed at the people who fed it, and workers who were careless for a split second lost fingers, hands and arms in machines designed to shred and tear. 
 Others, over decades, breathed in so much of the cotton fiber that it ruined their lungs, leaving them wheezing for air in identical mill village houses, or waving from wheelchairs parked on porches in the countryside.
But generations of men and women still lined up to serve the mill, many of them quitting school to take their places beside its machines. "It ain't when it's running that's scary," said Sonny Parker, who is 51 and has worked in cotton mills since he was 16. "It's when it ain't." 
In a blue-collar land where welfare is a dirty word and leaving these green foothills and ancestral graves is as unthinkable as a rocket-ship ride to another world, the Union Yarn Mill in Jacksonville has, for 95 years, offered the workers not only a living but an anchor.
The mill's paychecks financed homes, swing sets and Pontiacs, and made it possible for workers to live in a place where bank tellers ask about their mothers' blood pressure, convenience stores collect money in jars for sick children's doctor bills, and old men still hang dead snakes from the trees to make it rain. And inside the red-brick mill, the machines ran on and on, as if they would never stop.
On May 13, the last of a century's cotton will be processed into yarn and trucked away, the teeth of the giant machines will gnash at workers one last time, and the roar will fade to silence, forever.
Then, the Union Yarn Mill will move the machines to other plants in other towns, 197 men and women will lose their jobs, and a way of life will vanish here, with the closing of a gate.
"I quit school when I was 16, and Mama said either go back to school or go to work," said Smiley Sams, now 43. "My mama worked here. I got nine brothers and sisters, and all but one worked here. I got on Sept. 20, 1974. I don't know nothing else. I've never even filled out an application.
"This is all I've ever done."
It is not just work. It is as if the blood these people shed at their machines, and the fibers they ingested over time -- "eatin' cotton," they call it, with a smile -- have made this mill a part of them and them a part of it, all mixed together, metal, cotton, flesh and bone.
Billy Beal, who is 39 and has worked here for 15 years, lost part of the middle finger on his right hand in the mill, in 1987. "I was out three days, then I was back, running machines," Mr. Beal said.
He earns $11.92 an hour, has reared two children and paid off a house. He misses the end of his finger ("You'd be surprised how much you need that thing," he said), but he is not sure that he would give up 15 years of good money, 15 years of the friendships of people he considers family, for a 10-fingered life someplace else.
"Now," Mr. Beal said, "there's people who will lose everything."
The last week of production has dragged by like a funeral procession here in Jacksonville, a city of 10,000 people. Their mill will not close all at once, but is closing a room at a time, changing the very timbre of the place.
"It just don't sound right," said Randall Johnson, whom everybody calls Possum. "It's always been dangerous, hot, hard and nasty."
Alice Allen's husband, Jimmy, had a heart attack after he heard the news of the closing in March, but he is back at work. Every paycheck is crucial now.
In a company store, where the mill's name-brand clothing sold in a clearance sale for 75 percent off, mill workers bought double armloads of T-shirts and underwear, saying they would put them away and give them out at Christmas if they still did not have work. Then, some of them went to stand by themselves, to cry.

Found Cash Returned
Sonny Parker recently found a purse lying open in the parking lot of one of Jacksonville's grocery stores. "It had a big wad of cash money in it," Mr. Parker said. "Cash. Never seen so much money. Here I am, about to be without a job, can't get no job."
He stood over it a moment, he said, then turned it in at the store.
"I didn't earn it," Mr. Parker said, "so it wasn't mine."
For the mill workers, it is not a matter of searching for comparable work in a nearby town.
"There are skeletons all over Alabama," said Harvey Jackson, head of the history department at Jacksonville State University, just a few blocks from the mill.
The good-paying textile jobs that built many of the towns in the industrial South have been vanishing for decades, as manufacturers improve profits by moving to countries where labor is cheaper. The North American Free Trade Agreement, passed early in the Clinton administration, was a death knell for working people like the millers in Jacksonville.
For years, they feared it, surviving slowdowns and short time and temporary layoffs, bringing home as much as $14 an hour when they did work.
"People came to work sick, people gave their all to keep it open, to keep up production," said Mrs. Allen, who is 54 and has worked at the plant 22 years. "They thought that was their protection."
Fruit of the Loom, which operates the mill, has been in Chapter 11 since December. In March, it announced that it had found an overproduction of yarn and textiles and decided to close the Jacksonville mill.
"An awful lot of pain and suffering," said Wayne Flynt, a distinguished professor of history at Auburn University. "These are proud people. They will not want to be on welfare."
Brenda Bryant, 48, and her husband, Victor, 48, worked at the mill. They are selling their house, to keep the bank from taking it.
The word retraining is tossed around. But the hard facts are that not everyone will become a computer programmer or a real estate agent or get a job at the Honda plant being built in Lincoln, about 30 miles away. "A lot of them won't have the education for it," Professor Flynt said.
Some of them will have to leave, and that cuts worse than any machine. Randall Johnson, 30, said he would study to become a mechanic. But in a local economy glutted with laid-off blue-collar workers, Mr. Johnson is afraid he will have to leave to find work to support his wife and children. "I just want to stay," he said.
The mill has faded in its significance here -- Jacksonville State is the biggest employer -- but in a town where most of the mill workers are second- and even third-generation employees, the mill will always be the center of their existence. These are not people who long to escape from their hometown, but people who hunt, fish, fight, pray and like it here. And sometimes, when they walk out their doors, every stitch of clothing on their bodies is labeled "Fruit of the Loom."

Blessings and Curses
 Mill workers wondered what happened to Leon Spears after he got brown lung, the illness brought on by inhaling cotton fibers.
Mr. Spears retired from the mill after 19 years, when his breathing got so bad he could not work, and vanished to his sick bed. Then, one day last week, the 62-year-old Mr. Spears reappeared on his porch, in a wheelchair, feeling the sun on his face.
"I do pretty good, now, thank the good Lord," he said, but his hand, the one holding his inhaler, shook gently.
To him, the mill was a living, but no blessing.
"It put a lot of bread on the table," he said, "but in the long run, you pay for every piece of it."
The mill opened in 1906, and from the beginning people thanked God for it, then cursed it in the next breath.
Many of its first workers weighed in their last cotton sacks in the field and, the next day, took a job at the mill. It was brutally hot in summer, louder than anything they had ever heard, and safety was an afterthought.
But it was easier than dragging a pick sack along cotton rows without end, so they stuffed wads of cotton in their ears, and endured.
"My granddad lost all his fingers off his left hand, but not his thumb," said Linda Spears, Leon's wife.
Conditions and pay were so bad in the 1940's that the workers hanged the mill's superintendent, W. I. Greenleaf, but only in effigy.
As decades slipped by, conditions improved -- not that it was ever safe, ever easy. But it was always there. 
Debbie Glenn, 48, grew up surrounded by cotton, playing in her daddy's fields. She started at the mill when she was 19.
"You could get a job, if you wanted it," Ms. Glenn said. "I like to work. I got to stay at home. The people I worked with became closer to me than my own family."
Ms. Glenn's job on the machines played out this week, so she went to work in the company store. All day she smiled and chatted with people who came through not only to buy T-shirts but to talk about the mill's history and their connections to it. She smiled at all of them. She is one of those people who smiles all the time, even now.
"Her heart's broke, ain't it," said an elderly woman with a fist full of T-shirts.
"Uh-huh," another old woman said.

New Pontiac
Sonny Parker is a cotton miller because, when he was 16, he wanted a car.
"And there wasn't nobody else going to buy me one," he said.
Thirty-five years later, Mr. Parker lives in a little wood-frame house, which is paid for, and drives a 1983 Chevrolet pickup, which is paid for, too. "My kids never did without nothing," he said.
Others at the mill will lose their houses, he predicts, because their notes are too high to be met by minimum-wage jobs. They will lose cars, bought after mill officials promised them, just a few months before announcing the closing, that their jobs were safe.
The bosses did that, Mr. Parker said, because they knew the millers would work harder if there was hope, as they always have.
He and his wife, Theresa, who is also a mill worker, had just bought a like-new Pontiac Grand Prix, in gleaming red. He wanted to do something nice for his wife. She has brown lung.
"Look at us," Mr. Parker told her, then. "I got you something real nice. We can go anywhere in the world, in that." Or, most likely, they would just drive around town.
Now, they are both looking for work, wondering what they will keep, and lose. As he walked through a quiet room in the mill this week, he wished for the banging of metal, the whirring of gears, for the roar.
All he heard was his own footsteps.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 26, 2001

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article on May 16 about the closing of the Union Yarn Mill in Jacksonville, Ala., misstated the year that its operator, Fruit of the Loom, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. It was December 1999, not 2000.

HEADLINE: Building Up Central Europe on a Western Base 

BYLINE:  By PETER S. GREEN 

DATELINE: WARSAW 

 BODY:
Business is good these days, says Eric Rosedale, an American real estate lawyer in Warsaw, as he gives a tour of the many cranes, skyscrapers and empty lots visible from his 20th-floor office at Weil, Gotshal & Manges.
 "This is Saski Park, developed by AIG/Lincoln," a partnership of American International Group, the insurance and financial services concern based in New York, and the Dallas-based Lincoln Property Company, Mr. Rosedale said. "This building is being developed by Golub-Europe," an affiliate of Golub & Company, Chicago-based developers, and GE Capital. 
 A deep breath, then the list continues. Behind a new building for an insurance company is the Atrium business center, a complex developed by Skanska of Sweden. "And the main railway station is going to be replaced by the Zlota Center, a half-billion-dollar development by ING Real Estate" of the Netherlands, Mr. Rosedale said, before moving across the building for still more of the tour.
Poland, like much of Central Europe, is experiencing a building boom led largely by American and Western European real estate developers and investors. Along with Hungary and the Czech Republic, Poland expects to join the European Union sometime this decade.
Experts estimate that 90 percent of the commercial construction in Central Europe is financed by foreign developers. In Poland alone, foreign companies invested $2.5 billion in construction last year.
"We are looking at where are the places that are growing, and certainly Central Europe is going to be growing," said Michael Spies, senior managing director for Europe at Tishman Speyer Properties. Tishman Speyer, based in New York, is developing a one-million-square-foot complex of shopping, offices, hotels and housing in Krakow.
The Polimeni Organization, a developer based in Garden City, N.Y., has begun work on a $15 million, 200,000-square-foot shopping mall on the edge of Konin, a city of 83,000 people 120 miles west of Warsaw. It is expected to open later this year.
Philip Okun, president of Polimeni's international unit, said that unlike mall-saturated Long Island, Polimeni's home base, Poland has ample room for shopping centers.
"We came here and we flipped -- we couldn't believe the opportunities," Mr. Okun said. "There are plenty of cities with enormous potential. Poland is under-retailed."
Poland and its Central European neighbors are also under-officed, under-warehoused and under-residentialed, developers say. And on the larger construction projects, American and Western European developers have an edge: access to big money.
Seven Western-style megamalls have gone up in Prague the last four years, and two more are under construction, each anchored by a hypermarket. Most of the stores are foreign-owned chains, like Tesco of Britain and Royal Ahold of the Netherlands, and the developers are American or Western European.
With such an appetite for modern space, developers say their Central European projects yield a profit margin higher -- by two or three percentage points -- than that of similar projects in the United States.
Western developers also have a network of mainly Western-owned real estate agents and construction firms experienced in building to international standards. They say corruption and red tape in Central Europe are no worse than in most Western cities.
Local concerns have learned how to put up buildings on time and on budget, said Rob McLean, editor of Construction Journal, a Prague-based trade publication, "but in the modern sense of putting deals together, assembling financing, there was no expertise." That is where Western developers with a track record of success have the edge.
Among those helping with the bills is Lehman Brothers. The firm -- with Jones Lang LaSalle, a Chicago real estate services and investment management concern, and the giant construction concern Bouygues of France -- is a sponsor of the $400 million Central European Retail Property Fund, which acquires and develops large shopping malls in the region, $100 million projects of 440,000 to 660,000 square feet each. It is also about to close a $4 billion fund that will probably put part of its money into Central Europe, said Michael Capaccio, an executive director at Lehman.
Even after five years of the building boom, "there is no question there will be a sustained demand for well-thought-out retail," he said.
But for office space, the picture is not quite so rosy. In Warsaw, for instance, office space of 4.9 million square feet is under construction, half of it built speculatively and a fifth of it is unleased, said Darren Battle, Jones Lang's national director for Poland. The vacancy rate, he said, is among the highest in any European capital.
Prime office rents in the city center here fell 12.5 percent last year, to $31.20 to $33.60 a square foot annually, according to Mr. Battle, about the same as the average rate in Berlin.
"We are becoming a mature market with development cycles of overbuild, underbuild and institutional investors buying in," said Brian D. Patterson, managing partner at AIG/Lincoln Polska.
Still, developers and other real estate insiders say, any downturn in the demand for modern commercial space is temporary. In fact, Mr. Battle's research shows that a record number of new leases were signed in Prague, Warsaw and Bucharest, Romania, last year.
"The Warsaw office market is 1.4 million square meters," he said. "In the great scheme of things, that's nothing. But, two years ago it was 700,000 square meters." (A square meter is about 10.75 square feet.)
"Disposable income is forecast to grow," he added, "so in terms of opportunities for commercial property, we are nowhere near where we should be in terms of space."

HEADLINE: Wal-Mart and Home Depot Report Increases in Earnings 

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Wal-Mart Stores Inc. and Home Depot Inc. said yesterday that their first-quarter earnings rose as they kept a lid on costs and lured shoppers with low prices to weather the slowing economy. The J. C. Penney Company swung to a profit after posting a loss in the quarter a year earlier.
 Wal-Mart's earnings rose 4.1 percent, the smallest first-quarter gain in five years. Home Depot, whose profit was forecast to decline, eked out an increase of less than 1 percent. 
 Job reductions, rising energy prices and the slowing economy prompted merchants to contain expenses and sent shoppers looking for bargains on everything from clothes and household goods to home-improvement supplies. 
"Consumer spending appears to be stabilizing at its current levels," Wal-Mart's chief executive, Lee Scott, said in a conference call. "However, hopes for future improvement need to be tempered because of continued layoffs, high gasoline prices and increased utility costs."
Wal-Mart's net income in the quarter ended April 30 rose to $1.38 billion, or 31 cents a share, compared with $1.33 billion, or 30 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. The results matched analysts' estimates, according to Thomson Financial/First Call. Sales rose 12 percent, to $48.1 billion.
The company, based in Bentonville, Ark., said earnings would rise in the second quarter by about the same pace as in the first quarter and return to a double-digit percentage rate in the second half.
Shares of Wal-Mart fell $2.35, to $52. The company's board increased a stock buyback plan by $1 billion, to a total of $3 billion. Wal-Mart has repurchased $300 million of stock under the first plan, leaving $2.7 billion available for repurchases.
Home Depot's net income in the quarter ended April 30 rose to $632 million, or 27 cents a share, compared with $629 million, or 27 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. Sales rose 9.8 percent, to $12.2 billion. Analysts had expected the company to earn 25 cents a share, according to First Call.
Profit growth was curbed by lower lumber prices and unusually cool March weather that kept consumers from buying lawn mowers and other outdoor products.
Robert L. Nardelli, who was hired as the company's chief executive in December, has scaled back store openings and focused on customer service and reducing expenses. Home Depot, based in Atlanta, said it would meet analysts' profit forecasts of 37 cents a share in the second quarter.
Shares of Home Depot rose 95 cents, to $50.10.
J. C. Penney had net income of $41 million, or 13 cents a share, in contrast to a loss of $118 million, or 48 cents a share, in the period a year earlier.
Sales at department stores open at least a year rose 1.1 percent in the quarter ended April 28, the first gain in nearly two years. A 12 percent decline in catalog revenue lowered total sales to $7.52 billion from $7.53 billion. Shares of J. C. Penney, based in Plano, Tex., fell 86 cents, to $20.19 after it forecast a loss for the second quarter.

HEADLINE: Verizon Will Seek a Rate Increase for Local New York Calls 

BYLINE:  By SIMON ROMERO 

 BODY:
Verizon Communications said yesterday that it would seek approval to raise local phone rates in New York State for the first time in a decade.
 The company wants to raise rates by $1.25 a month for each residential customer, translating into an increase of around 6 percent on the average local bill of $19.93. Verizon, which has grown out of several mergers and takeovers, most recently Bell Atlantic's acquisition of GTE last year, controls about three-fourths of the state's local market. 
 The plan shows how much more consumers have benefited in recent years from competition in the long-distance industry than in the local phone business, which continues to be dominated by a handful of "Baby Bell" carriers. Since AT&T's monopoly was broken up in the 1980's, rates for interstate calls have declined nearly 40 percent while local rates have climbed more than 60 percent, according to the Federal Communications Commission.
Verizon's proposal comes after allegations that service quality in New York is deteriorating, with union representatives claiming that the company regularly falsified service reports to show improved responses. The New York State Public Service Commission asked the company last month to monitor its reporting procedures more closely.
Bob Master, a spokesman for the Communications Workers of America, Verizon's main union, said the increase should not be granted until Verizon "stops lying to state regulators about the quality of its service."
Verizon repeated yesterday that regulators had found no evidence of falsification of reports and said that the rate increase would allow it to improve the quality of basic phone service. The company also said that the increase would provide an additional $100 million in revenue a year, enabling it to make operations in New York more efficient. Verizon's rate of return -- its net revenue divided by its rate base -- is 4 percent in New York, compared with an average of over 10 percent in other states where the company operates.
"I think our customers will understand that the increase we're asking for is much less than the average inflation rate of 2 percent during the last 10 years," said Paul A. Crotty, president of Verizon New York.
Verizon already charges more for basic service in New York than its smaller competitors, according to a study released this month by the Telecommunications Research and Action Center, a nonprofit consumer advocacy group in Washington.
A spokesman for the Public Service Commission said yesterday that interested parties could voice opinions on Verizon's request at hearings later this year. If the commission approves Verizon's plan the increases will take effect in January. They would not affect about 500,000 low-income customers who pay as little as $1 a month for basic service.
On the issue of rate increases, Verizon said yesterday that it had repeatedly reduced residential phone charges in New York in the 1990's.
"It's time to bring New York in line with trends in other parts of the country," Mr. Crotty of Verizon said.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Divergent Lines"After the breakup of AT & T, competition in the long-distance business drove prices down while local phone rates kept pace with inflation. Graph shows the Consumer Price Index for local and interstate calls from 1985 to 2000.(Source: Bureau of Labor Statistics)

HEADLINE: Deere Earnings Miss Quarterly Forecast 

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
Deere & Company, the maker of heavy equipment, reported a weaker-than-expected profit in its most recent quarter yesterday as the slow economy and wet spring weather hurt sales.
 The company, based in Moline, Ill., said it earned $127.8 million, or 54 cents a share, in the quarter ended April 30, its second, down 37 percent from $204.3 million, or 87 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. 
Sales were steady at $3.8 billion. 
 Analysts had expected the company to earn 66 cents a share, according to Thomson Financial/First Call, and shares of Deere fell $2.49, or 6 percent, to $38.52.
The company told analysts on a conference call that it remained on track to introduce about 100 new products through the end of its fiscal year in October. With those additions, it will have updated or refreshed about three-quarters of its products over the last four years.
The company said it expected unit sales in the current quarter to be down about 11 percent from a year ago, with operating margins under significant pressure.

HEADLINE: Delays Possible for Over-the-Counter Allergy Drugs 

BYLINE:  By MELODY PETERSEN 

 BODY:
Allergy sufferers who hope that Claritin will soon be available over the counter may well be waiting for many months, if not years.
 On Friday, a committee of experts advised the Food and Drug Administration that Claritin and two other popular allergy drugs, Allegra and Zyrtec, were safe enough to be made available without a prescription. 
 But it is not clear that the F.D.A. has the authority to force the allergy drug manufacturers -- Schering-Plough, Aventis and Pfizer -- to make the products available over the counter.
And even if the government does order the change, the drug companies are almost certain to fight back in court. In fact, at the end of Friday's meeting, Pfizer delivered a 49-page legal brief to agency officials laying out why such a move would violate the companies' property rights and be illegal. 
The advisory committee review of the status of the drugs was requested by Wellpoint Health Networks, an insurance company. Typically, pharmaceutical companies are the ones that ask for permission to sell their drugs without a prescription.
Analysts watching the case say that it is not clear that the Bush administration will even try to push ahead with a process that began during the Clinton administration. They also say that the F.D.A. is unlikely to make any decision until the White House appoints a new commissioner to lead the agency. The post has been vacant since President Bush took office.
But executives at Wellpoint said yesterday that they would continue to press their case.
Dr. Robert C. Seidman, Wellpoint's chief pharmacy officer, said that he planned to call Dr. Janet Woodcock, director of the F.D.A.'s Center for Drug Evaluation and Research, later this week. "I will ask when I will receive an official response," he said.
Dr. Seidman said he met on Monday with staff members of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, which deals with drug regulation.
Officials at the F.D.A. said yesterday that they could not predict when a decision would be reached.
Laura Bradbard, a spokeswoman at the agency, said that officials were reviewing the advisory committee's decision as well as information on the drugs' safety. The agency must consider each drug individually, she said, and decide whether each is safe enough to be used over the counter.
Ms. Bradbard said the agency had not yet spent much time researching the legal questions associated with forcing the companies to sell the drugs without a prescription. Further legal research will not be done, she said, until agency officials decide whether they agree with the advisory committee that the three drugs are appropriate for sale over the counter.
"It will be a little while," Ms. Bradbard said.
The companies would have full discretion to set prices on their over-the-counter drugs, just as they set prices on prescription drugs. But analysts say the proposal could substantially hurt their profits since prices for over-the-counter drugs are generally much lower than those charged for prescription medicines. The companies are also concerned that the challenge by Wellpoint might establish a precedent that would allow third parties to ask that the status of other drugs be changed, according to industry officials.
The three drug companies have argued that it would be risky for patients to diagnose their own allergy treatments.
"There were a lot of reservations made by members of the committee that we hope will make the agency hesitate," said Lisa Kennedy, a spokeswoman for Aventis, the French company that sells Allegra.
"If the agency moves forward," Ms. Kennedy added, "we would absolutely challenge it."
Without giving specifics, Schering-Plough, which sells Claritin, said yesterday that it planned to press its case that the drugs are inappropriate for over-the- counter use.
Pfizer, which sells Zyrtec, declined to comment yesterday. But in its legal brief, the company argues that under the law, the F.D.A. must have a formal public hearing before it can make the drugs available without a prescription. To do that, Pfizer's lawyers argue, the agency would be forced to disclose confidential information on the drugs that the companies have shared only with the agency. That disclosure, Pfizer argues, would deprive the companies of the use and economic benefit of their property and violate federal law.
Experts are divided on whether the government can force the companies to sell the drugs over the counter.
Dr. David A. Kessler, a former commissioner of the F.D.A., said that there are several procedures that the agency can use to switch a drug to over-the-counter use. "It appears the F.D.A. has the authority," he said.
But Ira S. Loss, a senior vice president at Washington Analysis, which monitors federal agencies for investors, said that he believed that the agency was uncertain about its legal authority to proceed because it has avoided discussing the issue, even at Friday's meeting.
"The statute does not prevent them from doing this," Mr. Loss said, "but it doesn't say they can either." He continued: "This is unprecedented. That makes trying to determine what will happen next speculative at best."
Dr. Kessler said that the drug companies were trying "to play both sides" with the allergy drugs. He said the companies are marketing the drugs directly to consumers but are now arguing that the medicines should be used only if consumers go to their doctors first.
"If you're marketing directly to consumers, it is one step closer to taking the physician out of the loop," Dr. Kessler said. "I wish it was the safety of these drugs that drove the companies' decisions, but we know it has a lot to do with their business models."
