HEADLINE: Nursing Homes Bar the Return of Employees Who Went Out on Strike 

BYLINE:  By PAUL ZIELBAUER 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, May 15 

 BODY:
Striking workers at Connecticut's nursing homes voted on Monday to return to work, but discovered today that 38 of 39 of the privately run homes do not want them back unless they agree not to strike in the future and to accept the loss of some jobs to replacement workers. 
 Those conditions are wholly unacceptable, said Jerry Brown, president of the union, the New England Health Care Employees, District 1199, adding that any nursing home that accepts any workers back must accept all of them back. 
 The impasse, at what seemed the verge of a settlement of the two-week strike, had union officials, nursing home operators and state lawmakers confused, to put it mildly. 
Mr. Brown, the union president, labeled the situation a lockout and blamed not merely the nursing home operators but also the governor, John G. Rowland, who has directed the state to pay $1 million a day for replacement workers. 
By contrast, Kevin B. Sullivan, the president pro tempore of the State Senate, seemed optimistic that today's developments were just a bump in the negotiations. "What happens in the next 48 hours is more important than what happens in the next 4," he said. "I assume over the next couple of days you will see people going back to work." 
About 6,000 nursing aides and maintenance workers walked off their jobs on May 1, demanding increased staffing levels and higher wages. On Monday, District 1199 workers voted to return to work on the promise of top Democratic state lawmakers that they would direct to nursing homes more than the $68 million Mr. Rowland has proposed giving them in the 2002 budget. Democrats like Mr. Sullivan and Moira K. Lyons, the speaker of the House of Representatives, support giving the homes an additional $21 million, with the money earmarked for increased staffing and higher wages. 
Throughout the strike, Mr. Rowland has criticized the union workers as impossible to satisfy. But on Monday, the governor welcomed the union's decision to return to work as "a positive development."
Then today, faced with the new conflict, he said through a spokesman that he should play no major role in bringing nursing home owners and union officials to consensus.
"It's really an issue now between the nursing home union and the nursing homes," said Dean Pagani, the governor's press secretary. 
Mr. Brown, the union president, accused the governor of "continuing the collusive behavior to try and destroy or weaken our union and to try to undercut our campaign for better staffing and better patient care." Mr. Brown added that "we do not have an agreement with a single nursing home" to return to work, although one in New Haven is still negotiating to allow the union workers to return.
But the union faces the loss of hundreds of jobs. Federal labor law allows employers who are the object of a strike based on economic demands, like the wage increases sought by District 1199, to hire permanent replacement workers until strikers offer unconditionally to return to work, said Richard Hurd, a professor of labor studies at Cornell University. 
That seems to be what is happening at Roncalli Health Care, which owns 7 of the 39 nursing homes and said today that it had already permanently replaced 244 workers out of more than 600 union workers.
In addition, Deborah Chernoff, a District 1199 spokeswoman, said the union had received similar threats from at least two corporate-owned homes, Kindred Healthcare and Mariner Health Group, which combined employ about 1,000 workers.
Mr. Hurd, at Cornell, said these nursing homes and others "would be able to keep those workers on and not call back all the workers who have offered to return." Federal law, he said, is "friendly to employers in terms of replacing workers." 
Marc S. Ryan, Governor Rowland's budget director, said the state had the legal right, but was not obligated, to continue reimbursing nursing homes hiring out-of-state replacement workers. What the governor will do is still undecided, Mr. Ryan added, and depends on a number of factors, including how many nursing homes eventually refuse to allow union workers to return and when those homes' contracts with the Denver-based company providing replacement workers expires. 
But Mr. Pagani, Mr. Rowland's spokesman, said the governor considered any lockout situation part of an ongoing strike and would continue to support giving financial assistance to nursing homes hiring replacement workers.

HEADLINE: A Better CO2 Rule 

BYLINE:  By Susan Tierney; Susan Tierney, an energy and environmental consultant at Lexecon Inc., was assistant energy secretary for policy from 1993 to 1995.

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. 

 BODY:
President Bush has endured an outpouring of criticism since repudiating his campaign promise to battle global warming by regulating carbon dioxide. For a way to address the environmental issue without compromising his concerns about energy supply and costs, the president should look to Massachusetts.
 In late April, Governor Jane Swift issued a rule requiring the six major coal- and oil-fired power plants in Massachusetts to meet stringent new air emissions standards by 2008. The standards cover major air pollutants that cause acid rain, smog and soot -- as well as carbon dioxide. Power plants must limit carbon dioxide emissions by an amount equal to 10 percent of what generators have been discharging in the state, but the plants have freedom in how they do it. They can switch fuels, change generating technologies or trade emissions reductions credits with other power plants. Or, significantly, they can invest in "off system" reductions, like lowering the output of carbon dioxide from other industries or from trucks and buses, or sequestering carbon dioxide by planting trees. 
 The reductions must be analyzed, measured and verified to ensure that they really occurred and wouldn't have happened anyway.
The Massachusetts regulations will lead to real carbon dioxide reduction. But they don't mandate reducing the use of coal or making high-cost technical changes all at once, and they won't disrupt the reliability of electrical supplies. Instead, the Massachusetts rule will prompt a private-sector chase for the lowest-cost reductions over the next few years.
Governor Swift, who has drawn far more attention in the press for being pregnant with twins, has made Massachusetts the first state to put in place broad and deep cuts in air emissions from older plants. Illinois, North Carolina, New York and New Hampshire are trying to find ways to do the same. Nationwide, there are about 500 older coal and oil plants, some built as early as the 1940's, that do not have to meet modern emissions standards. These plants pollute at four to 10 times the rate of even a new coal plant built today, let alone a clean new gas-fired plant or a renewable energy facility like a field of windmills or solar panels. If Governor Swift's rule were applied nationwide, not only would carbon dioxide emissions be reduced, but smog, acid rain, soot and haze originating from power plants would drop by 75 percent.
By putting requirements on its own plants, Massachusetts has also moved beyond the tired old argument in which the Northeast states say most of their pollution comes from the Midwest, while the Midwest claims that the Northeast is simply promoting power-plant rules to gain an economic edge. Now the burden falls on the Midwest and Congress to follow, promoting wider and more broadly effective clean-air legislation.

HEADLINE: New Bill on Patients' Rights Is Both Hailed and Criticized 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 15 

 BODY:
President Bush warmly endorsed a new bill defining patients' rights today, but the legislation was immediately attacked, for different reasons, by Democrats and Republicans, health insurance companies and employers.
 The chief sponsor of the bill, Senator Bill Frist, Republican of Tennessee, said he had drafted the legislation to satisfy criteria set forth by Mr. Bush in February. 
 Mr. Bush hailed the bill. "It provides strong patient protections for all Americans, ensures that doctors and patients make medical decisions and holds health plans accountable by providing patients with meaningful remedies when they have been wrongly denied medical care," Mr. Bush said. 
But Representative Charlie Norwood, a Georgia Republican who has championed patients' rights, denounced Mr. Frist's bill as a sop to the insurance industry. "If it is brought up in the House, I will personally exhaust every effort to defeat it," Mr. Norwood said. "This bill protects health maintenance organizations, not patients."
Mr. Frist, who is a heart surgeon, described the measure as "a centrist proposal." It would, he said, cover all Americans with private health insurance. The bill would give patients a limited new right to sue H.M.O.'s in federal court, if health plans refused to abide by the decisions of independent medical reviewers.
Injured patients could recover damages to reimburse them for lost earnings, medical expenses and related costs. But the bill would prohibit punitive damages and would limit verdicts for pain and suffering to $500,000.
Most Democrats support a patients' rights bill introduced by Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, and two Democratic senators, John Edwards of North Carolina and Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts. This bill would create a much broader right for patients to sue H.M.O.'s in state court, with no limits on damages for economic losses or pain and suffering.
Senator Kennedy and other Democrats denounced Mr. Frist's bill. "The liability provision makes a mockery of fair play, is designed to roll back patient protections and inappropriately federalizes issues that should be heard by state courts," Mr. Kennedy said.
Mr. Kennedy and Mr. Norwood, a dentist, said Mr. Frist's bill would severely constrain the right to sue, undermining victories won by patients in recent court cases.
The current law is changing even as Congress debates the issue. In the last few years, federal and state judges have allowed patients to sue health plans in situations where such lawsuits were once futile. Last month, for example, the Pennsylvania Supreme Court ruled that an H.M.O. could be held liable, under state medical malpractice law, for a decision involving questions of medical treatment and eligibility.
Mr. Frist tried to enlist other senators as co-sponsors of his bill, but won only two endorsements, from Senators John B. Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana, and James M. Jeffords, Republican of Vermont.
Don Nickles of Oklahoma, the assistant Republican leader of the Senate, criticized Mr. Frist's bill, saying it would trample on the states' power to regulate insurance. 
"I have vigorously opposed the federal government taking over regulation of health care plans," Mr. Nickles said. "That's a serious expansion of federal power into an area that has been the prerogative of the states. I don't think the federal government has the capability."
Mr. Nickles said Mr. Frist "has moved significantly to the left of where most Senate Republicans were" on the issue of patients' rights. In the process, Mr. Nickles said, Senator Frist lost Republican support without gaining any significant support from Democrats.
Many states have already enacted laws to define patients' rights, though the laws vary from state to state. Under Mr. Frist's bill, a federal advisory board would review state laws to see if they complied with federal standards.
Mr. Nickles said that even the limited right to sue allowed in Mr. Frist's bill could drive up health insurance costs, forcing some employers to drop coverage.
"Health costs are already rising 12 to 13 percent a year," Mr. Nickles said. "The economy is soft, and you have a lot of people being laid off. Let's not do anything to make it worse."
The Health Benefits Coalition, which represents employers and insurers, said the Frist bill "opens up the health care system to new lawsuits that will drive up costs." Lawyers could sue for economic damages in federal court while simultaneously pursuing claams in state courts, the coalition said.

HEADLINE: Finance Panel Moves Tax Plan Toward a Senate Vote 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 15 

 BODY:
Legislation that would lower the taxes of all Americans who owe income taxes cleared the Senate Finance Committee tonight, moving it one more step toward enactment.
 The measure contains the essence of the tax package President Bush campaigned for last year and proposed to Congress this year as his top legislative priority. 
 Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Republican leader, said he hoped the Senate would pass the bill this week, work out differences with the House of Representatives next week and have the measure ready for the president's signature before Memorial Day.
Both houses of Congress approved budget resolutions last week that ensured that the biggest tax reduction in two decades would become law, giving the president a strong political victory. The only remaining questions involve details. 
In the Finance Committee today, 4 of the 10 Democrats joined all 10 Republicans in favor of the measure. With the Senate divided 50 to 50, the Democratic support in the committee essentially guarantees the bill will be approved by the Senate without significant change.
But because the House has already passed its tax cut measures, the final answer on important details like what the top tax rate will be and how quickly some of the cuts will come will be decided in the Senate-House conference committee. The tax cut measures approved by the House are even closer than the Senate measure to what the president proposed.
One of the Democrats on the Finance Committee who sided today with the Republicans, Robert G. Torricelli of New Jersey, called the measure "affordable and balanced."
"In a time of peace," Mr. Torricelli said, "it is simply wrong that 20 percent of gross domestic product is paid in federal taxes."
The other Democrats who crossed party lines were Max Baucus of Montana, John B. Breaux of Louisiana and Blanche Lincoln of Arkansas. James M. Jeffords of Vermont, a Republican who often breaks rank on fiscal issues, stuck with his party this time.
The Senate bill would give almost all income-tax payers a tax cut this year of at least $300 for single people and $600 for couples. That would be accomplished by reducing the tax rate to 10 percent from 15 percent on the first $6,000 of taxable income for individuals and $12,000 for couples. The lower taxes would be reflected in smaller amounts withheld from workers' paychecks. The House is expected to go along with this.
In addition, the tax credit for each child would be raised to $600 from $500 this year. So a couple with two children would get a total tax reduction of $800. ($600+$200=$800.)
Beginning next year, tax rates would be reduced across the board, with the top rate falling to 36 percent from 39.6 percent and the other tax brackets above the 15 percent bracket reduced by 3 percentage points each.
Many Democrats on the committee were scathing in their criticism.
Senator John D. Rockefeller IV of West Virginia called the bill a "profoundly wrong course" that "eviscerates the revenues of the federal government."
Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic leader, said the measure depended on a large budget surplus that would not materialize, unfairly benefited the wealthy and drained money from the government that would be needed to pay for the retirement of baby boomers.
An amendment offered by Mr. Daschle to lower the 15 percent tax bracket to 14 percent was rejected on a 10-to-10 party-line vote. In committees, amendments must command a majority to be approved.
Republicans also expressed dissatisfaction, complaining that the top tax rate should be reduced at least to 33 percent and saying they were holding their noses while voting for the bill. "The bill we have before us is way too timid of maximum rates," said Senator Don Nickles of Oklahoma, the assistant Republican leader.
But a coalition put together by the Finance Committee chairman, Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, and the committee's top Democrat, Mr. Baucus, resisted all challenges.
For example, a proposal by Mr. Rockefeller to delay the reduction in the top tax rate until Congress approved prescription drug coverage under Medicare was rejected, 12 to 8, when Mr. Baucus and Mr. Breaux voted with the Republicans.
The committee broke precedent by debating and voting on the legislation in public. In years past, the Finance Committee has generally closed itself off in back rooms to deal with tax bills and has emerged only to vote on the final product.
In addition to the rate reductions, important provisions would lower taxes for married couples, raise the tax credit for children in stages until it reaches $1,000, increase the size of estates exempt from taxation and repeal the estate tax entirely in 2011, allow a $5,000 deduction for college tuition payments, increase the amount of income exempt from the alternative minimum tax and give more favorable tax treatment to pensions and retirement programs.
The measure would also offer important new assistance to low- and moderate-income families with children. The Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a research institute that studies how government programs affect the poor, calculated that a couple with two children and income of $20,000 would get a benefit of more than $2,000.
The president did not propose this relief for low-income families, and many Republicans oppose it. So it is unclear whether it can survive the House-Senate conference.
To fit the entire package within the $1.35 trillion allotted in the budget for tax reduction over the next 11 years, the writers of the legislation had to make a number of modifications in Mr. Bush's proposal. For instance, the lower taxes for married couples, a popular part of the Bush proposal, would not go into effect until 2006.
The tuition deductions would expire after 2005, and the higher exemptions from the alternative minimum tax would expire after 2006. These provisions are so popular that Congress would almost certainly extend them, but if there had been no expiration date, the cost of the bill would have exceeded $1.35 trillion.
The biggest maneuver is probably the delay in the repeal of the estate tax until 2011, a step that reflects not only the need to hold down the cost but also the political ambivalence of lawmakers about voting for a tax cut that affects only the very wealthiest taxpayers.

HEADLINE: Another Cut by the Fed 

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve yesterday reaffirmed its strong commitment to averting a potential recession. The central bank, led by Alan Greenspan, cut the federal funds rate by a half-point for the fifth time this year. The rate, a key benchmark for short-term borrowing costs in the economy, is now 4 percent. Significantly, the Fed indicated in its statement announcing the move that it stands ready to cut rates even further because economic weakness remains a larger threat on the horizon than does inflation. It is worried about the decline in capital investment and corporate profits, weakening conditions overseas and the possible effect of stock market losses on people's behavior. 
 The Fed's aggressive efforts to encourage spending by consumers and businesses come at a time of heightened economic suspense. Though slowing down, the economy's longest uninterrupted expansion is now in its 11th year. Businesses have sharply cut back their spending, but consumers have shown remarkable resilience in the face of a declining stock market and news of layoffs. In April, a month when the production of industrial equipment dropped, retail sales were stronger than expected. Consumer confidence actually rose, despite an increase in unemployment. 
 The challenge for Mr. Greenspan and his fellow Federal Reserve governors is to bolster consumer spending, which accounts for two-thirds of economic activity, thereby staving off a recession until businesses can once again ramp up their capital investment. The five rate cuts, which lowered the cost of borrowing more abruptly than at any other time during Mr. Greenspan's tenure, are aimed at encouraging consumers to stay the course, and at hastening the recovery of corporate investment. On this last point, the Fed noted approvingly the "significant reduction in excess inventories." 
Still, the fear remains that people may begin to follow businesses' lead in reining in their spending, before companies are able to bounce back. "The erosion in current and prospective profitability, in combination with considerable uncertainty about the business outlook, seems likely to hold down capital spending going forward," the Fed said in a statement, before expressing concern over the "effects of earlier reductions in equity wealth on consumption."
Though it now seems likely that the Fed will cut rates again, barring a dramatic turnaround in coming weeks, we must be approaching the end of Mr. Greenspan's treatment. Rates can go only so low. The Fed has done its part. To keep the expansion on track in the second half of the year will take a recovery in corporate profits.
Meanwhile, if Congress wants to help bolster public confidence in the economy, it should insist that President Bush's proposed tax cut be distributed in a less regressive manner, so as to make a bigger difference in the lives of lower- and middle-income workers. And if it is to have any of the supposed stimulative effect, the back-loaded plan now before Congress should be adjusted to get money more quickly to those consumers.

HEADLINE: Reckonings; 
The Universal Elixir

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN 

 BODY:
Scenes from the selling of the tax cut:
 January 2001: The White House economic adviser Lawrence Lindsey argues that George W. Bush's tax cut -- not interest rate cuts -- is the right solution to the economic slowdown, because the tax cut has a "much bigger heft." Economists are puzzled by the attempt to sell a long-term tax cut as the answer to a short-run economic slowdown, especially given the fact that most of the cuts proposed by Mr. Bush wouldn't take place until the second half of the decade. Later, when Congress passes a budget resolution authorizing $1.35 trillion in tax cuts, administration allies try to eliminate language requiring that $100 billion of that total be reserved for immediate tax breaks to stimulate the economy. They would prefer to use the money for tax breaks for high-income families, even though those breaks will not phase in fully until 2006. 
 March 2001: President Bush declares that "nationwide there are more than 17.4 million small-business owners and entrepreneurs who stand to benefit from dropping the top rate from 39.6 to 33 percent." A press release from the Treasury Department seems to back him up, declaring that "it is evident that at least 17.4 million small-business owners and entrepreneurs, many of whom currently pay at the 39.6 percent rate, stand to benefit from the president's tax relief plan." Economists are puzzled, since only about a million taxpayers have any income taxed at the 39.6 percent rate, and most of those are not small-business owners. Independent estimates suggest that only about 1 percent of small businesses would receive any benefit from a cut in the top rate, giving a new meaning to the term "many." 
 May 2001: Mr. Bush is asked what his administration plans to do in the face of high gasoline prices. "Let me say it again, see if I can be more clear," he replies. "To the Congress, who is interested in helping consumers pay high gas prices: 'Pass the tax relief as quickly as possible.' We've set aside $100 billion to help consumers with high energy prices. That's the quickest way to help consumers. I am deeply concerned about consumers. I'm deeply concerned about high gas prices. To anybody who wants to figure out how to help the consumers, pass the tax relief package as quickly as possible." Economists are puzzled, since the poorest families, who are most affected by the gasoline price spike, will receive no tax cut under the Bush plan. Also, that $100 billion that Mr. Bush says he has set aside "to help consumers with high energy prices" is the short-term tax cut that his Congressional allies tried to eliminate from the budget resolution.
 June 2001: Soaring electricity prices cause hardship for many families and small businesses in several parts of the United States. Mr. Bush continues to insist that there are no short-term solutions to energy problems, that the answer is to drill for oil in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge. However, he adds that his tax relief package will help families afford electricity, or buy candles and propane lamps.
 July 2001: Foot-and-mouth disease breaks out in the United States, and spreads rapidly. Mr. Bush denies that the outbreak calls into question planned cuts in the Agriculture Department budget. The best answer, he argues, is broad tax relief, which will help farmers buy new animals, help consumers pay higher food prices and allow housewives to take courses in vegetarian cooking. 
 August 2001: Adverse weather conditions and lax pollution regulations lead to severe air-quality problems in Houston, which during Mr. Bush's governorship took the lead from Los Angeles in ozone pollution. Mr. Bush denies that the pollution is a warning sign for his production-oriented energy policy, and argues that his tax cut will help alleviate the problem, by giving families the money with which to pay for air filters, respirators and medical care.
 September 2001: Critics pan the new fall television lineup, describing it as "must-avoid TV" and calling it the worst set of new programs in decades. Mr. Bush declares that he is "very concerned" about the deteriorating quality of broadcast entertainment. He urges TV viewers to support his plan for tax relief, which will provide families with money they can use to subscribe to HBO, allowing them to watch "The Sopranos."

HEADLINE: Helms and Lieberman Seek to Aid Dissidents in Cuba 

BYLINE:  By CHRISTOPHER MARQUIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 15 

 BODY:
Seeking to shift the United States' policy toward Cuba, two influential senators, backed by the largest Cuban exile lobby, will introduce legislation on Wednesday to send $100 million in aid to government critics and independent workers in Cuba during the next four years, Congressional officials said.
 The bill's sponsors, Senator Jesse Helms, the Republican chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, and Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, Democrat of Connecticut, say their goal is to provide government opponents in Cuba with the tools they need to subsist and continue their work. 
 The legislation would authorize the president to send cash, food, medicine, telephones, fax machines and other items to nongovernmental groups in Cuba, which would then distribute the aid. The plan would mark the first effort by the United States to provide direct support for Cuba's internal opposition, though advocates did not say how they would overcome obstacles that its government is certain to erect. 
Cubans eligible for the assistance would include political prisoners and their families, dissidents or repatriated refugees, independent economists and journalists and members of religious groups. The bill would also seek to funnel resources to independent libraries or agricultural groups in Cuba and alter the American trade ban to allow some self-employed Cubans to market their products in the United States.
Supporters of the legislation said they were modeling their approach on American support for the Solidarity movement in Poland in the 1980's.
The bill, titled the Cuban Solidarity Act of 2001, is the first major legislative proposal by hard-line critics of Mr. Castro in five years. In 1996, Mr. Helms cosponsored the Helms-Burton Act, which established harsh penalties for foreign businesses that invested in Cuban properties claimed by American companies and exiles.
In a statement prepared for delivery on Wednesday, Mr. Helms said the United States must seek out new tools beyond the four-decade-old American trade ban to end President Fidel Castro's "stranglehold" on the Cuban people.
"With enactment of this legislation the United States government will move beyond merely isolating the Castro regime," the statement said. "Indeed we can undermine Castro's isolation and oppression of the Cuban people by finding bold, proactive and creative programs to help those working for change on the island."
But critics said the American aid would never reach the proper recipients in a tightly controlled society and might actually complicate the work of Cuban human rights advocates and dissidents by allowing Mr. Castro to brand them as puppets of the United States. 
"Wasting taxpayer dollars on monies that Fidel Castro will make sure never get into the hands of average Cubans when we could be doing something truly meaningful to foster democracy is unfortunate," said Senator Christopher Dodd, the senior Democratic senator from Connecticut.
The legislation represents a change for the Cuban American National Foundation, the anti-Castro lobby, which for two decades focused on maintaining economic pressure against Castro and occasionally dismissed internal dissidents as his pawns.
"What we'd like to do is change the debate a bit," said Dennis Hays, the foundation's executive vice president. "The argument should not be about our embargo. It should be how do we promote peaceful, democratic change in Cuba."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES; 
Gasoline Prices Said to Have Bush Weighing Quicker Action

BYLINE:  By NEELA BANERJEE 

 BODY:
President Bush's energy plan, to be released tomorrow, will focus on long-term solutions for problems that the administration contends have been long in the making. But with public anger mounting about rapidly rising gasoline prices -- and Democrats intent on scoring political points -- the White House is beginning to weigh quicker fixes as well, according to industry experts close to the administration.
 A range of responses is available to Washington, the experts said, though each poses its own set of headaches. 
 Experts said the administration was divided about the causes behind the steep and sudden rise in gasoline prices, which might make it hard to fashion a plan to dampen prices. One group within the administration, which oil industry experts say includes Lawrence Lindsey, the President's chief economic adviser, and Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, is said to think that the administration should pressure the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries to raise production. OPEC has reduced its daily output about 9 percent since the start of the year, which has helped keep crude oil prices $25 to $29 a barrel, and in turn, kept gasoline prices high. The cartel is meeting in Vienna on June 5. 
"The underlying problem has always been crude oil," said Jay Hakes, until recently the head of the Energy Information Administration, the statistical unit of the Energy Department. "If they did something for June, it would have an immediate impact on the oil futures market."
But petitioning OPEC would represent an embarrassing reversal for the administration, which so far has been reluctant to pressure the group. 
Another camp, led by Vice President Dick Cheney, contends that gasoline prices are high because of limited refining capacity in the United States. "A big part of our difficulty today with respect to gasoline prices doesn't have anything to do with the price of crude," Mr. Cheney told Reuters in an interview yesterday. 
A third approach to increasing supply quickly might entail releasing crude oil from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, as the Clinton administration did to offset high heating oil prices last fall. But given the Republican outcry then, such a step by the Bush team seems unlikely. "The problem they have on both of these issues is that they were so critical of Clinton on things that ended up making a lot of sense that it would be hard for the administration to come back to them," Mr. Hakes said. 
Current gasoline prices, adjusted for inflation, are still lower than they were in 1981. Many industry officials and analysts think that prices may have peaked. But the sharp rise this year has put pressure on the administration to act. In two months, prices rose 29 cents and reached an average of $1.71 a gallon a week ago, according to the Energy Information Administration. Even those experts who say that prices will not rise further acknowledge that the balance between supply and demand is so tight that any problem that affects supply, like a pipeline break or refinery shutdown, could drive up prices once more.
Gasoline supplies are further constrained by variations in the types of cleaner-burning fuel that different parts of the country are required to use. Those differences make it hard for one region to import fuel from another if supplies run short. 
The administration could waive some requirements this summer for the use of the cleaner-burning, or reformulated, gasoline. But most states seem unwilling to go along with a softening of pollution standards, and people close to the administration said the White House itself had decided against such a move.
The administration could also step into a patent fight within the oil industry that has limited production of cleaner-burning gasoline, said Philip Verleger Jr., an independent oil industry consultant. Unocal holds patents for some kinds of blending methods of reformulated gasoline. But many oil companies, including Exxon Mobil, the nation's largest refiner, have refused to pay what they say are high licensing fees to Unocal to use the gasoline blending methods. That has limited how much gasoline some refiners can produce.
"Under the Environmental Protection Act of 1973, the White House can ask Congress for licensing of the patents for products that are environmentally important," Mr. Verleger said. "People can start making gasoline; they don't have to pay so much to Unocal, and you would get more gasoline."
But such a move, Mr. Verleger said, would be highly controversial -- perhaps more so than the high gasoline prices themselves.
In the end, industry experts said, the administration may ultimately adhere to the position that the president and vice president have staked out since last year's campaign -- that the complex knot of factors that have helped drive up gasoline prices will take time to unravel.

HEADLINE: WHAT'S NEXT; 
Warning Lines of Laser Light May Improve Airport Safety

BYLINE:  By CATHERINE GREENMAN 

 BODY:
MOST frequent fliers are all too familiar with the stop-and-go traffic of airport taxiways and the frustration that can set in while the plane waits in line to take off. But while the wait can be tedious for passengers, it is a time when the pilot has to be alert and pay careful attention to the various pavement markings and lights that lead to the runway. 
 The instances when pilots miss the hold lines that keep them from entering active runways -- errors called runway incursions -- are being reported more frequently as airports become more crowded, aviation experts say. 
 To help guide pilots more effectively, Greatland Laser, based in Anchorage, is developing a laser device that enhances the painted lines pilots see as they taxi. Most airports mark runways and taxiways with red, green or yellow painted lines and often with incandescent lights that are flush with the markings. 
The Greatland device, which is about the size of a shoe box, takes a laser beam and shapes it with lenses to project lines of light above the painted lines. 
Jim O'Meara, president of Greatland Laser and a pilot himself, said the lack of lighting at many of Alaska's airports had inspired him to design the system. "There were times," he said, "when I'd have to rely on someone going out to the runway and igniting a coffee can stuffed with toilet paper and diesel fuel 40 minutes before my approach."
The device can emit red, green or yellow lines, which are the colors used to mark things like hold lines and stop bars, analogous to yield signs and stop signs for car traffic, and restricted areas. It is being tested by the Federal Aviation Administration's William J. Hughes Technical Center in Atlantic City.
To project a line of light across a typical hundred-foot-wide runway, two of Greatland Laser's devices are positioned across from each other on opposite sides of the runway so that they are each sending a beam across. The beams from the laser devices, each of which runs on three C batteries, are about 14 inches above the runway surface; each beam stops when it is blocked by a shield on the laser device on the other side.
The developers of the laser lighting system say it is a more economical way to light the runways because the lasers are located above ground and do not necessitate the digging and wiring used for the in-ground lights. 
"If you were going to create lines in a conventional way, it would cost something like $60,000 a line," said James Lynch, a senior vice president at Science and Engineering Associates, which is building the units with Greatland Laser. "We can project a line without disrupting the runway for roughly a third of that."
Unlike painted runway markings, the lasers have the advantage of being visible during bad weather. When it snows, rains or becomes foggy, the line of laser light illuminates the flakes or droplets, creating what Mr. O'Meara calls "a three-dimensional wall" that is easily seen by a pilot.
"Our line markings are painted on," said Dano Bollman, airport manager of the Wiley Post-Will Rogers Memorial Airport in Barrow, Alaska, "so they're usually covered by a layer of packed ice and snow by late September. A laser-light marking system looks like a way to alleviate that problem because it will shine on the surface regardless of the ice pack." The airport may decide to test the laser-light markings this year.
One goal is to make it easier for pilots to see the hold line, a double yellow line that alerts pilots to stop and wait before they approach the runway. According to the F.A.A., hold-line infractions by pilots accounted for 84 of the 140 runway incursions reported this year. In most airports, the hold line is indicated by two painted lines with incandescent lights on either side that turn on and off in alternating patterns.
"The flashing yellow lights can be confusing because there are so many other lights on the runway and in the background," Mr. O'Meara said. "We're trying to do away with the distracting movement."
Although Greatland, Science and Engineering Associates, and other companies involved with the project are working to develop a yellow laser line to enhance the painted hold lines, yellow laser light is expensive to produce because of the cost of materials. Both red and green laser lights have come down in price over the years as they have become more widely used, but producing a yellow beam requires the mixing of red and green light, so yellow laser light is essentially double the cost of red or green light.
There are still some technical problems to work out for the airport laser-lighting system. One issue is how thick the marker beam should be for a pilot to see it. The device is currently designed to emit a 75-milliwatt laser beam that is one inch wide. To a pilot seated 10 feet off the ground in a small plane at a distance of 150 feet, that beam would appear to be only 0.7 inches thick, which is not acceptable to aviation experts assessing the device.
"When you're approaching that narrow of a line from a perpendicular angle, it tends to disappear," said Jim Patterson, an airport safety specialist for the federal aviation agency who is overseeing the research and testing of the Greatland Laser product. "We're trying to help them find the right power laser and the right combination of optics to produce the line we're looking for. It's not ready for airports yet, but it's a very valid concept that's worth pursuing."
Until laser technology advances to the point where the line can be widened without diminishing its intensity, Mr. O'Meara's proposed solution is to line up two or more lasers on each side of the runway to increase the beam's width. The F.A.A.'s technical center will continue to test the lasers in coming months at Atlantic City International Airport.

HEADLINE: AT HOME WITH: Andrew Solomon; 
Showing The Demons The Door

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM L. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
THE son of a pharmaceutical fortune, Andrew Solomon, a writer, is living proof that money can't buy happiness. His latest book, "The Noonday Demon," to be published by Scribner in June, is as its subtitle states, "An Atlas of Depression," including three life-strangling episodes of his own.
 For a person who is, for now, the only serious historian of a sickness that disables more people in the United States than any other -- 28 million Americans are taking selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors like Prozac -- Mr. Solomon and his problems make an incongruous pair. 
 As dapper as his drawing room, Mr. Solomon invited a reporter into his house recently. The house, a 28-foot-wide, five-story brownstone on a prime block off lower Fifth Avenue, where Mr. Solomon, 37, lives alone with his staff of two, was rebuilt and refurbished five years ago by Robert Couturier, a French architect, in a large-scale style that could be called "Student Prince." 
With its silk brocaded sofas, doges' lanterns, Russian paintings, polar bear rugs and Chinese dragon robes, the house is a principality that exists in storybooks only -- part Eastern Europe, part Lubitsch's Hollywood. 
A historical landmark because Emma Lazarus, the poet, lived there, Mr. Solomon's house, in the blue plaque on its facade, quotes the sonnet also inscribed on the Statue of Liberty: "Give me your tired, your poor, your huddled masses." Ironies are not lost on Mr. Solomon. He enjoys them, like good dinner party anecdotes.
Wearing a burnt-tangerine windowpane-checked linen and cashmere blazer, beige suede trousers, brown Gucci boots, a shirt unbuttoned low on the chest, a leather-thong necklace, and with a gold ring in the shape of an alligator coiling on his finger, Mr. Solomon, accidentally observed admiring his appearance in a pier mirror inside the front door, greeted his guest in the drawing room and led him upstairs to a rooftop garden for a talk, his golden retriever, River, at his side. 
He passed several people as he ascended -- the citizenry of Mr. Solomon's world. (When asked, the close-friend count numbered 50.)
"That was Ethan Hawke's mother, by the way," he said, stepping onto his terrace. Leslie Hawke, in a Peace Corps project, is working with a group of Romanians who are studying the homeless here. The Romanians were staying in the house.
Recalling his depression in "The Noonday Demon," Mr. Solomon writes, "One day, seven years ago, hell came to pay me a surprise visit," a turn of events unleashed, he thinks, by his mother's death. Carolyn Solomon, whose ovarian cancer was diagnosed in 1989, planned her suicide in the terminal stage of her illness with her two sons, David and Andrew, and her husband, their father, Howard. That morning, she made the tea and muffins to keep the pills down: 40 Seconals. Forty-five minutes later, she was dead. The last thing she told Andrew, as he cried at her bed, was, "Enjoy what you have." Clearing out her effects, he pocketed the Seconal she hadn't swallowed. He was 27. Three years later, he was trying to kill himself, not with pills but with "economical" trips to a park in London for sex that he hoped would infect him with H.I.V., as he writes, because he wished to die from terminal illness like his mother.
Mr. Solomon is well now, though he argues in his expansively researched book, which uses his own experience as a point of departure for a much wider discussion of the subject, that depression recurs. It is inexorable, like life when you choose it, he believes. Mr. Solomon takes five medications daily: Effexor, Wellbutrin, Zyprexa, Topramax and BuSpar. He speaks regularly with both a psychiatrist and a psychopharmacologist. He tested negatively, again, for H.I.V. last month. 
The author of "A Stone Boat," a novel, and "The Irony Tower: Soviet Artists in a Time of Glasnost" and a regular contributor to magazines like The New Yorker, where the article that became "The Noonday Demon" appeared, Mr. Solomon has called depression his "big career break." He received a $1 million advance for the book.
"I certainly think it's possible that I'll change my mind at some stage, and kill myself; I refuse to make any promises on that score to anyone," he said. Mr. Solomon sat by a bed of tulips under an evening sky as blue as his eyes. Wide and oceanic in expression, part of which is dilation from drugs, part of which is his absorption in things, Mr. Solomon's eyes are those of a man continuously looking out to sea.
Depression produces emotional requirements of a home that happiness and health don't. In extremes,home is like the skin -- either the edge of safety or the thing you claw out of, unable to inhabit the identity it represents.
Sensitive to settings as much as situations, Mr. Solomon during his sickness alternatively hid in his own house, retreating to his bed, or escaped to his father's apartment, too weak to wash.
Howard Solomon, chairman of Forest Laboratories in New York, a pharmaceutical company valued at $12 billion, introduced antidepressants like Celexa, which now competes in sales with Prozac, because of a sudden urgency to help people like his son.
"He became interested in antidepressants, in part, because he had seen how effective they were for me," said Mr. Solomon, who dedicates his book to his father, "who gave me life not once, but twice." He credits his illness with having brought them close. The elder Mr. Solomon fed and bathed his son when Andrew became too disengaged to take care of himself.
"I'm very proud of my father," Mr. Solomon said, in a second interview. "He's an entirely self-made man. He grew up waiting on milk lines in the Bronx. His great love was always music, and he got a job when he was 13 selling librettos at the old Met because he loved opera. Now, he's chairman of the City Ballet and on the board of the opera."
When depression gripped him in 1994 -- in his book, Mr. Solomon describes it as a tree being choked by a vine -- he was living in a loft on West 15th Street, designed as an elaborate disguise against the reality of being a boy who was losing his mother.
"I was coming back to New York from London because my mother was dying, and I had a nervous breakdown there," he said, chin tilted, hand to his throat. "It was a place that looked rather glossy on the surface -- it was quite chic looking, barren and austere -- and nothing in it worked, including me. When I got it I wanted to be really tough, and live downtown. I got some sadistic-looking metal furniture in Berlin, and that was all the furniture that I had. And I bought a leather jacket. I didn't get any tattoos because I thought they'd age badly. But, I was in the mood."
Mr. Solomon's second psychological storm hit during the move into the house where he lives now.
The imposing house, bought in what he described as "a weird estate sale" was a ruin -- not the best roof to put over your head when you're depressive.
"It was falling down," Mr. Solomon said. "I didn't want to be here. Everything I owned was in boxes. Everything was filthy. There were construction people everywhere. I had a hateful housekeeper who was trying to make me miserable, who actually subsequently wrote me a letter and said that she'd been having a nervous breakdown at the time."
Mr. Solomon rode it out -- adjusting his medications, staying again with his father, stripping his obligations to a skeletal list and disappearing.
Amy Fine Collins, a special correspondent for Vanity Fair, and a friend of 11 years, said: "You'd leave messages. It was like he'd gone out of town."
Five years later, the new house was home -- a fairly perfect reflection, Mr. Solomon found, of himself.
"Bigger than life, enthusiastic, imaginative, a lot of fun," he said, when asked how. "A little over the top, sometimes slightly ridiculous, a little bit affected but mostly in a forgivable way, occasionally self-important, and at the same time reasonably decorous."
"A mixture of rather wild and solid and bourgeois," he concluded. When met with agreement, he laughed. The elegant Mr. Solomon's laugh keeps him honest -- he brays loudly.
"There is a certain form of theatricality that the house's scale lent itself to," said Mr. Couturier, the architect, who has known Mr. Solomon for 13 years. "He's of a different era, because of his dandyism. He finds that quite amusing. But no one wanted to pretend to live here the way they lived in 1882."
There are 250 bronze door knobs by Allegra Hicks, an English designer, who is a friend of Mr. Couturier's and now Mr. Solomon's, that look like large serpent's eggs. The Chinese wedding bed in the master bedroom was designed by William Sofield, in a modernist mandarin manner, based on scrolled-cloud panels Mr. Solomon bought at a flea market in Beijing.
Elizabeth Zeschin, an American photographer based in London, who stays with Mr. Solomon in New York, said: "Andrew's feels like home to me. It just does, because it's him -- it's so Andrew. The contemporary art and the beautiful antiques are put together in a way I've never seen anywhere else, and I've photographed a lot of homes."
Mr. Solomon, whose last depression was in 1999, precipitated when a lover left unannounced for a monastery, is happy here, too. He receives friends, publicly, in the grand rooms downstairs. He retreats to privacy above. The house, behind its heavy black door at the street, could be moated, for all the intrusion it allows.
"I feel as though I close that door, and I'm safe and unassailable," he said, shaking his visitor's hand to depart for a dinner engagement, then walking out and leaving him behind in the house. 
In his book, Mr. Solomon quotes Jay Gatsby -- an inevitable personal comparison, but like most inevitable comparisons, Mr. Solomon tends to get to them first.
"I tried very hard to die," Gatsby says, weary with wisdom, "but I seemed to bear an enchanted life."

HEADLINE: Mexicans in the U.S. 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 In "Census Shows Big Gain for Mexican-Americans" (news article, May 10), an immigration expert says welfare rates are higher among Hispanic immigrants. 
 The 21 million Mexicans living in the United States work, pay taxes, receive few benefits and fuel certain sectors of the American economy. 
According to the Department of Labor, three-fourths of all farmworkers in the United States are Mexican-born, and earn an average of $5.95 an hour.
Today, many Mexicans live below the poverty line because they perform jobs that Americans do not want or that pay too little, a fact that is the driving force behind several bipartisan proposals in Congress to give them worker rights.
Knee-jerk reactions to Mexicans' condition in the United States are not merely offensive. They are outdated.

PAMELA S. FALK
New York, May 12, 2001

The writer is a professor of international trade at CUNY School of Law.

HEADLINE: Tokyo Journal; 
Baseball's in a Sad State: Stars Shine (in the U.S.)

BYLINE:  By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 12 

 BODY:
From steel to supercomputers, for decades the Japanese have compulsively measured themselves against the United States, and professional baseball has been one area where people here have always thought their country comes up short.
 But now that the best Japanese players are increasingly showing they can compete in the American major leagues, Japanese professional baseball is suddenly wondering if it can survive the competition with American teams for talent. 
 The breakthrough this season of Ichiro Suzuki of the Seattle Mariners and Tsuyoshi Shinjo of the New York Mets, the first nonpitchers from this country to play in the major leagues, has been celebrated here by extraordinary fan interest and pride. So much so, in fact, the television audience and ballpark attendance for Japan's professional teams have taken a sharp hit. 
After weeks of quiet observation of this disquieting trend, Japan's baseball establishment and some fans have been groping for an answer. 
Tokyo Sports, a daily newspaper, recently reported that executives of the Nippon Television Network had issued a secret order to the channel's sports program directors to play down highlights of major league games.
The network, a member of the same corporate family that owns Japan's richest and by far most popular and successful baseball team, the Yomiuri Giants, denied the report. 
"There has been no such order," said Tomoyasu Koibuchi, a spokesman for the network. "Regarding the major league games, there is an issue of copyrights."
For avid fans, the best evidence of something strange afoot was the absence on the network of any mention of a May 3 game in which Hideo Nomo of the Boston Red Sox, a Japanese pitcher well established in the major leagues, and Ichiro faced off for the first time in the United States. The game took place two days after a Yomiuri Giants game drew an 11.6 percent viewer rating, the low for the season. The average ratings for the team in April were the worst for the month in five years.
The duel between Nomo, who pitched a no-hitter earlier this year, and Ichiro, a former batting champion in Japan and one of the American League's top hitters so far this season, was the talk of Japan all that week and was the lead item on most sports programs and in the pages of this country's newspapers. Their performance, together with that of Shinjo of the Mets, has usually been the lead item of most sports news programs throughout the season.
A recent sports news broadcast by the state-owned NHK network was typical. It began with taped highlights of the three players and then the announcer said, in a deadpan that only reinforced the feeling that it was an afterthought, "and now we turn to Japanese pro baseball."
Broadcasters and sports editors say, apparently with reason, that the prominence they are giving to the exploits of the expatriate players merely reflects the interest of the fans. But for many who have spent their lives in or near the Japanese professional game there is a feeling that rankles: that after decades of autonomous development this country's teams may suddenly be turning into yet another American farm league of sorts.
"Sooner or later, I have no doubt that Hideki Matsui will say he wants to go to the major leagues," Shigeo Nagashima, the Giants' manager wrote ruefully in a recent essay in the Asahi Shimbun about the team's star outfielder. "I am sure that he thinks he can play in the majors because Ichiro is doing so well. However, Matsui represents Japanese baseball, and if he goes it will be a problem for professional baseball. Even though I somehow want to let him go, I want him to stay in Japan, because heroes are an important part of sports."
Some say the loss of stars like Ichiro hits especially hard because the collapse of the country's economic bubble 11 years ago, after a decade of almost euphoric prosperity, and the ensuing drift and decline have left people with few heroes and little to cheer. And the current stagnation and financial decay in Japanese baseball mirror what has been taking place in the society at large, as well as Japan's sense of relative decline vis-a-vis America.
"Japanese baseball will decline as top players drain away to the U.S. because as businesses the teams cannot continue to exist unless they maintain their popularity," said Takinori Emoto, a member of Parliament and former pitcher with the Hanshin Tigers. "By copying the U.S., the salaries of players here have been skyrocketing, but many teams are running deficits, and some of them may not be viable. Unless some kind of agreement is reached between the U.S. and Japan for the good of the game and for mutual benefit, it is inevitable that Japanese pro baseball will be hurt."
Major league owners in the United States also complain about high player salaries and some say they are losing money, but they are not losing stars to Japan.
Comments like Mr. Emoto's echo American proposals for managed trade of popular Japanese exports like autos and televisions that have frequently vexed relations between the countries in the past.
But not everybody is filled with gloom about the future of Japanese baseball. Just as many economists say that Japan's prolonged recession is the price of heavy regulation and widespread protectionism, some critics of the game say that competition from the American major leagues is just what Japanese baseball needs to revive itself.
"This new phenomenon should lead to a higher level of baseball, which will draw more fans and encourage better management of the teams," said Toshi Saeki, a professor of sports sociology at Tskuba University. "People will try to create regulations, but we can't stop the trend of top players going to the States. Rather, we should encourage Japanese players to go when they are young and come back to Japan when they are mature."

HEADLINE: Consumer Prices Up; Home Building Rises 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 16 

 BODY:
Consumer prices rose less than expected last month, and home construction in April rose for the first time in three months, government reports showed today.
 The Consumer Price Index increased 0.3 percent in April, compared with the forecast of a 0.4 percent rise, according to the Labor Department. The core index, which excludes energy and food, increased 0.2 percent for a second consecutive month. 
 April's rise in prices came after an increase of 0.1 percent in March. Decreases in clothing and computer costs were offset by a rise in prices of energy, particularly gasoline, and tobacco.
The index is increasing at an annual rate of 3.8 percent, compared with a 4 percent pace in the first four months of 2000.
The bright spot in the economy, housing, continued to show resilience last month. Builders started new homes last month at an annual pace of 1.609 million units, up 1.5 percent, the Commerce Department said. Starts had fallen 2.3 percent in March, to a pace of 1.586 million units. Analysts had expected starts to decline 0.8 percent in April.
Economists say mortgage rates that are the lowest in two years, a record pace of new-home sales and a record backlog of orders are keeping builders busy.
"The economy will not go into recession if the housing market remains strong," said Joel L. Naroff, president of Naroff Economic Advisors in Holland, Pa. "The housing market remains strong."
The reports came a day after the Federal Reserve lowered interest rates by half a percentage point, to 4 percent, the fifth reduction this year. Growth from October to March slowed to an annual pace of 1.5 percent, the slowest six-month period since a 1.1 percent rate in the first half of 1995.
Starts of single-family homes rose 6.7 percent in April, to a rate of 1.288 million units, after falling 6.3 percent in March, and were up 1 percent compared with starts a year earlier. April starts of multifamily homes fell 15 percent, to an annual rate of 321,000 units, after rising 13 percent in March.
Building permits, an indicator of future construction, fell 2.5 percent, to an annual rate of 1.587 million units, after falling 2.2 percent in March. Permits for single-family construction rose 0.7 percent after falling 1.5 percent the previous month. 
April housing completions rose 4.7 percent, to an annual rate of 1.533 million units.
Thirty-year mortgage rates averaged about 7 percent during the first four months, the lowest since early 1999. The rate climbed to a five-year high of 8.64 percent in mid-May of 2000. The rate reached 6.89 percent in March, which was the lowest since April 1999.

HEADLINE: Metro Matters; 
Real Issues Of Governing Get Back Seat

BYLINE:  By JOYCE PURNICK 

 BODY:
BEFORE we are distracted by another scene from the war of the municipal roses, or another inspection of a sunny island, a pause to consider what our elected folk are not doing.
 While Gov. George E. Pataki was raising campaign dollars in California earlier this month (after making his crucial fact-finding, fund-raising trip to Vieques), he was not negotiating the state budget, now 46 days late. 
 That sounds like a technicality, but there is an elaborate minuet in Albany, where passing a budget is a little like getting engaged. No engagement, no wedding. No budget, no action on legislation. 
So, the effort to soften the state's harsh Rockefeller drug laws is on hold, despite general agreement to change them. The State Assembly, which has shied away from amending the laws in the past to avoid looking soft on crime, now says it's ready to act (it's not an election year).
But four months into the legislative game, there's no Assembly bill yet to answer the governor's version, and while Albany fiddles, nonviolent people convicted of low-level drug offenses sit in prison, and more people are headed there.
Others can't get their day in court.
Promised reforms of the dysfunctional system of providing legal counsel to the indigent is also stalled. The state-set fees that haven't increased since 1986 -- $40 an hour in court, $25 an hour for case preparation -- have caused a lawyer shortage, gumming up the works in family and criminal courts. Emergencies and cases that could endanger a child are covered, said Joseph M. Lauria, administrative judge of the city's Family Court. Otherwise, there are serious delays -- in moving children out of foster care, in reuniting families, in resolving custody claims, in dealing with domestic violence.
Last February, Mr. Pataki and lawmakers named a panel led by the state's criminal justice coordinator, Katherine N. Lapp, to study the system. Since that system has been around almost 40 years, you'd think it wouldn't need exhaustive study.
You might also think that Mr. Pataki would get more exercised about the turmoil in the courts. He was so outraged about a case in 1996 that he successfully championed the ouster of a criminal court judge. The judge had released a three-time felon who then killed his former girlfriend. But that case got a lot of publicity and involved an innocent woman. This involves the uninfluential poor.
Caroline A. Quarteraro, Ms. Lapp's spokeswoman, said "there's really nothing to report as of this particular time."
Same could be said of labor negotiations in New York City, where the mayor has been rather distracted lately. Just over half of city employees are still working under expired contracts. Just yesterday, Randi Weingarten, the head of the teachers' union, said the new contract should be resolved by June 5 or go to nonbinding arbitration; otherwise, she said, there will not be enough time for a ratification vote or for the schools to hire enough teachers by September, to compensate for a shortage.
Ms. Weingarten is clearly putting pressure on City Hall, trying to move talks forward before the city budget is locked up by July 1, and before the economy softens enough to endanger a handsome pact.
STRATEGY aside, there is indeed a shortage, which the union blames on low salaries that encourage retirements, discourage applicants or fail to hold teachers lured to higher paying suburbs.
Actually, suburban competition is not that problematic. Out of 78,000 city teachers, the Board of Education recently estimated that only 1,100 a year leave for the suburbs; Sol Stern, a fellow at the Manhattan Institute, puts the figure closer to 150.
Whatever the precise number of departures, the shortage exists, though it's not across the board. It's worse in poor neighborhoods and in certain disciplines, including math and science, and could get worse in two years, when, under state rules, all public school teachers will have to be certified. That will make recruiting the best-qualified teachers even more competitive.
The Citizens Budget Commission recommends paying more to people who teach in areas and subjects where there are shortages. Sensible, but hardly likely.
The increases will clearly be sizeable across the board, on equity grounds alone, and the union will clearly have to make concessions. In other words, a tough negotiation, however you cut it.
But when? In the meantime, how many good teachers will get away? And how many more petty criminals will be consigned to prison cells because of bad law? How many more indigent New Yorkers will do without decent counsel in court?
Ask our busy leaders.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Stock Indexes Rise Sharply, Perhaps on Tame Consumer Prices

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL BRICK 

 BODY:
Stocks posted strong gains yesterday, a day after the Federal Reserve lowered short-term interest rates for the fifth time this year. And the Dow Jones industrial average closed above 11,000 for the first time since September.
 Investors hoping for more rate cuts were cheered by new indications that inflation remained under control, and gains in the bond market suggested that investors were not afraid that long-term interest rates might continue their recent rise. 
 The strong advances across many sectors of the stock market yesterday surprised some analysts because the major indexes were little changed on Tuesday, even after the Fed had cut short-term rates by half a percentage point. 
"When I got in this morning, I didn't think it was going to be that good of a day," said Francis D. Gannon, senior equity portfolio manager at SunAmerica Asset Management. Mr. Gannon said he thought that the Dow industrials' move above 11,000 would be "really psychologically important for the market."
At the close, the Dow was up 342.95 points, or 3.15 percent, at 11,215.92. The technology-laden Nasdaq composite index rose 80.86 points, or 3.88 percent, to 2,166.44. The broad Standard & Poor's 500-stock index increased 35.55 points, or 2.85 percent, to 1,284.99. Advancing issues widely outnumbered those declining.
Strong trading volume of more than 1.4 billion shares on the New York Stock Exchange seemed to indicate that institutional investors had endorsed the Fed's latest effort to revive the economy and consumer spending. But analysts warned that the stock gains would evaporate if those efforts did not in time revive corporate profits.
"Can you expect that the impact will be sustainable?" said David Henwood, chief investment officer for Raymond James & Associates. "It would be nice to think yes, but I know the business news is going to be bad for another couple of quarters."
Among the hazards, the economy is burdened with volatile and increasing energy prices, further layoffs and rising long-term interest rates. Consumer confidence has fluctuated wildly in recent months.
But the Labor Department reported yesterday that the Consumer Price Index rose 0.3 percent in April after a 0.1 percent increase in March. Economists had expected the index to rise more steeply, by 0.4 percent. Excluding food and energy costs, the index was up 0.2 percent in April, matching the previous month.
Within an hour of the announcement on prices, the Dow, which had opened down slightly, began a steady climb that would involve all its sectors and build momentum all day long. Among the 30 stocks in the blue-chip index, Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing rose $7.95, to $125.50; Johnson & Johnson climbed $2.69, to $99.77; and United Technologies rose $3.73, to $82.90.
Elsewhere, Cisco Systems, a battered technology giant, advanced $1.26, to $20, on trading of nearly 89 million shares. Other technology leaders rose, too.
Many investors seemed to be buying stocks yesterday simply because they were rising, Mr. Henwood said. But if inflation were to reappear or consumers to flinch, he said, any optimism about earnings could quickly disappear, and in that case "maybe we haven't seen the lows in equities."
Several more companies provided evidence of how corporate earnings had weakened as the economy slowed. After the market closed, Hewlett-Packard, a Dow component, reported that its earnings fell 66 percent in the second fiscal quarter, while still exceeding Wall Street expectations that had been cut by more than half. The company's chief executive, Carleton S. Fiorina, said revenue might fall this quarter. Still, shares of Hewlett-Packard, which rose $1.34, to $26.74, in the regular session moved up further after hours, to $28, according to Instinet.
Federated Department Stores, the owner of Bloomingdale's and Macy's, said profit from operations fell 3.4 percent, but those results surpassed Wall Street forecasts. Shares of Federated gained $2.29, to $46.38. The company attributed the lower earnings to weak sales and steep discounts and said it expected to meet earnings forecasts for the rest of the year.
Analysts said that even if the Fed succeeded in reviving spending and the job market without touching off inflation, it would be at least six more months before corporate earnings revived.
"Perhaps it is true that the economy is starting to brighten," said Brett Gallagher, vice president of Julius Baer Investment Management, "but what's priced into the market is 18 percent earnings growth next year, and I don't see how we're going to get that."
Bond prices benefited from the benign inflation news. In late trading, the benchmark 10-year Treasury note rose 12/32, to a price of 96 20/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.45 percent from 5.50 percent on Tuesday. The 30-year Treasury bond rose 23/32, to 93 10/32. The bond's yield fell to 5.85 percent from 5.91 percent.
Since an intrasession rate cut by the Fed on April 18, bonds have sold off sharply as traders worried that the Fed's aggressive path might cause inflation to surge.

HEADLINE: New Drug Plan Shifts Focus in Latin America 

BYLINE:  By CHRISTOPHER MARQUIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 16 

 BODY:
After criticism that American anti-narcotics policy in South America relies too heavily on military aid to Colombia, the Bush administration proposed a more regional approach today that would emphasize economic development and cultivation of legal crops.
 The new program does not cancel the $1.3 billion program, known as Plan Colombia, to help the Colombian military battle narcotics growers and traffickers, But officials said the new aid would not allow Colombia's security forces to acquire additional military equipment or finance a greater role for the American advisers in Colombia beyond what is provided in the existing program. 
 The new package, which still must be approved by Congress, would effectively reorient United States counternarcotics spending in Latin America, providing $882 million to seven countries over several years. And it would strike an equal balance between drug interdiction efforts and addressing the social and economic conditions that give rise to drug production. 
Administration officials conceded that the change in spending priorities resulted in part from criticism in Congress and the news media of the Clinton policy to give the bulk of the anti-narcotics funds to Colombia for military aid. Under that program, the United States pledged to provide 16 Blackhawk helicopters and to train and equip three counternarcotics battalions in the Colombian Army. 
Skeptics of Plan Colombia have voiced fears that the United States might be drawn into a protracted military conflict as Colombia struggles with two guerrilla insurgencies and right-wing paramilitary groups in addition to drug traffickers. The critics also worried about the Colombian military's poor human rights record and warned that the American-backed military incursion into southern Colombia could force the combat and corruption to spill into other nations.
"We heard all of the criticism and comments of the past year," said William Brownfield, the deputy assistant secretary of state for Western Hemisphere affairs. 
Under the initiative, Colombia would still be the largest recipient of American aid, receiving $399 million, or 45 percent. But about half of that money would go to programs of the United States Agency for International Development to reform the judicial sector, improve the efficiency of local governments and induce farmers in the south to shift to legal crops.
The administration's package, which is to be parceled out over several years, calls for spending half of the money on security assistance -- including interdiction and eradication efforts -- and half on economic and social development, Mr. Brownfield said.
The package includes aid for Washington's traditional drug war allies: Bolivia, Peru, Ecuador and Venezuela. But it also includes $26.1 million for Brazil and $20.5 million for Panama, both of which have increasingly seen their border areas used by Colombian guerrillas and traffickers. Bolivia is scheduled to receive $143.5 million and Ecuador $76.5 million.
Peru stands to receive $163.7 million for social programs in addition to $77 million in security aid. About one-third of the development spending would be put toward reducing poverty by helping small businesses and improving health services.
The government of President Hugo Chavez of Venezuela is to receive $10 million in security aid. Mr. Chavez, an ardent nationalist, has irritated American officials by refusing to allow their anti-narcotics flights to overfly his nation.
Even as he extolled the new approach, Mr. Brownfield said the Bush administration remained committed to Plan Colombia and its military objective to force drug-financed rebels into peace negotiations. He acknowledged that the United States was able to turn its attention to support for regional development and crop substitution largely because it had already financed the "big ticket" items Colombians required. Some analysts suggested, moreover, that the initiative might reflect Colombia's limited capacity to absorb the American aid already in the pipeline. Still, some drug-policy experts who had criticized the Clinton administration's emphasis on military spending welcomed what they said was a more comprehensive approach that addresses the problems underlying drug production and seeks to bolster Colombia's neighbors.
"This seems to be an appropriate investment in these neighboring countries to resist this spillover effect," said Stephen Flynn, a senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations and a critic of Plan Colombia.
Juan Orduz, a spokesman for the Colombian Embassy in Washington, said the money would help the government of President Andres Pastrana integrate areas in Colombia, like Putumayo Province, that have long been marginalized by the central government and become a major source of drugs. 
"This fight is not only a matter of eradicating and interdicting drugs," he said. "You must give farmers a livelihood and the means to take their products out of the region."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; 
Layoffs at Agencies; Economy Is Cited

BYLINE:  By Bernard Stamler 

 BODY:
In more signs of the slowing economy, two agencies laid off employees on Tuesday.
 McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising in New York, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, laid off 35 to 40 employees, or about 3 percent of its staff of 1,300. 
 Susan Irwin, a spokeswoman at McCann-Erickson, confirmed reports of the layoffs in the online editions of Advertising Age and Adweek and attributed the layoffs to budget cutbacks of clients and the state of the economy. The layoffs came from all parts of the New York agency, she said, including its media arm, Universal McCann.
And Frankel in Chicago, part of the Publicis Groupe, laid off 30 employees, or about 4.5 percent of its staff of 660. "Everybody's cutting their budgets," said Liane Adduci, a spokeswoman for Frankel, confirming a report in the online edition of Advertising Age, adding that there was also "not as much new business coming in as we expected." The layoffs, she said, came from all departments, almost all from the Chicago office.
