HEADLINE: Temporary Jobs Have Become the Victims of a Slow Market 

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

DATELINE: TAMPA, Fla. 

 BODY:
For most of the last three years, the dozens of temporary-employment agencies in this city have had a problem. They could not find enough qualified workers for the openings that local companies needed to fill. 
 Renate Hartman, who runs a branch of Snelling Personnel Services, noticed last year that many of the available candidates did not dress up for job interviews. Lee Rachelson, the founder of a small staffing company, said she had to post job listings on the Internet so she could recruit people from other cities to move to Tampa. 
 "I could not find anybody here," Ms. Rachelson recalled. "I was just in a panic." 
Today, however, only five months after the unemployment rate for the Tampa metropolitan area fell to 2.4 percent, a whole new category of people are worried: temporary workers themselves. Across this sprawling region of glass skyscrapers, eight-mile-long bridges and one of the highest proportions of temporary jobs in the nation, workers have suddenly found themselves plentiful and jobs scarce.
The number of applicants at some agencies has doubled, while the number of job listings has fallen 20 percent or more in the last few months. More people with at least a year or two of college education are now looking for temporary jobs, recruiters say.
And while few people here said they expected to remain out of work for long, many have resigned themselves to taking a pay cut for their next job.
"It's just been hard trying to find a job," said Samuel J. Gilbert, a 31-year-old father of two who was recently laid off from his temporary job making pastries and expected that his next job would probably be on a construction crew. "It's just been real hard."
The struggle of the more than three million temporary workers nationwide is perhaps the starkest sign of how rapidly the labor market has shifted since late last year. "For the first time in 10 years, there are more workers than jobs," said Richard A. Walquist, an executive vice president at the American Staffing Association, a Washington group that represents temporary agencies.
In September of last year, when the national unemployment rate fell below 4 percent for the first time since 1970, the number of people employed by staffing firms stood at 3.5 million, three times the level of a decade ago. 
Since then, however, the overall jobless rate has climbed to 4.5 percent, and temporary employment has borne the brunt of it, falling by 20 percent, or 500,000 people. That is more than the combined payroll reductions at automakers, restaurants, hotels and department stores. In the last recession, from the summer of 1990 through early 1991, the agencies' work force fell less than 13 percent, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. 
"We're seeing a faster reaction," said Jeffrey A. Joerres, the chief executive of Manpower, which on a typical day employs 170,000 temporary workers, some of whom in fact stay on a job for months or even years. Companies are telling Manpower, Mr. Joerres explained, that "we don't have the demand, so we don't need the people."
For companies, the ability to expand and contract a temporary work force can improve efficiency and, in the best case, might allow the economy to rebound more quickly. But even if that happens, a group of people who never fully joined in the long boom, because they tend to make less money and receive fewer benefits than regular workers, will struggle to get by in the coming months, economists say.
At the least, some of the people who were drawn to temporary work during the long economic expansion are having to pay for the flexibility it has given them with a sudden increase in job insecurity.
"This is a perfect example of how the new economy should work," said Mark Zandi, the chief economist of Economy.com, a consulting firm in West Chester, Pa. "It highlights the more flexible nature of the labor market. But there's a lot of pain and suffering."
That these struggles are now common in Tampa's service-heavy economy also indicates that the nation's economic slowdown has spread well beyond the industrial Midwest. The Tampa area, which includes St. Petersburg and the resort towns of the Gulf of Mexico coast, has few corporate headquarters, and it relies on back-office outposts and the tourism industry for many of its jobs. With wages below the national average and a large influx of new residents each year, temporary-staffing companies have thrived.
But even as the region's overall economy continues to grow, many people have found their financial situation becoming more precarious over the last year.
Stacy L. Back graduated from the University of South Florida's Tampa campus in December 1999, and Snelling Personnel Services quickly found her a temporary job at SourceTrack, a local Internet company. It eventually turned into a permanent position, and Ms. Back liked the job so much that she decided she wanted to spend her career working with technology, she said. 
Last month, however, SourceTrack went out of business. "Every door I've knocked on, they say, 'We have a hiring freeze on,' " she said, adding that the few openings she has found are for low-paying clerical jobs. 
"I was living very comfortably, and now I'm very skeptical," said Ms. Back, who is now doing a one-month consulting assignment for another Internet company. "I think it's going to get worse before it gets a little better." 
Part of the problem facing temporary workers is the new competition for jobs. Since the start of the year, for example, Fingerhut, SBC Communications and WorldCom all closed call centers here, eliminating a total of about 1,800 jobs, and Bear, Stearns closed a technology office that employed another 140 people. 
The effect is obvious at A. J. O'Neal & Associates, a local staffing company with three offices around Tampa. The number of people who have walked through the company's doors looking for work has more than doubled recently, from about 20 each week to about 45, Denise R. Sutton, the company president, said.
Other recruiters said people even stream into temp-agency offices on Thursdays and Fridays, days that were quiet last year because job seekers had either found an assignment or decided to wait until the following week.
"The economy has taken a turn, and employers are looking to get more experience for less money," said Dana Kozloski, a 25-year-old who completed her M.B.A. at the University of Tampa after being laid off by a health insurance company last year. 
Ms. Kozloski has registered with a staffing company in the hope of landing a temporary job that would lead to a permanent job paying at least $35,000, the salary she was making in her last job. So far, though, she has had to settle for working as a nanny and using her air-conditioner less often, she said.
One 37-year-old woman said she had made $80,000 a year when working in the human resources department of an accounting firm in Chicago but has been unable to find a job paying $50,000 here. In the meantime, she is earning $12 an hour -- the equivalent of $24,000 a year -- doing a six-month project for a medical laboratory.
"I don't mind taking a step backward, but I'm not going to take four or five steps backward," said the woman, who asked not to be identified because she thought it would hamper her job search.
The effects have also started to spread to Hillborough County's main unemployment-benefits office, on the north side of Tampa, near the Busch Gardens amusement park. Because more people are coming to the office for help in finding a job, job seekers are no longer seen individually when they first arrive. Instead, a government employee gives tours of the office's computers and other resources to groups of about a dozen people at a time, Kym Bandy, who runs the offices, said.
On May 8, 500 people showed up for an all-day job fair at which companies were trying to fill 50 jobs. Coca-Cola did not bring enough applications for the many people in line to fill out, so an employee of the benefits office made copies. 
Besides increasing the supply of temporary workers, the recent layoffs have also reduced the demand for such jobs as companies cut their temporary work forces as well.
Tech Data, a computer company in nearby Clearwater, said in March that it would lay off all of its temporary workers but none of its permanent workers. Instead, it would ask the permanent employees to cut costs by reducing travel and taking the free pens and paper when they stayed in hotels, as The St. Petersburg Times first reported. 
Quality Distribution, a trucking company here, which relied on about 50 temps a year ago, is down to about 15 now. "For the first time in a long time, when we advertise, we just get an overwhelming response," said Barb Keslinke, the company's vice president for human resources. "We get people who are clearly overqualified for the types of positions we're recruiting for."
Many temporary employees, for their part, said they were struggling even to find good jobs for which they can apply. "Everybody I apply to says the same thing: 'June or July. We're going to start hiring in June or July,' " said Jarib A. Rodriguez, who was laid off from his job as a real estate assessor and is now trying to get a temporary job. "I can't wait until June or July."

HEADLINE: Bleak Statistics Tarnish Nevada's Glitter 

BYLINE:  By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS, May 12 

 BODY:
In this town of neon rainbows, where money gushes, time stands still and dreams endure despite the obvious odds, it is easy enough to think of Nevada as an adult version of Oz, and Las Vegas as its glittering Emerald City. But statistical realities in the nation's fastest-growing state are sepia-toned and stark.
 Pick almost any index of social well-being, and Nevada ranks at or near the very bottom of the 50 states, though it ranks near the top in personal wealth. Besides having the highest suicide rate (almost twice the national average), Nevada has the highest adult smoking rate and the highest death rate from smoking, the highest percentage of teenagers who are high-school dropouts, the highest teenage pregnancy rate and the highest rate of firearm deaths. 
 Nevada ranked 45th among the states for overall health last year, just above states like West Virginia and Arkansas, according to rankings compiled by United Health Group, a Minnesota-based health care company. 
Over the last 11 years, Nevada has scored between 43rd and 50th in the group's rankings, because of its rate of smoking, lack of health insurance and premature death rate, among other problems.
"You name it, we got it," said Bill Thompson, a professor of public administration at the University of Nevada-Las Vegas and an expert on the state's reigning industry, gambling. "It's no accident that the state that relies on the gaming industry as its essential economy has all these problems. We attract people, many in a positive way, but many in a negative way, people that are down and out and looking for a second chance, third chance. Vegas seems to promise another chance, but people who haven't made it elsewhere usually don't make it here."
The notion of Nevada as the last stop for life's unlucky gamblers is as old as the silver miners and as current as "Leaving Las Vegas," but public officials and health experts say the explanation for the state's low rankings on a range of problems is complex. New Jersey, where gambling is also a major industry, has the nation's lowest suicide rate, for example.
In Nevada, these experts say, a long legacy of low-tax, libertarian government, rural isolation and a steely tradition of self-reliance have combined with a population growth of more than 60 percent in the last decade that has left little sense of community to create a huge range of challenges to the state's mental and physical health.
Nevada has long been dogged by poor health rankings, but officials say that growth has made it even harder to attack underlying causes, since scarce public resources must go to treatment, rather than prevention. And though the state ranks relatively high in personal wealth, (its estimated per capita income of $18,795 in 1997, the last year for which data are available, ranked 12th in the nation), that has not translated into public expenditures.
"There's very little tradition of investment in public health or prevention," said Dr. Mary Guinan, the state's chief health officer who left a career as a pioneering AIDS researcher at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta to take her civil service job in Carson City, the state capital, two and a half years ago. "Some federal agency rates you on your investment in prevention, and Nevada was recently 50 of 50 states. There's very little investment in this, and people don't want big government, so this is what you get."
Indeed, Nevadans, content to rely on the $600 million a year in taxes and fees generated by gambling (about 40 percent of the state budget, with sales tax accounting for another 40 percent), pay no state income tax and relatively low property taxes compared with neighboring states like California. A flight attendant for Southwest Airlines bade a cheery farewell to a planeload of travelers from Los Angeles this week by saying, "Welcome to Lost Wages, and thanks for paying our Nevada taxes!"
Conservatives are quick to argue that social pathologies like suicide and smoking are not caused by low taxes or limited government, and that government's ability to solve them may be limited, too.
"There is a very strong political move afoot to increase spending in the state, and that's been rather universal in high growth states," said Stephen Slivinski, a fiscal policy analyst at the Cato Institute in Washington, which gave Nevada's Republican governor, Kenny Guinn, one of only two A's on its recent fiscal report card on the states. "My general concern is that they are not looking for more innovative solutions, a broader, less government-centered approach. There's a limit to what government can do, and it may very well be magnified by the fact that some of these pathologies go well beyond bureaucratic ability to effect change."
In the case of suicide, getting adequate data has been the first challenge. For reasons that are not entirely clear, suicide rates are generally higher west of the Mississippi River, and the eight states of the intermountain West -- Nevada, Colorado, Montana, Wyoming, Idaho, Utah, New Mexico and Arizona -- are all in the top 10. Experts suggest a range of causes, from isolation and depression in rural areas, to easy access to guns.
"There is a western culture that blends self-reliance into day-to-day management of one's life," said Dr. John Fildes, a surgeon who heads the trauma unit at the University of Nevada Medical Center here and is in the middle of a three-year study on suicide prevention financed by a $1.5 million grant from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. "And sometimes, people can see only one option: ending that life."
In 1999, the last year for which data are available, the suicide rate in Nevada was 20.1 deaths per 100,000 people, almost double the national rate of 11.4. But the rate was highest, 25.6 deaths per 100,000, in the rest of the state outside Clark and Washoe Counties, home to the two biggest cities, Las Vegas and Reno. Roughly 95 percent of those who kill themselves here are Nevada residents, not outsiders who come here just to die.
Dr. Fildes's study is trying to get better information about why people attempt suicide here, and to develop a statewide surveillance system for tracking suicides and attempts. The effort is complicated in rural counties, which may be geographically the size of Rhode Island or Connecticut with populations of just a few thousand.
Gambling, by itself, does not seem to be a dominant factor in driving the suicide rate, Dr. Fildes said. "If you consider gambling to be one of the addictive behaviors, like alcohol or drugs, all addictive behaviors are risk factors for suicide, but as an isolated behavior it doesn't appear to explain it," he said.
Other problems are equally puzzling. Dr. Guinan, the state health officer, said she cannot fathom why Nevada has the highest smoking rate among women, for example, which drives its overall rate to the highest in the nation. She noted that in the 90's, the rapid increase in the state's population was often not fully reflected in population estimates that were used to derive per capita rates for various problems, so Nevada often looked even worse than it should have compared with other states.
But even after adjusting for new population figures, Dr. Guinan acknowledged, Nevada is still at the bottom of many lists.
"We have no comprehensive tobacco prevention program in our state," she said. "In places like California with strong anti-smoking efforts, it's been shown that rates have fallen dramatically. Even our share of the national tobacco settlement money didn't go into prevention per se, but into scholarships."
Dr. Guinan also noted that Nevada has the strictest tobacco "pre-emption" law, which bars localities from enacting any anti-smoking regulations stricter than the statewide standards, which are lenient in a state where casinos, hotels and restaurants are full of the smell of secondhand smoke and businesses are not required to provide no-smoking areas.
But in other areas, Dr. Guinan said, the state compares favorably. It was one of the first to match federal spending for drug assistance to AIDS patients and has among the lowest sexually transmitted disease rates. Its playgrounds were recently rated the safest in a national study. Last year, after an intense battle, the state moved to fluoridate its drinking water for the first time.
Perhaps the biggest challenge for advocacy groups is galvanizing public attention and political support in a state where population turnover has been so rapid.
"We have 10,000 people moving into Las Vegas a month and roughly 5,000 moving out, so lack of community and lack of connection to one another is a huge factor," said Bob Fulkerson, state director of the Progressive Leadership Alliance of Nevada, an umbrella lobbying group of 45 liberal organizations from civil rights groups to organized labor. "This is the wild, wild West. The feeling is if you can't pull yourself up by your bootstraps, then it's your own damn fault. Combine that with the high turnover in population and you get a state whose political leaders don't want to provide the social services we need."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Bridgestone Disputes Need For a Broader Tire Recall
Bridgestone/Firestone lashed out at Ford Motor for having concluded that there are problems with Firestone tires that were not covered by the recall last August.
 "Let me state categorically -- tires supplied to Ford Motor Company, and other customers, are safe, and the tires are not defective," John T. Lampe, Bridgestone/Firestone's chairman, said in a letter to Jacques A. Nasser, Ford's chief executive. Page C2. 

A Huge Jump in U.S. Trade Deficit
The United States trade deficit expanded widely in March, to $31.17 billion from a revised $26.86 billion in February. Imports, led by a $2.8 billion increase for consumer goods, rose to $120.64 billion, while exports fell to $89.46 billion. The monthly increase in the trade deficit was the largest in nine years. C3.

U.S. Points to Oil Refinery Pollution
At least half of the country's 152 oil refineries are believed to be violating air-pollution laws, federal officials say, but with the refineries nearing capacity, the Bush administration is debating how hard to crack down. A1.

Exxon and Shell Lead Development
Exxon Mobil and Royal Dutch Shell led a group of eight oil companies that will take part in a $25 billion gas development program in Saudi Arabia, the biggest opening of its oil and gas industry to outsiders since the 1970's. C2.

Finger-Pointing in California's Woes
In the effort to determine what -- or who -- is at fault for soaring natural gas prices in California, Southern California Edison, one of the chief finger-pointers, is now also blaming Southern California Gas. C3.

It is planting season in Nebraska and talk about rising gas prices has farmers concerned about going further in the hole. A10.

De Beers Buyout Is Approved
Almost unanimously, shareholders approved a sweetened bid to turn De Beers into a private company with fewer formal obligations to report on its business. The $18.7 billion buyout by Nicholas Oppenheimer, left, chairman of De Beers, and his family, and Anglo American, the huge mining company, represented one of the most significant corporate shifts in South African history. C2.

Brazil Orders 20% Cut in Power Use
Faced with a rapidly worsening energy crisis that threatens to cripple Latin America's largest economy, the Brazilian government ordered consumers and businesses to cut electricity consumption by 20 percent or prepare for California-style blackouts. A4.

Nevada Comes Up Short in Rankings
It is easy enough to think of Nevada as an adult version of Oz, and Las Vegas as its glittering Emerald City. But statistical realities in the nation's fastest-growing state are sepia-toned and stark. Pick almost any index of social well-being, and Nevada ranks at or near the very bottom of the 50 states, though it ranks near the top in personal wealth. A1.

AremisSoft Shares Off Nearly 10%
Shares of AremisSoft skidded nearly 10 percent in reaction to articles critical of it. C3.

Hyundai Unit Approves Equity Swap
Hyundai Engineering and Construction, the parent of the Hyundai conglomerate, moved a step closer to total separation from the group by approving a plan to swap equity for $1.08 billion of its debts. The plan gives the company's creditors control of the company. C2.

VeriSign Awarded Internet Contract
The Commerce Department approved a new contract between the organization that oversees the Internet's address system and VeriSign, the company that once held a monopoly over the system. C3.

AUTODESK STOCK FALLS 11% AFTER WARNING ON PROFIT

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
 Autodesk Inc.'s shares fell 11 percent yesterday after the company, a maker of design software for architects, said its second-quarter earnings would not meet analysts' estimates. The shares fell $4.02, to $33.60. 
Autodesk is selling less to large corporate customers in the United States and Europe, who have reduced spending because of the slowing economy, said Steve Cakebread, Autodesk's chief financial officer. Some are waiting for new products to be released, he said. The company, which is based in San Rafael, Calif., said late Thursday that it expected earnings, excluding certain charges, of 40 cents to 50 cents a share for the quarter ending in July, below the 56 cents expected by analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home; 
Africa On the Agenda

BYLINE:  By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: BOSTON 

 BODY:
Secretary of State Colin Powell leaves on Tuesday for five days in Africa, visiting Mali in West Africa, South Africa, and Kenya and Uganda in the east. The tour of the huge continent is a considerable commitment at a time of stress in the Middle East and elsewhere. Why is he doing it? I asked the secretary that in a telephone interview. 
 "I have a personal interest because I am an African-American," he said. "But beyond that, perhaps the greatest disaster on earth is unfolding in Africa: AIDS. So it seemed to me that I should go to Africa early on." 
 The AIDS crisis is going to be a, perhaps the, dominant subject on the trip. Of the 36 million people in the world who have H.I.V. or full-blown AIDS, more than two-thirds are in sub-Saharan Africa. There are already 11 million AIDS orphans there, and that number is expected to triple within the next 10 years or so. 
"The heart of the next generation is threatened," Secretary Powell said, "people in their 20's and 30's. Because of the general lack of sufficient health care, the AIDS epidemic is liable to open the way for other diseases, like malaria and tuberculosis. But it's not just a health crisis. It's economic, it's social, it's a crisis of democracy.
"We've been talking lately about treatment, getting the drugs to people. But we don't want to lose focus on prevention. The great humanitarian necessity is to get the young generation to protect themselves." 
AIDS will be both an urgent and a ticklish subject in Secretary Powell's talks with President Thabo Mbeki of South Africa, which has more AIDS victims than any other country. President Mbeki set back anti-AIDS efforts there by questioning the accepted scientific view that H.I.V. causes AIDS. Even though that issue has now been put aside, his government has been reluctant to use drugs of proven effectiveness in preventing the transmission of AIDS from mothers to babies.
Giving up a legal battle in South Africa, the major international drug companies have agreed to make drugs available at very low prices. But there are still daunting obstacles to the use of those drugs on the scale needed, including the lack of adequate health infrastructures to administer complex dosages. 
Kofi Annan, secretary general of the U.N., has said it will take $7 billion to $10 billion a year in new money to carry out a realistic fight against the worldwide epidemic. Last week President Bush offered $200 million to that new global fund. The amount was immediately criticized as far too small, even derisory.
Secretary Powell seemed to bristle at that criticism. "I think the president should be congratulated, not criticized," he said. "If you add up all we're doing on AIDS, it comes to well over $700 million. The $200 million was a way to get started on the global trust fund. It's like starting an investment fund, and we're going to go on investing." 
Another difficult subject in the talks with President Mbeki will be neighboring Zimbabwe, where President Robert Mugabe has sent thugs to harass businesses as well as opposition politicians and the economy is in ruins. Asked what the United States could do there, General Powell said, "We can lend our good offices, but regional leaders must take the lead." 
The military conflicts that are ravaging parts of Africa will come up in several stops. Among those conflicts are the brutal civil wars in Sierra Leone and Sudan. Secretary Powell will meet representatives of nonprofit groups that try to get food to the starving in southern Sudan. 
Angola's bloody conflict is now 25 years old, and the rebel Jonas Savimbi is still terrorizing civilians. Henry Kissinger and other American conservatives helped put Mr. Savimbi on the map by supporting him as "anti-Communist," though he has always been interested only in power for himself. He now buys arms with illegally mined diamonds. I asked Secretary Powell if he would act to end the conflict. "I'm certainly going to try," he said. 
The Bush administration may not have been expected to pay great attention to Africa, but it has made a point of doing so. President Bush met with African diplomats in the White House Rose Garden this week and announced a summit meeting of African democracies in October. 
Skeptics may see American politics as one reason for the interest in Africa. I prefer to see a chance for this country, especially Colin Powell, to help resolve the profound problems afflicting that vast continent.

HEADLINE: A Gathering Storm in the Mideast 

 BODY:
Whatever illusions the Bush administration may entertain about a more detached American role in the Middle East should be erased by the rapidly escalating violence in the region, including yesterday's deadly terrorist bombing in Israel and the retaliatory Israeli air strikes. Only assertive, sustained American diplomacy is likely to keep the conflict from turning into a ruinous ordeal for both Israelis and Palestinians and a damaging setback to American interests in the region. Secretary of State Colin Powell, who is planning to travel to Africa and Europe later this month, should add the Middle East to his itinerary to see if he can at least persuade the two sides to diminish or end the bloodshed. 
 At this point, Israel and the Palestinians are engaged in a limited but ferocious state of warfare that grows in intensity by the week, hardening animosities and playing into the hands of those on both sides who favor the use of force. Recent weeks have brought a new level of killing, including the brutal assault on two Israeli teenagers who were beaten to death with stones, and a seemingly misplaced Israeli attack that killed five Palestinian officers as they were preparing a late dinner at a Palestinian outpost. 
 Yesterday's suicide bombing outside a shopping mall in the coastal town of Natanya killed at least five Israelis and wounded scores of others. The bomber was identified as a 21-year-old Palestinian grocery clerk from Tulkarem in the West Bank, not far from Netanya. For the first time since the 1967 war, Israel used warplanes to attack the West Bank and Gaza. The raids on Palestinian security headquarters in Ramallah and Nablus left at least nine Palestinians dead.
This dynamic must somehow be broken so Prime Minister Ariel Sharon and Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, can move from combat to negotiation. The United States is the only nation with sufficient influence in both camps to ease the tensions. Public calls for restraint and private telephone calls to Middle East leaders by President Bush and General Powell can help, but more active engagement is needed now. It may be inconvenient for the White House to fix its attention on the Middle East at a moment when taxes, the budget and domestic energy issues dominate the Washington agenda, but a diplomatic initiative today could help avoid a foreign crisis that seizes control of Mr. Bush's calendar. 
If the guns can be silenced, there is a basis for renewed peace talks. Jordan and Egypt have offered a peace plan that contains elements attractive to both sides. Next week an international panel led by former Senator George Mitchell will publish a report on the conflict that the Sharon government and the Palestinians have broadly endorsed, though disagreements remain on several important points. One of them is whether Israel, as the Mitchell report proposes, should suspend plans to enlarge existing settlements on the West Bank. Mr. Sharon has agreed not to build new settlements, but he is committed to expanding those already in place as their populations grow.
No president can afford to let the Middle East descend into turmoil. Protecting the welfare of Israel has been a central American commitment since the Jewish state was founded during the Truman administration. All presidents since then have tried to overcome the hostilities in the region, well aware that turbulence and military conflict in and around Israel can ripple through the region, creating instability, slowing economic progress and threatening to disrupt the flow of oil to the West. Mr. Bush must do no less.

HEADLINE: Energy Crisis Levels California Political Playing Field 

BYLINE:  By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 18 

 BODY:
Six months ago, there were few states so dominated by a single party and a single politician as California. Gov. Gray Davis and the Democrats controlled the government to such a degree that the demoralized Republicans could only nod quietly in approval when Mr. Davis dictated that everyone support his top three priorities, all of them, as he liked to say, education.
 Today, not only has the energy crisis replaced schools as the public's top concern but a new survey also shows that Mr. Davis's approval rating has tumbled even before a summer that is destined to bring soaring energy bills and rolling blackouts. The energy crisis may be bad for the state, but it has energized the Republicans in a way that no one here dreamed possible until now. 
 "There's no question things have changed for us in what you could call a favorable direction," said Dave Cox, a state assemblyman who heads the Republican caucus. "We do see an opportunity now that we didn't have before, and I want to make clear that we think we have the wrong governor in the wrong place at the moment."
According to a survey released this morning by the nonpartisan Public Policy Institute of California, Mr. Davis' approval rating has dropped to 46 percent from 63 percent in January, the first time it has fallen below 50 percent since he was elected in November 1998.
Strikingly, President Bush's approval rating among Californians is higher, the survey said, at 57 percent, in spite of Mr. Davis's claims that the president is partly at fault for the state's energy problems.
"This crisis is emerging in the public's mind as a bitter, partisan issue," said Mark Baldassare, the survey's director. "There is no sense that this is an emergency that is pulling people together. Davis is taking a hit for the problems, and the president is not."
The survey, conducted by telephone among 2,001 Californians from May 1 to May 9, has a sampling error of plus or minus 2 percent.
Perhaps its most worrisome finding was a sense of pessimism in the state. For the first time since the last recession in the early 1990's, the survey found, more Californians see the state moving in the wrong direction than in the right direction, 48 percent to 44 percent. In January, 62 percent thought the state was moving in the right direction.
This morning, Mr. Davis took what was perceived as a clear political step by bringing on board two former advisers to Al Gore; Mark Fabiani, Mr. Gore's deputy campaign manager, as a consultant on communications, and Nancy McFadden, Mr. Gore's former deputy chief of staff, to handle negotiations between his office and federal and state agencies.
Those announcements were followed in short order with another denunciation by Mr. Davis of President Bush for not ordering caps on wholesale power prices. Mr. Davis also assailed his predecessors for not encouraging construction of enough power plants.
The day before Mr. Davis also criticized the president for not ordering prompt refunds by the power generating companies for overcharging Californians. And he and his aides have blamed Republicans in the Legislature for frustrating his program to resolve the crisis.
"The Republican Party in this state is at its lowest ebb in generations," said Steve Maviglio, the governor's spokesman. "They think there's a political payoff in letting the governor fail at this. We think they're wrong."
But Mr. Davis's opponents say it is the governor who is doing most of the finger pointing. "He spends more time placing blame than on solutions," Mr. Cox said. 
Whether the energy crisis will threaten Mr. Davis's expected bid for re-election next year remains to be seen, but a race that was expected to be all but moribund now looks, at the least, like it will be lively.
According to the survey, while Mr. Davis's overall standing has fallen, residents do not directly blame him for the electricity shortages. Thirty-two percent blamed the utility companies, 26 percent blamed the former governor and Legislature, and just 10 percent blamed Mr. Davis and the current Legislature.
But the Republicans have clearly sensed an opening that did not exist before. "We are always looking for opportunities to take statewide offices, and this may be one," Mr. Cox said.
The actor Arnold Schwarzenegger dropped out of the nascent gubernatorial race after the publication of some unflattering articles about his personal life, but two other Republicans have announced bids and others are clearly considering runs. The Republican secretary of state, Bill Jones, has announced his candidacy, and William Simon Jr., a wealthy businessman who has never held public office, is planning a $1,000-a-plate fund-raiser.
Mayor Richard J. Riordan of Los Angeles and Peter Ueberroth, the former baseball commissioner and head of the 1984 Los Angeles Olympics, have been mentioned as potential Republican contenders. Neither has said he would consider a run, but the rumors show that the party is searching for a recognizable personality.
Even within the Democratic Party there is talk of a challenge, potentially from the state treasurer, Phil Angelides, or the attorney general, Bill Lockyer, even though neither has commented on a run.
"I think the governor is vulnerable and the sharks are in the water, even in his own party," said Bill Campbell, the former chairman of the Republican caucus in the Assembly. "Things can change in a hurry."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A California poll finds Gov. Gray Davis's approval rating tumbling. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Tax Analysts See Big Gains For Top 1% Of Taxpayers 

BYLINE:  By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
Under the tax cut plans now moving through Congress, the tax breaks for the wealthiest Americans gain value over time while most of the breaks for everyone else lose value, according to both supporters and critics of these plans.
 Tax analysts say the plans include some protections and favorable provisions affecting the top 1 percent of all earners that do not extend to the other 99 percent. A significant portion of the tax breaks for those not at the top come in the form of tax credits, whose value diminishes with inflation. 
 But the analysts also note that most tax cuts become more favorable to the wealthy over time, since all of their increased income is subject to lower rates. 
Several provisions that preserve or enhance the value of tax breaks for the very wealthy are common to both the House tax plan, which President Bush supports, and the plan developed in the Senate. Under both plans, virtually all taxpayers would receive larger tax cuts every year for the coming decade as more of the cuts are phased in. The Senate, however, would give less to top earners than the House would.
Critics of these plans say the administration designed them to further reward the wealthy over the long run. As John Buckley, the chief tax adviser to House Democrats, put it, "They are using inflation to take away a lot of things from everyone not at the top."
In response, Claire Buchan, a White House spokeswoman, said that the Bush tax cuts do not favor the wealthy. "The president's plan is aimed at helping people disproportionately in the lower brackets," she said. "On the whole this plan is targeted toward working families."
For those already in the 39.6 percent bracket, which applies to the top 1 percent of taxpayers, nearly every dollar of additional income, whether from higher earnings or the results of inflation, would be taxed at a lower rate. The rate would fall to 36 percent under the Senate bill or 33 percent under the House bill, though the lower rates would be phased in over 10 years.
Both bills would also create a new 10 percent tax bracket for the first $12,000 of taxable income for a married couple, or $6,000 for singles. These sums are now taxed at 15 percent. But the 10 percent rate would be phased in slowly, taking full effect only in 2007, with no inflation adjustment until then. 
The delays and the lack of an immediate inflation adjustment make this tax break worth less than it appears. For all married couples, the Senate version of this tax cut has a nominal value of $600 a year, or $3,600 in all, from now through 2006. But inflation of 3 percent, the usual assumption among tax analysts, would reduce the real value to $3,340. The House version, phasing in the rate reduction more slowly, would be worth just $2,328.
Under both bills, the child tax credit, which President Bush wants to double to $1,000 a child, loses value in two ways.
First, the full credit would not be available until 2011 under the Senate version of the bill, which is expected to face a vote on Monday. It would then be worth just $737 in today's dollars. The House would provide the full credit in 2006, when it would be worth $859.
Second, the income limits to qualify for the child credit are not indexed for inflation. The ceiling for the full credit is $110,000 in both bills, the equivalent of $81,100 in today's dollars if the full credit is available in 2011, or $94,500 if it is available in 2006. Several million families who would appear to qualify because they make less than $110,000 today would therefore not get the full credit.
The Senate bill, unlike the House version, allows the working poor to claim a portion of the child credit even if they pay no income taxes. The Senate bill, however, includes what amounts to a reverse inflation adjustment, to make sure that inflationary income gains do not help the working poor qualify for larger child tax credits. 
The child tax credit would not otherwise be adjusted for inflation before or after taking full effect in 2011. But the Senate would provide full inflation protection for a tax break pertaining to repeal of the estate tax, which applies only to the wealthiest 2 percent of Americans.
Congress is poised to phase out the estate tax, as urged by President Bush, and also provide a limited exemption from capital-gains taxes. Beginning in 2011, Americans would be able to leave $1.3 million to heirs and $3 million to surviving spouses, free of capital-gains taxes. The delay would make these benefits worth 26 percent less than their value in today's dollars. 
The Senate version of the tax cut provides for inflation protection on these tax breaks beginning in 2012, so that the amounts shielded from capital gains taxes would rise each year.
The tax cut provisions for pensions and retirement savings also have inflation protections that would primarily benefit those with high incomes. The Senate bill, in particular, would index a variety of 401(k) and other retirement savings plans for inflation, allowing the wealthy to put more money away while avoiding or deferring taxes.
The Senate bill would also provide, beginning next year, a tax credit intended to get the working poor to save for retirement, subject to income limits that would not be adjusted for inflation.
That may not be especially significant, however, because, unless Congress extends it, the credit would end on Dec. 31, 2006.

HEADLINE: The Energy Plan: Points of Light, and Heat 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "In Energy Plan, Bush Urges New Drilling, Conservation and Nuclear Power Review" (front page, May 17):
 President Bush's suggestion that money from the proposed tax cut can be used to adjust to rising energy prices is troubling. 
 Now we have a third rationale for the tax cut. The first was that the budget surplus belonged to the people and should be given back. 
The second was that there was an impending recession and that the tax cut would improve consumer confidence and stimulate spending.
Now he says that the tax cut can be used to help us cope with higher energy prices. This suggests that he either has difficulty with the math, since this tax cut cannot possibly be spread across so many different areas, or that he is beholden to special interests that prevent the proposal of viable energy solutions that will benefit the majority of the people.

DEAN MCKAY
Port Washington, N.Y., May 17, 2001

HEADLINE: THE CLOSE READER; 
Lord, Won't You Buy Me a Mercedes-Benz?

BYLINE:  By Judith Shulevitz 

 BODY:
Our text today is "The Prayer of Jabez: Breaking Through to the Blessed Life." This inexpensive, shirt-pocket-size volume (Multnomah Publishers, $9.99) has sold more than four million copies in the past year, and is the best-selling book in America right now. It has attracted a prodigious following among people who have chosen to repeat every day the one-sentence prayer that gives the book its title. ("Oh, that you would bless me indeed, and enlarge my territory, that your hand would be with me, and that you would keep me from evil, that I may not cause pain!") Jabez enthusiasts have risen up in churches and private homes and on the Prayer of Jabez Web site (www.prayerofjabez.com) to testify to the changes the sentence has wrought in their lives. National publications have made note; experts have been consulted; videos have been made; a sequel has been published, and others, including "The Prayer of Jabez for Teens" and "The Prayer of Jabez for Women," have been commissioned. "The Prayer of Jabez" has also been taken up by the mighty. The author, an Atlanta-based evangelical minister named Bruce Wilkinson, who was one of the leaders of the Promise Keepers movement, was recently invited to the White House. 
 What makes "The Prayer of Jabez" so appealing? The easy answer is that the book differs slightly from other how-to guides. Wilkinson has resurrected the once ubiquitous and now mostly forgotten genre of the published Sunday sermon. "The Prayer of Jabez" follows the rules that have governed American preaching since the Puritans came to the New World. It contains Scripture, doctrine and a practical application of both. The style is plain but fiery. 
 The Scripture consists of two verses from the Old Testament book of I Chronicles, a little-studied text otherwise made up of tedious genealogical lists. Wilkinson reads the verses closely and cleverly. They tell the story of an Israelite commoner whose mother gave him the unhappy name of Jabez, which the Bible tells us comes from "pain." (This is a folk etymology; the name is actually an inversion of the letters in the Hebrew word for pain.) Despite his inauspicious start in life, Jabez begs God "to enlarge his territories" and winds up being "more honorable than his brothers." 
That is all we know about him, but for Wilkinson's purposes, we don't need to know more. Jabez's obscurity, textually and socially, makes him an ideal vehicle for the traditional American Christian narrative of conversion and redemption. Jabez is a biblical everyman, vaguely discontented with his lot and ripe for a turn toward God. As Wilkinson puts it: "Things started badly for a person no one had ever heard of. He prayed an unusual, one-sentence prayer. Things ended extraordinarily well."
Wilkinson breaks Jabez's prayer into four parts and turns them into steps to be taken toward the good life. And then -- this is the point at which he turns a little snake-oil salesmanish -- he promises that if you take the steps, results will be yours within days. 
Those steps require remarkably little effort. If you ask for God's blessing (Step 1), he will enlarge your territory -- that is, in the modern American context, grant you success (Step 2). Wilkinson defines success in different ways at different points in the book. Sometimes it seems to consist in being a skillful evangelist. That's how Wilkinson measures his own success -- in numbers of converts and the speed at which he converts them. For other people success manifests itself in wealth and worldly esteem. "If Jabez had worked on Wall Street," Wilkinson writes, "he might have prayed, 'Lord, increase the value of my investment portfolios.' "
Because of remarks like these, Wilkinson has been accused of preaching prosperity theology. This is a serious charge, since the phrase is more commonly associated with the teachings of ministers who grow fat off the pennies of the poor. (The Rev. Jerry Falwell, for instance, once called the disgraced televangelists Jim and Tammy Faye Bakker prosperity theologians.) Wilkinson denies the charge, and it does seem a crude way to characterize "The Prayer of Jabez." Though the prayer certainly enjoys brand extension, it is a prayer, not a con game or a pyramid scheme. Wilkinson has a revival-meeting manner that makes it seem as if he's offering a tit-for-tat with God -- you pray to him; he'll make you rich -- but he also says that the Jabez prayer requires an acceptance of God's will whatever its form, not the presentation of an itemized demand. 
On the other hand, Wilkinson makes God's will awfully easy to accept, since he says God wants us to be successful. Indeed, Step 3, Wilkinson says, is to realize that God wants us to take entrepreneurial risks, to pile on more than we think we can handle. If we truly believe in him, he'll back us up. (In Jabez-speak, his hand will be with us.) Is it really God's business to help us avert bankruptcy? Wilkinson says yes. God doesn't want you to fail. He empowers because he is power itself. In fact, the reason to avoid sin (Step 4) is that it separates you from his energy current: "It is as if the electric lines to your house in Phoenix were severed and you were cut off from the immense power generators at Hoover Dam." 
A God who diverts his awesome supernatural force for the sole purpose of giving a jump-start to your personal and professional development may seem disconcertingly crass. But a deity who sounds like a motivational speaker at a business luncheon may also be the right deity for an era when megachurches sprawl across the land and more traditional houses of worship are going into genteel decline. The Jabez prayer grants the supplicant full access to the American cult of success, an adoration of power and material satisfaction untroubled by any sense that the world may be a tragic place or the fear that the enlargement of one's territory might leave others' diminished. That such upbeat theologies of convenience should have mass appeal is neither particular to our time -- think of Norman Vincent Peale, whose 1952 best seller, "The Power of Positive Thinking," was "The Prayer of Jabez" of its day -- nor all that deplorable. It's useful to have these ideas spelled out, rather than at work in the culture but unexamined. Many readers clearly find Wilkinson's worldview to be similar to their own. Those who don't can indulge a voyeuristic fascination with the church of what the Protestant theologian Reinhold Niebuhr, in 1950, called the American idolatry. He, however, found it disturbing. "The Gospel cannot be preached with truth and power if it does not challenge the pretensions and pride, not only of individuals, but of nations, cultures, civilizations, economic and political systems," Niebuhr wrote. "The good fortune of America and its power place it under the most grievous temptations to self-adulation."

HEADLINE: CHILDREN'S BOOKS; 
Arms and the Boy

BYLINE:  By Robin Tzannes; Robin Tzannes's books for children include "Professor Puffendorf's Secret Potions" and "Sanji and the Baker."

 BODY:
 THE BRIMSTONE JOURNALS
By Ron Koertge.
113 pp. Cambridge, Mass.:
Candlewick Press. $15.99.
(Ages 12 and up)
 In "The Brimstone Journals," the novelist and poet Ron Koertge attempts to understand the kind of school violence that has made such shocking headlines in the last few years. Presented as a series of journal entries written by 15 students at the fictional Branston (nicknamed Brimstone) High, the book paints a chilling picture of teenage life in the suburbs.
The students, for the most part confused and isolated, receive little guidance or sympathy from adults. When problems arise, their teachers, their parents and even the police prefer to look the other way, leaving them on their own. The youngsters themselves judge one another harshly, forming alliances on the basis of race, appearance, reputation and athletic ability. Their journals are filled with anger and pain. And no one is listening. 
The opening and closing entries are written by Lester, a fat boy who is mercilessly teased and sometimes beaten by the school jocks. In his journal, Lester confides that he likes to play naked with his father's gun, fantasizing about shooting the bullies who torment him. Guns are disturbingly easy to come by, and several other kids talk about them rather matter-of-factly. The most frightening of them is Boyd, a deeply troubled and lonely boy who begins plotting to destroy his enemies.
Alternately abused and neglected by his alcoholic father, Boyd falls easy prey to Mike, a psychopathic gas station attendant who appears seemingly out of nowhere. When Mike instructs Boyd to gather "foot soldiers," his first recruit is poor fat Lester. Reluctantly, Lester joins Boyd in the hope of getting the bullies off his back. Meanwhile, Boyd and Mike are building an arsenal of weapons and making a hit list.
As the suspense builds, other journal entries give us hope. Unexpected friendships form, a new group starts to play music together, and some of the students begin to understand and support one another. 
Meredith, a sexually promiscuous and sophisticated girl, befriends Lester and persuades him to tell the police about Boyd's plan. The police, skeptical at first, finally investigate; they discover Boyd's arsenal, and tragedy is averted. In the happy aftermath, parents start listening to their teenagers, counselors arrive at the school, and the students finally get the guidance and attention they so desperately need. For Boyd, however, it is too late, and we last see him being led away in handcuffs.
"The Brimstone Journals" is remarkable for its density. Through the very spare and economical text we come to know these 15 children and their lives, and the subplots are surprisingly intricate for such a slim book. While many of the portraits ring true, arousing our interest and compassion, there are some glaring stereotypes that will make readers groan in disbelief.
WHATEVER one may think of the characters, the events in this book are all too believable. In recent years, we have seen administrators adopting "zero tolerance" policies in reaction to school shootings and suspending innocent students for pretending a chicken finger is a gun, or for making harmless lists of people they like or dislike. Koertge, whose other novels include "Where the Kissing Never Stops" and "The Arizona Kid," suggests that we look beyond the guns and the hit lists, and simply listen to our children. Parents and teachers need to know what their children are thinking, and what's happening in their lives. At the same time, young people need to trust and accept one another.
Though I suspect most teenagers will find this novel a little corny, "The Brimstone Journals," if read by youngsters and adults together, might be just the catalyst they need to open an important and meaningful dialogue. It's certainly worth a try.

HEADLINE: STRUCTURES; 
The Braided Bunch

BYLINE:  By Mary Tannen 

 BODY:
It is an art that has been immortalized in African sculpture for centuries, and yet each work is ephemeral, meant to last a day, a weekend, a week or two at most. Historically, the configuration of coils and curls is a language indicating tribe, marital status, wealth and occasion. In Nigeria in the 50's, the photographer J. D. 'Okhai Ojeikere noticed that the hairdos were disappearing, giving way to glossy wigs. Then, just as suddenly as they started to vanish, they came back, but the language had altered. It was less tied to rural tradition, more in tune with urban life. Jazzy towers of braids mimicked the first skyscrapers in Lagos. There were swirls and spikes, symmetry and asymmetry. Realizing that this evanescent art could vanish again, Ojeikere began documenting it. And last year, his portfolio -- J. D. 'Okhai Ojeikere/Photographs" -- was published by Scalo. 
 African styles are now becoming global, appearing everywhere, on heads of all races. The geometry of these styles is built on a variety of techniques. Sometimes hair is plaited close to the scalp in a pattern of cornrows, or twisted into coils, or rolled into locks. Straight hair extensions can be braided into hair to make long shiny plaits, and wire is sometimes used to make the hair stand up. From these plaits and coils an edifice is built, secured by hairpins or needle and thread. Adornments, like feathers or beads, can be woven in. A do can take from 3 to 16 hours and cost from $45 to $700. 
 When African styles first appeared in America, some interpreted the language as one of militancy; women were even driven to file lawsuits against their employers defending their right to wear them. In time the hairdos won, and the meaning has altered, from defiant to proud. On a recent Friday afternoon, for example, all the clients at Turning Heads Beauty and Barber shop, in Harlem, which offers a full range of services including chemical relaxing, were having braids done, and a good third of them were men. According to Annu Prestonia, whose salon, Khamit Kinks, at 4 Leonard Street in TriBeCa, has dressed heads from Iman to Stevie Wonder, braids are a style whose time has come. She says that black women were so long oppressed by trying to live another aesthetic "they were afraid to swim or sweat because their straightened hair would go back." 
Thelma Golden, a director of programming at the Studio Museum in Harlem, says that braiding fits into the tradition of black body art and is "part of the rich stew of black culture." The stylist creates form, like a sculptor, yet since inspiration comes from both client and artist, and maybe the client's friend and whoever else is nearby, the hairdo is a collaborative work, similar to quilting.
As demand rose in this country, female African immigrants found in braiding a niche for entering the economy. In long, narrow storefronts on 125th Street, the stylists are almost all African and female, and the atmosphere is more African market than American hair salon. Recruiters roam the subway platform in Harlem, ready to pounce on prospective customers as they get off the train. Once a client is brought in, she chooses a style from the plastic-covered album, then sits in one of the folding chairs. Two braiders might work on her at once, chatting in French or a patois. There might be a child running around, and the smell of spicy cooking.
Whether an updo comes from an American salon or African braiding shop, it generates an Old World aura. It encourages a different gait, more measured, more regal. It demands a more studied way of dressing. It restructures demeanor, even interactions, into a new formality -- for as long as the wearer can stand to leave it in. 

GRAPHIC: Photos: These African dos are among the 110 that the Nigerian photographer J. D. 'Okhai Ojeikere documented from 1968 to 1985 and published last year. (J. D. 'Okhai Ojeikere)
