HEADLINE: Where Icebergs Are Born 

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE; JAMES BROOKE recently completed an assignment as Canada bureau chief of The Times.

 BODY:
FLYING up a fjord, our tour helicopter hovered over diving humpback whales and then skimmed low among icebergs floating in a stately stream from an unseen glacier. Over the rotor noise, our guide, Gitte Johnsen, bantered with her charges in Danish and English, throwing in a few words of her native Greenlandic.
 Then the red and white Sikorsky clattered over land, moving toward the ancient granite blocks of an abandoned Viking farmstead. Below, the treeless, brown landscape was etched with meandering caribou paths. Suddenly, Gitte switched mental gears. Lunging to a window, she raised an imaginary rifle to a gold earring and sighted down an invisible barrel at a caribou standing motionless. "Pow, pow, pow," she cried triumphantly. 
 The vision of a fat, late-summer caribou had peeled away our stylish guide's thin overlay of Copenhagen chic to reveal the hard-wired hunting instincts that for millenniums enabled humans to live in this beautiful and demanding land. 
Greenland, the world's largest island, has always floated in the northern mists of American consciousness as, well, up there. In children's geography games, spoilsports routinely deride Greenland as 85 percent covered by an ice sheet, ignoring the fact that the remaining 15 percent encompasses a land area the size of Norway, with rich cultures and glorious landscapes. But, for the last half-century, virtually the only Americans who visited Greenland were airmen, assigned to the coldest duty of the cold war. Although barely 15 miles east of Canada at the nearest point, Scandinavia's cultural colony in North America remained informally off limits to tourists from North America.
In recent years, Greenlanders have tried to build economic autonomy from Denmark, with hopes of one day attaining full political independence. Today tourism is quietly emerging as one of the island's leading industries. Attracted by pristine fjords to kayak, Viking ruins to hike, or simply icebergs to watch, about 31,000 tourists visited Greenland last year, a large number for an island that has only 56,000 inhabitants. Greenland today offers a basic tourism infrastructure of comfortable hotels, good restaurants, municipal tourism agencies and reliable air and boat service connecting coastal towns. But with Danes accounting for three-quarters of the visitors, the joys of Greenland have remained a Scandinavian secret.
Scandinavians fly from Copenhagen on direct Greenlandair flights to Narsarsuaq or Kangerlussuaq, the island's air hub, or on daily SAS flights to Kangerlussuaq, and then fly north to Ilulissat, to watch icebergs calve from glaciers. 
Every summer, Ilulissat Kangerlua, a fjord two miles south of Ilulissat, presents the spectacle of the world's largest concentration of icebergs outside of Antarctica. From a three-mile-wide glacier, 20 million tons of ice break off each day -- some into pieces as large as city blocks. 
To the south of Nuuk, the area around Narsarsuaq offers Viking ruins, including the preserved 1,000-year-old remains of Brattahlid, the hillside farm of Eric the Red, the Norwegian who led colonization of Greenland, in 986. At their peak, the Viking colonies probably numbered about 3,000 people, enough to prompt the Vatican to appoint bishops regularly for about 200 years. But in the mid-1300's, the Norse started abandoning their colonies around Nuuk, retreating southward. The last written trace of the Norse in Greenland was an Icelandic record of a Greenland marriage in 1408. Archaeologists now believe that the last Viking colonies in Greenland were abandoned around 1450.
To this day, historians argue over the mystery of the vanished Viking colonies -- whether they fell victim to plague, famine, attacks by Inuit or English pirates, or, most likely, were caught in a mini-ice age that cut off supply ships from Iceland, and destroyed Greenland's dairy economy. 
In 1721, after a three-century hiatus, a Danish king sent a missionary to Greenland, believing he would re-Christianize pagan Viking descendants. Instead, he found only Inuit. Had they lasted another 50 years, the Viking colonies could have served as supply stations for Europe's second, and more enduring, encounter with North America.
At Anavik, the Viking farmstead built at the head of a deep fjord east of Nuuk, I sat on a lichen-encrusted granite block, hewed by Viking hands almost a millennium ago. I tried to imagine managing without a windbreaker to ward off the early September chill, or the transportation convenience of a fjord-hopping tourist helicopter. Before me, a view swept down to dark waters, where bluish white icebergs floated serenely. Behind me a fiercely green meadow spread like a carpet up to the bare, rocky mountains. In this Arctic silence, a waterfall could be heard splashing half a mile away. Far below, on an alluvial beach, a cluster of tents signaled the presence of weekend caribou hunters, who had arrived by motorboat from Nuuk, threading their way through the icebergs.
Only a 90-minute jet flight across the Davis Strait separates Greenlanders from their Inuit ethnic and linguistic cousins in Arctic Canada. But different patterns of colonization have created divergent worlds. Walking down a street in Nuuk, a tidy Scandinavian-style coastal village that now markets itself as the world's Cool Capital, I tried to decipher bilingual signs, printed in both Danish and Greenlandic. Asking passers-by for directions, I frequently detected mild panic in the eyes of locals, who searched desperately for English verbs they learned in high school, but never needed to use.
FURTHER confusing visitors, Greenlanders seem to compete with the Welsh in adopting place names that are nigh impossible for outsiders to pronounce, like Ittoqqortoormiit (ee-DOH-grow-doh-meet), or "those that live where there is most peat." In full decolonization mode, Greenlanders also have abandoned the Danish names that once gave some of us a precarious toehold on their island's geography. Nuuk, for example, appeared on children's geography board games until recently as Godthab. American veterans who flew for decades into Sondre Stromfjord, near the island's southwest coast, will search maps in vain for their old base, finally finding the old airstrip under a new name, Kangerlussuaq, the international airport.
But, in an era of globalizing homogeneity, Greenland also offers a throwback to travel circa the 1970's: no CNN on hotel television, no AT&T USA Direct for cheap calls home, no easy Internet access, and people lighting up cigarettes at every turn. Greenland is one corner of the world where American influence has actually receded. 
While the American military virtually ran the island during World War II, the network of bases here has dwindled from 17 stations to one, in Thule, an electronic eavesdropping post in the far north. Contacted by telephone, taciturn United States Air Force officers made it clear that they were not pining for uninvited visitors from the home country. In Nuuk, home rule government's foreign affairs office now occupies a brown wooden cottage that, until 1953, held the offices of the last American consulate in Greenland.
As modern Greenlanders wean themselves from the generous Danish embrace, they hope to draw more tourists from North America -- Viking enthusiasts or simply those eager to explore. With no commercial flights between the United States and Greenland, the roughly 1,000 North Americans who venture to Greenland annually usually come on an Arctic cruise or via Iceland or Canada, the two North Atlantic countries with direct flights to Greenland.
Late last summer, I happened to be working in Iqaluit, so it was a quick hop on what some call "the Eskimo friendship flight" -- a weekly First Air flight between the capital of Canada's new Nunavut Territory and Kangerlussuaq. 
"I have been going for 25 years, and have never missed a year," Kenn Harper, a Canadian author and businessman, told me in Iqaluit. Referring to Nunavut, he added: "Tourism is doing better in Greenland than here." 
Once in Nuuk or Narsarsuaq, visitors who are not in a rush can forgo expensive air travel for Arctic Umiaq Line, a shipping service with two large boats and a small one that regularly link about a dozen towns from southern Greenland up the west coast. From June to mid-August, boats travel three times a week; in spring and fall, twice weekly and in winter once. The ships' slower pace allows visitors to meet local people. The frequency allows visitors to debark in a town for a few days before continuing on the next boat. Increasingly popular, the boats require reservations. (For details, see www.visitgreenland.com/aul.) 
Pressed for time, I hopped around the island via Greenlandair, the state airline, which serves 22 towns, half with fixed wing planes, half by helicopter. After landing in Kangerlussuaq from Canada, I entered Greenland without a passport check. Then, I jumped a quick Greenlandair shuttle to Nuuk, hardly a bargain at $520 round trip for an hourlong flight.
Other visitors later told me I should have stuck around. More than an old military base, Kangerlussuaq is now a base for day trips offered by the municipal tourism agency, Kangerlussuaq Tourism. The most popular is the musk ox photo safari, a 90-minute excursion that takes visitors jouncing across the brown rock landscape to see some of the 4,000 shaggy, sleepy-eyed beasts that graze locally. The agency also offers 15-mile rides to the edge of the nearest glacier, either by jeep or by Icelandic pony. From December through April, dogs pulling sleds in a fantail hitch take visitors on outings across the snow. 
In Kangerlussuaq and Nuuk, visitors may be tempted by boutiques selling elegantly cut coats and jackets made from sealskins. Americans can look but not buy, as Congress forbids United States residents to bring sealskin products into the United States. The legislation was aimed at the baby seal hunt in Canada, but it also swept up Greenland, where an estimated five million adult harp seals swim in the Davis Strait. Although seals in Greenland waters are as threatened as deer in the woods of New England, the law applies equally to them. This irks Greenlanders, who have been hunting seals for about 4,400 years.
Exhibits on sealing, kayaking, dog sledding and other facets of Greenland's cultural history can be found, with English-language texts, at the National Museum of Greenland, in Nuuk, down by the old colonial harbor. Deep in the exhibition rooms is the mummy room, a sad display of a family from the Qilaqitsoq area that died, probably in a boating accident, around 1475 A.D. Their body tattoos, hand-stitched boots and jewelry are little touched by the centuries. Outside, in the fresh air, the wharf is a good vantage point for watching whales and training by a new generation of Greenlanders skillful in the qajaq, or kayak.
A short walk from the museum are a series of restaurants that offer Greenland fare -- from herring to caribou stew. If you try the national dish, suassat, a seal meat stew often served in Greenland homes, make sure it has been fully digested before confronting United States Customs inspectors in Ottawa.
Like the Mercedes cabs at Nuuk's airport, service in restaurants can sometimes seem a little out of sync. On one hand, waiters have a Scandinavian formality that seems out of place in Nuuk, population 13,500. Then they can get distracted. During one lunch at Restaurant Nipisa, a white-tablecloth establishment, the lone waiter stayed on the telephone for 15 minutes.
As lunch stretched into two hours, I was reminded of a study conducted in the late 1990's by Danish doctors intrigued by Greenland's abnormally low heart disease rates. The doctors surveyed Greenlanders about risk factors, including stress. But, even after the word stress had been elaborately translated into Greenlandic, about one-quarter of respondents said they did not know what the doctors were talking about.
Optimists in a land synonymous elsewhere with winter gloom, Greenlanders have chosen as their national flag a red sun rising over white polar ice. Since Greenland has never had a revolution, residents chose June 21 as their national day. In this land of the midnight sun, Greenlanders focus on their longest day of the year, a day without darkness, a day without cold.

Land of glaciers is not all ice and snow

Getting There
For Americans, the easiest access to Greenland is the First Air flight I took last summer from Iqaluit to Kangerlussuaq. This flight begins every Tuesday morning in Ottawa, from which there are direct flights to and from Boston, New York and Washington, and stops in Iqaluit, then Kangerlussuaq and then Nuuk; a return trip is made every Tuesday afternoon. Information: (800) 267-1247; www.firstair.ca. 
Building on this flight, Tour Trends, (888) 318-7233), www
.tourtrends.on.ca, of Newmarket, Ontario, has developed a series of Greenland summer tours. No visas are required of Americans or Canadians.
From Iceland, Icelandair Holidays, (800) 779-2899, www.icelandair
.com, offers flights Monday through Saturday from May 29 to Sept. 29 from Reykjavik to Kulusuk, the largest village on Greenland's lightly populated eastern coast.
This summer, Icelandair will offer charter service to Ammassalik, a helicopter ride of less than 20 miles from Kulusuk; call (800) 779-2899. 
Greenlandair offers flights around the country; (299) 34 34 34; www
.greenlandair.gl.
For general information, contact the National Tourist Board of Greenland, Post Office Box 1615, DK-3900 Nuuk, Greenland; (299) 34 28 20, fax (299) 32 28 77. The Web site, www
.visitgreenland.com, has about 1,800 Web pages of English-language information on flights, hotels, sights, tours and tour operators.

Sightseeing
The one-day helicopter tour over whales and icebergs in Nuuk fjord to the Ilulissat glacier and the Viking ruins cost $238, at 8.38 Danish kroner to the dollar, and was booked at Nuuk Tourism, on the waterfront in the old port; Hans Egedesvej 29, Post Office Box 199, DK-3900 Nuuk; (299) 32 27 00, fax (299) 32 27 10; www
.nuuk-tourism.gl.
At Kangerlussuaq, the 90-minute musk ox photo safari is offered by Kangerlussuaq Tourism, DK-3910 Kangerlussuaq; telephone (299) 84 10 98, fax (299) 84 14 98; and on the Web at www.greenland-guide.gl/
kangerlussuaq/info; about $20.

Where to Stay
I stayed six nights at the 109-room Hotel Hans Egede, at 3 Aqqusinersuaq Street -- Nuuk's largest and most upscale hotel, with a sixth-floor restaurant, the Sky-Top, that affords views of the town and the harbor. In true Scandinavian style, the bathrooms come with elegant fixtures that require a few minutes of study to work. The rate for a single room, with a narrow, spartan bed, is $130; doubles from $146; the two suites are $286. Telephone (299) 32 42 22, fax (299) 32 44 87; on the Web, 
www.greenland-guide.dk/hhe.
More affordable alternatives in Nuuk include four youth hostels, a seaman's home and several bed-and-breakfasts; all can be reached through Nuuk Tourism.

Where to Eat
The Sky-Top restaurant at the Hans Egede offers a quiet atmosphere, beautiful summer sunset views and local specialties. I had tenderloin of reindeer on a bed of carrots for $23. The Greenland archaeologist I met there had roast rib of musk ox, with sauteed mushrooms and asparagus, also for $23. For reservations, call (299) 32 42 22.
Across the street and up a flight, Restaurant Nipisa, (299) 32 12 10, offers more elegant dining, often veering into Scandinavian fish and herring dishes. Though service was slow, I still came back, for the food and for the convenience. 
Cheaper lunches can be had at the airy cafeteria in the town's modern cultural center, Katuaq, on Skibshavnsvej, (299) 32 33 00. Two deli-style sandwiches with juice cost $14. 
A few blocks down from the Hans Egede Hotel, I had dinner -- pasta with three cheeses and a beer imported from Denmark -- for $11 at Rock Cafe, a self-service restaurant in the nonstop music style of a Hard Rock Cafe. JAMES BROOKE

SECTION: Section 5; Column 1; Travel Desk; Pg. 6

HEADLINE: FRUGAL TRAVELER; 
Stendhal's Florence, With E-Mail and Pucci

BYLINE:  By DAISANN McLANE 

 BODY:
I HAD no illusions about Florence: It is one of the biggest box office draws in tourism. And while my dream was to wander in silent reverie among Renaissance treasures and elegant palazzi, I knew it was more likely I'd be struck by Stendhal's syndrome in the company of busloads of tourists. Still, I was not prepared for the crowds -- no, throngs -- I encountered in the city on my four-day April visit.
 People spilled into the narrow streets, overwhelming the Vespas and Fiats that gingerly negotiated through the tourist parade. Visitors waited, patiently, and often in long snaky lines, at the doors of Florence's top attractions: the Duomo, the Uffizi Gallery and Prada. It's the kind of scene that usually wrecks my mood and drives me to my guidebooks in search of a Travel Plan B. 
 But not this time. I loved Florence. 
And actually I was glad for the company of so many strangers. In a city overflowing with gorgeous things that you not only can see and admire, but often can also buy and take home (at the fantastic exchange rate of 2,180 lire to the dollar), a certain guilty anxiety sets in after a while. Florence is a city of twin sirens, art and conspicuous consumption. But how do you navigate between them both? 
Stendhal's famous Florentine art attack was the result of aesthetic overload -- so much beauty! So little time! My swoons, on the other hand, tended to occur outside shop windows as I checked and rechecked the zeroes on my calcluator against the ones on the price tags, and a little voice inside my head whispered: "Hey, you can afford this!" In such moments, being surrounded by so many other people struggling under a load of Michelin guides, guilt and shopping bags made me feel much better.
Normally, I'm too busy thinking about travel expenses for luxury items to enter my radar. But getting to Florence, and staying there, was a deal as fantastic as the ones in the shop windows. In March, noticing that air fares to Europe were on sale, I checked around and found a ticket on Lufthansa through the Internet broker Cheap Tickets that would take me in mid-April from J.F.K. in New York to Florence then back from Rome to J.F.K. for only $400.
I flirted with the idea of just showing up in Italy without a hotel reservation, and catching a bargain on the fly. But then I remembered the 27 faxes I had to send to find a hotel room in Venice in 1999. Actually, it was easier to find reasonably priced rooms in Florence than it had been in Venice, even though April is the beginning of the city's high season. Using the Web, and the Florence guidebook from the useful Time Out series, I sent out a half-dozen reservation requests by e-mail, and got two "yes" responses from hotels in central Florence. Using my credit card number, I booked two nights in a single with bath at the Hotel Casci, just north of the Duomo, at $82 a night, and two nights at the Hotel Alessandra, near the Ponte Vecchio, also a single with bath, for $87.
Flying over the Atlantic, straitjacketed in a too-small economy seat in a full 747, my leg muscles paid the hidden cost of my discount ticket, but I consoled myself with the thought of the clean, warm bed waiting for me at the Hotel Casci.
"Hello, my name is Miss McLane, and I have a reservation," I told the desk clerk with a smile. He returned my smile, shuffled through some papers, and then paused uncomfortably. 
"You did not answer the last e-mail," he said.
I pulled out my confirmation letter, which I had printed out from my computer. The clerk frowned. 
"I am so sorry," he said. "We e-mailed you again because your credit card number did not verify. I am afraid we had to let your reservation go."
Despair. I had not slept the previous night, and my internal clock was still set to New York, where it was now 4:30 a.m. I looked at the reservation I'd sent out, and realized that, overeager to respond, I'd reversed two digits in my credit card number. But I'd never received the hotel's follow-up e-mail message. 
"Our e-mail, sometimes it does not work," the clerk admitted. "But don't worry. There is no problem. We find a room for you at the hotel across the street. Same price. It is a family-run hotel, just like this one. Hotel Europa."
He handed me a gift -- a cellophane-wrapped Florence calendar -- but the gesture barely registered as I pondered my bleak future. I hadn't seen the Hotel Europa in any of the guidebooks. Staggering with my bag, I darted through the traffic of the Via C. Cavour, found the address across the street, and went up a floor to the Europa in its small, creaky elevator.
At the desk, a gentle grandfatherly man, who introduced himself as Mr. Gassim, a Somalian who had bought the hotel with his family in the 1970's, had already been informed of my plight by the Casci's desk clerk.
"You must be tired," he said. "Don't worry about filling out the registration, I'll take your passport later after you rest. We have a nice room for you."
Taking my bag with a smile, he led me down the hall, and opened a door to a small room that was spotless, furnished simply with a twin bed, desk and wardrobe. I peeked in the bathroom -- teeny, but also clean, with a bidet, sink, and shower stall -- and felt relieved. This was just fine.
But there was more. Stepping over to the window, Mr. Gassim pulled open the shutters with a flourish, to reveal a postcard-perfect view of a lovely courtyard, and in the background, the Duomo.
"Your room with a view," he said merrily. "Enjoy your rest."
This is too easy, I thought, the next morning at breakfast as Mr. Gassim -- now in a white jacket, bustling about the Europa's lovely breakfast room with its faded frescoed ceiling -- taught me how to use the hotel's cappuccino machine, which, at the push of a button, hissed and sputtered and spat out a perfect latte on demand. I had the same thought as I bypassed a two-hour line and breezed ahead of the crowds into the Uffizi Gallery later that morning.
Before leaving for Italy, forewarned by friends and guidebooks, I'd made a reservation at the Uffizi. You can do this most cheaply by telephone -- it's a $1.50 fee on top of the normal $7 -- but I decided to do it through an agency I found online, www.weekendafirenze.com, which charges a $5 commission, opting for the convenience of e-mail over busy signals and a pricey overseas phone call. Much to my delight, the Internet agency sent my confirmation promptly, with a chit for a free cappuccino in a cafe near the Uffizi.
Getting in was a snap, but it took a while for me to get the hang of enjoying what, as it turned out, was Florence's most packed museum. At first, I used my pushy New York moves, elbowing my way to the Botticellis -- the "Primavera" is definitely worth breaking out the elbows. But then I began to notice how the crowd ebbed and flowed.
If you timed your approach to fit between the large tour groups, you could have those few precious moments alone (well, almost) with Michelangelo's "Doni Tondo." 
And at other museums, the crowds thinned to manageable size. I was astonished by Michelangelo's erotic, compelling "Bacchus" in the Bargello, but even more amazed by my access to it. I could have touched it if I wanted, and no one else was around in this museum that is said to be to sculpture what the Uffizi is to painting.
The historic center of Florence, I found, is the perfect playground for a traveler on a four- or five-day itinerary. The distances are not so large that you need to bother figuring out public transportation (or walking your soles off), but it is big and varied and fascinating enough to wander contentedly on foot.
There are easily learned landmarks -- the Duomo; the Arno River; the Ponte Vecchio, with its profusion of gold jewelry shops; the Piazza della Signoria, with its copy of Michelangelo's "David"; the fortresslike Palazzo Pitti -- to keep you from getting lost. And as I discovered while exploring the Oltrarno, a neighborhood of narrow winding cobblestone streets lined with apartments and artisan's workshops on the south, or left, side of the Arno, there are plenty of nooks and crannies in which to hide from the tour groups.
The Oltrarno became my favorite haunt, when I wasn't gaping at masterpieces or designer handbags. There, I watched elderly artisans rebuilding antique chairs, fitting fabulous heavy Florentine damasks over horsehair cushions. I found one of those hole-in-the-wall Italian lingerie shops where the salesclerk looks you up and down, then pulls out a dusty box from the wall, filled with exquisite silk and lace goodies that fit perfectly.
And I tended to eat on that side of the Arno, for after a day or so, I noticed there was an inverse correlation between the number of non-Italians in a restaurant and the quality of its food. The best meal I had in Florence was a lunch in Alla Vecchia Bettola, a trattoria not far from Oltrarno, in San Frediano. I was the only foreigner, and the staff was not overly friendly when I sat down alone at an outside table. But once I tasted a slice of the restaurant's exquisite beef carpaccio, covered with fresh artichokes and drizzled with rich Tuscan olive oil, I could have cared less about frosty service.
I ate well, though not always so splendidly, in Florence, and wished I had more time (and appetite) to restaurant hop. There were trattorias on nearly every corner with menus in my price range -- a typical meal of three courses and a small carafe of wine was around $25. But the quality varied wildly, even in the same meal. 
At Osteria del Cinghiale Bianco in Oltrarno, I ate an amazing, tangy plate of salami and other assorted cold cuts homemade from wild boar, a house specialty. But it was followed by a humdrum plate of stewed lamb. I yearned to know a local person, who surely would know exactly where to go and what to order.
I had much more success at shopping. I slid my hands into a pair of silk-lined Florentine-red leather gloves ($27) at Madova, just over the Ponte Vecchio in Colli, and said, si. In a boutique on the fashionable Via dei Tornabuoni, I took three tottering steps in black high-heeled mules from the Milan design house Costume National and then took them home, for $134 (in SoHo, at Tootsie Plohound, the same pair cost $235).
And, finally, in my weakest moment, I plunked down my credit card and bought a gorgeous silk scarf, patterned in swirling geometric Op Art pinks, blacks and oranges, at Emilio Pucci. No, it wasn't a bargain, but it appealed both to my 60's nostalgia, and to my growing affection for Florence (the Puccis are a noble old Florentine family).
I MOVED to the Hotel Alessandra, on the Borgo SS. Apostoli, for my last two days. It had no view, and I missed the Gassims' warmth. But my room, again with a twin bed, was a bit larger, and the Alessandra was much closer to the shops. 
Best of all, it had a new marble-tiled bathroom with a long, deep tub. I filled it with hot water and sprinkles of Florentine cologne made from 17th-century recipes (so they say) by the Santa Maria Novella Pharmacy ($27), and lay contentedly, wondering what in the world was turning me into such a fashion princess.
In the royal apartments of the Palazzo Pitti, drifting through room after room decorated with over-the-top velvet wallpaper and can-you-believe-this chandeliers, it hit me: The Medicis. It was all their fault. They surrounded themselves with things of great beauty, blurring the boundaries between art and conspicuous consumption. Now, hundreds of years later, as I walked through their rooms, their collections, their furniture, I understood where my sudden hunger for exquisite, if perhaps frivolous, things was coming from.
That night, in my room at the Alessandra, I deconstructed my haul, taking apart the packages, discarding the shoeboxes and fancy wrappings, and cramming everything into my carry-on. It was then that I noticed that none of the clothes hangers in the wardrobe of my budget hotel matched. And that every one was stamped with designer names: Prada, Gucci, Armani. 
I looked at the cast-off hangers of travelers past, the wastebasket filled with my abandoned shopping bags, then at my bulging suitcase, and I had to laugh. The real peril of Florence is Medici syndrome.

Bottom line in a city of bounty
I spent $118.25 a day during four days and nights in Florence last month, including hotel, food, local transportation, and museum admissions. The exchange rate was 2,180 lire to the dollar. 

Getting There
From Cheap Tickets, www
.cheaptickets.com, I got a ticket to Italy on Lufthansa from Kennedy International Airport in New York to Florence via Frankfurt, then back from Rome to J.F.K. The fare was $400, plus an $11.95 delivery charge.

Where to Stay
My $82 room at the Hotel Europa, Via C. Cavour 14, (39-055) 239-6715, fax (39-055) 210-361, www
.webhoteleuropa.com, was small but clean, with a closet-sized private bath (shower, no tub). The twin bed and other furnishings were Ikea-basic but the casement windows were triple-glazed. The rate included a breakfast of yogurt, cereal, bread, cheese and cappuccino.
The view from my $87 room at Hotel Alessandra, Borgo SS. Apostoli 17, (39-055) 283-438, fax (39-055) 210-619, www.hotelalessandra.com, was of a dark alley. But the room also had a big new marble bathroom with a deep tub and some inkling of Florentine design in the red bedspreads and drapes. Here, too, breakfast was a cold buffet.

Where to Eat
Alla Vecchia Bettola, Viale L. Ariosto 32r-34r, (39-055) 224-158, is a neighborhood trattoria near the Piazza Tasso in San Frediano. Rigatoni with meat sauce and beef carpaccio dressed with slivers of artichoke and olive oil came to $16.50 without wine.
At Le Volpi e L'Uva, a terrific little wine bar at Piazza de Rossi 1, in Oltrarno, (39-055) 239-8132, I had a glass of a velvety Sangiovese that, at $3.50, was the most expensive on that night's list. The bar closes at 8 p.m.
At Trattoria La Baruciola, Via Maggio 61r, (39-055) 218-906, in Oltrarno, I had a solid meal of ribbon pasta in a meat-and-tomato sauce, and arugula salad with tangy Parmesan for $21.55, including a small carafe of wine and dessert.
At Osteria del Cinghiale Bianco, Borgo S. Jacopo 43r, (39-055) 215-706, my big lunch with dessert, coffee and wine was $28.

What to See
I stuck to the major museums. Opening and closing times change frequently, so it's advisable to stop at a municipal tourist office (there's one at the Santa Maria Novella train station) and pick up a listing of hours. The office phone number is (39-055) 290-832.
I reserved my $7 ticket for the Uffizi Gallery, Piazzale Degli Uffizi 6, (39-055) 238-8651-652, through www
.weekendafirenze.com, which charges $5. Tickets can also be reserved by calling (39-055) 294-883.
The lines at the Galleria dell'Accademia, Via Ricasoli 60, (39-055) 238-612, were shorter, and moved faster than at the Uffizi -- most people were waiting simply for a glimpse of Michelangelo's "David," which is exhibited here with his unfinished "Slaves." Entry is $5.50.
The Bargello, Via del Proconsolo 4, (39-055) 238-8606, is a trove of Renaissance sculpture that, oddly, doesn't attract the crowds of the Uffizi. Entry is $3.70.
The Medicis' fortresslike Palazzo Pitti, Via Gucciardini at the Boboli Gardens, (39-055) 238-8614, is home to several museums, including the Galleria Palatina, with its Renaissance paintings, and the Royal Apartments, which provide a giddy glimpse of the high life in Florence, circa 1600. Admission to both is $5.50. DAISANN McLANE

HEADLINE: Uneasy Being Green: Tourism Runs Wild 

BYLINE:  By TIMOTHY EGAN; TIMOTHY EGAN reports for The Times from Seattle.

 BODY:
SUDDENLY, everyone is an eco-tourist, or so it seems. The traveler may be playing shuffleboard on a cruise ship, martini in hand, when a whale passes by, or hunting exotic species in a private wildlife park in Texas. Typical tourists? No, sir. To hear the marketers tell it, these activities are part of the fastest-growing segment of the world's dominant industry.
 A look inside any magazine devoted to travel tells the same story. Up pops the stunning rainbow of pictures of St. Vincent and the Grenadines, billed in an ad as "the last unspoiled Caribbean paradise." Or an enticement from the Florida Everglades, showing beach-lolling laziness alongside gator-gazing in a canoe, with the tag line, "Go Wild . . . Stay Civilized." And then there are expeditions to the coldest places on the planet, the Arctic or Antarctica, sold as Shackleton-era survival adventure with fine cuisine and decent wine. 
 Iceland is hot, with visits up nearly 20 percent last year. Ditto the maturing eco-havens of Central America, which saw an 8.8 percent growth in visitors in 2000 over the previous year. And Qatar, once so anonymous that most Americans probably thought it was a television brand rather than than a Middle Eastern emirate, is enjoying such a boom in nature-based travel the government is planning an eco-tourist resort by the very sea that was the centerpiece of the Persian Gulf war a decade ago. 
Gone is the old image of the green pilgrim, the sojourner with backpack and Tibetan prayer book. It was not long ago that the only people you would see in winter at the soggiest western edge of the Pacific Northwest were those trying to get arrested in an antilogging protest. Now the loggers are largely gone, and local businesses run ads in major newspapers touting old-growth forests and moss as eco-destinations, under a headline, "We'd hug a tree, but our arms aren't long enough."
Just in time, the United Nations has designated 2002 the International Year of Ecotourism. In an age when more than 500 million people travel for leisure, eco-tourism is growing by 20 to 30 percent a year, according to several private organizations that track travel growth. 
Half of all American adults took an "adventure" travel vacation in the last five years, according to the Travel Industry Association of America, a trade group that defines adventure as anything from camping to river rafting. About 24 million Americans traveled simply to watch birds or animals, the group says.
But what is good for hotels, guides and sellers of binoculars may not necessarily be good for sea turtles in the South Atlantic, puffins in Alaska or architectural ruins in the Andes. And so, as the green label is attached to all manner of travel, a number of countries and organizations are promoting a system to certify what is good eco-tourism and what is bad. 
They have their work cut out for them, of course, but at least one country -- Australia -- has already gone down the certification road, and has been given high marks by travelers, environmental organizations and tour groups.
Beyond the emerging certification fight is a concern that the world's growing curiosity about, say, blue-footed boobies in the Galapagos or gorillas in the upland mist of Uganda may ultimately put the birds and primates in peril. The second major cause of worry around the growth of eco-tourism, according to proponents of traveling light in the sand, is the question of whether the land, people and biological diversity of a given area can be sustained through waves of outside visitors. 
"We're not going to stop the movement by people to the last unvisited places on the planet," said Martha Honey, author of "Ecotourism and Sustainable Development: Who Owns Paradise?," published in 1999 by Island Press. "But we cannot continue to travel as we have." 
Any corner of the globe can go from hidden paradise to pejorative in little time. People worry that their favorite tucked-away beach or mountain hideaway will soon become Aspenized or Cancunized, to use the terms that have evolved to evoke excess, glitter and crowds where once there was mostly snow or sand. 
Hawaii is the first American state where legal challenges have been brought against using tax dollars to promote more visitor growth. The courts have been asked to decide whether money spent to bring in more tourists requires an environmental impact statement. If the environmentalists prevail, the state would have to weigh the impact of new visitors on the islands in the same way it now looks at proposed power plants or highways.
The flip side of the argument that tourists ultimately degrade a place is that tourists also create market demand and a political constituency for saving a place or a species. River guides in British Columbia, fighting mining proposals and logging in wild places, or even the sea turtle guides in Hawaii can attest to the power of creating instant conservationists out of visitors.
Major hotel chains, cruise ships and megaresorts have been underscoring their earth-friendly practices of late. Some of these enterprises do a commendable job of protecting the local environment, Ms. Honey said, but others are engaged in "greenwashing," promoting themselves as earth-friendly simply because they have small showerheads or do not wash guest towels every day.
"These are cost-saving measures, and they may have very little to do with eco-tourism," Ms. Honey said. 
Even defining eco-tourism, nearly a quarter-century after the term started to appear, is difficult. The most simple explanation is that eco-tourism is nature-based travel. That market is huge, and growing. Bird-watching alone grew 157 percent from 1982 to 1994, according to a study done by sporting goods manufacturers. 
Theme parks may still be big draws, but in survey after survey, travelers say they are looking for authenticity, unfettered nature, or a chance to swim with sea mammals, and to do it with a clear conscience. 
Cruise ship passengers, reflecting the tastes of the middle-age traveler, increasingly want to climb ice walls or visit native villages when they get off the boat in a port like Juneau or Skagway in Alaska. 
"I think we all see ourselves as Robinson Crusoe and we have to get there and be the pioneers," said Megan Epler Wood, president of the International Eco-tourism Society, which has members in 138 countries and is based in Vermont. 
Ms. Wood's organization, founded in 1990 to assist travel professionals, defines eco-tourism as "responsible travel to natural areas that conserves the environment and sustains the well-being of local people."
But determining what kind of travel is good for the environment, and does not turn the local folks into walking props, will be part of the heavy lifting in any certification process. Should travel agencies police themselves? Should government do the certification? Can a global organization like the United Nations decide what is good and what is not, especially when developing nations are starved for foreign currency? 
As those questions are being sorted out, travelers have to do their own homework. In Maui, for example, whale-watching and swimming with sea turtles have become enormous growth industries, with virtually all the services claiming to be whale-friendly. But not all the companies obey the federal regulation that whale-watching boats keep a certain distance, and stay out of the way of the big humpbacks as they go through mating rituals in the warm Pacific. Only an exhaustive search of Coast Guard records would turn up repeat violators. But who wants to spend a vacation going over public documents in a basement room? 
"The best thing a consumer can do is ask a lot of questions," Ms. Wood said. "If consumers are not demanding, businesses can get away with a lot of sloppy practices and broad claims."
Some environmental groups are trying to stimulate eco-tourism rather than simply monitoring tour groups.
A few years ago, the RARE Center for Tropical Conservation, an environmental group based in Arlington, Va., started an eco-tourism development program in some of the countries whose natural areas it was trying to protect. The group now trains former fishermen, hunters, even poachers, as nature, fishing or kayaking guides to give them an economic stake in conservation. More than 200 nature guides have been trained in Honduras, Costa Rica and Mexico, and given assistance on how to set up businesses, the group says. 
"We have turned poachers into nature guides, poachers into ambassadors of the environment," said Brett Jenks, president of RARE. "I don't think there is a better way to create a consituency for conservation than through eco-tourism."
In the Southwestern United States, along the border country where the Colorado River empties into Sonora, Mexico, another group has been trying to build a local economy of eco-visitors in a similar way. La Ruta de Sonora, based in Ajo, Ariz., promotes trips of three to eight days enabling visitors can follow the trade routes of pre-Columbian Hohokam Indians, retrace the footsteps of Spanish Missionaries, or look at migratory birds in the company of people who live in the desert delta. Rather than simply taking tourists to tramp around the desert and gawk at people living in adobe huts, the group has been able to assist those who live on the Sonoran side of the border to become active in the visitor trade.
"It's provided hope and an alternative in areas where agriculture may be marginal and there is a lot of poverty," said Steve Cornelius, of the Sonoran Institute, an environmental group that helped to set up the tours. 
But Mr. Cornelius also worries that too many tourists on the same off-the-beaten-path can be damaging. "Tourism can be a real threat to these areas," he said. "So we have to be careful."
ALREADY, some of the world's most biologically diverse areas have come under heavy regulation, while others are close to choking on the dust of tourist hordes. The Galapagos, Charles Darwin's living laboratory that inspired his theory of evolution, is under a strict quota of 60,000 visitors a year. Only licensed guides can take people to a small part of the national park. 
But the regulations have angered fishermen, who went on a strike last year and held three giant tortoises hostage. The government of Ecuador later increased the fishing quotas, and the tortoises were released, unharmed.
To some travelers, Machu Picchu has lost its mystery and allure since the Peruvian government has done little to slow the stampede to the formerly lost city. There are other ruins in the Andes that could take some of the pressure off Machu Picchu, but they have yet to catch the visitor wave.
Costa Rica is often held up by people in the travel industry as a model of light-on-the-land tourist development. It is known for its clean beaches, mystical cloud forests alive with orchids and butterflies, and well-run national parks. 
"They do eco-tourism very well in Costa Rica," said Ms. Honey, the author, who lived there. "And it has been largely beneficial to local people." 
Though a few major hotels chains along the line of Cancun high-rises have been proposed, Costa Rica has encouraged small-scale development. And the parks are now trying to get more people to come during the off-seasons -- anytime but winter. 
Even with a global economic slowdown, experts predict that world travel is on path to double in 10 years, when an estimated one billion people are projected to take a trip to another country. "Tourism at the turn of the century is growing faster than even our most optimistic predictions," said Francesco Frangialli, secretary general of the World Tourism Organization.
But with optimism also comes a cautionary note from people who have seen their particular paradise in peril. And they say: Be careful what you wish for.

The rules of the off-road
Leave it as you found it. That is the 
underlying theme of the basic rules of
conduct suggested for eco-tourists by various organizations, including the National Audubon Society, World Tourism Organization, Sierra Club, International Eco-
tourism Society and Conservation International.
More specifically, these are their rules: 
* In rural areas stay on designated trails and roads.
* Stay away from breeding sites and fragile environments.
* Do not disturb wildlife or pick plant specimens or other ground cover.
* Do not harass animals or approach them too closely. 
* Whether alone or with a group, be no louder than necessary.
* Do not litter; carry out all trash, garbage and human waste from wilderness areas.
* Do not buy souvenirs or mementos of threatened wildlife and plant populations. 
* Before a trip, familiarize yourself with local customs, as well as possible health hazards or security risks.
* Remember that you are not a guest but one of probably many tourists, so do not expect special privileges.
* Respect sacred sites.
* Dress in ways appropriate to places you visit.
* Do not offend the privacy of people who do not want to be photographed. 
* Learn at least enough words in the local language to be able to greet and thank 
others.
* Where prudent, help local communities by eating at their restaurants and shopping at markets.
* Listen and observe, but do not criticize or act as though you have all the answers.
 EDWIN McDOWELL

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Exhibit in Bronx on Energy Conservation; 
A Model City Of the Future

 BODY:
Talk about timing. With the nation concerned about the cost and supply of energy, the Cherry Tree Association -- a 500-member nonprofit community group in the Mott Haven section of the South Bronx that promotes economic development as well as gardening, arts and cultural events -- is sponsoring an exhibit of a proposed city of the future that will use solar, wind and fuel-cell technology. 
 The exhibit displays the drawings and futuristic designs produced for Cherry Tree by students at the New York Institute of Technology and the City College Architectural Center. 
 By incorporating some of those designs, Cherry Tree expects to convert its own building, Casa del Sol, a six-story, 7,000-square-foot former tenement, into a model of renewable energy production for a cleaner environment and improved quality of life.
Models of the planned conversion are part of the exhibit. The project is expected to be completed in the fall of 2003.
The exhibit at the Casa del Sol, at 672-674 East 136th Street, at Cypress Avenue, near the Cypress Avenue stop on the No. 6 subway line, is open Saturdays and Sundays from noon to 4 p.m. through June 23. Those who wish to visit the exhibit on weekdays should telephone the Cherry Tree Association office at (718) 292-6443 between 9 a.m. and 5 p.m. weekdays.

HEADLINE: THEATER/THE TONY AWARDS; 
A Couple of Regular Guys Bonding, Onstage and Off

BYLINE:  By JERRY TALLMER; Jerry Tallmer founded the Off Broadway Obie Awards in 1956.

 BODY:
THEY are a couple of unemployed steelworkers kicking around haplessly in Buffalo, their mill closed, their gutted manhood defined by a few lines of Terrence McNally's script right at the top of the show:
 "Hi, I'm Dave Bukatinsky. I just defrosted a refrigerator and vacuumed the living room. And how was your day?" 
 "Hi, I'm Jerry Lukowski. I'm 32, out of work, divorced, in debt . . . if I don't make some money soon they won't let me see my son. I'm fed up, angry and, oh, yeah . . ." 
Dave is the large and, some would say, rotund one. Jerry is the lean and, some would say, handsome one. Before the musical "The Full Monty" is over, they and a few of their equally jobless buddies will have recaptured their manly self-esteem and, in the process, brought certain bare facts into play before an all-female sellout audience in Buffalo and an even larger gathering of males as well as females in a Broadway theater called the Eugene O'Neill. Actually, their show could probably cheer up even Eugene O'Neill.
"You know," said Patrick Wilson, the lean and handsome actor who portrays Jerry Lukowski, "a lot of middle-aged men come up afterward and say, 'My wife dragged me here, but I love it.' "
"The nudity," said John Ellison Conlee, the large, rotund actor who portrays Dave Bukatinsky, "is really a very small aspect of the story. It's not about nudity, it's about bravery -- doing exceptional things." 
Mr. Wilson and Mr. Conlee had never met before taking part in a workshop for "The Full Monty" 14 months ago in New York. Now they have 2 of the 10 Tony Award nominations received by the Broadway hit that has been hatched out of the 1997 British film of the same name.
What had immediately struck Mr. Conlee on his first reading of the script, he said, was that "this was one of the most accurate portrayals of male friendship I'd seen in the theater." He and Mr. Wilson, Mr. Conlee said, "don't talk about it a lot, but" -- as characters in the show and as actors and human beings -- "we do depend on each other."
Most often in such instances, he said, "You have to really make or create that chemistry, but in terms of working with Patrick, we got really lucky."
"At that first meeting at the workshop, we instantly took to one another," he added. "If not, we would have worked on it, but we didn't have to." 
Mr. Wilson agreed. "We clicked from Day 1," he said. "The funny thing is, now that there's talk of tours and so forth, the producers keep saying, 'We've got to find two guys with your chemistry.' Well, the chemistry of Dave and Jerry, or John and me, is more than almost any relationship I've ever had. And it was a total crap shoot; the producers had no idea what they were getting."
Mr. Wilson is up for best performance by a leading actor in a musical. The competition in that category consists of Nathan Lane and Matthew Broderick of "The Producers," Kevin Chamberlin in "Seussical" and Tom Hewitt in "The Rocky Horror Show." Mr. Conlee has been nominated for best performance by a featured actor in a musical. The competition: Andre De Shields from "The Full Monty" and three candidates from "The Producers": Roger Bart, Gary Beach and Brad Oscar.
"What are the Tonys again?" asked Mr. Wilson, straight-faced. "Will Antoinette Perry be there?"
Earlier this month, he and Mr. Conlee were grabbing some nourishment an hour and a half before curtain time. They didn't look like actors. They looked like, well, maybe not steelworkers, but plain everyday members of the great American work force dressed for a night's bowling.
Except that people quite often ask Mr. Wilson if he knows he looks a little like Paul Newman.
"Interestingly," Mr. Conlee blithely interjected, "that happens to me all the time."
"In a single week," Mr. Wilson declared in bemusement, "one woman came up and said, 'You look like Paul Newman'; a second woman said, 'Did anyone tell you you look like Pat Boone?'; and a third said I reminded her of a young George Bush." 
"That," Mr. Conlee murmured, "is because you're a brilliant transformational actor."
Mr. Wilson briefly met the real Paul Newman -- "my idol," he said, with no irony whatsoever -- late last year. "He had seen the show, and was very complimentary. I wanted to tell him a lot of things. I didn't say any of them. I walked away sweating."
Is there any correlation between the acting profession and the unemployment those steelworkers up in Buffalo are experiencing?
"Sure," Mr. Conlee said, "that's part of our business. I think whether you're employed or unemployed, even successful actors, distinguished men in their 70's, get this, 'Oh, you're that guy . . .' " and the voice, he said, trails off in vague forgetfulness. 
For his part, Mr. Wilson said: "I haven't had a lot of experience with struggling or with being unemployed. Still, if you're in a show and it's closing, when Tuesday night comes around and it's over, you're through. So translate that to blue-collar America." 
Actually, neither man comes out of blue-collar America.
Mr. Conlee was born in 1968 in Atlanta, where his father is in real estate. He went to Centre College "in historic Danville, Kentucky," and then for a bachelor of fine arts degree at New York University. Although he did some acting while growing up in Atlanta, Mr. Conlee said, "It never occurred to me that I could do it for a living until I was halfway through college." The first show he was in at Centre College was "Equus." He played the father. "Most of my work has not been in musicals," he said. In regional theater his shows have ranged from "The Misanthrope" to "The Compleat Works of Wllm Shkspr (Abridged)." 
Mr. Wilson, who was born in 1973 in Norfolk, Va., grew up in St. Petersburg, Fla., where his father and brother were and still are television anchormen. His mother is a singer and teacher "who did church music for about 40 years," and as a boy he sang in a choir. He has a bachelor of fine arts degree from Carnegie Mellon University, and most of his work -- seven or eight shows -- has been in musicals, including "Bright Lights, Big City" Off Broadway and a touring version of "Carousel." 
Despite the fact that Broadway musicals ("The Producers" and "The Full Monty" apart) are usually driven by female stars, neither Mr. Wilson nor Mr. Conlee believes the business is particularly tougher these days on male musical-comedy talent.
"I really think it's easier for men," Mr. Wilson said, "harder for women. There are just more roles for men. Actually, it's harder for women in all industries."
MR. CONLEE added: "I think the business in general is harder for women. There are much more demands on women, just in terms of looks, for instance." Both men should know what they're talking about: both their girlfriends, they said, are actresses.
Both men had also seen the British film "The Full Monty," starring Robert Carlyle and Mark Addy in the roles they themselves now have, long before they knew the movie would be turned into a Broadway musical.
"To me," Mr. Wilson said, "when I heard that Terrence McNally had done the book, that meant the producers were taking it seriously and not going to splatter the movie up on stage."
It also meant that once Mr. Wilson, who has no children, had read the script, the "idea of having a son, of being able to speak with a son" -- as the character does in the show -- "became exciting." To him, he said, it meant a kind of graduation, "to the next level of parts -- fathers and things -- instead of just tortured heroes."
Both Mr. Conlee and Mr. Wilson have, of course, been in their share of failed shows. "After the first flop," Mr. Wilson said, "you say, 'O.K., I have no idea what makes a hit.' " In this particular instance, Ethel Merman and Bert Lahr -- courtesy of Cole Porter -- gave the answer long ago: "Friendship, friendship, just a perfect blendship."

HEADLINE: ART/ARCHITECTURE; 
A Mythical Metropolis Materializes in Queens

BYLINE:  By FRANKLIN SIRMANS; Franklin Sirmans, a freelance curator and writer, is the former U.S. editor of Flash Art International magazine.

 BODY:
IN Italo Calvino's "Invisible Cities," Marco Polo and Kublai Khan conjure imaginary destinations out of thin air. A similar trick is being pulled off with industrial-strength nylon canvas and aluminum tubing by Alexandre Arrechea, Dagoberto Rodriguez and Marco Castillo, three young Cuban artists known as Los Carpinteros (the Carpenters). Their "Ciudad Transportable" ("Transportable City"), which opens today at the P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center in Queens, is a mythical metropolis situated at the intersection of sculpture and architecture -- a blurry meeting place where distinctions between art and work fall away.
 Abstracting the forms of vernacular Cuban structures -- lighthouse, factory, apartment house, church, jail -- into a collapsible city of tents, Mr. Arrechea, Mr. Rodriguez and Mr. Castillo have pared the inessentials and left only sleekly designed metaphors that have the surface clarity of work by Richard Artschwager or Donald Judd. 
 " 'Ciudad Transportable' is our most ambitious piece to date," Mr. Rodriguez said by e-mail from Los Angeles, where Los Carpinteros are working on an exhibition, their second, at the Grant Selwyn Fine Art Gallery; it is scheduled to open June 28. "The original idea has to do with the minimal basic space that any community needs to live, or the environment in which life occurs."
The work's 10 off-white tents, ranging in height from about 6 feet to 15 feet, invite the viewer to walk inside and look out the mesh windows at the other "buildings" of the symbolic city. "They are not being romantic or sentimental," said Alanna Heiss, the director of P.S. 1, who organized the exhibition. "Their sculptures are discreet and intelligent."
Fabricated in Los Angeles under the supervision of Rosa Lowinger, a conservator, "Ciudad" was originally exhibited outdoors on the Havana waterfront this past winter, at the Seventh Havana Biennial. At P.S. 1, it is installed both indoors and out, spread over three floors of galleries and the outdoor courtyard. (After it closes, on Sept. 3, "Ciudad" will be rebuilt again, at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, where it opens Sept. 23.
It's not an accident that the minimalist forms of "Ciudad Transportable" are both beautiful and functional. Los Carpinteros have from the beginning questioned the validity of the distinctions between high and low, art and artifact. They embraced a healthy ambiguity along with their name, which was given to them by their peers, according to the Havana-based art consultant Cristina Vives, because in their early years they worked in wood so much. 
They adopted the name as their signature, Mr. Arrechea said, because the designation "has nothing to do with art, and mixing it into the world of art creates doubt in and of itself." 
The three met in 1991, at the Instituto Superior de Arte in Havana, and first began exhibiting as Los Carpinteros in 1994. Always exploring the meeting ground of art and society, they used their earliest works, figurative portrait paintings, to comment subtly on the status quo.
An early series, called "Interior Habanero" ("Havana Interior"), was linked to the repressive political climate of the years after Cuba's loss of economic aid from the Soviet Union. Stating that the paintings had been commissioned by a fictional Cuban-American collector, Los Carpinteros created purposely equivocal works like "Havana Country Club," a portrait of the artists golfing on the art institute grounds, which had been a country club before the revolution. By February 1995, the three were showing at the Whitechapel Art Gallery in London. In 1996, they abandoned painting to devote themselves to drawing and sculpture. And by 1998, when they created "Provisionalismo?", a partly built house of bricks and pipes that was shown in New York at the New Museum, their work had repudiated the sculptural object in favor of architectural and furniture-based structures. Working from a mental, if not always physical, base at home in Cuba, Los Carpinteros are exemplary -- in fact, quintessential -- traveling artists in the trade winds of the current global art circuit.
They live in Havana but view themselves as itinerant and typical of the current climate in which, Mr. Arrechea said, "travel has become a routine part of work." In addition to two Havana Biennials, they have been shown at contemporary art spaces in New York, at the 1997 Johannesburg Biennial, and in group exhibitions of Cuban artists around the world. They also figure prominently in the new book by Holly Block, "Art Cuba: The New Generation," published by Abrams.
Like many young artists, especially sculptors, with grand aspirations, much of Los Carpinteros' early work was concentrated in drawings and sketches that craftily illustrated larger sculptural works to come. An examination of images of these early drawings reveals that most of their initial aspirations have been fulfilled. Taking the work to the next level, working sculpture by sculpture, Los Carpinteros still begin each project by imagining it on paper, using the drawings as a kind of internal communication.
They started drawing "Ciudad" in 1997, as an exercise, said Mr. Castillo: "It was a form of training for an emergency that we do not yet know, and that we can't quite predict."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Los Carpinteros are, from left, Dagoberto Rodriguez, Alexandre Arrechea and Marco Castillo. Their "Cuidad Transportable," right, abstracts common Cuban structures. (Eileen Costa)

HEADLINE: DANCE; 
Staying Afoot Amid Upheaval

BYLINE:  By HOLLY WILLIAMS; Holly Williams teaches at the University of Texas at Austin and writes regularly about dance for The Dallas Morning News and The Austin American Statesman.

DATELINE: FORT WORTH 

 BODY:
THE two cities couldn't be more different. Fort Worth "where the West begins," in the words of Will Rogers -- delights tourists with its wood-planked stockyard and cowboy dance halls. Dallas, twice as large and a sleek center for banking and insurance companies -- and just 30 miles east -- offers a labyrinthine freeway system and a John F. Kennedy assassination site museum.
 By tradition, the cities shrug each other off, meeting only where and when they must. One thing they do share, and have shared successfully for seven years, is a ballet company. 
 The Fort Worth Dallas Ballet will perform beginning on May 29 at the Joyce Theater in Chelsea. The program comprises Stanton Welch's "Fingerprints" and Kevin O'Day's "Principia" (both New York premieres) and Peter Anastos's "Yes, Virginia, Another Piano Ballet" of 1974.
But even as it ventures away from home turf, this is a company undergoing major artistic upheaval. In February, the "amicable" departure of the artistic director, Benjamin Houk, was announced by the board. Only three years before, Mr. Houk had replaced Paul Mejia, who departed hastily after 11 years with the company; according to newspaper reports, sexual-harassment complaints had been lodged against him.
A disciple of Balanchine, Mr. Mejia brought a number of the master's works to the company, when it was still based solely in Fort Worth, and helped lift it to artistic maturity. Although Mr. Mejia's own choreography was often criticized (and his ballets were the only other repertory offered), the company established a solid reputation for staging Balanchine works.
"The problem was not that we offered Balanchine repertory," David Mallette, the executive director, said recently, "but that we offered the same Balanchine works over and over."
Now the company is starting a search for a new artistic director. Meanwhile, Bruce Marks, a former artistic director of the Boston Ballet, has been recruited as artistic adviser to help program the 2001-2 season and audition dancers. He will choreograph "Romeo and Juliet" for the troupe. Bruce Simpson, a former dancer and ballet master with the State Theater Ballet of South Africa, is in place to rehearse the company through next season and stage "The Nutcracker." 
"This company has gone through tremendous changes in the last four years," Mr. Marks said, "leaving the dancers, I would say, stretched and somewhat dazed at the same time." In the last three years, 24 ballets have been added to the repertory. For next season, Mr. Marks has revived some Balanchine works, in line with the administrators' commitment to bring back pieces the company has done well in the past. The Joyce program, Mr. Marks suggests, shows the company to best artistic advantage and should be of interest to New York audiences.
As an example of the successful support of a dance company by two distinct cities, the Fort Worth Dallas Ballet has become an anomaly. Most other such experiments have failed.
"In almost every instance, two cities have tried to merge two existing companies, and it just doesn't work," Mr. Mallette said. "One becomes the default company, and the other loses staff and dancers. They also fail because of the enormous costs of hauling people and productions back and forth over long distances."
Neither problem plagues Mr. Mallette's company. It began as a grass-roots regional troupe in Fort Worth 40 years ago; and it has only to load up dancers and sets for a 45-minute trip to Dallas. Housed in a strip mall that could be anywhere but is just outside Fort Worth's distinctive downtown of restored brick, the organization has a school with 140 students, two studios and a core company of 23 dancers with additional apprentices and understudies.
But the story of the Fort Worth company's survival is also the story of Dallas's inability to keep its own ballet company despite several tries. The downfall of the Dallas Ballet in 1988, when Flemming Flindt, formerly of the Royal Danish Ballet, was the artistic director, followed a painful fund-raising campaign that had dancers in tutus panhandling passersby. Another company, Ballet Dallas, emerged from the ashes only to fold several years later, leaving Dallas with no ballet at all.
The path was clear for the Fort Worth company to move into the Dallas market, and its first ventures included a "Nutcracker" production in the Fair Park Music Hall. (Fair Park, in Dallas, is the home of the enormous Texas State Fair every October.) A separate nonprofit company, the Dallas Supporters of Fort Worth Dallas Ballet, was formed to raise the money needed to present the company in Dallas. Since then, the ballet company's budget has tripled, to $4.2 million a year. And under Mr. Houk, repertory broadened to include historical reconstructions ("Billy the Kid," "The Moor's Pavane" and "Rodeo") as well as story ballets and works by contemporary choreographers.
Fiscal caution has guided the company's Dallas season, which offers fewer performances and less repertory than in Fort Worth. "We buy what we can pay for," said Ann Woesser, the president-elect of the Dallas board. "We do think we'll grow, but the slowing economy this year has made it hard for all nonprofits to raise money. We don't want to bite off more than we can chew."
When the company performed in New York in 1990 and 1991, it presented Mr. Mejia's "Cinderella" at the City Center. But the Joyce program, Mr. Mallette said, is calculated to show the company's emergence in a "serious technical and artistic way."
"We are looking forward to the opportunity to bring ourselves above the national radar, even through the company's artistic transition," he added. "Did we consider not going? Sure, but as the dust settled a bit, we couldn't find a compelling reason not to go. We are ready."
Having Mr. Marks and Mr. Simpson in place for the next year removes some of the pressure to complete the search for Mr. Houk's successor quickly, allowing the company time for much-needed soul-searching. Dancers, members of the technical staff and board representatives have all contributed to the discussions, said Ruth Knouse, the Fort Worth board president. "We had to determine what we wanted to be when we grew up."

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Town Houses and Apartments Along the River; 
158 Condos Are Going Up in Croton-on-Hudson

 BODY:
Picking up where a previous developer left off during the real estate recession of the early 1990's, the Kalian Companies of Red Bank, N.J., will construct the 158 town houses and apartments left to be built at Half Moon Bay along the water in the village of Croton-on-Hudson in Westchester.
 Joe McGinley, the company's vice president for sales and marketing, said Westchester's housing market was strong enough, even with the current economic downturn, to justify completing the condominium complex. "There's a real lack of housing inventory in the county," he said. The recession a decade ago devastated the real estate market, he said, and many builders of residential and commercial developments were unable to complete them. 
 In its 17-year history, Kalian has developed single-family homes, town houses and condominiums throughout New Jersey. It has ventured into Westchester, Mr. McGinley said, because such scenic pieces of buildable riverside property are rare finds. In 1997, Kalian acquired about 15 acres for $1.975 million from the Half Moon Bay Acquisition Corporation, the original developer, according to the Cortlandt town assessor's office. Site preparation has begun and construction is expected to be completed within two years. 
Kalian's prices for the Half Moon Bay units, which will range from 1,000 to 2,500 square feet, are to start in the low $200,000's for one-bedroom town houses and go as high as the mid-$600,000's for two-bedroom units, he said. Many of the homes will overlook the Hudson. The median sales price for new condominiums in Westchester in the first quarter of this year was $212,000, according to the Westchester County Board of Realtors. Like the 120 existing homes at Half Moon Bay, which were built 10 to 15 years ago, the new units will be clustered in horseshoe-shaped groups that face the river. The new developer will add a second clubhouse and a pool to the existing clubhouse, marina and community center.
Other Kalian projects currently under construction include Carriage Gate, which consists of 239 units in Raritan Township, N.J.; Pine Lake Village, 65 units in River Vale, N.J.; and Brookside, a 394-unit adult community in Monroe Township, N.J.

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey; 
Warehouse Market, Though Cooling, Is Still Healthy

BYLINE:  By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
THE nation's softening economy notwithstanding, warehouse distribution centers the size of football fields continue to sprout around exits of the New Jersey Turnpike, while older industrial buildings in the Meadowlands are being bulldozed to make way for new ones. 
 To be sure, the state's industrial market has cooled from last year's heated pace and tenants are taking longer to make deals. But the market is still healthy, developers and commercial brokers say. And though rents have stabilized, there are at least 20 companies in the market needing 250,000 square feet or more of warehouse space, according to Cushman & Wakefield, the national real estate services company. 
 In the last year, the industrial vacancy rate in the 11 northern and central counties rose to 6.2 percent from 5 percent, said the Trammell Crow Company, another real estate services concern. That rate, however, is still considered low in the 725-million-square-feet market. 
The market is in "a period of adjustment," said George P. Malloy, a senior vice president at Trammell Crow in Chatham. "Leasing is good, not great, and there has been a shift in the balance of supply and demand as inventories increase." 
The market continues to draw new players and investors. "Industrial properties have consistently provided safe, if not spectacular, returns, so for many investors it is a defensive play," said Andrew J. Merin, an executive vice president at Cushman & Wakefield who heads its metropolitan-area financial services group. 
Mr. Merin said that investors, particularly pension funds, were forming alliances with developers "to give them instant access" to product to buy. 
One such marriage is that of Keystone Properties Trust, a real estate investment company based in West Conshohocken, Pa., and CalEast Industrial Investors, made up of LaSalle Investment Management, a division of Jones Lang LaSalle, and the California Public Employees Retirement System. Under the venture, they will buy $170 million worth of properties in the next few years in central and northern New Jersey. 
Since entering the state in 1997, Keystone has acquired nearly eight million square feet around the Meadowlands and Exits 8A and 10 of the turnpike. Its first two projects, totaling 983,000 square feet, are under way in the 8A region and they are being built on speculation. In addition, the company has bought or optioned 200 acres on which it could build up to three million more square feet. 
John Begier, Keystone's chief investment officer, said his company was building in the New Jersey market because of its size and diversity. He added that while there are "supply constraints, tenants need modern warehouses to expand." 
Mr. Malloy said that in the next three months there might be be "an opportunity for tenants" to make better deals. But the "market should be up and running again by the third or fourth quarter" as companies expand or consolidate scattered operations under one roof, he said.
There is six million square feet of industrial space under construction in New Jersey. About half of it, including Keystone's two projects, is along the turnpike corridor. 
At Exit 10, Heller Industrial Parks of Edison recently completed and leased a 170,000-square-foot speculative warehouse distribution center and is building one with 968,000 square feet. The two-building, $34 million project is rising on 52 acres at the end of Mill Road.
Jeffrey J. Milanaik, the company's president, said that though the market was stronger than six months ago, it was still uncertain and tenants still cautious. 
Mr. Milanaik said that "to gain some momentum," his company had lowered its asking rent modestly at the larger of the two new buildings to $4.80 to $4.90 a square foot annually from slightly more than $5. In turn, he said, his company is negotiating leases on three deals totaling 600,000 square feet and has two more prospects for 200,000 feet. 
Heller also has approvals to develop four million square feet near Exit 8A in South Brunswick. But Mr. Milanaik said because that market "has an oversupply of space, it does not make sense to add more until the existing space is absorbed."
As of the first quarter, there were some 2.2 million square feet of space under way in the 8A market, which covers parts of South Brunswick, Monroe and Cranbury. But after a lull in leasing, deals are again being made.
AMONG the most recent tenants leasing space is the Fleming Companies, a food distributor in Lewisville, Tex., which is taking 440,000 square feet in a 526,000-square-foot speculative building that Opus East L.L.C. of Bethesda, Md., put up in South Brunswick. The building is the first of three planned at the company's 90-acre park, which will have 1.2 million square feet. 
James Lee, a senior vice president at Opus, said his company was moving ahead on a second speculative building, of 350,000 square feet, at the park. 
At least three more companies plan to lease or buy buildings that will be built for them, commercial brokers said. Among them are Tommy Hilfiger U.S.A., the sportswear manufacturer, which is expanding into a 475,000-square-foot building at a planned two-building park of almost a million square feet on Cranbury South River Road in Cranbury. The developer is the Sudler Companies of Parsippany. 
In addition, Pearson Education, a publisher in Upper Saddle River, is taking a 800,000-square-foot building at a 150-acre park, also in Cranbury, that the Rockefeller Group Development Corporation is planning. It will rise on half of a 300-acre parcel owned by the Carter Wallace Corporation. 
Gene Preston, a vice president of the Rockefeller Group, said the proposed park would ultimately have two million square feet. He said he expected state and federal approval in a few weeks of his company's application to open an extension at the Cranbury site of the foreign trade zone it operates in Mount Olive in Morris County. 
A free trade zone, which allows for decreased or delayed custom fees, is new in the 8A region. "It will help attract multinational companies," Mr. Preston said. 
Area landlords at first fought the zone but now may pursue an application of their own. 
Mr. Malloy of Trammell Crow added that it would take just two more sizable deals to reduce the speculative space at 8A to 2 percent from 5 percent. 
Agreeing with that assessment is Charles C. Lee Jr., Keystone's senior vice president for marketing and leasing. Though tenants are taking longer to seal deals, there "are 8 to 10 users in our flight pattern," he said of his company's two 8A projects. 
Mr. Lee said a 473,000-square-foot building rising west of the turnpike was to be completed by July; a 510,000-square-foot project, which is expandable to a million square feet, on the east side of the turnpike, will follow in October. Asking rents are $4.95 a square foot. 
In the Meadowlands, Cushman & Wakefield reports that there are more opportunities to find space today than three months ago. But commercial brokers added that the region, which covers parts of seven communities in Bergen and Hudson Counties, continues to draw attention from tenants, especially those that want to be near Manhattan, keeping the vacancy rate at 4.5 percent. 
Earlier this month, Federal Express leased a 127,000-square-foot warehouse at Chippewa Street in South Hackensack, according to Alexander Summer/Cresa, a commercial brokerage in Paramus. 
To meet the needs of the market for modern space, Forsgate Industrial Complex, a development company based in Teterboro, is razing an empty 128,000-square-foot one-story building with 14-foot-high ceilings at Huyler Street and Route 80 in South Hackensack. The plan is to replace it with a new 140,000-square-foot building, to include a new mezzanine, with a 34-foot-high ceiling, 22 loading docks and floors that can support 2,000 pounds a square foot, said Charles Klatskin, a partner.
He said the project, to be completed by next year's first quarter, cost $100 a square foot to build. But he said he expected tenants will pay up to $13 to $14 a square foot for such space. The average asking rent in the area, Cushman & Wakefield said, is $6.60 a square foot.
"Finding a building in the Meadowlands with both high ceilings and strong floors," Mr. Klatskin said, "is like finding a water fountain in the desert."
