HEADLINE: Colonial Revival: Shaping and Reshaping the Island 

BYLINE:  By HELEN A. HARRISON 

 BODY:
WHEN the businessman and philanthropist Ward Melville and his architect, Richard Smythe, mapped out the redevelopment of Stony Brook, they chose the Colonial Revival style for the shopping and service complex that transformed the village in the early 1940's. 
 Starting with what Melville described as a "hodgepodge of structures of no beauty, crowded in among a few residences well built in the Colonial tradition," they fashioned a hybrid community center that not only harmonized genuine 18th- and early-19th century buildings with new construction, but also accommodated modern-day needs and conveniences within an idealized Colonial framework. 
 To make sense of this phenomenon, which by no means was confined to Stony Brook, the Long Island Museum of Art, History and Carriages -- a mere half mile from Melville and Smythe's renovation -- has organized "Improving the Past: The Colonial Revival on Long Island," an exhibition that will remain on view through Nov. 4. 
With paintings, prints, architectural drawings, furniture, photographs, publications and artifacts lent by several museums and drawn from the Long Island Museum's own collection, the show represents the geographical region from Flushing to East Hampton and focuses on the architecture and decorative arts of English heritage. Dutch Colonial references -- like Father Knickerbocker, who invites homebuyers of 1908 to settle in the cozy Dutch-themed community of Jamaica Park South -- are also included, but the emphasis is on the veneration and adaptation of English precedents. 
Nostalgia for America's Colonial past began in earnest in the mid-19th century, when firsthand experience of the Revolutionary War was fading and its veterans were dying off. William Sidney Mount, the Stony Brook genre painter, recorded the new-found reverence for historical continuity in "Great-Grand-Father's Tale of the Revolution," an 1852 canvas on loan from the Metropolitan Museum of Art, in which an elderly veteran recounts his wartime exploits to his descendants. As the children listen attentively, the old man delivers his oral history lesson while contemplating an effigy of George Washington, thus linking the Colonial era to the young nation's future through the power of memory.
To set the stage for the revival phenomenon, the museum's history curator, Joshua Ruff, has assembled a sampling of memorabilia commemorating national icons, especially Washington. The armchair in which the general reportedly sat while visiting the Ketchum family of Huntington in 1790, lent by the Winterthur Museum in Delaware, memorializes both Washington himself and the vernacular furniture of the pre-Revolutionary era -- a style later copied in popular reproductions for the mass market. 
Washington's home, Mount Vernon, established a precedent for numerous adaptations of a more genteel sort, including the 1903 James L. Breese House in Southampton. Designed by the firm of McKim, Mead & White, and now known as Whitefields, it is one of the Island's many grand country houses and summer cottages built in the late-19th and early-20th centuries that reflect Colonial influences.
Another outstanding example is Chestertown House, the Southampton retreat of the industrialist Henry F. du Pont. Completed in 1926, the house was designed as a showcase for du Pont's important collection of Colonial antiques, including an imposing late-18th-century wing chair, English prints, a hooked rug and Staffordshire pottery lent to the exhibition by the Winterthur, which du Pont established as a center for the display and study of American decorative arts. According to Mr. Ruff, du Pont originally envisioned his museum in Chestertown House, but ultimately opted for a location near Wilmington, his company's base of operations. Period photographs show the Chestertown interior as a pastiche of real and recreated Colonial elements, in which reverence for the past is wedded to modern comfort.
With its concentration of second homes for wealthy and influential tastemakers, Long Island was at the forefront of Colonial Revival architecture and decoration in its heyday, from the 1870's through the 1950's. Emily J. de Forest filled her Cold Spring Harbor retreat with rare Pennsylvania German artifacts, many of which are now in the Metropolitan's collection. In Oyster Bay, Bertha King Benkard assembled a suite of elegant antiques that might once have graced the town houses of upper-class New Yorkers. One of her acquisitions, a handsome early-19th-century card table on loan from the Museum of the City of New York, was later re-worked by Ernest Hagen, one of the many craftsmen and designers who specialized in high-quality reproductions. In their Flushing workshop, the Company of Master Craftsmen produced replicas of Duncan Phyfe furniture from the Metropolitan's collection for the parlors and board rooms of the elite, while in Sag Harbor, the Alvin Silver Manufacturing Company made elegant flatware based on early American prototypes.
At the opposite economic extreme, the exhibition evokes the rustic simplicity of East Hampton's "Home, Sweet Home," immortalized in John Howard Payne's popular 1822 ballad as a symbol of an increasingly urban and industrialized society's nostalgia for the timeless harmony of rural life. The quaint saltbox cottage, with its fabled stone hearth, had become a tourist mecca even before the railroad made it readily accessible from New York City. William Cullen Bryant praised its unsophisticated virtues in "Picturesque America," his compendium of attractions published in the mid-1870's, and artists made pilgrimages to it. 
One of its most devoted fans was Childe Hassam, the American Impressionist painter. In 1919, Hassam bought an 18th-century home in East Hampton, where he painted "Colonial Quilt," a still life in which the antique coverlet, artfully arranged before a window, is enclosed in an actual window frame. Hassam's views of venerable village landmarks, including "Home, Sweet Home," and the adjacent Mulford farm, attest to his enduring affection for these remnants of the area's New England heritage. Echoes of this admiration can be found in the modern variations on the saltbox and other Colonial-derived vernacular housing designs that are ubiquitous in suburban developments nationwide, with a fair share in 20th-century Long Island communities like Levittown.
As the exhibition clearly shows, Colonial-style revisionism involves a compromise between past and present. Improvements like central heating, electric lighting and modern appliances are integrated into faux 18th-century homes, and stables and outbuildings have been replaced by attached garages. The desire to return a semblance of Colonial charm to Stony Brook village did not deter Melville and Smythe from installing paved roads, parking lots and fire hydrants. Even genuine Colonial survivors, like Williamsburg, Mount Vernon and Monticello, have been adapted to meet contemporary traffic and safety requirements. Paradoxically, the popularity of historical relics threatens their integrity and sometimes even their survival. 
But if the ancient Windsor chair is now too fragile to sit on, countless sturdy replicas are available, and home furnishing outlets offer up-to-date electrified versions of the smelly, dangerous old oil and gas lamps. In "Improving the Past," sales catalogs and promotional brochures tout the tastefulness and charm of period designs, as well as their adaptability to modern living. The exhibition celebrates the Colonial Revival's longstanding appeal and enduring influence on American taste, and illustrates the many refinements that keep it in continual evolution.

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Somerset, N.J.; 
Diversity, Stability and Convenience

BYLINE:  By JERRY CHESLOW 

 BODY:
WEDGED between the city of New Brunswick and the more rural southern section of Franklin Township, Somerset, N.J., is a model of diversity. The village's neighborhoods vary from tightly packed urban areas along the New Brunswick city line to sprawling, tree-lined suburban developments of hundreds of houses on half-acre lots. Although one-third of its school population lives in poverty, Somerset is also a magnet for young professionals, who are drawn to its stable neighborhoods, convenient shopping and easy commuting to Manhattan.
 Somerset forms the northeast quadrant of the 47-square-mile Franklin Township in Somerset County. A Chamber of Commerce map shows the village as running from the New Brunswick line to Cedar Grove Lane to the west. The area is home to three-fourths of the township's 51,000 residents and encompasses its business district, most of its major cultural attractions and an 18-hole golf course. 
 Realtors say the housing market is red-hot. "Houses here sell for about one-third less than similar ones in nearby towns like East Brunswick and North Brunswick," said Mary Barrood, a broker who owns the Barrood Real Estate and Insurance Agency on Easton Avenue. "Priced right, a house in good condition on a desirable street will sell within days. Every agent has a list of three to six customers who are ready to buy." 
Michael Santini, a broker who owns Prudential Golden Key Realty in neighboring Piscataway, says Somerset buyers are typically young professional couples who commute to jobs in Manhattan. "They are looking for homes in turnkey condition in stable neighborhoods near shopping, highways and New York City transportation," he said. 
Somerset is minutes from Interstate 287 to the west and the New Jersey Turnpike to the east. Easton Avenue, a section of Somerset County Route 527 along the northern edge of Somerset, is lined with shopping centers, and two major malls -- Bridgewater Commons to the north and the Brunswick Square to the east -- are within 15 miles. 
The neighborhoods most in demand are the 996-unit Levitt Homes, built in the mid-1960's off John F. Kennedy Boulevard and DeMott Lane, and Foxwood, a 300-unit development of three- and four-bedroom split-levels and bilevels built in the early 1960's off Franklin Boulevard. Four-bedroom Levitt Cape Cods, colonials and ranches on streets like Landry or on Renfro Court sell for $200,000 to $280,000. Foxwood houses bring $175,000 to $200,000, Mrs. Barrood said. 
"I love the space and the diversity of the community," said Carol Devine, who has lived in a three-bedroom ranch on five-eighths of an acre in the Levitt section, together with her husband, Jim, and her daughter, Lauren, 15. for the last 14 years. "However, the area has become more crowded and congested lately because of new housing in Franklin and other parts of Somerset County. Jim, on the other hand, misses the feeling of a downtown." 
Harder to sell are older colonials and Cape Cods on streets near the New Brunswick line. "This area of Somerset developed earliest, so its housing is showing its age," said Frank Hasner, township director of economic development for Franklin. "A lot of the property is owned by absentee landlords, so the yards are not as well maintained."
Houses on streets like Main or Kossuth near New Brunswick are priced at $120,000 to $160,000.
Franklin Township has started buying property near New Brunswick as part of a neighborhood redevelopment effort. Kenneth W. Daly, the township manager, says Franklin is negotiating with contractors over the construction of so-called infill housing, new sidewalks and other public amenities. The township is also seeking state and federal funds to provide loans and grants to property owners for renovations and improvements. 
THE first part of the economic redevelopment effort, a $2 million reconstruction of the 13-acre Naaman Williams Park off Matilda Avenue, is under way. When complete this summer, the park will include a swimming pool, a splash area, two basketball courts, a jogging trail, two tennis courts, a multiuse field and a playground.
According to Mrs. Barrood, 46 Somerset single-family homes were listed for sale in the Multiple Listing Service at the start of May. They ranged from $89,900 for a two-bedroom, one-bath older Cape being sold as-is on Frank Street near New Brunswick to $564,900 for a four-bedroom, four-bath colonial on Maher Road.
The largest new development is Glen Eyre, Les Maison Des Artistes, where 78 custom homes are being built on streets named for artists, like Picasso Court and Degas Lane. The houses start in the high $300,000's.
Most of Somerset's condominiums are in the Quailbrook section off New Brunswick Road. It includes 2,213 condos on streets named for the late Challenger astronauts. Prices range from $85,000 for one-bedroom apartment-style units to $280,000 for some three-bedroom, two-and-a-half-bath town house units with one-car garages and basements. 
Also in the Quailbrook section is the 197-acre county-owned Quail Brook Golf Course, where Somerset County residents who register with the county's Department of Parks can play a round for $14 on weekdays and $16 on weekends.
The largest apartment complex is the 649-unit Franklin Greens off John F. Kennedy Boulevard, where one-bedroom units rent for $895 and two bedrooms bring $150 more. The best-known apartment complex is the 398-unit Somerset Estates, formerly called Edgemere, off Franklin Boulevard, where two-bedroom units rent for $975 and three bedrooms for $1,200. 
Among the new tenants at Somerset Estates are Mary Clinton and her two sons: Keon, 14, and Kendall, 8. "We moved here to be closer to my job as a kitchen supervisor in a New Brunswick hospital," Mrs. Clinton said. "The apartment is large enough for us, the rent is affordable and the neighborhood is clean."
Mrs. Clinton's children attend the Franklin Township public schools, a 6,100-student kindergarten-through-12th-grade system that includes five elementary schools, the Sampson G. Smith Intermediate School and the 1,450-student Franklin High School. However, Mrs. Devine says that, because of concerns about behavioral problems in the school system, she sends Lauren to a private school in a nearby town.
But Sgt. Richard Grammar, head of the Police Juvenile Bureau, says that the schools are extremely safe but suffer from a reputation created 20 years ago when they were more violent. "I send my own child to kindergarten in Franklin," he said. "We have had no serious incidents all year."
Sergeant Grammar heads a 10-officer team that teaches classes and participates in school recreational activities.
The elementary schools are arranged as magnets, with two schools stressing the fine, visual and performing arts; two stressing science and technology; and the fifth stressing the arts, science and technology and international studies.
Enrollment in the system is growing rapidly, with class sizes at each of the schools above the state average of 20.6. The superintendent of schools, Frank V. Pepe Jr., projects that there will be 7,000 students in the system by 2005. Last week, Franklin Township voters approved a referendum for the construction of a new high school, expected to cost $50 million.
Each classroom has at least one computer and each school at least one computer laboratory. The high school has six computer laboratories. At the end of last year, 30 percent of Franklin's classrooms were connected to the Internet, compared with a state average of 70 percent. Mr. Pepe says that all classrooms will have Internet access by the end of this year.
THE student body is diverse, with 57 different languages spoken in the homes and enrollment of 300 in English as a second language courses. Among the highest concentrations are Spanish; Gujarati, an Indian language; Cantonese; and Arabic. Mr. Pepe sees diversity as a strength and says he seeks to "affirm every child in every family." 
On last year's College Boards, Franklin High School students achieved combined verbal and mathematics scores of 956, compared with a state average of 1,012. "The comparison doesn't reflect the achievement of our students in becoming Americans or the fact that 30 percent of our students live in poverty," Mr. Pepe said. Of the 266 members of last year's graduating class, 81 percent went on to two-or four-year colleges.
There are two private schools in Somerset: the 695-student Rutgers Preparatory School for prekindergarten through 12th grade and the 590-student St. Matthias, a Roman Catholic school for prekindergarten through eighth grade. Tuition at Rutgers Prep ranges from $11,500 to $17,150. Tuition at St. Matthias is $4,370. 
A milestone in Somerset's history was the opening in 1834 of the Delaware & Raritan Canal, a 44-mile inland navigation route between New York City and Philadelphia, which runs along Somerset's northern border.
Closed as a freight system in 1933, the canal and its towpath now form the Delaware & Raritan Canal State Park, which is used for canoeing, fishing, hiking and biking. 
Somerset also figured prominently in World War I. In 1913, the Marconi Wireless Telegraph Company built a giant radio transmission station in Somerset and suspended a milelong antenna from a series of 440-foot-high steel masts along the canal route.
In 1918, President Woodrow Wilson used the station to broadcast an appeal to Germany's Kaiser Wilhelm II to abdicate, an address that historians credit with hastening the armistice.
The station has since been dismantled. However the Guglielmo Marconi Memorial Plaza, on the corner of Easton Avenue and John F. Kennedy Boulevard, has been dedicated to the inventor.

HEADLINE: The Laptop Idea Is Spreading 

BYLINE:  By DAVID PARKER 

 BODY:
CONNECTICUT has not been a leader in classroom technology or, specifically, in giving laptop computers a key educational role, said Nick Caruso, a senior associate at the Connecticut Association of Boards of Education.
 Education Week magazine two years ago ranked Connecticut 42nd among the 50 states in terms of effort on school technology, he said. But across the state's 169 local school districts, plenty of initiatives are in progress, in districts as dissimilar as Greenwich and Hartford. 
 "It's kind of like we're poised to really move ahead," Mr. Caruso said.
Janice Gordon, the mobile learning coordinator for the Hartford school system, said the city launched a laptop program last year in all three high schools to address an alarming dropout rate. 
With 90 percent of students' families at or below the poverty rate, Ms. Gordon said, "we're doing everything we can to motivate the students, to have them see education as relevant."
The leased IBM laptops, now in the hands of more than 350 9th and 10th graders, go home with the students, as they do in Kent and Bloomfield, she said. In most homes they're the first computer the family has had, and while "motivating the students we're also motivating the families."
"They start to get excited by what's going on in the high school," Ms. Gordon said. "Parent participation has usually not been very strong here."
After about 14 months, Ms. Gordon said there was a 92 percent retention rate for students in the program.
In Greenwich, there is a different approach to laptop use. Susan Wallerstein, the technology and media coordinator, said two middle schools had deployed a limited number of laptops for in-school use. The aim is to carefully choose the technology that meets specific educational needs, Ms. Wallerstein said.
Statewide, several magnet schools have also developed laptop programs, and Mr. Caruso predicted the trend will continue, as the educational benefits become more obvious.
For one thing, he said, "what we consider a computer is going to change a lot." He said he thinks that more schools will look favorably at smaller, sometimes less costly laptop models.
Meanwhile, the cost of textbooks, now $60 or more apiece and rapidly outdated, keeps skyrocketing. That will make schools consider the educational and economic alternative of giving students a single three-ounce computer disk, which, with an Internet link, will give them instant access to more material, continuously updated.
"When you look at it that way," Mr. Caruso said, "the cost issue becomes less a deterrent and the digital learning alternative becomes both more timely and appropriate.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Business Centers; 
Modern Office for Rent: Daily Rates Available

BYLINE:  By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
The illusion is quite convincing. The lobby is spacious, with a staffed reception desk, a waiting area with comfortable seating and wide hallways. If a call comes in for the XYZ Corporation, the operator answers, "Thank you for calling the XYZ Corporation."
 There are conference rooms for meetings with clients, file cabinets with digital locks and word processing and other support services. If a visitor arrives, he or she is escorted to an office for a meeting. 
 But what appears to be an bastion of Corporate America may only be a 150-square-foot office rented for a few weeks or months. This is a business center, the modern version of the temporary office suites that have been around for about the last 30 years. 
The offices, operated by the Rockefeller Group Business Centers on two floors of the building at 1180 Avenue of the Americas, have been carefully designed to conceal how big or small their tenants are. There are no names on the doors to the suite or on any individual offices.
"We don't advertise ourselves on the floor because it could be confusing to the guests of our clients," said Frederic Z. Sondik, a senior vice president of the Rockefeller Group. "Our telephone operators have screens, which tell them how to answer calls to our clients. We don't even have numbers on the doors, the way hotels do, that would give an idea of the size of our clients."
Mr. Sondik said his company got into the business center business when it still owned Rockefeller Center and needed to find tenants for some vacant floors in the landmark buildings. The company subsequently lost control of the center but remains in business as a property owner and developer and as the owner of Cushman & Wakefield, the real estate services company.
The business center unit of the company still operates a floor and a half at 45 Rockefeller Plaza in addition to the Avenue of the Americas location. The parent company plans to build a six-story, 100,000-square-foot building in San Jose, Calif., that would have four floors occupied by the business center.
The Rockefeller Group business center operations are small compared with the giants of the industry -- Regus Business Centers and HQ Global Workplaces -- which have a worldwide presence, although the business models are similar.
A business center converts the fixed costs of entering into a long-term lease, designing and building space, acquiring telecommunications and computer equipment and hiring a staff into a variable cost for clients who use the offices for short-term renewable periods. The rental rate for such space is higher than for raw space and all services are additional expenses, but a client has the advantage of buying what it needs and no more.
MR. SONDIK said typical business center clients were management consultants, financial services executives like those in venture capital, executive recruiters and advertising sales representatives. They need furnished offices at a respectable address with support services available, but may not need them for an extended time.
But others in the business say larger companies are being attracted to business centers because they allow them to conserve capital.
"Seventy percent of our clients are national and multinational companies," said Robert R. Gaudreau, executive vice president and head of American operations of the British-based Regus. He said the recent economic slowdown had made companies reluctant to enter into long-term leases, particularly in areas of the country where rental rates remain high.
"Nobody wants to sign a 10-year lease in New York and get locked in at the top of the market," he said. "And why should they tie up their operating capital in Sheetrock, carpet and paint?"
A variation on this theme is Offices2share.com, a Web site that is intended to link companies that have excessive office space with others looking for a short-term space. "We are an aggregator of short-term space, from 80 square feet to over 100,000 square feet," said Jeffrey Landers, the president of the company. He said the site was supported by a fee paid by companies listing available space and by banner advertisements placed by companies seeking tenants, including Regus.
Regus has two locations in New York, one on the 93rd floor of 2 World Trade Center downtown and 70,000 square feet on two floors in the building at 245 Park Avenue at 46th Street in Midtown.
"The executive suite business has been around for about 30 years and evolved from call-answering centers for traveling salesman," said Gary Kusin, chief executive of HQ, which is largely owned by the Frontline Capital Group, an affiliate of Reckson Associates Realty, a real estate investment trust based in Melville, N.Y..
He said the business changed in the mid-1990's toward one that is more service oriented because of three factors. First, he said, was improvement in communications technology, which allowed executives to be based closer to customers and farther from headquarters. Another consideration, he said, was the globalization of business, which required offices around the world. Finally, he said, there was the trend of outsourcing noncore operations, including office space and the associated services.
"That is what converted executives suites to office services," he said.
Mr. Kusin said telecommunications and technology companies, including dot-coms, were the most aggressive in using temporary offices and services. "Through 2000, we had record occupancy, always north of 90 percent," he said.
But that concentration of dot-com and telecommunications tenants has become a problem as the shakeout in those sectors has continued. "We have clearly been impacted by the economy, and our occupancy is down to the mid-70's," Mr. Kusin said.
Nevertheless, he said the downturn in occupancy could be nearing an end, as inquiries from prospective tenants seeking short-term space were picking up again. He said about 2 percent of all the office space in the country was devoted to business centers. HQ has 26 locations in Manhattan, including space in the Chrysler and Woolworth Buildings, in 1633 Broadway at 50th Street and in the Wall Street area.
A business center operator typically leases space on a long-term basis from a landlord and subdivides for clients or enters into a joint venture with the building's owner, which conserves capital and allows more rapid expansion. "We have joint ventures with Equity Office Properties, Crescent Real Estate and, in Canada, with Brookfield Financial Properties," Mr. Gaudreau of Regus said, referring to three large owners of office buildings.
The space is fitted out with offices as small as 150 square feet, which would otherwise be difficult to find. Instead of a thick, complicated lease, the space is rented on a license agreement, like a hotel room, and can be paid for by a credit card.
THE offices are furnished and equipped for telecommunications and Internet access. Typically, the client rents his work space -- Mr. Gaudreau said the typical charge is about $28 a day outside expensive markets like New York and San Francisco -- and pays for other services as needed.
Typically, the rental rate is higher for short-term occupancies than longer ones, but if an executive needs an office for a few hours to conduct job interviews in a given city, business center executives say, they are prepared to accommodate him.
When it comes to services, at the Rockefeller Group business centers in New York, a conference room can be rented for $50 an hour or $280 for a full day. Word processing service can be had for $36 an hour, or if it is a rush job, for $54 an hour. Administrative assistance costs $28 an hour.
"People can come in here and start doing business without any startup costs or delays," Mr. Sondik said. "They don't have to have a lawyer for the lease and an architect for the space. They don't have to purchase equipment and wait three months for a T-1 line to be installed."
He said the center had what he called "virtual office clients" who occupied no space but had an address and telephone number, rented a few file cabinets and used a conference room when they were in town.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut; 
Fairfield Market Reacts to Wall St. Ups and Downs

BYLINE:  By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
THE single-family housing market in Fairfield County, where shots fired from Wall Street land with particular resonance, is responding to the tumultuous stock market with corresponding ups, downs and inconsistencies. High prices resulting from months of low inventories have led buyers to bid above asking prices, in turn leading to more houses becoming available by newly motivated sellers seeking handsome profits.
 "It's almost unpleasant the way people behave to get the house before somebody else does," said Amy Carter, a broker with William Raveis Real Estate in Wilton. "It's a seller's market," she added, an opinion shared by county brokers, some of whom also hear echoes of the 80's, when the economy sank and overpriced houses bought in boom times were suddenly worth less than their outstanding mortgages. 
 People who are making windfall profits on their homes can pay more for new homes, said Barbara Webski, a broker at William Pitt Real Estate in Stamford, "but people who are currently renting are getting a tough education in the bidding wars." 
John Clapp, a professor of real estate at the University of Connecticut's Center for Real Estate and Economic Studies, sees no effect on high-end prices in certain areas. "Over the five months ending in March," he said, "prices in Stamford grew more than 40 percent from the previous year. But in Bridgeport, prices are going down by up to 12 percent a year." A range of $360,000 to $375,000 prevails in Bridgeport and Danbury, he said, "but Danbury is growing rapidly, and a 10 to 20 percent increase in prices is accelerating."
In Greenwich, usually the most resilient of Gold Coast towns, the average price of a home declined by 3 percent last year, to $1,782,885, from $1,842,040, said Russell Pruner, owner of Russell Pruner & Associates, a real estate brokerage company. "We're still getting multiple bids and selling over asking if the house is well priced and in good condition," he said. But his company's statistics show that 61 fewer homes were sold in the first quarter of this year than the 197 sold last year, a 31 percent decrease. Yet the number of available properties rose to 398 from last year's 372. 
The average price of a home in Stamford is now $517,181, while the median price -- with an equal number of houses priced higher and lower -- is $415,000, according to statistics provided by William Pitt. "We have sold 179 houses" in the first quarter, Ms. Webski said. Last year, 292 homes were sold in the first quarter, when the median price was $397,000 and the average was $461,805. "Prices are coming on a little too high," she said, "then dropping down two weeks later and down again in another two weeks." 
Homeowners hopping on the seller's bandwagon in Norwalk have created a very hot market, according to Carol Ann Falasco, a broker at Coldwell Banker. "Prices are outrageous," she said. A two-bedroom, one-bath house of 1,500 square feet sold for $304,000 in January and was resold on April 22 for $335,000. "People come here for a better deal, knowing that prices are lower than in surrounding towns," Ms. Falasco said. "They call from out of town, and by the time they get here the house is bindered. We used to negotiate; now buyers realize they grab it or lose it."
Norwalk's traditionally viable market in the mid-$100,000's to high-$200,000's has shrunk markedly. The first quarter of this year produced 251 listings at a median price of $374,900 and an average of $513,741. Last year's 250 listings over the same period were at a median price of $369,250 and an average of $458,498. 
Rapid growth in Danbury is attributable in part to buyers from across the border in New York State in northern Westchester and southern Putnam Counties, drawn by lower prices and lower taxes. "Normally you would have local people moving up," said Allyson Bernard of Real Estate Professionals of Connecticut L.L.C., a Danbury brokerage, "but we've had an influx of new buyers with money who go directly to the upper levels of housing." But some buyers, she said, are backing off, saying they will wait for a more realistic market.
STARTER homes that were priced at less than $200,000 have jumped to $220,000 and $230,000. A four-bedroom house on the desirable West Side runs from $400,000 to $550,000, and newly built houses are priced at up to $600,000, according to Richard Jowdy at Danbury Prudential Real Estate. 
Just before last Thanksgiving, Warren and Patricia Lee put their Wilton house up for sale. They have been the sole owners since it was built for them 37 years ago. "We had a lot of traffic, but no sale," Mr. Lee said. The price was lowered to $509,000 from $519,000 a month later, and again in March to $495,000. It sold in April at that price. The four-bedroom, two-and-a-half-bath house on 2.3 mostly wooded acres is air-conditioned with a two-car garage, and like most back country homes has a well and septic system. 
The sale price is typical of a decade ago, but in today's Wilton it is almost an anomaly. "A million dollars is the average here now," said Mary Schuler, a Raveis broker. "We have 45 homes priced over $1 million. Within this past year, I had one buyer pay $51,000 over asking on a million-dollar cash sale."
Raveis customers who need a mortgage can use the company's own American Mortgage Services, a component of the Homelink program originated by William Raveis a year ago to provide customers with free mortgage placement involving 30 lenders and 1,500 loan programs. "Our agents are not required to use us," said Jeffrey Stephanoff, a senior vice president of the mortgage service, "but we have captured more and more of the sales." 
Homelink also automatically provides a free personal coordinator who takes over the moving, home inspection, transfer of utilities, choice of vendors for landscaping, alarm systems, pet fencing, newspaper delivery and so on. The system has been adopted by 79 brokerages across the country that are part of his network. Other real estate companies are starting similar services. 
Shopping for homes in Westport, Weston, Fairfield and Stratford is available through the Westport office of Coldwell Banker. Some higher-end Westport deals have fallen through, said Venus Weinrich, the office manager, "because a lot of people who were expecting big bonuses have not gotten them, or they may not have bid enough, or they asked for too much from the inspection." The low end, she said, in the $500,000's and up is selling faster. 
"You get more for your money in Stratford," she said, "especially if you're looking on the water. Prices are 25 to 30 percent lower than in Westport, but of course you don't have the schools." Weston and Easton prices remain stable and high. Fairfield, a five-minute commute beyond Westport, has at its low end three-bedroom, one-and-a-half-bath Cape Cods that were $200,000 now selling for more than $300,000. In Fairfield's high-end neighborhoods, Southport's waterfront antiques and contemporary homes and Greenfield Hill's properties where homeowners can keep horses continue to sell for millions. 
New Canaan has had a 15 percent decrease in first-quarter sales but a 20 percent increase in prices. "Approximately 30 percent of our active inventory is new construction over $2 million," said GiGi Melillo of Coldwell Banker. Of 140 properties listed, most are between $1 million and $5 million, with only 44 under $1 million.
More than 50 new homes are being built in New Canaan, including one of 22,000 square feet. "There are a lot of knockdowns," said Hiram Peck, the town planner, referring to the practice of buying existing houses, demolishing them and putting up larger, more ostentatious ones, derided by detractors as McMansions. "Empty lots, when you can find one, go for $750,000," he said.
The high end in Darien, "from $2.4 million and up," said Chris Simmers, manager of the Prudential office there, "is a little soft. We've had one buyer drop out because of Wall Street losses, but the stock market really hasn't affected us yet. Properties are still going to multiple offers."
New construction countywide continues at a moderate pace, rarely falling below the million-dollar range in lower Fairfield. In upper Fairfield, Trumbull and Monroe have a dozen new homes for sale by Munson Builders of Fairfield, priced at $500,000 to $700,000. According to Maureen Callaghan, director of sales and marketing, a handful of new Munson-built homes in Westport and Southport are priced at $1.1 million and up.
In Westport, where a battle over McMansions has been raging for two years, stiffer regulations on house size will be presented at a September public hearing. Cathy Barnard, Westport's town planner, said, "We have not seen a slowdown in building permits, but projects are becoming more complicated, requiring protracted review." The reasons are a lack of land except for marginal parcels with slopes and wetlands, and tear-down-and-rebuild projects that challenge planning and zoning concepts.

An article in Connecticut and Westchester copies last Sunday about the Fairfield County market misstated the affiliation of Venus Weinrich, an executive who commented on the Westport area. She is the manager of the Preferred Properties office in Westport, not the Coldwell Banker office.

HEADLINE: Ansonia Gets Hit Where It Really Hurts 

BYLINE:  By VIRGINIA GROARK 

 BODY:
FOR more than a decade, Latex Foam Products has provided a steady stream of customers for J.R.B.'s Restaurant.
 Located across the street from the Ansonia manufacturing plant, the dimly lighted restaurant and bar has sold pizza and grinders to employees who have stopped by for lunch, played host to going-away parties and or had a drink after work. 
So when Dawn Kahyaoglu, a co-owner of the restaurant, saw flames shooting from the factory's roof last Monday, she burst into tears, fearing first for her customers' safety. She is wondering what impact the fire will have on her business and her tenants who live above the restaurant and work at the plant. 
"I'm not really a money-hungry person," she said. "Just to know that they're all O.K. is enough. This is going to affect a lot."
Ms. Kahyaoglu is one of several business owners in downtown Ansonia who are trying to gauge the impact of the fire that turned a manufacturer of pillows, foam mattresses and cosmetic sponge pads into a mound of twisted metal, charred brick and smoldering debris.
The factory was not only one of the largest taxpayers in this blue-collar town, it also was one of the largest employers, drawing hundreds of people downtown each day.
Company officials have said they would not decide whether to rebuild until they discussed the finances with insurers. But even if they decide to reopen, workers said it would be a long time before the plant would be operational. That means many workers could face long stretches of unemployment or they may have to move to search for work. 
"Just the whole thing is devastating," said Ken Kreiger, co-owner of Spector Furniture on Main Street, which sells the plant's mattresses and pillows. "If people aren't working in the area, obviously it's going to affect everybody."
So while workers like Charlie Ferriolo, a 30-year-old production supervisor at the plant, try to figure out where they will go next, some downtown merchants are wondering how they will survive when the people who used to work at the plant stop coming in.
Paul Ciocca, co-owner of Eddy's Bake Shop on Main Street, is considering reducing his staff.
"We will have to see what the effect is going to be," he said. "It's the last thing we want to do." 
The fire comes at a time when Ansonia is trying to make a comeback. In the heart of the Naugatuck River Valley, the community has been known for years as a place that is not only home to competitive high school football teams, but also a place where weaving mills and factories once flourished.
In the early to mid-20th century, thousands of people came downtown to work at the mills that sit along the Naugatuck River. Charles Seccombe, 75, who owns a downtown men's clothing store, said that when he was a young boy the sidewalks were filled with people.
"You'd always be pushed off the sidewalk," he said.
Over the years, the town faced its share of disasters. On Aug. 19, 1955, a day some residents refer to as Black Friday, a flood devastated the town, causing more than $20 million in damage to commercial and residential buildings, said Phyllis Judd, a historian at the Ansonia Library. And economic downturns forced factories to close, move out of town or reduce staff. Today, hundreds, not thousands, of people, work at the remaining plants.
"It's just been a long slide here," said Bill Bassett, president of the Shelton-based W. E. Bassett Company, which makes everything from tweezers to emery boards. "Ansonia is one of those towns that has certainly been impacted by it. They certainly don't have the employee base that they used to have, and the newer firms aren't coming in." 
Latex Foam, an offspring of the Sponge Rubber Products Company, a factory that burned down in Shelton in 1975, is one company that has managed to survive. The company, which opened its plant in Ansonia in 1984, boasts that it's the world's largest producer of latex pillows and cosmetic sponges. Last year it had sales of about $50 million, a company official said. 
The company developed a reputation of being community oriented, playing a significant philanthropic role in the region. In addition to giving money to social service groups, it has donated mattresses to a domestic violence shelter. Employees have given clothes and other items to My Sister's Place, a nonprofit thrift store whose proceeds benefit the Ansonia-based Birmingham Group Health Services' domestic violence programs. 
"They have just been really, really good community citizens," said Marilyn Cormack, president and chief executive of the Birmingham Group. "They would identify a need and they would be right there to help us." 
Despite the loss, Mr. Kreiger, whose furniture store has existed since 1890, said the town would recover. Ansonia and the Naugatuck Valley have a long history of working together to overcome adversity.
In addition, Ansonia is beginning to experience a turnaround, the Kreigers said. As businesses and people move north from Fairfield County in search of cheaper land, places like Ansonia should benefit. Just last month, Obsidium Antiques opened in a former bank building on Main Street. Across the street, a women's boutique shop, Only For Her, has opened. "It's on the upswing," Ken Kreiger said.
Still, the fire will be likely to affect places like Eddy's Bake Shop. The Main Street bakery sold doughnuts and coffee to employees who stopped by before work and it baked cakes for office functions. 
"You don't know what's going to happen," said Mr. Ciocca, whose family has owned the bakery for about 40 years. "I think time will tell how bad it's really going to be."

HEADLINE: What I Did (for Others) on My Summer Vacation 

BYLINE:  By BILL KENT 

 BODY:
YOU'RE not supposed to work during your vacation.
 So why would anyone want to volunteer to wash dishes, sort cans at a food bank, seat patrons at a theater, tackle painting projects or spend quality time with elderly, disadvantaged or disabled people on their vacation? 
 Here's why, according to Betty Rooney of Ridgewood.
"We are so fortunate in so many ways," she said, "that I want our children to realize how fortunate they are, and to build relationships with families and other people who may not be so fortunate."
Twice a month this summer, Mrs. Rooney expects to take her husband and four children to a soup kitchen, a family shelter or a state park, and help out with what most would call chores. 
Helping out during the vacation season "is even easier because there are more outdoor activities that are really easy," she said. "The family decides what we want to do, when we want to do it and how much time we want to put into it. Then I contact the organization, work out the details, and then we just show up."
In April, for example, the Rooneys showed up at the New Jersey section of Palisades Interstate Park and spent a Sunday morning cleaning up the park's waterfront.
"I had never been there but we picked this because my 6-year-old, Brendan, likes boats," Mrs. Rooney said, "and I heard the park had a marina, I figured, why not?" 
The Rooneys' efforts were supervised by a park ranger "who told us all kind of interesting things about the park, its geology and place in history," she said, adding: "I never expected to learn so much. Things like that happen all the time when you volunteer. There are always unexpected benefits."
Some volunteers have even found love. Synergy, a Monmouth County volunteer group of 80 single professionals, ranging in age from 20 to 65, has recently celebrated its second wedding among its members, though "that's not what we're about," said Rob Rowley, an Atlantic Highlands developer who is also the group's treasurer. 
Members of the group, now in its 11th year, expect to volunteer for as many as 25 events each month this summer, which range from food bank duty to staffing athletic competitions and taking tickets at concerts.
"We work for thank-you's, T-shirts and lunch," Mr. Rowley said. "We don't go into this asking for anything other than an opportunity to help."
Though some members have children, "we usually don't involve children unless there is something that lends itself naturally to them," he said. "Not everything we do is a day at the beach."
Sometimes, though, volunteering really can be a day at the beach.
This summer Clean Ocean Action, a nonprofit environmental assistance group based in Sandy Hook, is sponsoring monthly beach cleanups at numerous beaches on the Jersey shore. To learn about local beach cleanup dates, contact the local beach patrol, or call Clean Ocean Action at (732) 872-0111.
Volunteers get a free T-shirt, a free hat, a bag to put the trash in, "and the gratitude of a lot of people," said Patrick Campitelli of Brigantine's Beach Patrol.
While most shore communities have machines that sift the sand for trash and debris, Lisa Helm of the Brigantine's Marine Mammal Stranding Center observed that "the machines don't get everything."
"A lot of the floating trash that builds up at the tide line gets mixed in with organic debris, where it poses a danger to animals that forage there for food," she said. "To protect those animals, you really need human beings to go over it and collect what might be dangerous."
The Stranding Center, which cares for whales, dolphins, sea turtles and other marine animals caught in shallow waters off New Jersey beaches, uses volunteers as guides at its museum, but requires prospective volunteers to apply in advance and be able to offer several weeks of part-time service.
"The volunteer work here is very specific," Ms. Helm said. "We don't have one-day or walk-in positions. Even to work in museum as a guide requires extensive education and training. So we need people who can give us a long-term commitment. But if you have the time, and you're willing to give us the commitment, we can give you an understanding of the marine environment, and our relation to it, that you'll never forget."
According to Janet Sharma, executive director of the Bergen County Volunteer Center, an organization that seeks to match volunteers with nonprofit agencies that need their services, New Jersey has some 5,000 nonprofit agencies that need unskilled volunteers "for anything from a few hours a day for as many days that they can spare" for tasks as simple as talking to the elderly to as labor intensive as restoring the Battleship New Jersey on the Camden waterfront.
Of those agencies, Ms. Sharma said, about 1,200 "are family friendly in that they can accommodate families and work with them to make the experience meaningful for teenagers and young children. Some have restrictions in that they might limit participation to children over a certain age. Some organizations, like assisted living facilities, prefer families with young children who can interact with the seniors. I know of some centers that are happy to have mothers with babies come in, to give the seniors a chance to see and maybe hold the baby."
Ms. Sharma, who is also the chairwoman for the National Volunteers Council, said that the idea of including a volunteer experience in vacations is gaining ground "among families and single people who want something more than a typical getaway."
"You get to meet people you wouldn't normally run into, find out interesting things about a community or a place," she said. "The feeling that the people get of knowing that they're helping someone else -- you can't put a price tag on it or measure it in decibels."
Some organizations simply wouldn't exist without volunteers. Cape May's Mid-Atlantic Center for the Arts was founded in 1971 by volunteers, who offered visitors walking tours of the city's historic houses as a way of raising money to restore the Emlen Physick mansion.
Currently using as many as 400 volunteers this summer as docents, guides, ushers and event assistants in Cape May and Wildwood, the organization is not only the largest nonprofit cultural group on the Jersey Shore, it also uses the largest number of senior adults.
"We have one volunteer who is 90 and as active as ever," said Mary Stewart, the center's deputy director, who started folding brochures for the organization when her family moved to Cape May. "We almost never use walk-ins, but you never know. I started as a walk-in when my husband and I moved here, and my sons still volunteer for many of our events. If we're lucky enough to be full for the day, we can refer you to other organizations that could use your help."
Sue Adams, an equestrian instructor at the Atlantic Riding Center for the Handicapped in Egg Harbor Township, takes volunteering families, especially on days when inclement weather threatens, though children should be at least 12 years old.
"We are a 100 percent volunteer organization," she said. "Nobody's getting paid for this, not even me. We constantly need help feeding the horses, grooming and tacking and cleaning the stalls. We also welcome volunteers with disabilities. Volunteers are not given a chance to ride the horses, but they can get close to them and learn more about them. There's also the satisfaction of helping people with disabilities enjoy a day of riding."
For information on volunteering in New Jersey call (800) 865-8683. At the Web site www.volunteerconnections.org, visitors can click on the New Jersey location or type their ZIP code (or the ZIP code of their vacation residence) in the search engine. This will supply the addresses and telephone numbers of the nearest of New Jersey's 13 regional Volunteer Centers.
Ms. Sharma recommends contacting the volunteer center "as far in advance of your vacation date as possible because some activities, such as soup kitchens or ushering for special concerts, are quite popular and tend to fill up quickly. There's actually a waiting list at some soup kitchens."
In addition to getting free T-shirts, food and admission to shows, volunteers may also deduct some out-of-pocket expenses from their federal income taxes, such as the cost of transportation to and from the site where the work is scheduled to take place, parking costs, equipment purchased specifically for the activity (trash bags, sponges, gloves and paint brushes) and meals, if these are not provided or paid for by the organization. Volunteers should save their receipts for all out-of-pocket expenses and consult an accountant before filing. 
Here's how to reach agencies mentioned in the article: Atlantic Riding Center for Handicapped, (609) 926-2233. Volunteer Centers of Bergen County, (201) 489-9454. Marine Mammal Stranding Center, Brigantine, (609) 266-0538. Mid-Atlantic Center for the Arts, Cape May, Jane Bonner, Volunteer Coordinator, (609) 884-5404, extension 152. Palisades Interstate Park, (201) 768-1360. Synergy, care of the Volunteer Center of Monmouth County, (732) 278-1927.

HEADLINE: COPING; 
Getting on Board The Mule Train

BYLINE:  By FELICIA R. LEE 

 BODY:
WHEN it came to mules, there was barely a virgin in sight. The women in the second-floor shoe department of Bloomingdale's the other day were mostly mavens appreciating the sexy, backless little shoe that is suddenly de rigueur everywhere from hip bars to hushed offices.
 Going half-shoeless in a city full of grime, glass, potholes and grates would seem counterintuitive, if not downright silly. Black, yes. Barefoot, no. But the mule is now mainstream as New York heats up, and the young and the not so young from Mott Haven in the Bronx to Midwood, Brooklyn, are taking the plunge. 
 Shoe shoppers at Bloomingdale's and other stores in New York admit the mule's obvious drawbacks as city wear. Sidewalks can be booby traps, constant pedicures are a must, and heaven forbid you need to run. But mules are cute, comfortable and glam once you learn how to walk in them, fashionistas say. And, after all, God gave New Yorkers taxis.
"No matter what shoes you wear in New York, you have to walk with your head down anyway," said Berna Goldstein, a chic 40-year-old from Murray Hill who works in the lingerie industry and was shopping at Bloomingdale's with her friend Kathy Morehouse. "There are always crevices, cracks, the different heights of the sidewalk. I have fallen off my mules a little bit." Ms. Morehouse, who is five months pregnant, was trying on a pair of Polo sneaker mules in red and blue canvas. No heels, just wedges, given her condition. 
A question for these women: Is there something antifeminist about the whole "bare" look in women's clothes, from the foot-baring mule to plunging tops to clingy, diaphanous skirts, a look that was daring three seasons ago and seems a fact of life this year? Whatever happened to comfort? To function before form? 
"No one issued an edict," Ms. Morehouse said. "No one is making anyone wear it." 
A few feet away, Eileen Booth, 23, a receptionist at a Brooklyn law firm who has never worn backless shoes before, was checking out a pair of slinky taupe Martinez Valero mules. She put them on and walked with the delight of a little girl playing dress-up. 
"They feel almost like they might slide off," she said, "but I always carry a second pair of shoes in my bag." To be honest, she admitted, " If you dressed the way you should in the city, you would never look good."
The economy faces a downturn, but women still want their mules. Wendy Liebmann, president of WSL Strategic Retail, marketing and retail consultants in the Flatiron district, says shoes are the new lipstick, a pick-me-up that doesn't involve investing in a new wardrobe.
When the mule first became widely popular a couple of years ago, retailers and social observers talked about how women were influenced by everything from looser office dress codes to television shows like "Sex and the City" that put an emphasis on baring more from head to toe.
There is also a defiance involved in the incongruity of wearing delicate shoes to walk indelicate city streets. Just as New Yorkers picnic on tar beach and kids splash in the spray of hydrants, so there is a certain fantasy element in tottering around town in mules.
Some women are to the mule born. No walking lessons for them.
"Honestly, we don't get, 'How do your wear them?' " said Barbara Parisotto, a spokeswoman for Sigerson Morrison, a hip Prince Street boutique that features pointy-toed mules in colors like orange, mauve and cherry red. Best sellers include an almost flat metallic leather mule in raspberry sorbet and a spectator-style mule in army and acid greens with pedestal heels and a little bow.
Mules go back to 18th-century Europe, where they were worn by men and women alike, although they no longer carry the same overtly sexual connotations they did in the 1950's, when you knew exactly what Marilyn Monroe had in mind when she slipped into hers. Fashion historians suggest that the current popularity of the mule reflects a growing tendency for shoes to show more foot. Even toe cleavage is deeper.
"They're also extremely comfortable," said Valerie Steele, a historian who is acting director of the Museum at the Fashion Institute of Technology. "You just have to learn to grip with the sole of your foot to walk."
Learn to walk?
Ms. Steele laughed. "If a drag queen can learn to walk in heels," she said, "I can learn to walk in mules."

HEADLINE: PRELUDES; 
The Boardroom Is Not the Beach

BYLINE:  By ABBY ELLIN; Abby Ellin is a Manhattan writer. Her column on starting out in the world of money appears the third Sunday of each month. E-mail: preludes@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
HEY, you in the backwards baseball cap! Your image needs some help.
 Yes, everything that Jackie Onassis, Diana Vreeland and your grandmother said was true. To get ahead in this world, you need to put your best foot forward. And if it is unmanicured and wedged in flip-flops, you probably will not get the respect you deserve, especially in a job market that is becoming more competitive as the economy slows. 
 "Image is everything these days," said Ray Drasnin, chief executive of Drasnin Communications, an advertising and public relations firm in San Diego. "Last year, it was hip to be trendy, but in 2001 and beyond you need to be polished, with extraordinary business acumen."
Lauren Solomon, president of the Association of Image Consultants International, with about 600 members worldwide, agreed: "In the past few years, the emphasis was on youth and fast cash, but now there's a return to a traditional approach to getting real money. Your image had better speak volumes."
The role of image consultants has evolved. No longer is the focus on the "outer you" -- what season best corresponds to your eye and hair color, for example. Now the consultants examine the "whole package" -- including attitudes and behavior. Their help can come in handy, whether you're applying for a sales job or seeking money for a start-up. 
"If you want investment capital, you need to look like more than a creative, out-of-the-box thinker," said Mr. Drasnin, who has helped many people in the dot-com world blend into the neo-new economy. "You need to look like a young business person, not like you're ready to spin disks, pour cocktails and drive your Porsche back to the West Coast." (The same rules apply, by the way, to the over-50 crowd that still wears ponytails and combat boots.)
In the neo-new economy, metal hoops cannot protrude from eyebrows (or any other visible body part), at least not in the boardroom. Nor can you zip into meetings on roller blades or wear pants that fall to your knees and T-shirts emblazoned with slogans like "So many beers, so little time."
No one is saying that you have to become a Stepford staffer. But you do need to recognize the fine line between individuality and insolence. Conventionality has its time and place. "If people were more conformist, they'd make their mark later but be more grounded," said Charles Sacarello, founder of Charles & Associates, an international image consulting firm with offices in New York and Europe. Mr. Sacarello and his business partner, David Steinberg, have coached a number of clients from high-technology industries. And many of them "have suffered because they looked geeky or goofy," Mr. Sacarello said.
"They weren't taken seriously by their elders," he added.
To help clients overcome their Rodney Dangerfield complexes, he talks with them for hours, usually on their own turf. Focusing on goals, he asks questions like these: What are your assets and weaknesses? Who are your role models? Which three words describe you? Which three words would you like to describe you? 
He often accompanies clients on shopping trips, to supplant their wardrobes, or to dinner, to offer lessons in cutlery. Sometimes he plays spy, watching clients from afar and later reporting to them on their behavior.
"Some people truly have no idea how others perceive them," he said. For $500 to $10,000, depending on the number and range of sessions, he is happy to tell them. 
Sometimes, the issue is not sloppiness but what can happen after founding a high-tech company in one's early 20's. Richard La China, now 27, was the founder and chief executive of Axxis Computer Technologies in San Diego, which he sold recently. He is now a managing director of the buyer, All Bases Covered, a computer and network support company. Mr. La China said that for years, he had difficulty gaining the respect of his elders. "When they were my age they weren't executives and C.E.O.'s; to them, I was just a kid," he said. "But I was also very confident, which bothered them."
It also didn't help that he spent his first few paychecks on two Mercedes, a 4,200-square-foot home with an ocean view, and a $9,000 Rolex watch. Still, he said, he wasn't aware of the impression he was making until an older executive told him to buy an '82 Buick and dump the gold. "I was upset because I worked hard to get what I had, but people were taken aback by my flashiness," he recalled.
SO he called Mr. Drasnin, who helped him finesse both his appearance and demeanor. They talked goals, desires, humility. They talked branding, marketing, strategy. In 1999, he won the Young Entrepreneur of the Year award from Ernst & Young, and he says he couldn't have done it on his own. "Ray helped me figure out what I needed to look and act like to be respected in this world," he said.
Sure, he has kept his watches and cars, and his bathroom still overlooks the Pacific, but he has diluted his look and no longer thinks that he has all the answers. In turn, he lectures to high school students and community youth groups. One of the first things he tells them is this: "Be presentable. That's what's acceptable in the business world."

HEADLINE: CITY LORE; 
A Man, a Span, a Plan

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL MISCIONE; Michael Miscione wrote and directed "The City of Greater New York: The Story of Consolidation," a documentary.

 BODY:
HERE is a modest proposal: Let's rename the Washington Bridge.
 Not that big gray Hudson River bridge that connects Manhattan to New Jersey. That's the George Washington Bridge. 
 The Washington Bridge, built in 1889, goes over the Harlem River and connects Manhattan to the Bronx. But ever since its name was co-opted by its crosstown rival, it has suffered an identity crisis. 
One way to end the confusion would be to rechristen the bridge after the man who first suggested building it, a forgotten 19th-century Gotham hero named Andrew Haswell Green. Green devoted five decades of public service to the city, perhaps influencing its early development more than any other figure. Central Park, the Museum of Natural History, the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Bronx Zoo, Riverside Park, the New York Public Library, even the very boroughs that compose New York today, owe their existence, in some measure, to Andrew Green. Yet no bridge, no park, no school, no street, honors his legacy.
Green was born in 1820 in Massachusetts, moved to New York as a teenager, became a lawyer and was president of the Board of Education.
In 1857 the State Legislature, at the urging of prominent citizens who feared that Manhattan Island would one day be carpeted entirely with buildings, appointed a commission to design and build Central Park. Green, a staunch supporter of parks, rose to head it. For 13 years he presided over all park work, kept the project on budget, fended off outsiders' attempts to meddle with the Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux design and coaxed new from the Legislature. Even Olmsted, who often fought ferociously with Green, admitted that the man "did a hundred times more work than all the rest of the commissioners together."
When the commission's authority was extended beyond the park's borders, Green set to work planning, improving and beautifying the city, a task he continued for the rest of his life. He laid out the streets in the undeveloped reaches of town, built more parks and lobbied for new bridges and aqueducts. He fought to preserve natural and historic treasures. He created or built homes for many of New York's greatest cultural institutions.
Green's greatest triumph came late in his career. In the 1880's, merchants thought that New York Harbor, the engine that drove the region's economy, was being mismanaged by the lax, often corrupt municipalities that controlled its waters. So Green championed the idea of consolidating the outlying cities, towns and villages into New York City, which then consisted only of Manhattan and part of the Bronx.
Brooklyn was then the nation's third-largest city, and indignant Brooklynites railed against "Green's Hobby," as they called consolidation. For years they fought Green and his allies. But just when consolidation seemed doomed, the Republican Party boss Thomas Platt embraced the proposal and drove it through the Legislature. In 1898 the five boroughs were born, and Andrew Green was dubbed "the Father of Greater New York."
Green's bizarre death, in 1903, stunned the city. A deranged stranger mistook him for another man and shot him dead on the steps of his home. Several grand memorials for him were proposed, but none were built except for a forlorn granite bench near 104th Street in Central Park -- constructed in 1929 and rededicated in 1998 -- that is so obscure it is not marked on most park maps.
Which brings us back to the Washington Bridge. When it was erected, 14 years before Green's death, it was considered something of an unofficial monument to the man. Why not make it official?

HEADLINE: GRASS-ROOTS BUSINESS; 
A Valley Lush in Velcro and Baggy Shorts

BYLINE:  By JOEL KOTKIN; Joel Kotkin is a senior fellow at the Davenport Institute for Public Policy at Pepperdine University. His column on the Main Street economy appears the third Sunday of each month. E-mail: grassrts@nytimes.com

DATELINE: HUNTINGTON BEACH, Calif. 

 BODY:
TWO decades ago, Robert B. McKnight Jr. was a "surfer dude" who hoped to make a few easy dollars selling Australian-made board shorts, those baggy swim trunks worn by surfers, along the balmy beaches of this Southern California town.
 "We didn't think of this as an apparel business," said Mr. McKnight, now 47, and still tanned and trim. "We thought we'd sell some shorts from the back of the truck, hang out on the beaches and chase women. Then we'd go to work for our dads or I.B.M." 
 But the tide somehow shifted. Mr. McKnight, working from a large office here, is now chief executive of Quiksilver Inc., an apparel powerhouse that expects to have worldwide net sales this year of nearly $600 million, up from $516 million last year and nearly twice its 1998 total. Quiksilver and other apparel companies that have headquarters or major operations in the Orange County suburbs are part of the burgeoning active-sports market, catering to skateboarders, snowboarders and surfers alike. Industry experts estimate nationwide revenue in this segment as high as $2.4 billion.
Mr. McKnight and his competitors credit their success to positioning. They view their businesses not as fashion companies but as promoters of an active lifestyle that they have followed with an almost religious passion themselves. The businesses stand apart from the mainstream garment industries in New York or Los Angeles, relying largely on specialty stores, the Internet or their own outlets to sell their products.
Paul Naude, president of the North American operations of Billabong, an Australian surfwear company with global sales of about $250 million, says the primary task of companies in his industry is to capture the exhilaration and individualism -- the "rush" -- of surfing, skateboarding and snowboarding for the young adults who make up much of their primary market.
"We understand the intangibles that trigger the juices of the youth culture," said Mr. Naude, 45, who got his start building surfboards as a teenager in his native Durban, South Africa, and still has the physique of a serious surfer. "It's all about the freedom of doing board sports -- and the older I get, the more passionate I am about it."
That explains how many of the top companies, like Quiksilver, Billabong U.S.A. and Ocean Pacific Apparel, chose to place their corporate headquarters and design offices in this beach-rich area, about an hour south of the teeming garment district of Los Angeles. So many companies and suppliers have now clustered in this region that it is widely known as "Velcro valley," for the adhesive material commonly used in surfwear shorts and shirts.
"These guys wouldn't be caught dead working out of downtown L.A. or New York; they really are about a completely different approach," said Stuart Berman, a marketing consultant in Los Angeles. "They want a more relaxed, out-by-the-beach lifestyle."
DESPITE their relaxed image, industry executives like Mr. McKnight are not as laid back as one might think. They have steadily built their industry well beyond its roots, Mr. Berman pointed out. What started with boards and shorts has now expanded into goods ranging from T-shirts and shoes to dresses. And their market includes children, teenagers and middle-aged adults.
That expansion, he said, has been greatly enhanced by the rapid growth in recent years of board sports, notably snowboarding and skateboarding. Those sports have driven the industry's appeal beyond its original strongholds in Australia, South Africa and Southern California, to Europe, Japan and even Middle America.
As many as 11 million Americans are now skateboarders, up from five million or six million a decade ago, said Angelo Ponzi, who runs Board-Trac Inc., a market research firm based in Trabuco Canyon, also in Orange County. Snowboarding, which barely existed a decade ago, now has several million active participants in the United States, he said. The numbers for both sports are now higher than for surfing, whose strongholds remain largely in Southern California and Hawaii, he said.
Surfing "is the granddaddy of it all, but you need a beach and a wave," Mr. Ponzi said.
"Skating allows anyone with a street and asphalt to share in that culture," he added. "Then there's snowboarding -- it's all opening up the surfwear experience to lots of people in places like Iowa."
Board-Trac estimates about one in four teenagers and young adults participate in "extreme sports," a category that includes the board sports. But even those who don't participate are influenced by the styles worn by these athletes. "Everyone wants to be like Joe the Surfer or the cool kid on a skateboard," said Hezy Shaked, president of Tilly's, an activewear retailer based in Irvine, with 14 stores in the state.
But no retailer may reflect the growing influence of the "Velcro valley" more than Pacific Sunwear. Started as a small surf shop in Newport Beach in 1980, the chain, based in Anaheim, has more than 600 outlets in 48 states and in Puerto Rico, up from 112 stores just five years ago. Eighty-five percent of the stores are outside California, and the store with the highest sales is in the Roosevelt Field shopping mall in Garden City, N.Y., said Timothy M. Harmon, the company's president.
"This is no longer a California concept," said Mr. Harmon, who has worked for mainstream retailers like Abraham & Straus, Bullocks and Millers Outpost. 
The growth of the industry, however, makes some longtime industry insiders, like Mr. Naude of Billabong, concerned about potential overexposure. But most experts see continuing growth ahead. The popularity of surfwear-inspired products outside California and other traditional strongholds will continue to feed off youth-oriented media, most notably MTV and the Internet, said Richard A. Baker, president of Ocean Pacific.
Mr. Baker, whose company's sales are expected to top $217 million this year, up from $160 million last year, says most conventional apparel makers sell an image of a product that may have nothing to do with their own daily lives. But he said most top surfwear executives, and often their families, still embrace what their products promote. Most rarely miss a chance to catch a wave at home, or to use business as an excuse to visit surfing Valhallas like Hawaii.
"This is still a real passion for most of us," Mr. McKnight said. The industry's success, he added, "is really about the loyalty we have to this active lifestyle and the fact that our customers relate to that lifestyle."

White, 11, shopped recently at Pacific Sunwear's No. 1 store, in Roosevelt Field in Garden City, N.Y. (Phil Marino/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS; 
Catherine Weltz, Gautier Beurnier

 BODY:
Catherine Louise Weltz, the daughter of Carol Cahn Weltz of Palm Beach, Fla., and S. Robert Weltz Jr. of Santa Barbara, Calif., was married yesterday to Gautier Jacques Paul Simon Beurnier, a son of Rose-Therese and Jean Beurnier of Paris. The mayor of the Eighth Arrondissement of Paris, Francois Lebel, officiated at the municipal building there. 
 Mrs. Beurnier, 31, was until December a vice president and senior account planner at Lowe Lintas & Partners, the advertising agency in New York. She is now an independent marketing consultant in New York. She graduated from Skidmore College. Her father, who is retired, owned a seat on the New York Stock Exchange. Her mother is a buyer and sales associate at the Sonia Rykiel boutique in Palm Beach. 
 Mr. Beurnier, 30, is a vice president for investment banking with Marsh & McLennan Securities, a unit of Marsh & McLennan, the insurance and financial services company in New York. He graduated from the University of Paris, where he also received a postgraduate diploma in economics and finance. He received a master's degree in finance from l'Ecole Superieure de Commerce, a business school in Paris. His mother is the managing director for the development of malls in Europe for Atemi, a commercial real estate and property development company in Paris. His father oversees the real estate department of Monoprix, a retail chain based in Paris.
