HEADLINE: THE BOATING REPORT; 
Personal Watercraft Stirring Debate

BYLINE:  By HERB McCORMICK; Herb McCormick is the editor of Cruising World magazine.

 BODY:
Considering the factions each represents, the two adversaries share surprising common ground. The lawyer who lobbies on behalf of the personal watercraft industry in Washington and the San Francisco-based ecologist who is on the frontline in limiting certain waterway access to what he calls "thrill craft" are both sailors.
 Monita Fontaine, the executive director of the Personal Watercraft Industry Association, has crossed the Atlantic Ocean and logged some 20,000 miles aboard her custom 34-foot wood sailboat, Hither, Thither and Gone. 
 Dr. Russell Long, the executive director of the environmental organization Bluewater Network, is a veteran America's Cup skipper, a lifelong ocean racer, and the holder of several sailing speed records aboard his hydrofoil-equipped multihull, Longshot. 
During phone interviews last week, it was clear that both Fontaine and Long share a strong affinity for the water. But when it comes to who can play on it and how -- particularly in the national parks system -- they are diametrically opposed.
From sections of Biscayne Bay in Florida to the San Juan Islands in the Pacific Northwest, and in numerous places in between, personal watercraft riders are currently denied access to many waters for a variety of issues including safety and pollution. 
Fontaine contends that personal watercraft, or Jet Skis, are getting a bad rap. "Today's P.W.C.'s are cleaner and quieter than ever before," she said. "They're convenient, affordable and economical, and a great way for families to get out on the water."
But Long sees it another way. "In terms of boating-related injuries, P.W.C.'s are far more dangerous than any craft we've ever seen on U.S. waters," he said. "That's before you examine the water, air and noise pollution issues."
In recent weeks fresh fuel was poured over the frequently heated personal watercraft debate after published remarks and related action by Secretary of the Interior Gail Norton concerning the use of the craft in the national parks.
In March 2000, the National Park Service published a regulation banning personal watercraft in 66 of its 87 parks. Later, the 21 remaining parks became the subject of a federal lawsuit filed against the park service by Long's Bluewater Network seeking an across-the-board ban. In the terms of an out-of court settlement with the park service reached last December, personal watercraft in those parks will also be banned in September 2002, if the individual parks fail to complete and pass an environmental impact study on the effects of continued Jet Ski usage.
But earlier this month, citing "red flags" about how the bans in those 21 parks were instituted, Norton temporarily lifted the restriction in four parks: Cape Lookout National Seashore in North Carolina; Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area in Pennsylvania and New Jersey; Indiana Dunes National Lakeshore in Indiana and Cumberland Island in Georgia.
"My understanding is that the Jet Ski industry has been raising hue and cry over the settlement and has specifically targeted Gail Norton to re-open a number of parks including these four," Long said. "I could definitely see her trying to reverse the Jet Ski regulations."
On the other hand, Fontaine believes that the basis of the settlement -- the individual environmental assessments -- fits a continuing pattern of unfairness. "I don't know if the N.P.S. will be able to afford such an undertaking," she said, referring to the park service. 
"It will be expensive," she added. "And isn't it tragic that instead of those moneys going to improve facilities, or hire more Park Rangers, that taxpayers will be paying for studies that quite frankly will be most difficult to carry out but will prove that the latest P.W.C.'s are superior to other vessels."
Ultimately, assuming the regulation as outlined goes forth without interference, both Fontaine and Long agree that it will most likely come down to the individual superintendents to respond, or not, at their respective parks. Some will simply fail to act and accept the ban. Others, particularly in popular Western personal watercraft waters such as Lake Powell and Lake Mead, will proceed with strong local support.
When putting forth their arguments, both Long and Fontaine also speak of what many hold true as fundamental American tenets. 
"The national parks have the highest protection mandate of all our public lands," Long said. "They're different. There should be a place where people can escape from the stresses and craziness of modern life. By allowing Jet Skis unbridled access to these unique places you give away a fundamental right to these important values."
Fontaine said: "The lockout crowd wants to establish what the appropriate use is for our national parks. It's their vision, not the American vision. These parks were set up for recreation, for Americans to take their families and get away from their computers and televisions and be outside together and play."
The issue is clearly conflicted. Further information is available on the Web sites for Fontaine's and Long's organizations: www.pwia.org and www.bluewaternetwork.org.
Long and Fontaine may have sailing in common, but the issues on the personal watercraft matter are far from resolved. Until they are, the river between them will remain wide and deep.

HEADLINE: French Trains: Fast and Faster 

BYLINE:  By ERIC PFANNER 

 BODY:
AAH, springtime in Paris. Sidewalk cafes, music in the air -- and day after day of rain. Luckily, Parisians will soon get relief from one of the wettest years on record. It comes in the form of a new high-speed rail line that will chop more than an hour off travel times from Paris to such sunny southern cities as Nice, Cannes, Marseille, Aix-en-Provence and Avignon. 
 The $3.5 billion TGV Mediterranee is really just a 156-mile extension of an existing line that stretches south from Paris beyond Lyon. But it will complete a high-speed link from the English Channel to the Mediterranean, allowing seamless service at 186 miles an hour. 
 The 490 miles from Paris to Marseille -- roughly the distance between Boston and Richmond, Va. -- will be covered in only 3 hours 9 minutes, down from the current 4 hours 20 minutes. From Marseille, trains will continue to run east over conventional tracks, at lower speeds, to destinations along the Cote d'Azur.
The rail line could be bad news for Air France, which dominates domestic travel. The airline acknowledges that it could lose up to 25 percent of its business on Paris-Marseille flights, which take just over an hour. The French national railways, known as SNCF, predict that the market share for the plane vs. train to destinations served by the new line will be reversed from the present 60-40 in favor of air. 
To fight back, Air France briefly cut fares on the Paris-Marseilles route and several others served by the new TGV to as little as $70 for travel this summer. By contrast, the first-class off-peak fare for a Paris-Marseille round trip on the new TGV is $110 (second class is $84), though reductions of 25 and 50 percent are common. 
In addition to speeding up the trains, the SNCF is adding more, to encourage business travelers to use the Paris-Marseille route for one-day round trips. 
Not long ago a business traveler planning a trip to Marseille, known for off-duty sailors, organized crime and soccer, might have been eyed with suspicion. But a rising economic tide in the south of France, led by high technology and pharmaceutical industries, has lifted Marseille's boats as well. 
A more popular destination for many American visitors is Aix-en-Provence. The elegant Provencal city will have its train travel times from Paris the most sharply reduced of any destination on the way south. Previously, travelers had to go first to Marseille for a change of train and a total time of about five hours. On the new line, routed through Aix, the time from Paris is just 2 hours 54 minutes. 
In part because of the prospect of a shorter weekend commute for well-to-do Parisians, prices of second homes in the region are said to be rising sharply. 
Faster transportation links will presumably contribute to the growing crowds along the Riviera. But in the image-conscious region, that means the possibilities for seeing and being seen will only get better, said Brigitte Renaud-Wolter in the tourism office at Aix-en-Provence. "Some people want to be able to sit and watch people walk by, to critique their clothes."

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS; 
Tracy White, Lakshman Achuthan

 BODY:
Tracy Ann White and Lakshman Radh Achuthan were married last night in Lewisboro, N.Y., at a house owned by the bride's parents, Shelby White and Leon Levy of New York. Rabbi Jon Haddon performed the ceremony.
 Ms. White, who is keeping her name, is a senior producer for Trackers.net, an Oxygen Media site for teenage girls. She is also the creator of "Traced," an online autobiographical animated short that is also shown on the Oxygen cable television channel. She is a member of the board of the Lower East Side Tenement Museum. She graduated from Columbia and received a master's degree in professional studies from New York University's Interactive Telecommunications Department. 
 The bride's parents are philanthropists known for their collection of antiquities. The bride's mother is a member of the boards of the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the New York Botanical Garden, and is also a freelance journalist and the author of "What Every Woman Should Know About Her Husband's Money." 
Mr. Levy is the chairman of the Oppenheimer Funds, the New York mutual fund management firm that is a successor company to Oppenheimer & Company, in which he had been a partner. He is also the chairman of Avatar Inc., a real estate company in Coral Gables, Fla., and president of the Institute for Advanced Studies, a private nonprofit organization for studies in physics, mathematics, philosophy and social studies in Princeton, N.J. The bride was adopted by Mr. Levy. Her biological father, the late Rodney White, was also a partner in Oppenheimer & Company.
The bridegroom is the managing director of the Economic Cycle Research Institute in Manhattan, which forecasts national and international business and inflation cycles. He is also on the advisory board of the New York City Office of Management and Budget. He graduated from Fairleigh Dickenson University and received an M.B.A. from the C. W. Post campus of Long Island University. His mother, Joy Mayfield, lives and practices psychotherapy in Wainscott, N.Y. His father, Dr. Radh Achuthan of Southhampton, N.Y., is a professor of physics at the L.I.U. campus there.
Ms. White and Mr. Achuthan met in January 1999 when a mutual friend invited them for dinner at Bar Pitti, an Italian restaurant in SoHo.
"We learned that we had missed meeting each other many times over the years," Mr. Achuthan said.
Both had attended the Putney School, a private boarding school in Putney, Vt., but Mr. Achuthan was two years ahead of Ms. White. A few years later, they narrowly missed meeting at Columbia, where Ms. White was attending the undergraduate school and Mr. Achuthan was a research economist at the Center for International Business Cycle Research at the business school. Two years later, Ms. White had just left a job as the assistant to the producer of "Debates/Debates," a nationally syndicated public affairs program, when Mr. Achuthan joined the program and became a regular guest.
"It took us a few years," Ms. White said, "but when we finally met, it was at the right time and in the right place."

HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 5-20-01; 
Lights, Camera, Strike!

BYLINE:  By George Packer; George Packer is the author of "The Village of Waiting" and, most recently, "Blood of the Liberals."

 BODY:
When the Writers Guild of America and the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers settled on a tentative three-year contract earlier this month, a nation of entertainment consumers breathed a sigh of relief. Thanks to the work of able negotiators, the citizens of the Republic were spared an undue wait for the next teen gross-out flick, and no executive order was required from President Bush to avert the substitution of reality programming for evening dramas. 
 A curious thing has happened in the past few years: say the word "strike" and you're more likely to think of an expensively dressed member of the N.B.A. Players Association or the Screen Actors Guild than the smudged face of a coal miner. Labor action, to judge by its coverage in the media, has gone so far upscale that it now comes under the heading of entertainment news, with an entirely new vocabulary of industrial relations. One no longer hears much talk of those old staples, wages and benefits. In the case of actors and writers, the grievances revolve around six-figure salaries and a thing called "residuals." During the basketball and baseball strikes of the 1990's, the relevant terms were "salary cap" and "revenue sharing." The workers who showed the most bargaining clout in the past year have been the six members of the International Brotherhood of Situation Comedy Actors, "Friends" Local, who demanded a raise and got $750,000 apiece per episode. 
 Without denying athletes and entertainers their rightful share of the staggering profits they help produce, it is worth asking what the new face of labor -- Patrick Ewing's, Harry Hamlin's -- says about our culture's attitude toward work and pay. The amount of attention given a strike reflects the kind of jobs society regards as truly essential. Once, headlines were made and presidents intervened when steel and coal strikes threatened to disrupt vital national industries. A few years ago, President Clinton tried to mediate the baseball strike. The essential work of our time is the film script, the TV commercial, the split-finger fastball and the slam dunk.
At some point toward the end of the 20th century, the working-class hero died. A certain prestige once attached to labor, even to the worst paid and dirtiest work. "Blue collar" denoted half the entire culture, with its own customs and habits and diversions, its vices and its heroism. In the age before it was covered by "Entertainment Tonight," labor unrest was a drama played out by desperate people facing off against cops with sticks raised. Many Americans feared or even hated the unruly mob, but they were at least aware, whenever it rose up, that their lives depended on labor. Even antilabor violence was a sort of backhanded tribute: Andrew Carnegie and Henry Ford noticed the people who worked for them, if only to shoot and club them into submission.
After 1950 or so, unions began to lose their cachet, first through success -- partnerships with big business, ever-expanding contracts, enough cash for large-scale corruption -- and then through failure, as the unionized work force fell from 29 percent of the private sector in 1970 to 12 percent in 1992 and entire industries shut down or moved overseas. Liberal intellectuals who once cast their moral lot with Joe Hill felt no solidarity with the hawkish George Meany, let alone the racist Archie Bunker, and moved on to other causes. By the beginning of the 1990's, there were no more workers -- everyone was a contractor.
The recent high-profile labor disputes in sports and entertainment have restored the notion that industrial relations are adversarial. They haven't resurrected the worker as hero, though; if anything, they have created the impression that labor actions are contests between two equally overpaid, out-of-touch groups, that the strike is the moral equivalent of a technical foul. And perhaps, by association, they make the grievances of America's other workers -- those arguing for an increase of a dollar an hour in wages instead of $1.3 million in residuals -- seem a little less legitimate, if not altogether invisible.
Here is a phenomenon just as strange as the 39-percent-tax-bracket striker: a whole new economy of workers has begun to form unions and even, occasionally, to go on strike, but we almost never hear about them. They aren't miners or steelworkers, but janitors, food service workers, industrial launderers, home health aides. They recently appeared on the national radar screen when a student sit-in at Harvard drew attention to the fact that a university with a $20 billion endowment pays part of its work force less than it can live on. The press took note, the university negotiated and perhaps Harvard's dining hall staff and janitors will see their wages raised. If so, it is because the country's most privileged young people, with the backing of stars like Ben Affleck and Matt Damon, took up their cause. Does anyone imagine that Harvard's working poor could have won over the media and brought the university to heel on their own?
Service workers don't occupy a place in the public imagination or the hierarchy of social worth, not even the place once reserved for factory workers. There is no perceived nobility in smearing cream cheese on a bagel, no storied subculture of emptying bedpans. Most of us don't really want to know what makes our civilization possible. We live with a kind of illusion in which hotel rooms somehow clean themselves. Strikes are little eruptions from below, announcing the human foundation that most people walk on without giving it a thought. In the age of reality TV, all-sports cable and stars on strike, it is easier than ever to imagine that we walk on air.

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
Alternative To a Tax Cut: A Revitalized Public Sector

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
GO back through all the writings on capitalism, back to Adam Smith, and a bedrock principle asserts itself repeatedly. It is that government provides services the private sector cannot provide as well or will not provide at all. Building airports and putting satellites into space are obvious examples. So is financing unemployment insurance. Yet in the current debate over tax cuts versus budget spending, this principle is ignored. 
 The nation, as a result, is being locked into a $1.35 trillion tax cut over the next decade without ever hearing a discussion in Congress of how the government might have spent that money if there were no tax cut. Context is lacking. There is much debate over keeping the tax cut small enough to preserve the budget surplus or big enough initially to stimulate a weak economy. But no one insists on considering the many ways that government spending might be better than a tax cut in bringing Americans greater well-being in the decade ahead. 
 "They are debating arithmetic instead of political economy," said William Niskanen, chairman of the conservative Cato Institute.
There are exceptions, of course, to the bipartisan skittishness toward public spending and Big Government. The most outspoken lately is Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the Massachusetts Democrat. In a recent speech, he reviewed the host of ways in which government spending over two centuries had lifted living standards. Almost always in the past, he said, the private sector and the government have acted together to meet the nation's requirements.
Mr. Niskanen, a libertarian economist, is hardly a Kennedy ally. He beats the drums for cutting taxes and shrinking government. But he, too, recognizes the generations-old principle that government spending has a legitimate role in a market economy. His spending would be vastly smaller than Mr. Kennedy's. In only four cases, he said, citing education, highways, public sanitation and mass transit, does some public spending "have a higher level of payoff than private spending." 
"A higher level of payoff." That is the key. If that guidepost could be spread across Congress -- replacing the prevailing view that public spending is by nature wasteful and a drag on the economy -- then tax cuts would cease to be so mesmerizing. In the debate that would follow, the entire tax cut might even give way to public spending that promised a higher level of payoff than giving the money back to the private sector.
Consider child care and care of the elderly, occupations that require warmth and emotional support. These are qualities the marketplace consistently undervalues, says Nancy Folbre, an economist at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst. There are good reasons. Quality of care is hard to measure in dollars and cents. And consumer preference does not kick in. The consumer is the child or the old person, and in most cases neither one has the leverage to demand quality. A result: Care providers are underpaid and thus often not up to the task.
Raising salaries through public subsidies would help solve the problem, Ms. Folbre contends, and would spread quality care to families that cannot afford it now, even middle-class families. The payoff in well-being and proper child-raising would exceed what private companies, on their own, are willing to provide. "Policy makers have to be thinking much more carefully about market failures in the care sector," Ms. Folbre said.
MARKET failures also show up in health insurance, pension coverage, mass transit, affordable college education and pollution control -- to name just a few of the issues that should make an appearance in a Congressional debate over tax cuts versus public spending. New research, for example, shows that poor children from minority groups are more likely to become productive adults if they are enrolled in small classes during the first three years of elementary school. That requires many more teachers than the private sector is likely to support.
The Democrats once carried the flag for public spending, but Bill Clinton and Al Gore shifted the emphasis to preserving the surplus and keeping government small. And the debate died, although public opinion polls suggest that it should be resurrected. Americans react negatively to questions about "government spending," said Humphrey Taylor, chairman of Louis Harris & Associates, the polling company. But they often favor more spending on services they want: education, health care, medical research, highways, police, air traffic control. 
"It is all in the phrases you use in asking the questions," Mr. Taylor said, "But people are beginning to make the connections. They are becoming aware that big tax cuts mean cuts in the services they want. That is a step forward."

HEADLINE: Investing; 
A Retailer's Strategy To Sustain a Revival

BYLINE:  By MICHELLE LEDER 

 BODY:
JUST six months ago, things were looking pretty bleak for investors in Restoration Hardware, the quirky home-products retailer. The stock of this former Wall Street darling, which traded as high as $37 in July 1998, had plummeted to 50 cents, and some people wondered whether it was just another flash in the pan.
 But investors who stuck with the company, based in Corte Madera, Calif., have been rewarded in recent months: the stock now trades at $5.98. 
 So what is next for Restoration Hardware, a chain of 104 stores in 31 states that attracts an upscale urban clientele with merchandise ranging from inexpensive Bite the Man dog toys to reproduction Mission furniture? 
There seems to be some basis for optimism. In the fiscal year ended Feb. 3, during which Restoration struggled for survival, it had sales of $369.5 million, up from $298.9 million a year earlier. Sales at stores open at least a year, an important measure of a retailer's performance, rose 5.8 percent in the fourth quarter while earnings, at 56 cents a share, beat Wall Street expectations.
"This could have been a 50-cent stock that went to zero," said Barbara Miller, a specialty retail analyst at Goldman, Sachs, who has a lukewarm "market perform" rating on the stock. "This is not a stock that anyone is buying for this quarter. This is a stock that people are buying for the potential and the management. If it works, it will go a lot higher than $6."
Investors in Restoration may now be betting on Gary G. Friedman, a veteran retailer who was named chief executive on March 21. That day, Restoration also announced that it had completed a $15 million private placement of preferred shares and had renegotiated credit lines with lenders to give it more flexibility. In two days, the stock jumped to $4 from $1.8125.
Mr. Friedman, 43, had been president and chief operating officer at Williams-Sonoma, the home furnishings and cookware retailer. There, he built up the Pottery Barn brand and expanded stores and the company's catalog. He left when he was passed over for the chief executive's job.
Since taking the reins from Stephen Gordon, Restoration's founder and still its chairman, Mr. Friedman has begun closing unprofitable stores, including one of the company's two stores in New York City. He has said the company will not open any new stores anywhere for two years. "The company was positioned a lot more clearly three to four years ago, but then they got away from the vision," Mr. Friedman said. "That lack of clarity diluted Restoration's message."
One of Restoration's problems is that it grew much too quickly, said Frank J. Pados Jr., the executive vice president at Desai Capital Management, which has been a Restoration investor since before the company went public in June 1998. 
"The number of stores was getting too big and they had to get back to basics," said Mr. Pados, whose firm still owns more than 5 percent of the company's shares.
Management was too thin for the ambitious expansion, analysts said, and made errors like putting popular merchandise on sale when stores could have obtained full price. Sales per square foot slumped 7 percent in 2000, to $520 from $559 in 1999.
Mr. Gordon said that in a growth spurt in 1999 and 2000, the company's stores stocked "too many goods for our customers to focus on."
Mr. Friedman, known for his merchandising skills, plans to start selling more linens and curtains, products that carry higher profit margins and that have been very successful at Pottery Barn. One of Restoration's major problems, Mr. Pados said, has been that its merchandise mix, while interesting, has not changed often enough to keep people coming back to its stores. 
N. Richard Nelson Jr., a retailing analyst at Stephens Inc. who is neutral on the stock, said, "This company isn't out of the woods yet by any means, but he seems to have a good game plan in place."
OF course, analysts and investors say, it will be many months before most of Mr. Friedman's changes take root. They remained calm about the company's report on May 10 that same-store sales for the three months ended May 5 fell 16.2 percent, a result that the company predicted back in March.
Mr. Friedman's effort to remake the company comes during an economic slowdown -- and after many upscale consumers watched investment portfolios shrink in value in the last year. Furniture, always a strong seller at the company, has been particularly difficult, Mr. Nelson said. "The economy," he added, "is certainly not working in their favor."

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT; 
Betting On Winners And Losers In Energy

BYLINE:  By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
GREAT fortunes are often made -- and lost -- in times of crisis.
 At the moment, though, it is hard to identify clear investment winners and losers from the 100-odd recommendations that the Bush administration made last week on energy. One reason is that some businesses have already capitalized on the run-up in prices of oil, natural gas and electricity. Another is that it is unclear which of the initiatives will be enacted. 
 Philip K. Verleger Jr., an economist who runs his own energy consulting firm, PKVerleger L.L.C., in Newport Beach, Calif., took time to sort some of this out. Here are excerpts from the conversation.

Q. Did the president's energy proposal surprise you at all?

A. What surprises me is that in many ways it is so timid. It is a very mild program.

Q. What would have been a bold thing to do in the energy plan?

A. I was hoping for a call for immediate deregulation of electricity generation and associated pricing for consumers nationwide. That would have created some huge windfall profits over the short term, but a windfall-profits tax would have dealt with that.

Q. But you have reservations about whether the situation is as grave as the president suggests, don't you?

A. It doesn't seem to me we really needed an energy message at this point. In 1971, 1973, 1974 and 1977, we were facing a crisis. Supplies were tight, and there were no mechanisms like the Strategic Petroleum Reserve to deal with the situation. The circumstances right now are not the same. We are dealing with constraints from volatile prices resulting from structural changes in the economy.
Instead of vertically integrated power companies like Consolidated Edison or Southern California Edison, we have smaller enterprises and horizontal corporations. That change has changed the behavior of markets. The president quite rightly points out the logistical problem we face in terms of not enough pipelines and insufficient electricity transmission facilities. But it is not clear that his solution is the 21st-century solution, which would be to uncouple homes or office buildings from power grids and hook them up to their own generators.

Q. If the electricity problem in California had not developed and oil was $28 a barrel, would President Bush have pushed this program?

A . Mother Nature presented the president with this opportunity, and he seized it. Without California, he would not have had the opportunity. But the problem in the West is due to the drought out here. Water levels have only been this low once in the last 80 years. I estimate the drought in the Northwest reduces the supply of electricity to the Western states by about 8 percent.
To close that gap, we either have to have blackouts, substitute oil-fired or natural-gas generating capacity to make up for the lost hydro capacity, or raise prices.

Q. Which parts of the energy program do you see becoming reality?

A. I think they will get through the things they can do by regulation. For instance, they can resolve the uncertainty for refineries about fuel specifications and requirements they would have to meet in terms of local emission standards. The Environmental Protection Agency under Clinton was unduly nasty. They can open some of the federal lands that were closed off for exploration. And they can get the tax credit for hybrid vehicles.

Q. What won't the administration get?

A. I don't think they will get the Alaska Wildlife Refuge, but they don't really need it. It does nothing to address national supply issues. We will still be subject to blackmail by foreign producers.
And I don't think this giant interstate power grid the president wants is likely to happen. The idea tramples on states' rights.

Q. The president also recommended that automobile fuel-economy standards be reviewed. Will that make a difference?

A. If they make a large-enough tax credit for hybrid vehicles, they don't have to change the standards, because the kick you get from hybrids will improve fuel economy.

Q. From an investment perspective, are there any clear winners?

A. The temptation will be to invest in oil drillers, but I don't think that is the right conclusion, because there is already a lot of drilling going on. The rush to build new power plants will help power generators for a year or so, but then they will be losers because there will be much too much power. Toyota and Honda, which are the two companies with current, marketable hybrid automobiles, are going to be big winners. Other auto manufacturers that have models like that due out soon could also do well. Pure-play refiners like Tosco and Valero may do well.

HEADLINE: The Nation; 
Everyone's Trying to Fix the Economy

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
WHATEVER turns out tobe happening to the economy the numbers are still all over the lot, but the general drift remains downward -- government can hardly be accused of standing idly by. 
 Last week, the Federal Reserve cut interest rates by half a percentage point for the fifth time this year. The rate reduction of 2.5 percentage points in less than five months is the economic equivalent of applying defibrillators to the patient; if this doesn't jolt the expansion back to life, there's probably little hope. 
 But just in case, Congress was moving with unaccustomed speed toward delivering a stimulant of its own in the form of a tax cut. 
Contained in the $1.35 trillion tax reduction that Congress hopes to deliver to President Bush by Memorial Day is $100 billion earmarked to give the economy a boost this year and next. That is 20 percent more than either party was contemplating a few weeks ago, and may be enough to make a difference.
"The direction Washington is headed is a helpful one," said Thomas D. Gallagher, an analyst at the International Strategy and Investment Group, an investment firm. 
The policy response has been particularly impressive in comparison to previous downturns. It has taken the Fed 19 weeks to cut interest rates by 2.5 percentage points this year, Mr. Gallagher said. The last time the nation was heading into recession, in 1989 and 1990, it took the Fed 80 weeks -- a year and a half -- to cut rates that much. And while Congress has moved speedily to cut taxes this year, in 1990 Congress and the first Bush administration were raising taxes to battle an expanding federal budget deficit.
The problem is that lower interest rates and tax cuts both take awhile to work their magic. In the meantime, the economy could get worse. And there is some doubt as to whether lower rates will be effective in addressing this particular slowdown, which has less to do with a drop-off in purchases by interest-sensitive consumers than with decisions by companies to pare back spending on plants and equipment.
In coming months, analysts expect unemployment to continue rising from its current level, 4.5 percent. And developments like rising gasoline prices and rolling electricity blackouts could create pressure on politicians to "do something."
Mr. Bush says the best antidote to higher energy prices is to give people more money through the tax cut. But not all low and moderate-income workers would gain from the cut, and it would do little to cushion the drag on corporate profits from higher energy prices.
In any case, both parties on Capitol Hill, mindful of the political risks of higher prices at the pump and rising unemployment, have been studying additional steps they could take over the administration's objections. They include repealing the federal gasoline tax, threatening oil companies with price-gouging investigations and imposing price caps on electricity.
For its part, the Fed signaled that it is prepared to keep cutting rates until a recovery is certain. Unfortunately, deciding when it has done enough is tricky, because it takes a while before rate cuts show up in the economic data.
The old rule of thumb was that it takes 9 to 12 months for a change in Fed monetary policy to ripple fully through the economy. By that standard, the rate cuts would kick in only at the end of the year. There is evidence that the process has accelerated in recent years. Still, it will take some time. In the same way, the effect of the tax cuts will be delayed, probably into next year.
Some of the tax cut will be retroactive to the beginning of this year, and some people could benefit from reduced withholding rates starting perhaps this summer. But most people won't get all their money back until early next year, when they file their tax returns.
Whether the one-two punch of monetary and fiscal policy will be enough to avert a full recession and point the economy quickly back toward healthy growth remains a matter of debate among economists. 
One camp argues that this slowdown will not be easily halted by lower rates and tax cuts. In this view, the problem is not the traditional one of inducing the consumer to start buying again. It is, rather, a problem of waiting out a downturn in investment among companies that for years gorged on new computers, telecommunications equipment and more efficient factories.
While perhaps not as effective as they would be in a traditional downturn, monetary and fiscal policy can help in that situation by underpinning confidence and demand for goods and services. Economists who see an investment-led decline tend to think that continued rate cutting will be needed, and that the tax cut could do some good. 
Some investors, however, are betting that this will turn out to be a more traditional business cycle slowdown, and that the policy response has already been overdone. In the futures markets, the mentality now is that the Fed will actually start raising interest rates later this year or next.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH; 
Setting Rates By the Numbers

BYLINE:  By ALEX BERENSON 

 BODY:
ELIMINATE Alan Greenspan.
 It sounds like a line from a cheesy political thriller. But the proposal is serious, an intriguing if flawed pitch for a radical change in the way this nation sets monetary policy. 
 Of course, no one really wants to do away with Mr. Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman. But 14 years into Mr. Greenspan's tenure at the helm of the Fed, his once unblemished reputation has faded, albeit only slightly. 
The Fed's ability to raise and lower short-term interest rates is its primary control over the economy. An increase in rates raises borrowing costs for consumers and businesses, leading to deferred spending and slower growth and inflation. A cut in rates has the opposite effect. Mr. Greenspan's goal is to keep the economy growing as fast as possible without causing inflation to rise.
The job has always been tricky. And it has become even more difficult as stock investors have intensified their focus on the Fed's interest-rate moves. Rising stocks encourage consumers to spend more, while a falling market dampens consumer spending. That indirect "wealth effect" can overwhelm the Fed's direct control over borrowing costs. But the Fed cannot always predict how stock investors will react to a change in short-term rates.
Mr. Greenspan raised short-term rates too slowly in 1999 and 2000, leading to the Nasdaq's bubble, critics say. He compounded the error, they add, by failing to cut rates last fall, hobbling the economy. Now, by making five rate cuts this year, he has overcompensated and risks another bubble.
Balancing growth and inflation is simply too much for one man, even Mr. Greenspan, says Jonathan Hakala, who spent more than a decade as a bond trader before quitting in 1998 to start a venture capital fund. Rather than relying on Mr. Greenspan, he suggests allowing the market to set short-term rates, as it now sets long-term rates.
Here is how Mr. Hakala's plan works: The Fed would announce a target rate for the 10-year Treasury note of 4 percent. If the Treasury note rate exceeded 4 percent, the short-term rate the Fed controls would be set at 4 percent plus double the difference between the 10-year rate and 4 percent; if the 10-year rate fell below 4 percent, the short-term Fed rate would be 4 percent minus double the difference.
For example, if the 10-year note rate is 5 percent, the Fed's short-term rate would be 6 percent. If the 10-year rate was 3 percent, the short-term rate would be 2 percent. Over the long run, the Fed's goal would be to keep both short-term and long-term rates at 4 percent and inflation as close to zero as possible. And because rules for setting short-term rates would be public, investors would have more certainty about what the Fed wanted.
"There's overwhelming pressure for a market-based, transparent, no- or low-inflation economy, and the people who try to resist it are dinosaurs. It's inevitable," Mr. Hakala said. "We need something that is not a personality cult around one very talented individual."
It is fair to say Mr. Hakala's plan so far has not won much support on Wall Street, where the accepted wisdom is that using a single mechanism to set short-term rates would be a mistake.
The interest rate on the 10-year note does not change solely because of investors' expectations of inflation, said David A. Wyss, chief economist for Standard & Poor's DRI. For example, a financial panic in Japan could cause Japanese investors to sell their American Treasury securities and push up rates on the 10-year note. Under Mr. Hakala's rule, the Fed would raise rates just when it should lower them, Mr. Wyss said. Also, productivity growth changes over time, affecting the inflation-free growth rate. Mr. Hakala's plan does not account for that, Mr. Wyss said.
"Greenspan's done a better job than an automatic rule," Mr. Wyss said. "I wouldn't say he's been perfect, but I'd say he gets at least an A-minus."

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends: Power Politics; 
Looking to Win The Energy Issue

BYLINE:  By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
IN every room at the Holiday Inn Campus in Eau Claire, Wis., a sign implores guests to preserve energy by re-using their towels. But Terri Mertz, the hotel's general manager, said that typically guests in no more than five rooms (out of 137) do so.
 "People probably think, 'I'm at a hotel, so they can pay for my towels,' " Ms. Mertz said. 
 Therein lies a lesson for President Bush and the Democrats, who in releasing competing energy blueprints last week each tried to present theirs as the responsible approach to the nation's twin desires for affordable energy and a clean environment. 
Both parties have commissioned polls that show that Americans (particularly prized independent voters) place a far greater priority on encouraging conservation than on producing more oil and gas. Yet there is a huge gap between what people say they want and how they act. In fact, Americans have long resisted taking steps in their own lives to reduce energy consumption.
This contradiction, ambivalence or hypocrisy could provide a political opening for either party, especially the Republicans, whose energy plan offers only a passing glance at conservation. In the end, Mr. Bush may not suffer politically if, deep down, people are loath to change their lifestyles. The Democrats, in contrast, are asserting that the White House doesn't care about the environment and that its policies would force people to curb their energy use -- or pay higher rates -- not because of any crisis but so that oil companies could reap greater profits. 
Both sides, then, are seeking to exploit an uncertain electorate, an inherently risky game. For Republicans, the challenge is to avoid being seen as despoilers of the Earth; the Democrats need to protect themselves from being portrayed by Republicans as more concerned about championing the spotted owl than people's livelihoods.
"A large fraction of the American public consider themselves to be concerned about the environment," said Cutler J. Cleveland, director of the Center for Energy and Environmental Studies at Boston University, "yet they also want the freedom to behave in ways that are not constrained by the price or cost of energy. They are outraged with every nickel-a-gallon increase in the price of gasoline."
For generations, Americans have been accustomed to abundant and cheap natural resources. Even today, oil and gas are still relatively affordable compared both to inflation and to prices worldwide. This creates a problem for conservationists because, historically, conservation has really worked only when the cost of profligacy has hit consumers' pocketbooks. Thus, the Arab oil embargo during the Carter administration drove Americans to fuel-efficient cars only because gasoline shot up in price and often was not even available.
For now, despite the specter of rolling blackouts and warnings that gas could top $3 a gallon, most people do not seem panicked enough to change their ways. In California, however, where there is a crisis, two-thirds of the guests at the Westin St. Francis hotel in San Francisco are happily re-using their towels at the management's request. 
Absent a crisis, financial incentives can encourage conservation. If the Holiday Inn in Eau Claire offered a discount for people who re-used their towels -- or even a free cup of coffee -- the response might be better.
"Any time you ask people to do something new, they have a disincentive to do it," said Raymond de Young, an environmental psychologist at the University of Michigan. "If you're basically telling people that there's no pleasure in what we're asking them to do, people are going to ask, 'What's in it for me?' And they're going to be afraid they're going to be taken for a sucker."
American public planning has also discouraged conservation. For example, people might prefer taking public transportation in Los Angeles. But if there are no convenient subway or bus lines, what choice do they have but to drive? Similarly, people may feel embarrassed about driving gas-guzzling sport utility vehicles, but if the government is afraid of imposing more stringent fuel economy standards on them, or placing higher taxes on gas (which is far cheaper here than in any European country), why scold their owners? In fact, a Transportation Department study made public late last week found that the average gas mileage of new vehicles in the 2001 model year had slipped back to the level of 1999, which was the lowest since 1980.
If anything, postwar America has encouraged energy consumption, hence the proliferation of highways, suburbs and automobiles, all subsidized. Unlike the Japanese or Europeans, who have limited energy reserves and have had no choice but to do things like flick off light switches, the United States psyche has never been as oriented toward efficiency. The average American uses nearly twice as much energy as the average European, experts say.
LAST week, a conservation-minded customer brought a stack of hangers to a cleaner here for re-use, and was told, "We don't do that." The store clerk threw them out.
Amory B. Lovins, a prominent advocate of energy efficiency, said skinny copper wires that carry electricity to light fixtures can be found above the ceilings in many buildings. If fatter wires were installed, he said, there would be an energy savings of nearly 200 percent.
"It's a subtle but pervasive example of how our market system is not using energy in a way that saves money," said Mr. Lovins, who heads the Rocky Mountain Institution in Snowmass, Colo. "If an electrician were altruistic enough to buy the fatter wire, that electrician would never have gotten the job in the first place because he would not have had the lowest bid."
So it is that, while politicians have been competing to be perceived as pro-conservation (a joke making the rounds here is that Mr. Bush is planning to reinstall solar panels that Jimmy Carter put in the roof of the White House), they have taken care not to suggest anything that would spoil the sacred American way of life. No one wants to repeat the mistake made during the energy crisis of the 1970's by Mr. Carter, whose call for austerity left people wondering whether they would find themselves shivering in the dark under a blanket.
"I reject that term, sacrifice," said Gov. Gray Davis of California, a Democrat. "We're asking people to reduce their personal energy consumption by at least 10 percent. But that is not difficult to do. People don't have to have every light in the house on, every television operating, even when no one's watching and all the computers are on 24 hours a day. That's simply wasteful and unnecessary."
The White House has apparently banned the word sacrifice from its talking points. On the contrary, Ari Fleischer, the White House press secretary, declared that "Mr. Bush believes that energy use is a reflection of the strength of our economy" and "the American way of life is a blessed one and we have a bounty of resources in this country."
Those remarks and other by Vice President Dick Cheney, while cheered by the energy industry, made the White House appear so blithely indifferent to the environment that Mr. Bush was forced to dress up his energy policy with conservation initiatives.
Predictably, this has not satisfied environmentalists, who note that there are few mandatory conservation measures. "You can summarize the president's energy policy as real men dig, drill and burn," said Philip E. Clapp, president of the National Environmental Trust, "and conservation is for wimps."
Republicans, well aware that Democrats are widely viewed as more environmentally sensitive, are emphasizing the economy and the consumer. The White House has lined up both conservatives and labor leaders behind its policy to make the point that it would help the economy stay competitive -- and that creating jobs, especially during a time of economic uncertainty, should be the highest priority.
Implicit in this view is that environmentalism is bad for the economy and bad for the average worker. "There is a tremendous opportunity for Republicans to discredit environmentalists," said Myron Ebell, who is in charge of global warming issues at the Competitive Enterprise Institute, a conservative group. "There is something fundamentally anti-consumer and undemocratic about Democratic coercion to force people to change their lifestyle. The effect of their policies would be to lower the American standard of living."
Democrats counter that people have grown too sophisticated for such scare tactics and that there are enormous hidden costs -- health care, toxic cleanups, loss of tourism -- to a policy that pushes production at the expense of the environment. 
"The Bush people are approaching this as a trade-off: either you sacrifice or you dig in the national forest," said Mark Mellman, a pollster who has conducted surveys on the environment for the Democratic National Committee. "The public says you can have both."
But can people really have it both ways? Advocates on both sides agree that to successfully grapple with the nation's energy needs and the demands for clean air, water and a landscape not utterly despoiled, there has to be some balance between production and conservation. Finding that balance, at least politically, is the big challenge.
"We're all guilty," said Senator Richard Durbin, an Illinois Democrat. "We all want the benefits. But we don't want to make the sacrifices."

 CORRECTION:
An article on May 20 about Republican and Democratic efforts to find political advantage in the nation's current energy problems misstated the period of the Arab oil embargo. It was 1973-74, not during the administration of Jimmy Carter, who was in office from 1977 to 1981.

HEADLINE: A Presidency Reconsidered 

BYLINE:  By David Gergen; David Gergen, a professor of public service at the Kennedy School at Harvard and editor at large of U.S. News & World Report, served as special counsel to President Ford from 1975 to 1976.

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE , Mass. 

 BODY:
Throwing caution into Boston Harbor, the trustees of the John F. Kennedy Library have made a gutsy decision: they will present their annual Profile in Courage award tomorrow night to Gerald R. Ford. And for what? For pardoning Richard Nixon! In a single, swift stroke, the trustees will thus complete the revival of one president, honor the spirit of another and send a message that should be heard by leaders everywhere.
 A generation ago, Mr. Ford's pardon looked like a one-way ticket to oblivion. He and his team had heavily suggested that he would not even consider a reprieve until prosecutors had brought formal charges against Mr. Nixon, an event that seemed months away, if not years. But then, at 11 a.m. on a Sunday morning just 30 days into his presidency, with church bells pealing in the distance, Mr. Ford went on national television to announce that he had granted "a full, free, and absolute pardon unto Richard Nixon for all offenses against the United States." 
 By the time Mr. Ford reached Burning Tree for an afternoon of golf, it was his presidency that was in flames. His press secretary had resigned. An overnight poll by The New York Times found his approval ratings dropping from a lofty 71 percent to 49 percent. In Pittsburgh the next day, people booed him for the first time and demonstrators shouted, "Jail Ford, jail Ford!" A worker by the airport fence expressed a widespread view: "Oh, it was all fixed. He said to Mr. Nixon, 'You give me the job, I'll give you the pardon.' "
Nearly all of us who had worked for Mr. Nixon in the White House were as surprised as the public. Mr. Ford had disclosed his intent to only a tiny number of us and only at the last minute. I heard his speech while driving and almost veered into a ditch. But we also knew Mr. Ford to be so thoroughly honest that a deal with Mr. Nixon or Alexander Haig, Mr. Nixon's chief of staff, was inconceivable. He had clearly acted out of conviction.
Sadly, we could never convince the public of that. President Ford's honeymoon was irretrievably shattered, and two years later, the pardon cost him the election against Jimmy Carter. For a long while, it appeared Mr. Ford would enter the books as a footnote. He had served in the White House only 895 days. Despite his many good works after leaving the White House, often undertaken in tandem with Mr. Carter, he could not escape the shadows of the past.
Recent years, however, have brought a change in perception. The first signal came in 1996, when Richard Reeves, a journalist who had earlier savaged Mr. Ford as Bozo the Clown, wrote a remarkable article in American Heritage; its title was "I'm Sorry, Mr. President." Lamenting the press's growing penchant for trashing public figures and manfully admitting his own part, Mr. Reeves wrote that Mr. Ford "had done a better job than I had predicted or imagined" and added, "You have my respect and thanks, Mr. President."
This past summer, when Mr. Ford was rushed to the hospital in Philadelphia on the opening night of the Republican convention, a wave of nostalgia swept over the delegates and into the press corps. Television news channels stood poised to break in with specials if his condition turned grave.
But the real U-turn came when George W. Bush began selecting his team. Three of his top choices -- Dick Cheney, Donald Rumsfeld and Paul O'Neill -- were properly seen as "Ford men." Alan Greenspan had served as Mr. Ford's chief economic adviser and remains close to the former president. One of the co-chairmen of President Bush's Social Security commission, Richard Parsons, was a senior White House aide in the Ford administration. Brent Scowcroft, Mr. Ford's national security adviser, is the mentor of Mr. Bush's national security chief, Condoleezza Rice. The Ford influence is everywhere.
True, Mr. Cheney, Mr. Rumsfeld and the others today sound more like products of the Reagan years than the Ford era. They, like their party, have moved to the right since the 1970's. Curiously, Mr. Ford himself moved closer to the center after he became president and has remained there since. Perhaps the wider perspective of the office forever changed him.
And now the award in Boston prompts the question: Why this flowering of Mr. Ford's reputation? Why now?
Presidential reputations, as the historian Arthur Schlesinger Jr. pointed out some years ago, tend to rise and fall with changes in the political climate. Harry Truman has enjoyed one of the most spectacular comebacks, rivaling his own election victory in 1948. Dwight Eisenhower has also experienced a lift since political scientists have had a chance to look through his private papers, and with the horror of Vietnam fading, Lyndon Johnson is gaining stature for his civil rights bills.
Mr. Ford's revival rests less upon his achievements than upon his spirit of leadership. Historians do not yet grant him the credit he deserves for policy gains like the Helsinki accords he negotiated with Leonid Brezhnev, the first serious crack in the Iron Curtain. Some claim (wrongly) that he had a mediocre mind. But after all the scandals, shenanigans and excessive spin of intervening years, Mr. Ford shines through as a man of honor, decency and plain talk, qualities that look good in the rear-view mirror of history.
Moreover, Mr. Ford's moderation seems close to the mood of the country today. In the early 1990's, Americans rejected the Bill Clinton health initiative as too liberal, and in the mid-90's they rejected the revolution of Newt Gingrich as too conservative. A wide swath of the electorate seems more comfortable these days with the moderate, pragmatic approach that characterized the Ford presidency.
But it was the pardon that most defined Mr. Ford, and now even some of his former critics are finally recognizing how gutsy it was. Mr. Ford said not long ago that as a new president, he was spending 25 percent of his time on the problems of one man, Mr. Nixon, when there was a looming economic crisis, a coming summit with the Russians and a storm brewing in the Middle East. He knew he would be risking his reputation with the pardon, but attending to the problems of the country came first. 
Many today still think he was wrong to let Mr. Nixon off the hook. I happen to think he was right (though he might have stage-managed the decision more adroitly, signaling to the nation in advance where he was heading). But even those who disagree with his pardon should agree that it took real political courage. 
A true democracy, John F. Kennedy wrote in "Profiles in Courage," has faith that its elected representatives "will exercise their conscientious judgment -- faith that the people will not condemn those whose devotion to principle leads them to unpopular courses, but will reward courage, respect honor and ultimately recognize right." The trustees of the Kennedy Library thus salute both President Ford and President Kennedy tomorrow night. But they do more: they are telling leaders everywhere to pay less attention to daily polls and more attention to their inner voices. Give up the slavish obedience to popular opinion so embedded in politics today, and take up the standard of what's right, even when it threatens one's political survival. As Jerry Ford found, you may be condemned by millions but one day -- perhaps a quarter century later -- win an honored place in history.

HEADLINE: INVESTING: DIARY; 
Is Greenspan's Salary A Bit Irrational?

BYLINE:  By Robert D. Hershey Jr. 

 BODY:
"Irrational exuberance," of course, is the phrase once used by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, to allude to the runaway bull market in stocks.
 So how might a rational investor characterize the Federal Reserve salary structure, in which Mr. Greenspan, who sets the nation's main interest-rate benchmark almost single-handedly, earns a smaller paycheck than dozens of his underlings? 
 To be sure, some Wall Street traders and analysts make more money than their bosses because of outsized profits generated by their departments. But there is little doubt that Mr. Greenspan is the Fed's most valuable player and the only one of its officials most people could name.
Mr. Greenspan's salary this year is $161,239, according to the central bank. Although that is an increase from $141,300 in 2000, it is still less than a superstar baseball player makes in a weekend. And it is also less than the annual pay of each of the 12 presidents of the Fed's regional banks (not to mention less than what at least 11 staff members were making as long as six years ago, when the privacy-conscious Fed was forced by a Freedom of Information Act request to disclose salaries, unconnected to names, of various officials).
The other governors of the Federal Reserve Board earn $145,115, while the salaries of the 12 regional presidents -- deemed to require pay closer to that of the private market than the people who labor in Washington -- range from $205,000 to $303,000.
And who gets the top regional presidential pay? Not, as one might expect, William J. McDonough, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, the permanent vice chairman of the Federal Open Market Committee and generally considered the system's No. 2 official. He makes $283,300, or $19,700 less than Robert Parry, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, who has more seniority. Robert D. Hershey Jr.

HEADLINE: U.S. Germ Warfare Review Faults Plan on Enforcement 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL R. GORDON and JUDITH MILLER 

 BODY:
A confidential Bush administration review has recommended that the United States not accept a draft agreement to enforce the treaty banning germ weapons, according to American officials.
 The recommendations appear certain to distress allies, who back the draft accord and are concerned that the new administration is concentrating too much on new military programs and not enough on treaties and nonproliferation. 
 After six years of negotiations, diplomats in Geneva have produced the draft agreement, known as a protocol, which would establish measures to monitor the ban on biological weapons. 
A 1972 treaty, which 143 nations have ratified, prohibits the development, production and possession of biological weapons. But the treaty has always lacked a means of verifying compliance. United States support for the protocol is critical to the effort to give the treaty teeth. 
The Clinton administration cast the new protocol as an important tool to stem the spread of biological weapons. And international negotiators in Geneva have been rushing to complete it by November. 
But the new Bush administration has taken a far more skeptical approach. In a unanimous review, its interagency team concluded that the current version of the protocol would be inefficient in stopping cheating, and that all its deficiencies could not be remedied by the negotiating deadline.
"The review says that the protocol would not be of much value in catching potential proliferators," a senior American official said.
The White House has yet to formally endorse the review's conclusions, but since all the relevant agencies agreed to it, the White House is considered virtually certain to go along. The real issue is what steps to adopt in light of the recommendations, and how to proceed diplomatically. Although the review strongly objects to the current version of the protocol, it does not rule out fresh attempts to address monitoring. 
And the review is also emerging as a sensitive diplomatic problem. President Bush heads to Europe next month, and his administration has already been under fire for steering too unilateralist a course on foreign policy, by backing away from the Kyoto accords on global warming and, to a lesser extent, the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty. So the White House is eager to avoid a new split.
Tibor Toth, the Hungarian diplomat who has overseen the effort to negotiate the protocol, will fly to Washington this week to try to change the Bush administration's mind, American officials said.
"Different constituencies seem to see different flaws, which indicates it is a pretty good compromise," Mr. Toth said in a telephone interview. "If it still needs to be fixed, we have the time. Barriers have been raised to nuclear and chemical proliferation. If the world community fails to agree on a protocol to strengthen the ban on biological weapons after six years of talks, it will send a very unfortunate message." 
The first step to ban germ weapons was taken when President Richard M. Nixon and other world leaders signed the treaty in 1972, at the dawn of arms control. But the agreement had no means of enforcing compliance. That became an enormous concern after President Boris N. Yeltsin conceded in 1992 that the Soviet Union had violated the accord by maintaining a long-standing biological-weapons program after the treaty went into force. Then evidence was acquired after the Persian Gulf war confirming that Iraq also had germ weapons, heightening fears over biological warfare. Most of the dozen or so countries that are believed to have biological weapons programs -- like Iran, Iraq, Libya and North Korea -- are members of the 1972 treaty.
So a decade ago, during the administration of Mr. Bush's father, the United States and other nations began studying what could be done to monitor the treaty. Six years ago, they began talks on a new protocol.
There have been many obstacles. China, which has little experience with formal arms-control treaties, is reluctant to allow on-site inspections. Pakistan is concerned that inspectors searching for germ weapons might investigate its nuclear weapons sites. And in the negotiations Iran has been trying to weaken controls on the export of biological equipment and materials, saying they hurt its civilian economies.
The United States, for its part, has had conflicting motivations. On one hand, it has worked to limit the scope of visits by foreign inspectors in order to protect American pharmaceutical and biotechnology companies, which dominate the worldwide industry and are concerned with protecting their trade secrets. 
And at the behest of the Pentagon, the government tried to limit inspections of American biodefense installations, which develop vaccines and protective equipment and analyze the germ warfare threat. 
As a result, the United States has not been as tough on verification as most of its allies. And yet Washington also hoped that the protocol would discourage cheating. 
Under the 210-page protocol, parties agree to make known their vaccine production facilities, the largest biodefense installations and facilities that do genetic engineering or aerosol studies with germ agents that are most likely to be used in weapons. But it would not require a declaration of all types of facilities that could be used to make weapons, including food and beverage plants and some pharmaceutical plants. 
As for inspections, a new executive council would be established and a majority vote of the body would be required before an investigation of a suspicious plant could be carried out. That procedure, insisted on by American industry, is less strict than a similar provision in the treaty banning chemical weapons, which stipulates that such investigations are to be done unless there is a vote by three-fourths of a similar body to block them. Inspectors under the biological protocol would have to be granted access 108 hours after an inspection was approved.
Defenders say the goal of the protocol was never to provide air-tight verification but rather to increase the chances that cheaters would be caught and thereby deter violations. Some monitoring and openness, they say, is better than none. 
But critics of the protocol say the accord would not really provide much security. A nation that was determined to cheat could find a way to do so and might use the limited inspections to throw other nations off the trail, they say. In this view, the United States would open itself up to inspections and get little in return.
When the Bush administration took office, the issue came to the fore. Donald A. Mahley, the American negotiator at the talks, proposed a review. The interagency group he led included working-level officials from the State Department, the Pentagon, the Commerce Department, the Energy Department and intelligence agencies.
The review found 38 problems with the protocol, a handful of them serious. But its basic assessment was very critical. It concluded that the verification measures in the treaty were unlikely to detect cheating. At the same time, the review concluded that these same provisions might be used by foreign governments to try to steal American secrets.
The review recommended that the United States not support the draft protocol that Ambassador Toth had overseen. And it concluded that there was not enough time to fix all the problems before the negotiating deadline.
Secretary of State Colin L. Powell has approved the review, which has been circulating in the administration. Officially, however, the White House insists that the review has not been completed, in part because it has yet to figure out a new policy.
But as word of the review has begun to seep out, it is already prompting debate. Barbara H. Rosenberg, a specialist at the Federation of American Scientists, said the Bush administration should have worked to improve the accord during the last negotiating round if it did not like it. Instead, the United States was passive, with the new administration claiming that it could not act while the policy review was supposedly under way.
"The U.S. sat quietly throughout the sessions and said nothing," Dr. Rosenberg said. "It made no effort to improve the text."
But Michael L. Moodie, a senior arms control official in the first Bush administration, said the protocol was severely flawed and needed to be replaced by a new approach. 
"The protocol was not going to get the job done," Mr. Moodie said. "It is it not going to deter proliferation." And if it was put into effect, he said, "we still would not be confident that there were not major violations going on."
If the White House, as expected, affirms the review, it has several alternatives. One is to try to improve the accord before the November deadline but to accept the fact that the United States is unlikely to obtain all the changes it would like. But there is little or no support for that approach in the administration.
Another is to ask that the deadline be extended so that negotiators would work on a substantially different protocol.
Or the United States could take a significantly different approach. Supporters of that idea, which is being actively discussed in the administration, say Washington should propose a stripped-down version of the protocol that would provide for investigations when violations of the convention are suspected. Such inspections, for example, might be carried out if there was a suspicious outbreak of disease, as happened in Sverdlovsk, Russia, in 1979 when anthrax spores escaped from a biological weapons plant.
There is a recognition within the administration that breaking off talks on biological-weapons monitoring altogether is not feasible because of diplomatic costs. That is especially the case because the administration is already involved in sensitive talks with its allies on the missile defense issue and has been eager to show that it is not ideologically opposed to arms control.
Still, the turnabout in American policy is likely to provoke concern from American allies, particularly the British, who have been very active on the treaty. 
When Prime Minister Tony Blair visited Washington in February, he insisted that the United States promise to pursue nonproliferation measures and not just missile defense, and the Bush administration agreed to mention nonproliferation in the statement that both leaders issued.

HEADLINE: The World: Of TV and Soccer; 
The Power of Celebrity Hits Italian Politics

BYLINE:  By ALESSANDRA STANLEY 

DATELINE: ROME 

 BODY:
BOASTING that he alone can straighten out Italy's tangled legal code, Silvio Berlusconi has already compared himself to Napoleon, which takes some of the fun out of finding parallels for Italy's new and unusual prime minister.
 The conservative media baron, who defeated Italy's center-left last Sunday, is short, ambitious and staggeringly self-confident. It is not hard to imagine him snatching a crown away from a pope and placing it on his head with his own hands. Though not an imperial crown, since Italy is a democracy. Something more along the lines of grabbing a laurel offered by the head of Italian state television. 
 As prime minister, he would have influence over the running of Italy's three state-controlled networks, an unsettling prospect given that Mr. Berlusconi already owns Italy's three largest private networks. 
Conflict of interest is now one of the most glaring issues facing his administration, but television alone does not explain his rise to power. Mr. Berlusconi owns Milan AC, the soccer team that won the national championship in 1993 and again in 1994, the year he was first, if briefly, elected prime minister. Even before he entered politics, the tycoon had a hero's status that eludes most American business leaders, except perhaps Ted Turner at his swashbuckling height as founder of CNN and owner of the Atlanta Braves. Soccer is Italy's passion, and soccer built Mr. Berlusconi's image as a winner, a can-do businessman above the clique of grey-faced politicians that had run Italy since the end of World War II. 
Mr. Berlusconi took his party's name from a soccer chant, "Forza Italia," and used his advertising company, his TV stations and his innate talent for communications to introduce American-style campaign kitsch -- anthems, badges, jazzy political ads -- to Italy. 
He used many of the same techniques this time (he got around a ban on TV ads by plastering posters of himself all over Italy and mailing a gauzy 128-page biography to every family). His victory nonetheless stunned the outside world, where the idea that a Ted Turner or Rupert Murdoch could become prime minister while retaining his media holdings is unthinkable. The reaction from abroad in many ways echoes the 1980 American presidential elections, when a stunned Europe woke up and wondered, "Americans elected an actor?" 
Mr. Berlusconi has a bit of showbiz in his blood -- he worked his way through law school as a nightclub crooner on cruise ships. But like Ronald Reagan, who was governor of California for eight years, Mr. Berlusconi has spent the last five years in parliament leading the center-right opposition and honing his free-market economic platform as well as his political skills. 
Italians elected him not because they believed he could fulfill all his promises, but because they felt he was bold enough to try. He was also helped by a center-left government that was internally divided after five budget-cutting years in power. 
Mr. Berlusconi sold his vision of a more efficient, less bureaucratic Italy with the simple slogans and enthusiasm that helped him woo advertisers when he began piecing together his TV empire. He now controls 80 percent of that market.
Mr. Berlusconi's legendary business acumen -- he made a fortune in real estate, TV and also publishing, financial services and insurance -- stood him in good stead in politics. He out-negotiated the center-left government, avoiding reforms to the electoral law that could have helped his rival Francesco Rutelli win the election, without yielding on a conflict-of-interest law that would force him to sell off media assets. Now, he says he will pass his own law -- while asserting there is no conflict of interest.
He argues that he is already too rich too steal, and just wants to help other Italians succeed. His economic platform is Reaganesque -- lower taxes, trim the state and coax private investment to help finance huge public works projects. He is conservative, but American-style -- his unabashed embrace of capitalism and the joys of money clash with Italy's traditional right-wing ideology, which is statist, Catholic and suspicious of overnight wealth. 
His appeal to ordinary Italians is also like Mr. Reagan's. He has the high gloss of celebrity, a sunnily confident manner and keeps his programs simple. 
Mr. Berlusconi is too Italian to do his own ranch chores, however. Shots of him at "Arcore," his vast estate outside Milan, are taken poolside, or in gilded salons surrounded by Renaissance paintings. If anything, he has a touch of Nancy Reagan -- Mr. Berlusconi once cited his Albanian servants as proof that he has no bias against immigrants. 
Behind the scenes, he isn't disengaged as Mr. Reagan was. He doesn't delegate, and his hands-on approach is closer to Alexander M. Haig Jr.'s. Mr. Berlusconi's passionate anti-communism, a bit anachronistic now that the cold war is over, is more personal than any American president's. He views all attacks and criminal charges as part of a vast left-wing conspiracy to bring him down. He rarely displays a sense of humor when denouncing his opponents' "Bolshevik" tactics. 
Italy's respected conservative columnist Indro Montanelli, 91, was once close to Mr. Berlusconi. (He quit as editor of his newspaper, Il Giornale, when the boss went into politics and expected his paper to support him.) Asked if there was any connection between Mr. Berlusconi's right-wing populism and Mussolini, Mr. Montanelli, no fan of fascism, seemed insulted on Il Duce's behalf. "Oh no," he said. "I knew Mussolini, and there is a great difference. Mussolini came from politics, and he was as big a historical figure as he was disastrous for Italy." As a better analogy, he suggested, "Bel Ami," Maupassant's Belle Epoque Sammy Glick.
The Italian intelligentsia despises Mr. Berlusconi, for some of the same reasons many Americans were appalled by Mr. Reagan. They see him as vulgar, misguided and, given his control of TV, newspapers and so many businesses, dangerous. Before the election, Umberto Eco called on voters to conduct a "moral referendum" against him.
Mr. Berlusconi says he wants to reform the legal system, a scary notion coming from someone who still faces trials on corruption charges. But changes to the constitution require time and several rounds of voting in Parliament, and can be contested by referendum. 
HE is not going to change Italy's foreign policy, nor can he get away with tax cuts and deficit spending that would drive up the already high public debt. Italy, locked into the fiscal constraints of the euro, doesn't have the freedom to set its own course that Mr. Reagan and Britain under Margaret Thatcher, Mr. Berlusconi's other hero, enjoyed. 
Giuliano Ferrara, a newspaper editor who is an old friend and advisor of Mr. Berlusconi's, argued that Italy and the world should give the new prime minister a break. "The snobbish left blames him for bringing politics down to the lowest common denominator, but that isn't really so bad if it rids Italy of its smothering paternalistic ideology," Mr. Ferrara said. "If Italians will let Berlusconi build his bridges and highways, do his job and pardon him a few exaggerations, then maybe Italy will really get out of its mess."
