HEADLINE: Listen Up! It's Time for a Profit; 
A Front-Row Seat as Amazon Gets Serious

BYLINE:  By SAUL HANSELL 

DATELINE: SEATTLE 

 BODY:
IT is an unusually sunny day for Seattle, but no one can tell in the narrow, windowless conference room where Russell Allgor is drawing graphs on a white board. Dr. Allgor earned his Ph.D. at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology developing quantitative methods for making chemical plants more productive. Last summer, he moved from Bayer Chemical to Amazon.com and has built an 800,000-equation computer model of the company's sprawling operation, meant to help do most everything from scheduling Christmas overtime to rerouting trucks in a snowstorm.
 Dr. Allgor's work is part of a major shift in direction for Amazon.com, the online retailing giant. Its watchwords have changed from the buoyant "get big fast" to the pedestrian "march to profitability." And instead of designing zippy new features for its Web site and plotting new industries to conquer, its employees are turning to the tedious work of ordinary companies: cutting costs and raising revenue. 
 On this early Wednesday afternoon in May, Dr. Allgor has set out to answer one of Amazon's most vexing problems: how to keep inventory at a minimum, while ensuring that when someone orders several products, they can be shipped in a single box, preferably from the warehouse -- the company has six -- that is nearest the customer. 
"I can't follow so many numbers," said Lyn Blake, a vice president who previously ran Amazon's book department and now oversees company relations with manufacturers. "Remember, I didn't go to M.I.T. or Purdue, but I control the checkbook here." (The acerbic Ms. Blake has a journalism degree from Indiana University.)
Dr. Allgor's analysis is simple, but to Amazon veterans it is heretical: Amazon should increase its holdings of best sellers and stop holding slow-selling titles. (It would still sell these titles but order them after the customer does.)
"We need your buyoff on this," said Jim Miller, Dr. Allgor's boss, looking cautiously at Ms. Blake. Mr. Miller is a vice president in Amazon's unit that handles distribution and warehouses (and he holds an engineering degree from Purdue).
"You're not going have it," she snapped, "until you show how many items will no longer show 24-hour availability." If a product is in stock, Amazon guarantees customers shipment within 24 hours. For products it must order, it lists longer delays.
"I worry about the customer's perspective if we suddenly have a lot of items that are not available for quick delivery," Ms. Blake added.
Fueled by big dreams and seemingly endless cash from investors, Amazon.com created an almost magical offering for consumers: Tap into a Web site and buy any book -- and, later, music and lots of other merchandise as well -- at a low price, with responsive service and quick shipment.
Now Amazon has assigned people like Dr. Allgor to analyze why it is losing money. What the company is finding, over and over, is what many skeptics have long contended: its magical offering is complicated, expensive and inefficient.
BETWEEN his habitual belly laughs, Jeff Bezos, Amazon's founder and chief executive, says his company is exactly where he had always wanted it to be. Amazon's plan, imitated by hundreds of other Internet companies -- was to grow first and to figure out how to profit later.
Amazon did get big fast. It opened outposts in four countries. It expanded to become a general store selling electronics, kitchen gadgets and lawn furniture. Last year, 20 million customers bought $2.8 billion worth of merchandise -- more revenue, Amazon says, than for any 5-year-old company in history. But it also lost $1.4 billion doing so.
Nearly all its rivals have vanished or are just limping along, conserving their last drops of cash. And Amazon, with its head start and foresight to raise $2.1 billion, is one of the few dot-coms left that will ever find out whether that that crucial second phase can work.
"We have been planning for a long time for this inflection point, after expanding geographically and our product categories in 1999," Mr. Bezos said. "This is the right time to focus on the fundamental economics of our business, even if it means sacrificing growth."
That is not to say that Mr. Bezos has gotten everything right. Hardly. Amazon promised investors big returns from its deals to promote other Internet companies like Pets.com and Living.com, most of which paid Amazon in stock, not cash. Oops. Those companies are defunct. And last year, Mr. Bezos set an internal goal of $5 billion in sales for 2001; it now expects no more than $3.6 billion.
Mr. Bezos readily acknowledges that he was wrong on Pets.com and the like, and that he underestimated the impact of the economic slowdown on Amazon's sales. But he says that once the company achieves its goal of turning an operating profit in the fourth quarter -- a goal that is hardly guaranteed -- it will concentrate anew on expansion.
"A major focus in 2002 will still be profitability, he said. "We're not in this business to break even. But next year we will pursue a more balanced strategy. Growth is an important factor in our profitability."
Despite Amazon's size, this plan is as provocative and unproven as it was when Mr. Bezos founded the company in 1994. After all, Amazon is at heart a mail-order merchant. And nearly every successful mail-order company has used a variation of the same formula -- a limited selection of unique products. Only the high margins provided by such private-label goods can pay the costs of marketing, warehousing and shipping.
Amazon, instead, wants to be the online equivalent of Wal-Mart, with so much sales volume that it has the buying power and efficiency to sell the same products available everywhere, but at low prices, and still make money.
To Amazon's critics, and there are now many, that is a recipe for mediocrity, if not total collapse.
"The more I learn about the dumb things they did, the more I believe there is room for improvement," said Lauren Levitan, an analyst at Robertson Stephens. She said the company was hobbled by a stagnating book business and low margins in electronics, its second-biggest line. "Once you stop selling 30-pound bags of concrete," she asked, "what can you do to find sustainable and profitable growth?"
AGAINST the rising chorus of criticism, Amazon agreed to a request by Money & Business for a close look at the steps the company was taking to become profitable. The company invited a reporter to spend three days observing a half-dozen meetings on inventory management, marketing, pricing and customer service.
There was much, of course, that Amazon kept off limits -- top-management strategy sessions, discussions about links with outside retailers like Borders and Toys "R" Us, and negotiations, if any are occurring, to raise more capital or restructure its debt.
Even so, a clear picture emerged of a company wrestling at every level with turning growth into profits. Many of the meetings and decisions in the first week of May concentrated on coping with the torrent of data from a new accounting system that for the first time calculates how much money Amazon makes or loses on each product it sells. The system takes into account the company's cost to ship, the frequency of returns and 47 other factors.
Executives found that more than 10 percent of the products sold from the electronic, kitchen and tool departments lost money, while 5 percent of the book, music and video products were losers. So the company is looking for ways to cut those losses. It is pressing manufacturers for better deals and finding more efficient packaging for bulky products. In some cases, it is raising prices or eliminating unprofitable products. And it is looking to have other companies handle warehousing and shipping of some products on its behalf -- something it once rejected outright.
Ananth Raman, a professor at Harvard Business School who has studied retailers' operations, said other companies had been able to increase profits by 2 to 19 percent of sales by studying profitability per product and using the other tactics that Amazon is talking about. But such tools are notoriously difficult.
"There is no silver bullet," he said. "They are talking about doing the right things. But that doesn't mean they are doing them right."

9 a.m. Thursday, May 3
"This is a controversial project," Lyn Blake reminds the half-dozen executives she had convened. "The publishers are unaware of what we are doing."
Amazon has worked hard for years to convince publishers and other product makers to sell goods to it directly, rather than forcing it to pay higher prices from wholesalers.
Now, Ms. Blake tells her group, Amazon can actually do better by buying many of its books from distributors, which offer quicker turnaround and allow Amazon to keep less inventory. Distributors are also less prone to making the kinds of shipping errors that wind up costing Amazon much money to sort out, she said.
"Operationally needy," is how Ms. Blake describes the systems of most of the publishing houses.
She would know. Ms. Blake spent 10 years in publishing, most recently as vice president for sales at Macmillan. She joined Amazon in January 2000 as the head of its book business and quickly used her inside knowledge to secure better deals from publishers.
Those moves, along with price increases on best sellers, have substantially improved Amazon's margins. (Its book, music and video business actually started making money last summer and its gross profit -- the markup minus cost of excess inventory -- rose from 20 percent in 1999 to 25 percent last year.) In January, Ms. Blake was put in charge of relations with all vendors.
At the meeting this day, one aide, Michael Seifert, reviews the costs and benefits of using distributors for two dozen major publishers. For all but four, he says, Amazon should deal only with distributors.
"Even for super big items?" Ms. Blake asks incredulously, wondering whether Amazon should rely on a wholesaler for the next Harry Potter phenomenon.
"Yes, that's what the analysis says," Mr. Seifert answers.
Ms. Blake, concerned about possible limits on quantities available from distributors, adds, "If there are any allocation issues at all we go out and buy them directly," from publishers.
Besides having distributors supply books to its warehouses, Amazon is preparing to take the more radical step of hiring the Ingram Book Group, the book distribution giant, to mail books directly to customers.
In some ways, that makes perfect sense. Why should Amazon unpack a book sent by a distributor, only to repack it and send it to a customer? But competitors argue, as had Amazon, that outside arrangements are too risky.
"I can't see entrusting our customer relationships to an outside company," said Steve Riggio, the acting chief executive of Barnesandnoble.com. "If things go wrong you are in for a pot of trouble."
Ms. Blake, however, counters that, "You won't be able to tell if a book is sent from our center in Fernley, Nev., or Ingram in Laverne, Tenn."
While Amazon moves away from direct relationships with publishers, its electronics business has a different problem. It remains handicapped because it is not an authorized dealer for many of the biggest makers of audio and video equipment, and it cannot get expensive products from wholesalers.
"Saying you are in the consumer electronics business without Sony is like being in the sneaker business without Nike," said Greg Drew, chief executive of 800.com, an online electronics store. "Not to have Sony and Panasonic and Kenwood and Pioneer and Toshiba is completely pretending." Amazon contends that as its sales grow, even stubborn manufacturers will have to join in.

10 a.m. Thursday, May 3
Ms. Blake and the others have packed up their notebooks and reconvened in another room on the seventh floor of the office building that Amazon calls "US1," because it houses sales operations for the United States. The rhythm of the day is like high school without the bells. If this is second period on Thursday, it must be the United States merchandising meeting.
Item No. 5 on today's agenda is meeting rationalization. Ms. Blake has handed out an elaborate grid of 26 regular meetings and who attends them. David Risher, Amazon's senior vice president in charge of United States retail businesses, who has popped in to watch, barks out: "You should draw a line through one-third of those meetings."
At the end of the meeting, participants must volunteer some way in which they are contributing to "the march to profitability."
"We've had a much more liberal return policy than our competitors and we may tighten it up a bit," says Cindy Ruppenthal, who works in the electronics area. It is expensive to handle returns of products that may contain dozens of individual parts in a box, she says. If something is missing, Amazon must then fight it out with customers. She says her group is looking to hire an outside company to retrieve expensive returns from customers' homes. That way, there can be no dispute about the product's condition.
There is much discussion about using outside companies at Amazon these days -- for service, for product shipping, and even more broadly, to sell products on its site. Amazon already sells Toys "R" Us products alongside its own. In that deal, Amazon handles toy shipping, but it may not do so with other companies. It may link with another big store chain to add an entirely new department, but it will also turn to smaller companies to fill in corners of its product line it doesn't want to handle.
So a customer may see a VCR sold directly by Amazon, but a large-screen television offered by an outside company. The template for this is already visible in Amazon's used-product offerings. On many Web pages on which it sells books, CD's and other products, an advisory informs the customer that the same product is available used. Clicking a button takes the shopper to a list of individuals and dealers whose prices are often substantially lower. (Amazon earns a 15 percent commission on their sales.) Soon, Amazon will start selling new products using the same format.
"We are committed to universal selection," Mr. Risher said. "But if we can't sell something profitably, we'll find someone who can."

4 p.m. Thursday, May 3
Amazon's corporate headquarters is in the Pacific Medical Center, an Art Deco former hospital perched on a steep hill overlooking Safeco Field. Unlike US1, which is filled with windowless compartments, the headquarters has bright offices with panoramic views of the city.
One such room is occupied by Maryam Mohit, a vice president for Web site development.
When she joined Amazon in 1996, her job was to add features to the site that would entertain customers and sell more merchandise. Now the tasks are more prosaic. They include redesigning the site to reduce the number of times that customers need to contact Amazon customer service.
Eight people are assembled in Ms. Mohit's office to go over problem areas of the site.
"It was really bad," says Jess Scheibach, a project manager who found that three-fourths of customers who had tried to change their passwords had failed to do so. She reports that a few changes in the layout of the password change page doubled the success rate.

10:30 a.m. Friday, May 4
Taymour Tamaddon, finance manager for Amazon's electronics, kitchen and tool departments, is the hero of the day. Using an Excel spreadsheet, he created a system meant to provide a precise proposal for how each product can be made more profitable. It is the culmination of months of work in the company.
Last December, in what has become an oft-repeated story, Mr. Bezos toured a warehouse and noticed that workers needed 15 minutes to assemble a special box to hold the company's best-selling patio chair.
He returned to the office and banned products that were so expensive to handle or ship that they could not be profitably sold. 
Rather than simply searching for a handful of other egregious examples, the company built the computer model that calculates the pretax profit, or contribution margin, for each product. The task was hardly easy. A team spent six weeks weighing and measuring 30,000 products to come up with accurate shipping and packing costs. Others tallied calls to customer service about products. (Complex ones, like digital cameras,generated far more calls, say, than music CD's.) 
This day, Mr. Tamaddon shows how the system analyzed a $10 pack of Polaroid instant film. It starts with a reasonable margin, but after all the costs of handling the product, Amazon loses $1 a pack.
"Consider bundling," the computer read, suggesting that single packs be combined, to sell two or more. Or, the computer program suggested, the company should find another merchant to handle and ship the film. In other cases, the computer recommended keeping tighter reign on inventory, pressing the vendor for more discounts, or raising prices.
Ms. Ruppenthal perks up at the recommendation of price increases, saying there is danger in raising prices too much.
"We need some loss leaders," she says, using the retail term for merchandise intentionally sold at a loss. "It creates customer satisfaction."
But Carl Gish, the manager of the electronics store, complains, "I saw the data, and the number of loss leaders is ridiculous."
He asks if the system could focus more on automatic price raising. "We took our prices down to meet competition," he says. "But we didn't bring prices back up as the competition went away."
Rather than relying only on detailed analysis to find unprofitable products, Amazon also created an electronic form that employees can fill out to describe problem products.
For example, Amazon was selling a $9 candle holder -- a large glass bowl containing rocks. It was meant to be filled with water that would float the candles. One customer returned the product four times because the rocks had shattered the glass during each shipment. That product is no longer part of "earth's biggest selection."
One question raised by this and many other examples, of course, is this: What was Amazon thinking to begin with? In retrospect, a glass bowl of rocks seems an unsuitable product for a mail-order company. Or, why did Amazon build five warehouses when it could easily hire companies like Ingram Books to handle much of its shipping?
Mr. Bezos's response is that, yes, inefficiency was all part of the plan. "We made a very deliberate decision to overbuild, although we hoped we were overbuilding by a little bit," he said. "If we hadn't done that, we would have disappointed customers, as a lot of Internet companies did, and we wouldn't be around anymore."

Profitable or Not? It Depends on Who's Measuring
IT will dominate retailing around the world. Or it will be the Internet's most spectacular flameout.
There are few companies that provoke as wide a range of passionate predictions as Amazon.com. And that is hardly a surprise; few companies have tried to do so much so fast while losing so much money.
The current state of Amazon's finances only intensifies the puzzle. Like many other technology and retail companies, Amazon now says its sales will grow far more slowly this year than it had expected. But at the same time, its profit margins are widening and its expenses are falling faster than it and others expected.
That makes it more likely that the company will meet its goal of breaking even, by its idiosyncratic measure of pro forma operating profit, in the fourth quarter of 2001.
That is not the toughest standard it could set. Amazon's pro forma profit excludes $33 million a quarter in interest on $2.1 billion in debt, severance payments and other expenses from restructuring, and accounting charges related to investment losses, stock options and acquisitions.
Moreover, sales volume drives Amazon's profit, so the holiday season should be its best. (It will not say if it will remain profitable next year.) Then again, its pro forma fourth-quarter loss was $175 million in 1999 and $60 million in 2000, so there is room for improvement.
There are signs that Amazon is moving in the direction it wants. 
Amazon's brightest area is gross profit, or revenue minus the cost of goods sold. Gross profit is reduced by any inventory write-offs and by shipping charges, because shipping fees are included in revenue.
Amazon's gross profit, which was 18 percent in 1999 and 24 percent in 2000, increased to 26 percent in the first quarter of this year.
The margin may be helped by Amazon's effort to cut inventory and to further reduce the number of orders shipped in more than one box.
The company's other costs are declining somewhat. It is sharply cutting back on marketing, and its fulfillment costs -- mainly the expense of running its warehouses -- were at 14 percent of sales in the first quarter, down from 17 percent in 2000.
Warren Jenson, Amazon's chief financial officer, pointed out that total expenses for United States operations decreased by 9 percent in the first quarter, from the previous year, even as sales increased 11 percent.
While analysts expect a small loss in the fourth quarter, rather than the break-even that Amazon predicts, many say the goal is within reach. 
The far bigger question is whether Amazon can return to growing without sacrificing profitability. 
Its international operations are still a drag, losing $34 million in the first quarter. And it is not clear when they will be profitable. Growth in the United States, meanwhile, is slowing. In the first quarter, its book, music and video sales, still its largest segment, increased by only 2 percent. Analysts have also started to notice a distressing churn in its customer base. One-third of its 30 million customers have not made purchases in the last year.
MANY critics contend that Amazon has fundamentally picked an impossible proposition.
"Their model just doesn't work," said Claire Gruppo, president of Gruppo Levey & Company, a New York investment bank specializing in direct marketing companies.
A good catalog merchant, she said, has fulfillment costs of 11 percent (compared with Amazon's 14 percent) and, more important, gross margins in excess of 50 percent (versus Amazon's 26 percent). 
Mr. Jenson counters that with high volume and rapid inventory turnover, Amazon can make money on far lower gross margins than the typical catalog company.
"You can either charge a lot and sell a few units, or you sell a lot of units with a small margin," he said. "We think the latter is a bigger business." SAUL HANSELL

An article last Sunday about Amazon.com's efforts to become profitable misidentified the Tennessee town that is headquarters to the Ingram Book Group, a distributor hired by the company to mail books directly to customers. It is La Vergne, not Laverne. 
The article also misstated the reason an Amazon.com office building in Seattle is named "US1." The name stands for Union Station 1, part of an office complex. It is not Amazon's abbreviation for the building that houses the company's United States sales operations.

HEADLINE: Recasting the Iraq Sanctions 

 BODY:
Recognizing that the international embargo on trade with Iraq has become increasingly untenable, the United States and Britain will soon propose a reasonable narrowing of the sanctions to bar the shipment of arms and weapons-related material to Saddam Hussein's regime. Even nations that are weary of the 11-year ban on trade with Iraq should support restrictions designed to prevent Baghdad from rearming and once again threatening its neighbors. But Washington and London will have to make a concerted diplomatic offensive if they hope to prevail at the United Nations Security Council and gain Mr. Hussein's assent for a plan that would return international weapons inspectors to Iraq. 
 A decade after the Persian Gulf war, most of the world has lost interest in isolating Iraq. Some nations are lured toward complacency by short memories of Mr. Hussein's invasion of Kuwait and the prospect of profitable business deals with Baghdad. The change in attitude is shortsighted, but with permanent members of the Security Council like France, Russia and China anxious to abandon the embargo, the United States and Britain have no choice but to fashion a new approach. 
 Under the British-American proposal, the Security Council would develop a specific list of military and industrial items that would be banned from sale to Iraq. Iraq would still be required to deposit all its legitimate oil revenues in an escrow account controlled by the U.N. Yet the country would be free to import whatever nonmilitary goods it wished, effectively ending the embargo on civilian commodities. The U.N. has permitted Iraq to import food, medicine and other essential items, but Mr. Hussein has cynically limited such purchases to stoke foreign complaints about the hardships the embargo has inflicted on the Iraqi people.
In return for a relaxation of the trade ban, Mr. Hussein would have to allow the U.N. to resume weapons inspections, which have been suspended since 1998. He is unlikely to accept the deal unless he is convinced that the Security Council is united in its determination to maintain an arms embargo and will not set aside the broader trade restrictions until he lets inspectors back into Iraq to monitor weapons programs. He may well reject the plan even if faced with an undivided Security Council, but there will be no hope of obtaining his agreement if France, Russia and China remain wobbly.
The plan will also prove unworkable if nearby nations like Syria, Iran, Turkey and Jordan are unwilling to enforce the prohibition on arms sales by carefully inspecting overland cargo shipments to Iraq. All these nations now openly permit the smuggling of banned goods in and out of Iraq. 
If the new diplomatic initiative fizzles, President Bush is sure to face escalating pressures to support Iraqi efforts to unseat Mr. Hussein. American financial assistance might be appropriate if there were an organized, well-led opposition within Iraq, or in the Iraqi exile community, but that is not the case. Mr. Bush should not entertain any proposals to use American military forces or weapons in concert with Mr. Hussein's foes. 
Engineering a change in governments is easy to champion but extremely difficult to execute, even in the rare cases when it may be justified and consistent with American principles. A bungled program to remove Mr. Hussein from power would embarrass the United States and recklessly endanger the lives of Iraqis who would like to see a democratic government installed in Baghdad.

HEADLINE: The $4 Trillion Tax Cut 

 BODY:
Soon after the Congress passed President Ronald Reagan's big tax cut in 1981, a few in the administration realized that their achievement amounted to a Pyrrhic victory. The tax cut, as it was taken up by lawmakers, grew out of all proportion, creating huge deficits that strangled the budget and the economy for nearly 15 years. Exactly the same prospect is in store if Congress approves the misshapen, misconceived tax cut now racing through Capitol Hill. The Senate is aiming to conclude its version of the tax cut this week, with President Bush hoping to sign it into law by Memorial Day. Yet with every passing day, the tax cut's flaws become more obvious. 
 A week ago, it looked as if the Senate would approach the tax cut with somewhat more restraint than the House, which rubber-stamped Mr. Bush's original proposal of a $1.6 trillion tax reduction over 10 years. A handful of moderate Democrats led by Senator Max Baucus of Montana persuaded the Republican leadership to scale the size back to $1.35 trillion and add some provisions favoring taxpayers of moderate means. The best amendment they added would make the higher child credit partially refundable as a payment to Americans who pay no income taxes. But upon inspection it is also clear that, in terms of scale, the so-called bipartisan tax cut before the Senate merely purports to be more responsible than Mr. Bush's proposal. In reality, its cost is staggering and it poses a serious danger to the basic federal safety net over the next 20 years. 
 The tax cut's $1.35 trillion price tag is a deception. The figure was calculated with an array of artificial devices that disguise the true cost. Some of the tax cuts to be enacted abruptly expire before the 11-year period is up, even though everyone knows that there will be pressure to let them continue. Other provisions are phased in slowly, with most of them not fully enacted until 2009, 2010 and 2011. This means that although the tax cut technically costs $1.35 trillion in the first decade, its cost in the second decade -- when the baby boomers will all be retired -- is more than $4 trillion. The tax cut cannot be paid for except by raiding the Social Security and Medicare trust funds. It is a scheme that seems deliberately aimed at wrecking the basic American retirement programs, perhaps to force their dismantling or privatization.
Most inexplicable is why many Democrats and Republicans who have stood by the social safety net for years seem ready to shred it now. On the Democratic side, Senators John Breaux of Louisiana, Robert Torricelli of New Jersey and Blanche Lincoln of Arkansas joined with Senator Baucus to approve this tax cut in the Finance Committee. Some Democrats say cynically that because so much of this tax cut does not take effect until many years from now, there will be plenty of time to rescind its most expensive features, so why not vote for it now? That is not an argument so much as an abdication of responsibility.
In trying to ram this tax cut through, the Republican leadership has made a mockery of Senate rules. When the Senate parliamentarian ruled against several attempts by Trent Lott, the majority leader, to advance the tax cut and budget, Mr. Lott dismissed him. Last week, there was no tax bill available until the night before the Senate was to begin voting on amendments. No time was allowed for the bipartisan Joint Taxation Committee or other outsiders to draw up detailed cost estimates. The White House and Mr. Lott clearly feel that time is their enemy. The more this tax cut is examined, the more its support will erode.
Take the argument that this tax cut is geared to the economy, and to the middle class hit by credit-card debt and energy bills. If that is the argument, why is only a pittance to be distributed in the next year? Why is more than a third of the tax cut going to the wealthiest 1 percent of taxpayers, who pay about a quarter of all federal taxes? Why, most of all, the need for haste? This is a tax cut that is so costly, so focused on the wealthiest Americans and so certain to drain vital resources for basic government services that few Americans who had a chance to scrutinize it would let Congress get away with it. Now it is in danger of becoming law without Americans' even realizing its defects.

HEADLINE: The World; 
In a Land of Sun and Music, CD Pirates Play Robin Hood

BYLINE:  By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil 

 BODY:
WHEN the United States government and the American recording industry complain about rampant piracy of intellectual property rights, the kind of scene they have in mind is Avenida Paulista, the main shopping street here in Brazil's largest city. The latest releases of Britney Spears, Madonna, U2 or the Back Street Boys can cost up to $14.50 in record shops here, but that doesn't stop anyone from hearing them. Street vendors, operating from simple metal stands, offer the same titles for $2.75.
 As the Recording Industry Association of America and the Bush administration see it, the situation is easily defined: record companies face calamity in Brazil because Brazil's government isn't doing enough to protect copyrights. 
 Ask Brazilians about the problem, though, and you will hear a very different view -- one that offers an insight into the twists that economic logic produces when a third world country confronts globalized pricing and distribution of a product that it consumes with a passion. 
This is, after all, a country that defines and expresses itself through song as much as any other in the world, which means that Brazilians view any attempt to limit access to music as an attack on their culture and national identity. So the battle here over CD pricing is much more than a mere dispute over terms of trade.
In fact, it is Brazil's deep tradition of musicality that has attracted record companies and artists here to begin with. Brazilians have won the Grammy award for World Music for four consecutive years. And foreign performers like Paul Simon, Sting, David Byrne, Peter Gabriel and Rod Stewart have made what the Brazilian pop star Gilberto Gil sardonically calls "cultural safaris" here, looking for exotic rhythms and harmonies to reinvigorate their own music.
All of this figures in the outrage voiced here whenever CD prices are discussed.
"It is the avarice, the unyielding rapaciousness of the record companies that foments the violation of recording copyrights in Brazil," said Nehemias Gueiros Jr., an intellectual property rights lawyer and former record company executive. "When you have a predatory price policy incompatible with the economic reality of a country, then you are simply paving the way for piracy."
In the old days of vinyl, before the record industry had fully awakened to the Brazilian market's potential, local companies had more leeway. So the prices were more in line with what Brazilians earn -- about one-tenth, on average, of what North Americans earn. These days, five major foreign-owned companies dominate the music market here, and on average, a CD costs only slightly less than in the United States.
Typically, hit CD's by American performers cost even more than those of Brazilian artists, a fact that might seem to violate the basic principles of Economics 101.
Theoretically, American companies could discount their offerings here to stimulate demand, since those records long ago paid off their costs with sales at home. But Marcio Goncalves, the director-general of the Brazilian Association of Record Manufacturers, said it doesn't work that way. A higher price is needed, he said, because otherwise "artists would cancel their contracts and move to another label" in protest. In addition, others point out, the globalization of markets makes it possible for a lower price here to undermine prices at home.
"The higher price for recordings here is maintained not so much with Brazil itself in mind, but to avoid sales to the United States and Western Europe," said Antonio Carlos Manfredini, an economist at the Getulio Vargas Foundation, Brazil's leading economic research institute. "It's simply not worth it to them to threaten their markets in the North by means of aggressive pricing in Brazil."
As a result, record company profit margins in Brazil may be even higher than they are in the United States. Mr. Gueiros, who worked at Sony and BMG before opening his own law firm and boutique record label in Rio de Janeiro, calculates that the average producer's cost of a CD in Brazil, which includes royalties that are kept lower than in the United States, is less than $3.
BUT in another sense, the approach backfires, because it has helped pirates gain an estimated 40 percent of the CD market. Brazil remains the world's sixth-largest market for legal CD'S, with 104 million sold last year, but those numbers work out to less than one for each of the country's 170 million people. Economists and others with market experience argue that sales would zoom and piracy decline if the record companies would trade profit per unit for volume.
"The first thing you learn as a musician in a poor country like this one is that you can charge $2 for a ticket to a show and play to a full house or charge $3 and look at empty seats," said Joao Luiz Lobao, a pop star who is a critic of the recording industry here. "It's a matter of simple economics, but all those highly paid record executives don't seem to understand it."
THE situation has obvious parallels with the Napster controversy in the United States, in which the recording industry is trying to block free distribution of music over the Internet so that record companies can preserve their own ability to sell music for a fee. While court rulings so far have largely favored the record companies, the judge in the case has offered critics of the industry something of a rallying cry. "There is no such thing as a free lunch," Judge Marilyn H. Patel has said. "But sometimes lunch is more expensive than it should be."
The Brazilian government has made similar arguments in another dispute with the United States, over patents on drugs used to treat AIDS -- a global dispute in which American drug companies have recently made concessions on pricing in the third world in light of the health crisis AIDS represents there.
In the less desperate but nevertheless emotional matter of music, just as with pharmaceuticals, Brazilians and other Latin Americans are quick to paint such disputes as the continuation of a pattern that dates to colonial days, in which North America and Europe cheaply obtain raw materials here (for example, musical ideas and rare substances from the rain forests) and sell back finished goods (CD's and sophisticated drugs) at exorbitant prices. 
But if resentment that the record companies are acting like a cartel is strong here, it does not mean there is a likelihood of any firm action soon to solve the problem. 
"Institutions in Brazil are fragile, and they are fragile on both sides," Dr. Manfredini said. "In a low-income country, the regulatory authorities have difficulty protecting the rights of both producers and consumers, and so there is not an institutional structure to control price fixing and other abuses" perpetrated by the same companies that complain that their rights are not being protected when piracy results.
There is also the matter of payola, a practice long outlawed in the United States. "Part of the marketing budget goes to obtain airplay, which not only makes the cost of records higher but results in an artificially imposed cultural dictatorship that distorts the evolution of Brazilian music," said Mr. Lobao.
So the field remains ripe for CD piracy, and there seems little chance that measures like the recent formation of an Inter-Ministerial Committee on Piracy -- one response to the American pressure -- will stem it.
"Any economist recognizes that the protection of intellectual property rights is important, but the situation is far more complicated than the record companies are willing to admit," said Dr. Manfredini. "You can't take the word of the fox when he is talking about the chicken coop."

HEADLINE: Team Bush: Partisan but Nimble 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
IT was the morning after Congress took a big step toward giving President Bush much of his proposed tax cut, but the plan's primary architect, Lawrence B. Lindsey, the chief White House economic policy adviser, already had other things on his mind.
 The commission appointed by Mr. Bush to develop a plan for private investment accounts in Social Security needed office space, background material and a schedule, Mr. Lindsey was told at his daily staff meeting on the second floor of the West Wing. 
 Other issues followed in quick succession: Delta Air Lines seemed headed toward a showdown with striking pilots at its Comair subsidiary. And the leading industrial nations were establishing a task force to study how to give low-income people better access to computers. 
A few minutes later, Mr. Lindsey headed into a meeting on the administration's policy toward government-chartered, shareholder-owned corporations like Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, a topic of intense interest to Wall Street, the mortgage industry and financial regulators. That afternoon, he went downstairs to the Oval Office, to brief the president on energy policy, then to a meeting about overhauling Medicare.
Having watched his father lose the presidency in part because of how he handled the recession of the early 1990's, Mr. Bush has kept economic issues front and center in his administration. And that has put a particular focus -- and onus -- on Mr. Lindsey and the rest of Mr. Bush's team of economic advisers, including the Treasury secretary, Paul H. O'Neill, and the budget director, Mitchell E. Daniels Jr.
The president came to office with an agenda full of proposals to reshape economic policy along conservative lines: cutting taxes, restraining government spending, giving people the chance to invest their Social Security money, expanding free trade, reducing regulation. 
Mr. Bush and his advisers also inherited a slowing economy and all the political risk that comes with it. And they have been confronted with the kinds of unexpected challenges -- like threatened airline strikes, rolling blackouts in California and rising gasoline prices -- that can overshadow or derail even the best-planned agenda. 
Four months after inauguration day, it is too early to judge the team's performance. Its ultimate grade may hinge more than anything else on the depth and duration of the current business cycle downturn, something that is largely out of the administration's control. 
"You're asking about a three-point shot that's still in the air," Mr. O'Neill said.
But the team has avoided the distracting stumbles into unwanted controversies that plagued President Bill Clinton during his first months in office. And it has set into motion many of the biggest items on its to-do list, heartening conservatives with its focus on smaller government, deregulation and individual responsibility.
To the president's ideological opponents, the team's approach is fiscally irresponsible, a payoff to its corporate patrons and an effort to repackage right-wing policies in a centrist guise.
But even some of the administration's harshest critics say they have been impressed by the discipline and political touch that the president and his team have brought to pursuing their agenda, especially the tax cut. 
They say the team has been particularly nimble in turning events to its favor. When the economy turned downward, Mr. Bush's tax plan, originally presented as a way to send the federal budget surplus back to taxpayers, became an antirecession program. When gasoline prices surged, the tax cut became a subsidy to help consumers cope with rising energy costs. And Mr. Bush's support for more oil and gas drilling became the solution to the rolling blackouts afflicting California.
"Tenacity and focus and consistency are the most important aspects of a new presidency," said Robert B. Reich, who was secretary of labor in Mr. Clinton's first term. 
"This team has been remarkably effective, unified and focused on getting a huge tax cut," Mr. Reich said. "They've spoken with one voice. They have refused to compromise when that was helpful to them and compromised when they had to. And they've done it without igniting strong public opposition so far."
It is a team heavy on corporate and Washington experience, with a strong ideological bent but no close ties to the epicenter of the market economy, Wall Street. 
While it has championed free markets and sought to portray itself as above special-interest politics, it has proved willing to pursue a limited industrial policy in some cases, as in its support for shielding operators of nuclear power plants from liability or in providing government subsidies for clean-coal technology. And while many of its members came to office espousing a policy of blocking international bailouts of countries that get into financial trouble, the Bush team has already backed new International Monetary Fund loans to one strategically important ally, Turkey, and is supporting a package being negotiated by another economically struggling nation, Argentina.

Getting Their Feet Wet
Most of the economic advisers are still settling into their jobs. At the Treasury Department, Mr. O'Neill spent his first few months on the defensive over his early remarks on the dollar (he is still establishing his credibility with the financial markets as a defender of a strong currency) and a flap over whether he could hold onto his stock in Alcoa, the company he ran for 13 years (he eventually decided to sell it).
At the Office of Management and Budget, Mr. Daniels has brought a political sensibility to the often arcane world of spending plans and regulation, but he remains little known outside conservative Republican circles.
Josh Bolten, the deputy White House chief of staff, indulges a renegade streak by riding a motorcycle, but is one of Mr. Bush's most trusted policy advisers. The United States trade representative, Robert B. Zoellick, has as much experience in foreign and economic policy as any Republican in Washington, and his behind-the-scenes role in the Florida election uproar showed that he is a skilled partisan as well.
Many other appointees will play important roles, too. John B. Taylor, who is awaiting confirmation as under secretary of the Treasury for international affairs, is sometimes mentioned as a possible successor to Alan Greenspan as chairman of the Federal Reserve. R. Glenn Hubbard, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, is eager to put economic research to work on behalf of Mr. Bush's professed philosophy of "compassionate conservatism."
The team has two important honorary members. One is Vice President Dick Cheney, who has a voice in nearly all domestic policy matters, as he does in foreign policy. The other is Mr. Greenspan, who has close relationships with Mr. O'Neill, Mr. Cheney and Mr. Lindsey and has made no secret of his support for major elements of the Bush agenda, including tax cuts, Social Security investment accounts and free trade. Indeed, when Mr. Bush made his first trip to Washington as president-elect, Mr. Greenspan was the first person with whom he met.

The Early Leader
The relative influence of the economic team's various members is difficult to assess this early in the administration. But for now, the hub of policy-making is Mr. Lindsey's paneled office a floor above the Oval Office.
Whatever influence Mr. Lindsey wields -- and outsiders who have dealt with the White House say it is considerable -- is partly a function of his role as director of the National Economic Council. The council coordinates policy across cabinet departments and agencies, not only on highly visible issues like tax cuts but also on the full array of economic and business issues that confront the White House, including those involving trade, the financial markets, technology, labor, regulation and the budget.
But Mr. Lindsey's power is derived more from his close relationship to Mr. Bush. A former Federal Reserve governor and a policy aide in the administration of the president's father, Mr. Lindsey, 46, signed on early as the Bush campaign's economics expert and more than anyone else was the author of the tax-cut plan.
He is also ideologically compatible with Mr. Bush, leaning slightly to the left of conservative orthodoxy just often enough to buttress the president's compassionate-conservative theme. He persuaded Mr. Bush to use his tax-cut plan to address quirks in the tax code that take a big bite from the earnings of low-income working people, especially single parents. 
But in most ways, his ideological view is traditional. To a conservative like himself, he said, the greatest threat is "the overweening bureaucrat with the power of the state behind him who may be unchecked in his ability to tell someone how to run his life."
Mr. Lindsey says that any suggestion that he has any particular influence with Mr. Bush is exaggerated, and that his main role is to forge consensus on issues before they reach the president. But people inside and outside the administration say Mr. Lindsey's view on what that consensus should be is often heeded, partly because he has a good sense of what Mr. Bush wants. 
While it is difficult to say when his view is the deciding one, Mr. Lindsey rarely seems to be on the losing side of a debate. This year, he argued in favor of dropping Mr. Bush's campaign position that industrial emissions of carbon dioxide should be regulated -- and the position was dropped. 
Along with Mr. O'Neill, he pushed successfully to withdraw American support for an international push to crack down on tax havens in the Caribbean, saying the effort was intended to discourage competition among nations to offer lower tax rates. 
On many economic issues, Mr. Lindsey is the last to offer an opinion to Mr. Bush. He meets with the president at least three times a week for formal economic briefings, where, he said, Mr. Bush often starts by asking, "Hey Lindsey, when are we going to get some good news?"
Mr. Lindsey has long had a bearish economic outlook. He sold all his stocks in 1998, saying he wanted to be able to sleep at night, and during the campaign he urged Mr. Bush to think about an inevitable downturn.
As a result, the new administration was ready to sell its tax plan as an economic stimulus plan when it became clear that the long expansion was faltering.
"I was somewhat skeptical about the late 1990's, and I had a view that at some point there would be an adjustment," Mr. Lindsey said. "You deal with the hand you're dealt, and one of the first things you do is say, 'This is the hand.' You don't try to bluff your way through. You don't say everything is fine. You say, 'These are the facts, and I have a program that knows how to deal with the facts.' "
For now, he said, he sees the economy balanced between a relatively healthy consumer sector and a downturn in technology investment, yielding "subpar growth, in the zero to 2 percent range." He said that economists should be humble enough not to predict when conditions might change -- but that he was optimistic for the long run.

Not One to Play Games
At a hearing a few weeks ago before a House appropriations subcommittee, Mr. O'Neill was asked about heavy overtime being worked by the Secret Service, which is part of the Treasury Department. Mr. O'Neill, who knows his way around government from a stint in Washington in the 1970's, gave a polished answer, including the news that he had cut back on his own security detail to save money and to free agents for more pressing needs.
But his performance that day was something of an exception. In his first few months on the job, Mr. O'Neill has gained a reputation for blunt talk, impatience with the elaborate political dance that is necessary to get anything done in Washington and a tin ear for the nuances of policy debates.
At his confirmation hearing, he said he was "not going to make a huge case" that Mr. Bush's tax cut was an effective way to keep the economy out of recession -- at a time when Mr. Bush was making just such a case.
On taking office, Mr. O'Neill decided that he should be able to keep the $100 million in Alcoa stock that he had amassed as chief executive, only to change his mind after it became clear that he would face constant questions about potential conflicts of interest. 
As for the debate within the administration on global climate change, he has been criticized by conservatives as not being sufficiently opposed to regulating industrial emissions. And an article in The Wall Street Journal portrayed him as spending considerable time studying worker safety issues at the Treasury Department.
A result has been a sense outside the administration that Mr. O'Neill is less of a force in the big policy debates than many people had expected him to be, given his success at Alcoa and his long ties to Mr. Greenspan, who as an Alcoa director in the 1980's helped Mr. O'Neill land his job there. 
"The perception is that he's not as much involved as one would expect the Treasury secretary to be, given the nature of the agenda," said Bruce Bartlett, an economist at the National Center for Policy Analysis, a conservative research group.
The perception is not entirely fair. Whatever his influence, Mr. O'Neill is very much at the center of the action within the administration. He briefs the president regularly and meets for an hour or two a week with Mr. Greenspan, who worked with him at the White House during the Ford administration, when he was deputy budget director. Mr. O'Neill also participates in National Security Council meetings and is host for a regular lunch at the Treasury Department that includes Mr. Lindsey, Mr. Bolten and other officials like Donald L. Evans, the commerce secretary.
"I don't feel I've ever been left out of something I should have been involved in, or included in something that was a waste of my time," Mr. O'Neill said. "Having been involved in a lot of other administrations, this one has a nice developing balance about the way we work together. There's a lot of collegiality and volunteered respect among the participants."
So far, Mr. O'Neill has been dealing with an agenda that was set before he joined Mr. Bush's team, especially on taxes. He may have his best opportunity to make his own mark as the administration turns to international economic affairs, particularly its stance toward the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.
He is deeply skeptical about trying to prop up the currencies of countries in financial trouble. And while he sees the international financial institutions as having a role to play, he says the I.M.F. in particular needs to do a better job of heading off crises rather than dealing with them after the fact.
The key to dealing with economic problems in developing nations, he said, is "intervening earlier, which means accepting responsibility for being identified with precautionary action rather than waiting until people's economies are down around their ankles and you rush in like some kind of hero."

A Mechanic Who Can Laugh
Economic policy is usually debated at the lofty plane of the macroeconomy, but it is often carried out at a nuts-and-bolts level. And the ultimate repository of policy hardware in any administration is the Office of Management and Budget, which turns ideology and political compromise into hard numbers and concrete regulation.
In the Bush administration, the man with the wrench is Mr. Daniels, and he has been using it to carry out Mr. Bush's priorities of holding down government spending, streamlining management of government programs and lifting the regulatory demands on business.
A political assistant in the White House under President Ronald Reagan, Mr. Daniels subsequently became an executive at Eli Lilly in his native Indiana, but he stayed active in Republican politics and in promoting supply-side economics.
Last year, he helped run a losing campaign for governor of Indiana, for a conservative Republican, David M. McIntosh, but played no role in the Bush campaign. He was recommended to Mr. Bush by Al Hubbard, an Indiana businessman who is a friend of the president, and within weeks he was helping to write the administration's first budget.
He has already drawn fire from Democrats for championing a tax cut that they consider reckless and spending cuts that they say will hurt the government's ability to address social and economic problems. But if nothing else, he has proved that the administration's chief bean counter has a sense of humor.
Asked during a news conference last month about a proposed cut in the budget of the Energy Department, he said the previous year's budget had been higher than normal because of the costs associated with wildfires near some research laboratories in the West. "We had a big debate at O.M.B. and decided not to start another fire this year," he said. "Therefore we did not renew that particular $500 million expenditure."

First Florida, Now the World
Bob Zoellick, a veteran of the White House and the State and Treasury departments in the two previous Republican administrations, spent much of November and December in Florida, helping Mr. Bush capture the final electoral votes he needed. He is now gearing up for a campaign that could be almost as bloody in political terms: winning authority from Congress for Mr. Bush to negotiate trade agreements.
Expanding trade is a core principle in Mr. Bush's economic plan. But there is a bitter divide in Congress over the issue, reflecting the broader debate in the country and around the world over whether governments should manage the globalization of markets to ease the impact of rapid change on workers, industries and the environment.
His job will be all the more difficult if the economy continues to weaken, driving up the unemployment rate.
Mr. Zoellick says that increasing trade by cutting tariffs is the equivalent of a tax cut in terms of helping a slowing economy, and that businesses are increasingly looking at markets abroad as the domestic market cools off. But he knows that he is in for a fight.
"This is a wonderful opportunity for us to shape the future of the international trading systems, and unfortunately, we're falling behind," he said. "We need to regain momentum globally and regionally and bilaterally. A key element is trying to rebuild support with the Congress and the public."

The Rest of the Team
A number of Mr. Bush's economic aides have lower profiles but are also likely to play crucial roles in policy decisions. At the Council of Economic Advisers, R. Glenn Hubbard will develop the economic rationale for many administration plans, including overhauling the social welfare system and dealing with regulatory issues. A former professor at Columbia University, he is best known for his work supporting the theory that reducing the top income tax rate will generate increased economic activity and for studies suggesting that Americans can move up the economic ladder over their lifetimes.
"I can't imagine being more on the front line," he said.
Mr. Bolten, 46, a former investment banker and general counsel to the United States trade representative in the first Bush administration, works a few doors down from the Oval Office as the deputy chief of staff for policy. He ran Mr. Bush's policy development operation during the campaign, and continues to have a hand in almost every decision on economic-related issues, helping to bring together the substance and the politics on any given topic.
As the Treasury Department's top international official, Mr. Taylor, an economist from Stanford University, will be on the spot the next time an international financial crisis flares. In the past, he has expressed support for encouraging the industrialized nations to coordinate, at least informally, their inflation targets, to help stabilize the relative values of their currencies. And he has advocated shifting the focus at the World Bank from supporting social welfare programs in poor nations to helping them improve productivity and economic growth.
But some economists say Mr. Bush put Mr. Taylor on his team at least partly to groom him for a bigger job. A world authority on monetary policy, Mr. Taylor would probably be near the top of any Republican president's list of possible replacements for Mr. Greenspan, whose current term ends in 2004.

HEADLINE: MEDIA; 
The Economist Revamps to Compete Better on the Continent

BYLINE:  By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: LONDON, May 20 

 BODY:
Think of The Economist magazine for most of its 157 years and the temptation is to think of monochrome slabs of dense type offering much the same lofty overview as its editor, Bill Emmott, has of London -- on clear days -- from his 13th-floor corner office.
 But, as of mid-May, as aficionados of this particularly British-cum-global institution already know, The Economist has shifted. Full-color images have penetrated its inner pages. A new index and guides to its sections offer a belated acknowledgment that it was not always the most accessible of publications. A list of Internet sites, available to subscribers, provides links to Web sites, including one that is to be updated between weekly issues of print. The redesign is the first in 14 years and comes only weeks after a similar revamping at the London-edited international edition of Time magazine. The changes illustrate the scramble that is under way among international magazines in Britain and America for a slice of an advertising market that increasingly depends on readers among Europe's growing business and entrepreneurial elite. 
 In recent years, Time and Newsweek, American stalwarts of the international magazine business, have sought to expand European business coverage with extra reporting staff. For the last three years, Fortune International, another unit of Time Inc., has been challenged by the relatively new Forbes Global for the market among European and Asian senior executives.
Business Week, a McGraw-Hill publication, assigned an editor to Paris 18 months ago to steer coverage of the Continent. And, in the thick of this American onslaught on Europe's business audience, The Economist has sought to reverse the trans-Atlantic flow: 300,000 of its 760,000 readers, Mr. Emmott said, are in North America. "The pressure," he said, "is to be different, not the same."
At the core of this clash of the weeklies is a perception of fundamental changes, particularly in Europe, the last decade. "'Everyone has more business coverage, and the market is growing every year," said John Rossant, Business Week's Europe editor in Paris. "There is an equity culture. People own stock. They are interested in corporate leaders."
That reflected a basic shift in Europe's outlook. "During the cold war, the prism through which we viewed the world was geopolitical," said Fareed Zakaria, the editor of Newsweek International, a Washington Post Company publication. "In today's world, its economics and business."
Not only that, said Bob Crozier, the London-based publisher of Forbes Global, which has a circulation of some 110,000. The market for business magazines, he said, is set to grow as more and more Europeans use English as the lingua franca of business. "English as a second-language is spoken by people under the age of 40," he said. "So you have got this under-40 business elite that's educated and fluent in English," often with the backing of a business education in the United States.
That combination of circumstances has left most organizations with healthy advertising growth. According to a recent survey by Competitive Media Reporting, the advertising revenues of just six international publications in Europe -- Time, The Economist, Newsweek, Fortune, Forbes, Business Week and The International Herald Tribune, which is jointly owned by Washington Post and The New York Times Company -- grew from $183 million in 1996 to $251.9 million last year.
Including a broader range of competitors, said Charlie Crowe, editor in chief of Media and Marketing Europe magazine, the size of the potential European advertising market could be around $700 million.
But there may be gloomier prospects ahead as the United States economy slows, pressure for cost-cutting increases and European growth begins to look patchy. Zenith Media, a British media buying company, says the overall size of the total European magazine ad market, which includes publications ranging from trade to fashion magazines, is set for less-than-stellar growth -- from $18.8 billion this year to $19.8 billion in 2002 and $20.7 billion by 2003.
"You have to change just to stay as strong as you are, and you should not change in a panicky way," Mr. Emmott said of the makeover. "If we hadn't made the change sometime soon, we might have been struggling to keep our circulation growth, so it was an unavoidable cost."
In the last decade, he said, The Economist's circulation rose 69 percent. The redesign will add $5 million to its costs, but, against that, its ad revenue in Europe, excluding Britain, has risen from $59 million in 1996 to $72 million last year, according to the recent C.M.R. survey, compared with Time Atlantic with $76.7 million from a higher European circulation and including British revenues.
The positioning is not just in layout and the old adage that all news is local still has a strong pull. The Economist, Mr. Emmott said, is a global magazine and a proponent of economic globalization and free markets with 80 percent of its sales outside Britain. But, with the first, redesigned issue of May 12 to 18, he chose three different covers for three different regions -- a British election cover for Britain, a Timothy McVeigh cover for the United States and a conservation story for other regions.
At Newsweek International, Mr. Zakaria said, he planned to hire columnists like Christopher Hitchens of Vanity Fair to write a "Letter from America," giving a foreign view of the United States for a foreign audience. At Business Week, Mr. Rossant said, he might add more European voices in book reviews and comment columns, as Time already does in its Europe, Middle East and Africa edition, which has a circulation of some 630,000.
"Other publications within any category you can think of are domestic plus international," Mr. Emmott said. "But we see ourselves as global." Of course, part of the publication's branding has always been linked to its quirkiness -- two things the redesign left unchanged were the slablike editorials and the absence of bylines for even the most egotistical among its 72 staff journalists.
And it is precisely that authoritative tone and sense of mission as capitalism's guardian that gives the magazine its particular cachet. Just recently, for instance, The Economist published a lengthy investigative article about the corruption charges relating to Silvio Berlusconi, the free-wheeling billionaire who is Italy's newly elected prime minister. "We have been founded for all our history on free markets and classic liberalism," Mr. Emmott said. "That makes it incumbent to blow the whistle when businesses are discrediting capitalism and the liberal system." But wasn't there an element of buzz-generation in choosing such a sensational topic? Certainly not, Mr. Emmott said. "I'm not like Vanity Fair or Talk," he said. "I don't measure response to The Economist by buzz."

HEADLINE: MEDIA; 
Rules of TV Business Change as Network Race Tightens

BYLINE:  By BILL CARTER 

 BODY:
As the broadcast networks wrap up another season and simultaneously start pitching new shows for next season, one conclusion is dominant: everything is changing, from the rules of the television business to the fortunes of each network.
 In the season that will finish this week, CBS became younger, ABC grew older, NBC was dented on its mighty Thursday and Fox edged closer to the top than it has ever been. 
 "Survivor," augmented by the season's biggest new hit, "CSI," remade CBS as a network that really could reach young people -- some of the time.
"Who Wants to Be a Millionaire," which led ABC to decisive victory last season, dropped off under the weight of four-times-a-week exposure, carrying ABC with it.
NBC had almost no success in the fall but hung on to win another season among the young viewers coveted by advertisers thanks to long-running hits like "ER" and "Law & Order." 
Fox added more shows with youth appeal like "Boston Public" and "Dark Angel" and crept within a few tenths of a rating point of NBC.
The season officially ends on Wednesday with the four-network ratings race closer than it has ever been. As the networks unveiled their plans for next season in elaborate, noisy presentations in New York last week, the sound emerging from behind all the loud bands and confident pronouncements was that of a lot of old rules crashing.

Better the 2nd Time Around
The latest breakthrough idea in programming: repeats. At both Fox and ABC, repeats will occupy regular positions on the fall schedule.
Fox, which has regularly run a weekly repeat of its Saturday series "Cops," filled an 8 p.m. hole this season with a repeat showing of its hit, "That '70s Show" -- with great success. Next season, Fox has a new entry: A "comedy wheel" that will consist of "classic episodes" of such established Fox series as "The Simpsons" and "Malcolm in the Middle." ABC will again use a repeat edition of its sketch show, "Whose Line Is It Anyway?" every week.
Sandy Grushow, the chairman of the Fox Entertainment Group, said the need to reach ever more fragmented audiences was driving the same-week repeats. He noted that networks were routinely buying third and fourth runs of hit shows rather than just two.
"I think at some point a network is going to take a night like Saturday, where they can't get arrested, and it's going to start looking like double-run theater," Mr. Grushow said.
An even wider trend is called multiplexing, or double-bursting episodes -- shows that play on the network one night and on a cable network, usually also owned by the network's parent company, the same week. The economics are seductive because second runs on a cable network can offset the financial deficit each show carries.
Among the examples expected next season: "Once and Again," on ABC and Lifetime; "CSI" on CBS and TNN; "Gilmore Girls" on the WB and TNT; "Law & Order: SVU" on NBC and the USA network. Fox is trying to work out a deal, probably with its sister cable channel FX, for a second run of its promising suspense series "24."
The moves are reminiscent of the way HBO runs hit shows like "The Sopranos." Mr. Grushow said. "To some degree, we are moving away from the exclusive model to the aggregate model," he said.

Wake Up to Reality
Mainly used in short-run bursts last season, reality shows are essential parts of fall schedules for next season, with "Survivor" and "The Amazing Race" on CBS, "The Mole II" on ABC and "Temptation Island II" on Fox.
On NBC, after disavowing any plan to emulate ABC's multiple weekly runs of "Millionaire," reneged and will show "Weakest Link" twice a week.
The reason, said Jeff Zucker, the president of NBC Entertainment: the reality-game genre may be fleeting and the networks need to cash in right away. "I just don't think these programs will ever have the same life span as a show like 'Law & Order' or 'ER,' " Mr. Zucker said.
The shows also do not have an afterlife in syndication, but they cost much less than any other hour-long series to produce. "The economic model is really good," Mr. Zucker said.
Of course, that is only true if the shows succeed. The risk is a reality show that is rejected quickly by viewers but must be played to humiliating completion anyway. NBC learned that bitterly last season with the XFL. 
That performed so disastrously that NBC has taken to describing its competitive position two ways: with the XFL and without the XFL.

Comedy Overruled
Comedy, which reached record numbers on the networks less than a decade ago, looks to be in eclipse, CBS, ABC and NBC will introduce only seven new comedies among them, their lowest combined totals since the early 1980's. Fox, which often zigs while the others zag, is adding three, but that will bring the total number at Fox to 11 (Fox says 12 but it is counting the "comedy wheel," which repeats three of the 11.)
NBC, which hit a high-water mark of 18 four years ago, is now trotting out only eight situation comedies. ABC also will have eight, like NBC, on only two nights. CBS will have but six, also on two nights.
"People are tired of the old setup-joke formula, especially young viewers." said one head of a television production studio, who insisted on anonymity. "If you can't come up with a comedy that has a twist, it's not going to make it."
The legal or crime drama is supplanting the sitcom as the favored genre. While only 16.5 hours of sitcoms are planned next season on the four big networks, more than 20 hours of prime time will contain some legal theme, from the hard-edged, as in "Law & Order," to the far softer, as in bowling-alley law on "Ed."

Movies Moving Out
No more ripped-from-the-headlines sagas or disease-of-the-week?
Maybe not. The network television movie, once such a staple it filled two nights a week on various networks, is apparently all but out of business.
Only CBS will cling to a movie night, Sunday, a night when three networks once battled it out with simultaneous movies. ABC and NBC eliminated made-for-television movies from their regular schedule, with Mr. Zucker declaring the institution dead, "a vestige of the past."
Abysmal ratings are the main reason. But competition is another, with movies now being churned out by myriad cable channels. Fragmentation is a factor. With so many shows on television, Mr. Zucker said, it takes an enormous amount of promotion to break through the clutter.

To 'ER' Is Unforgivable
Haunted by the $13 million an episode that NBC was forced to pay to bring back "ER" three years ago, networks are now trying to make deals that protect them from facing monstrous increases in the license fees for hit shows.
When a network installs itself as a co-producer on a series, as many new shows are now constructed, it is asking for extremely long, or even what is being called perpetual, license deals.
These are intended to cap the price a network will have to pay no matter how successful a show becomes. In exchange, shows are receiving bonuses based on ratings. But the studio head said, in practice, the bonuses turn out to be another negotiation, with a network perhaps cutting the promised bonus in half.
Even shows that are not co-productions with a network are being given terms longer than the formerly traditional four-year initial contracts, some as long as eight years.
But there are still some producers who can demand the four-year deals and win them. "You're not going to get a John Wells or a David Kelley to agree to some extended deal," the studio head said.
Indeed, he said, the threat of another "ER" is not entirely over -- and NBC is again the network in the potential vise. Thanks to the power of Mr. Wells, and his partner, Aaron Sorkin, the hit show "The West Wing" received an initial four-year deal; it enters its third season next year.
"I think it could happen all over again with 'West Wing,' " the studio head said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Schools Get Tool to Track Students' Use of Internet
ESniff, which makes a program that monitors corporate Internet networks, plans to make a modified version of it available to schools today. A federal law requires almost all schools and libraries in the United States to choose a "technology protection measure" to protect minors from inappropriate online materials.
 The program, eSniff Solution, is a so-called packet sniffer. Because all Internet traffic is broken into data packets before being sent from one computer to another, a packet sniffer can sit on the network and watch the traffic go by, sniffing for the information it has been programmed to sense. Page C6. 

Global Stock Indexes Are Adjusted
Morgan Stanley Capital International, which compiles widely followed global stock indexes, announced an overhaul that could prompt a flurry of buying and selling as money mangers adjust their portfolios to the changes. C2.

The At Home Corporation is worth so little that its controlling shareholder, AT&T, is willing to issue stock worth $464 million to avoid taking any more shares in it. C12.

Another Wrinkle in Privacy Fight
In the increasingly futile battle against unsolicited marketing, consumers may be vulnerable to incoming mail from an eyebrow-raising source: employees who have used addresses from their companies' databases to do their own freelance marketing. In general, corporate policies about the use of customer data tend to focus on how it can be used by the business -- not necessarily by employees. C4.

The Economist magazine of Britain has been redesigned for the first time in 14 years, weeks after a similar revamping at the the international edition of Time, edited in London. C11.

A new contract covering the the registry database for dot-com addresses raises questions about whether the system has been truly opened to competition. New Economy. C4.
